Enactus takes all majors and cares deeply about providing a valuable college experience for its members, through social events to professional development workshops. If you want to learn more, please visit us at michiganenactus.com
Summary: Enactus is a Ross-based undergraduate consulting club that conducts pro-bono projects with an emphasis in sustainability and social impact with local and global clients. With a diverse family of 40 members and 10+ majors, we would love to have you too!

Name: EnCore
Description: EnCore is a multicultural, co-ed, hip hop dance group based at the University of Michigan since 2000. EnCore performs team members’ choreography at a variety of campus events and Ann Arbor from charity events to Dance Mix to bar nights. @encoreumich
Summary: EnCore is a multicultural, co-ed, hip hop dance group based at the University of Michigan since 2000. EnCore performs team members’ choreography at a variety of campus events and Ann Arbor from charity events to Dance Mix to bar nights. @encoreumich

Name: End the Cycle
Description:
In Washtenaw County, around 1/3 of homeless people are children. These homeless children are 9 times more likely to repeat a grade and 4 times more likely to drop out compared to a student with a stable home. In End the Cycle, we are dedicated to creating equal opportunities for all, with the goal of bridging the gap in educational inequity. We provide educational services in the form of after-school tutoring, college application help, standardized test prep, and mentorship to students from lower socioeconomic backgrounds.

Members of ETC can be a tutor (where you tutor underserved students on zoom based on your schedule), and they can also join committees. We have committees dedicated to fundraising/donations, social media/advocacy, educational resource creation, and programming/workshops that anyone can join. Committee members do not need to apply to join, and projects are up to the committee to decide what to pursue. Past projects include: refugee/immigrant english program, juvenile court after school program, summer program, thanksgiving fundraiser for homeless students, etc.

 

For more information, please visit our website: https://endthecycleatum.org
Summary: We provide educational services in the form of after-school tutoring, college application help, and mentorship to homeless students within Washtenaw County. We focus on creating programs that respond to the needs of our community.

Name: Energy Club at Ross
Description:
Our mission is to provide our members with education and employment opportunities in the energy industry that enable them to become leaders of the energy transition. This includes three primary objectives:

  1. To promote interest in energy among students and faculty at the Ross School of Business.
  2. To provide a forum for students to learn more about opportunities in the energy industry and discuss energy-related topics.
  3. To facilitate career development in traditional and renewable energy sectors by mentoring talented students and connecting energy recruiters with these knowledgeable, motivated career seekers.

We process memberships on CampusGroups - please join HERE instead of registering on MaizePages
Summary: The Energy Club at Ross (ECR) is a group of primarily graduate students who share an interest in energy. ECR provides opportunities to explore the rapidly-changing energy landscape, while gaining exposure to career opportunities in the industry.

Name: EngageYpsi
Description: EngageYpsi aims to make a meaningful difference in the community of Ypsilanti. Ypsilanti is located within 10 miles of the University of Michigan, yet has vast needs that are often overlooked. Through this organization, Michigan students can find meaningful ways to serve those in the community through education, mentorship, youth events, and more.
Summary: EngageYpsi is an organization building bridges between Ann Arbor and Ypsilanti by connecting University of Michigan students with service opportunities.

Name: Engaging Scientists in Policy and Advocacy
Description:
Founded in Fall of 2017, Engaging Scientists in Policy and Advocacy (ESPA) aims to promote the participation of research scientists in policy and advocacy. We are an interdisciplinary group of undergraduates, graduate students, faculty, and staff at the University of Michigan, ranging from chemistry to public policy. The goals of this group is to provide training and implementation for two skills:

1. Effective science advocacy and communication

2. Comprehension and analysis of science policy

Both of the above skills are vital for the professional development of aspiring science policy professionals, as well as the engagement of scientists as public citizens. Additionally, many of our events help members engage with the public and government, providing valuable opportunities to build trust in scientists and science.
Summary: Promoting the participation of research scientists in policy and advocacy

Name: Engineering Global Leadership Honors Society
Description: The mission of the Engineering Global Leadership Honors Program is to develop the personal, professional, and academic capabilities of our members. Through this development, members strive to build lasting relationships with other members, company representatives, and the University of Michigan community. EGL is built on 4 key "pillars": Engineering, Business, Culture and Leadership.
Summary: The mission of the Engineering Global Leadership Honors Program is to develop the personal, professional, and academic capabilities of our members through engineering excellence, business acumen, cultural awareness, and leadership development.

Name: Engineering Honors Student Advisory Board
Description: The Honors Student Advisory Board (HSAB) creates social, academic and community engagement opportunities for students in the College of Engineering Honors Program.  The HSAB advises the Honors Program staff on student priorities and promotes community-building experiences.
Summary: The Honors Student Advisory Board (HSAB) creates social, academic and community engagement opportunities for students in the College of Engineering Honors Program.  The HSAB advises the Honors Program staff on student priorities and promotes community.

Name: Engineering Student Government
Description:
The mission of Engineering Student Government (ESG) is to support students and work directly to improve the student experience in the University of Michigan College of Engineering. ESG works through a combination of committee initiatives, resolutions, funding, and direct action with faculty and staff to improve the academic, social, extracurricular, and day-to-day lives of students.

Our purpose is to foster a community of support, leadership, and camaraderie within the college, facilitating collective action, finding solutions to broad problems, and enabling students to thrive.

You can get involved by emailing esg.executive@umich.edu or visiting https://esg.engin.umich.edu/ .
Summary: Engineering Student Government handles funding, programming, and represents the College of Engineering student body.

Name: Engineering Trek
Description: etrek is an annual trip for University of Michigan Engineering Graduate Students to Israel to explore the unique technical and academic community and experience Israel's unique culture. Approximately 30 graduate engineering students will be granted the opportunity to explore Israel's facademic and tech communities and the rich culture by means of a one week trip throughout Israel. Participants will visit the Israel's premier technical university, Technion, in Haifa, the vibrant start-up community in Tel-Aviv, and the innovative ways that Israel manages the water in the Israeli desert, the Negev. Furthermore, participants will have the opportunity to see rich history in Caesarea, visit important religious sites in Jerusalem and more! Visit our website, etrekMichigan.org, for more information on this year's trek.
Summary: etrek is an annual trip for University of Michigan Engineering Graduate Students to Israel to explore the unique technical and academic community and experience Israel's unique culture.

Name: EnspiRED Runway
Description: EnspiRED hosts a variety of events throughout the year that aim to raise arts awareness and promote confidence amongst our members on campus. We serve as an advocate for the arts through several outlets including but not limited to fashion, singing, dancing, painting and so much more. Our biggest event each year is our annual charity fashion show.
Summary: EnspiRED brings to the University of Michigan a space for creative expression through primarily fashion, music, and art. We aim to foster community and confidence through various events during the school year, volunteer work, and a charity fashion show.

Name: Entertainment & Media Club
Description: The Entertainment + Digital Media Club is a student-run organization for University of Michigan graduate students actively pursuing careers in the Entertainment industry. E+DM works to support graduate students actively pursuing careers in the Entertainment industry (film & television, media, music, and gaming).
Summary: The Entertainment + Digital Media Club works to support graduate students actively pursuing careers in the Entertainment industry (film & television, media, music, and gaming).

Name: Entertainment, Media & Sports Business Association at the Ross School of Business
Description: The Entertainment, Media & Sports Business Association at the Ross School of Business was established to support MBA students interested in pursuing a career in the sports business industry. EMSBA's primary goal is to educate its members about the available jobs in sports while facilitating networking opportunities within the industry, as well as within the University of Michigan community. Through events and other experiential activities, EMSBA brings the Ross sports business community together to learn about the industry, develop personal career paths and enjoy the tremendous sports environment that is Michigan sports.
Summary: The Entertainment, Media & Sports Business Association at the Ross School of Business (EMSBA) was established to support MBA students interested in pursuing a career in the sports business industry.

Name: Entertainment, Media, and Arts Law Students Association
Description: EMALSA is a student-run organization that strives to provide events for the University of Michigan Law School community to explore opportunities within the entertainment, media, and art law fields.
Summary: EMALSA is a student-run organization that strives to provide events for the University of Michigan Law School community to explore opportunities within the entertainment, media, and art law fields.

Name: Entomology Club
Description:
Welcome to Bug Club! We are a club for bugs and bug enthusiasts. We focus on two main goals: Appreciation, and Education. As a club we appreciate insects for their beautiful and complex lives, behaviors, and biology.  We want to learn and teach about insects through speakers, meetings, activities, and any opportunities that present themselves. If any of these do not interest you, don't worry! Members are free to participate in what interests them and avoid what does not. Bug Club is a welcoming space for people of all races, genders, sexualities, religious affiliation, and species (bugs included!). We hope to see you at one of our treks or meetings!

Please join our GroupMe if you are interested! https://groupme.com/join_group/87521358/uaeURWHo
Summary: We are a club for insect enthusiastics, activists, and anyone who wants to learn more about entomology.

Name: Entrepreneurship and Venture Capital (EVC) Club
Description:
EVC is comprised of graduate University of Michigan students that are dedicated to furthering their educational and professional goals as prospective entrepreneurs, intrapreneurs, and investors in the startup ecosystem.

Whether students want to start their own venture, learn about investing in ventures, or seeking opportunities as a founder or funder post-Ross, EVC will facilitate experiences and active relationships with firms, founders, advisors, and alumni in the entrepreneurship and venture capital ecosystem. 

Thank you for your interest in EVC! To join Entrepreneurship & Venture Capital, you must join on CampusGroups: http://ross.campusgroups.com/evc
Summary: The Entrepreneurship and Venture Capital (EVC) club brings together students dedicated to educational and professional goals of becoming founders or funders in the startup ecosystem. Learn more and join the club at http://ross.campusgroups.com/evc

Name: Entrepreneurship Creativity Club
Description: ECC is established for the expressed purpose of furthering student entrepreneurial skills/projects in an action-based learning environment via access to peers and local start-ups. Additionally, there will be a development component focused on expanding on the ideas taught in ALA/PSYCH 223.
Summary: The Entrepreneurship Club hopes to develop effective student organizations and leaders through training and education.

Name: Entrepreneurship Through Acquisition Club
Description: The Michigan Ross ETA Club gathers MBA students, alumni, investors, advisors, and business owners to discuss finding, acquiring, and running lower-middle-market (LMM) companies. The Club organizes educational sessions with ETA investors, hosts an annual conference, and provides resources -- such as introductions to anchor investors and internships -- to prepare students to launch their own search fund. The ETA club is committed to increasing accessibility and awareness to the search fund asset class across the entire Ross community.
Summary: The Michigan Ross ETA Club aims to educate and motivate Ross MBA students to pursue a career in entrepreneurship through acquisition / search funds.

Name: Environmental Consulting Organization at the University of Michigan
Description: The Environmental Consulting Organization at UM is a sustainability consulting organization at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. With a primary focus on the environment and sustainable business practices, we help businesses, political organizations, nonprofits, and other groups across the Southeastern Michigan area and the broader United States implement more sustainable practices, craft solutions to broader business problems, and research trends in the future green economy.
Summary: Our mission is to demonstrate that any business is able to adopt sustainable practices. We aim to create a community of students and professionals that collaborate on innovative, sustainable projects. All majors are welcome!

Name: Environmental Health Student Association
Description:
The Environmental Health Student Association (EHSA) will bring currently enrolled Environmental Health Science (EHS) students together in an informal environment for both social and academic engagements. This organization will prioritize providing a platform for the development of professional relationships with all students, faculty, and the University of Michigan’s administration, as well as outside entities in the field of public health. It will represent all Environmental Health Science students and promote interdepartmental interactions within the School of Public Health.

EHSA hopes to:

  1. Develop fellowship among all students, faculty, and staff within EHS;
  2. Facilitate discussion surrounding departmental, campus-wide, and local/global environmental issues (i.e. curriculum, waste composting, Flint’s water crisis, and Great Lakes’ Oil Pipeline);
  3. Provide a social network to corroborate positive interactions and mentorship between 1st and 2nd year students in the EHS program;
  4. Encourage interest in Environmental Health Sciences to prospective and current University of Michigan Graduate students;
  5. Present ideas and innovative programs/activities related to EHS to benefit the University of Michigan’s campus community, and
  6. Promote volunteer opportunities that allow EHS students to interact with surrounding communities and provide beneficial assistance when needed (i.e. Huron river clean up, and community kitchen volunteer).
Summary: EHSA will bring currently enrolled EHS students, SPH Faculty, U of M administration, and outside entities in the field of public health together to provide a platform for the development of professional relationships through social & academic engagement.

Name: Environmental Law Society
Description:
ELS enhances the law school experience by providing opportunities for students to explore issues related to environmental law in a variety of settings. ELS also aims to enrich the law school and university environment by sponsoring various opportunities for students with an interest in the intersection between the environment and law.

ELS may pursue any activity that the ELS Executive Board deems relevant and beneficial to our mission, so long as such activity is not prohibited by policies of the University of Michigan (UM) and the University of Michigan Law School (UMLS). In the past, among other activities ELS has hosted speakers on topics relevant to our mission, arranged activities that concern or address issues of the environment and the law, offered law students with these interests an opportunity to socialize and network, sponsored various academic and professional opportunities for law students interested in environmental law, and provided information about post-law school employment in the environmental field.
Summary: ELS provides an opportunity to learn about environmental law and to connect with other interested students.

Name: Epidemiology 890 Student Organization
Description: To support students in Epidemiology 890, Doctoral Seminar in Epidemiology, including but not limited to building a sense of professional affiliation with the field of epidemiology and provide practice in the presentation modalities of the discipline.
Summary: To support students in Epidemiology 890, Doctoral Seminar in Epidemiology, including but not limited to building a sense of professional affiliation with the field of epidemiology and provide practice in the presentation modalities of the discipline.

Name: Epidemiology Doctoral Student Organization
Description: The Epidemiology Doctoral Student Organization (EDSO) provides opportunities to build social and professional connections between UM epidemiology students and faculty through activities designed to encourage skill-building, communication, and social engagement.  The goal of EDSO is to facilitate a positive and welcoming environment for doctoral students.
Summary: The purpose of EDSO is to facilitate communication between UM Epidemiology doctoral students and faculty and to provide opportunities to enhance the experience of Epid doctoral students.

Name: Epidemiology Student Organization
Description:
The Epidemiology Student Organization is a student-run organization whose mission is to provide academic, professional, and social support to Epidemiology students at the University of Michigan School of Public Health. 

ESO functions as mediator and advocate for students within the Epidemiology Department and, more broadly, at the School of Public Health. The goals of the organization are to: collaborate with faculty, staff, administration, and alumni to strengthen the department and to represent the student voice within the department and to the school; and to provide programming that supports the mental, physical, emotional, and academic well-being of Epidemiology students
Summary: ESO provides academic, professional, and social organization for Epidemiology students in the School of Public Health.

Name: Epsilon Alpha Sigma Sorority
Description: The Empowered Arab Sisterhood (ΕΑΣ) was founded by Rula Othman on April 24, 2012 at the University of California, Los Angeles. Upon the recruitment of nine founding mothers, ΕΑΣ was born. Striving to bring an Arab presence to Greek life, the organization worked towards becoming the first Arab sorority in the nation. As a strictly cultural organization, ΕΑΣ expresses no religious or political affiliation but rather focuses on the humanitarian aspect of the conflicts plaguing our Arab countries today. Through this focus, the ladies of Epsilon Alpha Sigma aim to expose our peers to the diversity that exists within the Arab world and the impact Empowered Arab Women have made and continue to make both within our immediate communities and all around the world.
Summary: The purpose of this sorority shall be to unite it's members in a sisterhood based upon the bonds of sincere and lasting friendship, to stimulate one another in the pursuit of knowledge and success, to promote the moral and social culture of it's members.

Name: Epsilon Eta
Description:
The purpose of Epsilon Eta (Beta Chapter) is to foster a community with a conscious awareness of the intrinsic relationship between people and their environment through academics, communities, and service. This includes a commitment of 1-4 hours per week, between one-hour chapter meetings on Sundays and completing various engagement requirements throughout each semester. 

We strive to prepare our members for careers in the environmental field by providing a hub for networking, support, and professional development. By facilitating resume workshops, offering professional headshots, building an internship database, connecting with our alumni network, and hosting speakers who work in a variety of fields, Epsilon Eta aims to be the foundation for our members’ futures working in environmental careers.

By committing to Epsilon Eta, members also commit to a minimum of 10 hours per semester of volunteer service. We host 3-5 large group volunteering events per semester, as well as facilitate weekly and recurring opportunities to serve to our community. Our service focuses on restoration, community action, activism, and environmental justice.

Fostering a strong community is what gives Epsilon Eta momentum. Weekly study groups, reading roundtables, social events, excursions and rec sports teams spark and nurture relationships within the group. Our bonds allow us to better understand each other and our many viewpoints in order to better consider those from across the environmental movement and advance the larger conversation on sustainability.
Summary: A Professional Environmental Fraternity

Name: Equity, Civil Rights & Title IX Office
Description: The Equity, Civil Rights & Title IX Office oversees, facilitates and supports the University’s efforts to ensure equal opportunity for all persons regardless of race, color, national origin, age, marital status, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, disability, religion, height, weight, or veteran status in employment, educational programs and activities, and admissions.
Summary: The Equity, Civil Rights & Title IX Office oversees, facilitates and supports the University’s efforts to ensure equal opportunity for all persons in employment, educational programs and activities, and admissions.

Name: Erb Institute Student Advisory Board
Description: The Erb Institute Student Advisory Board supports the academic, social, and professional pursuits of Erb Institute MBA/MS students. SAB advises Erb Institute staff on student priorities and promotes student participation in Institute activities.
Summary: The Erb Institute Student Advisory Board supports the academic, social, and professional pursuits of Erb Institute MBA/MS students. SAB advises Erb Institute staff on student priorities and promotes student participation in Institute activities.

Name: Erb Undergraduate Fellows Council
Description: The vision of the Erb Undergraduate Fellows Council is to hear the opinions and voices of fellows of the Erb Institute and plan and execute social and professional events to build community and develop skills for all members.
Summary: The Erb Undergraduate Fellows Council is a selected group of students in the Erb Institute's Undergraduate Fellows Program that collaborate to create and execute events for the entire program. We are not affiliated with the Erb Institute or U-M.

Name: Eta Kappa Nu
Description: Eta Kappa Nu (HKN) exists to recognize the academic achievements of students in the EECS department. In addition to simply having scholastic achievement, we value character and demonstrated commitment to the various communities of which we are a part. As such, members must participate in community service activities in order to successfully join. We also provide opportunities for socialization among our members, as well as with other societies, including TBP, SWE, and IEEE. We also represent the EECS student body to the EECS department and College of Engineering by participating in various committees and events. Corporate recruiters come to HKN to bring technical and recruiting talks to campus, both specifically for HKN members as well as for the whole EECS student body.
Summary: An honor society for students in the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department. We manage the dB Café in the EECS building, contribute to community service projects, and facilitate social and networking opportunities for our members.

Name: Eta Sigma Phi
Description: The Alpha Eta chapter of Eta Sigma Phi, the national Classics honors society, is dedicated to the promotion of interest in the classical world. Members participate in weekly meetings and events such as faculty talks, graduate student panels, game nights, museum visits and more.
Summary: The Alpha Eta chapter of Eta Sigma Phi, the national Classics honors society, is dedicated to the promotion of interest in the classical world.

Name: Eternal Light
Description: Every minute, 11 people die of hunger. That equates to millions of people every year. The Eternal Light Student Org. is a charity student organization with a mission to fight hunger and poverty in our nearby communities. We strive to combat the hunger problem by working with other organizations in our area to pass out food and essentials to those in need regardless of their identity, color, race, religion.
Summary: The Eternal Light is a charity organization dedicated to fighting hunger and poverty in our community. It is a community service oriented club for the members.

Name: European Business Students Association
Description: The EBSA intends to increase interaction among Ross students interested in Europe through professional and social events. The club will assist students interested in internships or full-time careers in Europe, facilitate relations with Ross alumni in Europe as well as European Ross alumni across the globe, and serve as a resource for European students exploring career opportunities in the U.S. Additionally, the EBSA will promote the Ross School of Business to potential applicants from Europe. Finally, the club intends to educate members of the Ross community about the culture and traditions of different European countries.
Summary: The European Business Student Association provides opportunities for students of all backgrounds to involve themselves professionally and culturally with Europe.

Name: Every Three Weekly/UAC
Description:
Styled after the prestigious humor newspaper "The Onion," the Every Three Weekly seeks to provide the University of Michigan campus with a biting, satirical look into hot news items, current pressing issues, and happenings on campus in a newspaper that is published about once per month.

If you would like to receive an application to join the Every Three Weekly, please email us at threeweeks@umich.edu.
Summary: The E3W Newspaper delivers a fresh batch of wit and cynicism to the campus, you guessed it, every three weeks.

Name: Executive Presence Club at Ross
Description: A student-led organization that provides a safe and inclusive space in order to empower students to have a platform to connect with internal and external advisors, and practice guidance received in a safe and non-judgmental environment on executive presence in the different stages of their careers - while recruiting, during their career progression, and while representing their organizations to customers and stakeholders.
Summary: An inclusive community to learn strategies and tactics to understand, practice, and preach executive presence

Name: Exposure Productions
Description:
Here at Exposure Productions, our mission is to produce pro-shot films of live productions for students and professionals, and to create promotional material for these local artists so they may create a wide and accessible audience on the internet. We want to provide our local theater makers, musicians, dancers, and artists a streamlined and concise process of creating personalized video content. These videos may include recruitment videos, teasers, series, social media videos, and full-length pro-shot performances. Exposure Productions also aims to give up and coming filmmakers professional experience before entering the industry.

Joining our organization means you'll help produce, film, and edit these videos while collaborating with local artists to make something special. For more information about getting a pro-shot scheduled or to join the organization, please navigate to our website.
Summary: Exposure Productions is a student-run production company specializing in filming live performances.

Name: Facts On the Ground at Michigan
Description: A group of student leaders dedicated to "clearing the fog" of disinformation on campus surrounding the Israel-Hamas War and the Israel-Palestine conflict through educational initiatives that foster diverse, productive, and fact-based dialogue.
Summary: A group of student leaders dedicated to "clearing the fog" of disinformation on campus surrounding the Israel-Hamas War and the Israel-Palestine conflict through educational initiatives that foster diverse, productive, and fact-based dialogue.

Name: Faith & Enterprise Consulting
Description: Our mission is to create a space where faith and business intersect, grounded in Christian values such as love, servitude, humility, and hard work. Together, we strive to build a community of like-minded individuals committed to integrating these principles into business consulting. Through collaborative projects, we will work with churches and non-profit organizations to enhance various aspects of their operations, including media, fundraising, financial planning, strategy, and organization. As we pursue these goals, we are dedicated to fostering a Christ-centered, safe, and supportive environment, where our shared faith and passion drive positive change.
Summary: In our community of Christians with diverse skills, we share a common identity as believers and a passion for business. We want to bridge an intersection for both these things through hands-on consulting projects and faith-based conversations.

Name: Fall Engineering Career Fair
Description: The purpose of this organization is to bring companies to the University of Michigan to empower engineering students to find careers in industry, allow student members to refine their leadership and organizational skills, support the Society of Women Engineers and Tau Beta Pi, while maintaining and building relations with corporate representatives on an individual and organizational level. The next Fall Engineering Career Fair is September 8-9, 2025.
Summary: The purpose of the Fall Engineering Career Fair is to bring companies to the University of Michigan to empower engineering students to obtain careers in industry. We are one of the largest student-run career fairs in the nation.

Name: FATE
Description:
Are you looking for a volunteer opportunity that engages youth in Detroit? If so, Give Merit’s mentorship program, FATE, is looking for University of Michigan students to become mentors!  

 

WHO WE ARE 

Our student organization, “FATE”, is a collection of students who recruit and participate as mentors for the FATE program (facilitated by a non-profit organization called Give Merit) located in Detroit. Give Merit exists to enhance and extend educational opportunities to Detroit youth through innovative enrichment and mentorship activities. Since 2012, Give Merit has worked intensively with Detroit high school students through its FATE program.

 

THE FATE PROGRAM 

FATE is a four-year, cohort-based program for high school students in Detroit who attend the Jalen Rose Leadership Academy. Its mission is to provide resources and opportunities for Detroit youth to embrace education and become world-class citizens, with a goal to motivate each student to graduate high school and attend college.

 

CURRICULUM

The four-year curriculum features four capstone projects which include creating a marketing / advertising campaign, designing their own Merit product collection, planning and executing a city-wide charity event in Detroit - check out this video about "FATE In Our Stars" (video), and participating in rotational internships as a youth-driven marketing firm. The curriculum is complemented by ongoing soft-skill building activities and regular excursion workshops where students are exposed to a variety of local / national organizations such as Zingerman’s, Google, Carhartt, and Plante Moran.

 

BEING A MENTOR

As mentors, we are paired with 1-2 mentees for the entire year which offers a lot of opportunities for relationship building. The purpose of the mentorship component of the FATE program is to provide guidance and support to our mentees throughout the year. We help facilitate workshop activities where students learn skills in business, marketing, and design thinking while also supporting our mentees as they develop personally and academically. We do our best to demystify the college experience by talking to them about our majors, our extracurricular activities, and what we hope to do after graduation. 

 

JOIN US!

We are looking for students who are interested in making an impact in their community and investing in the lives of youth by becoming a mentor! Mentors will be assigned to one cohort (9th - 12th grade) and will attend programming on a weekly basis in Detroit! Transportation can be provided if needed. 

 

Check out this video to learn more about the FATE Program (video) and this video to learn more about the mentor experience! (video) 

 

For more details about mentorship, please contact us at mentorwithfate@meritgoodness.com
Summary: Join us in mentoring Detroit youth through the FATE Program! FATE provides resources and opportunities for Detroit youth to embrace education and become world-class citizens, with a goal to motivate each student to graduate high school and attend college

Name: FeelGood at the University of Michigan
Description:
FeelGood is a volunteer youth movement committed to ending global hunger in our lifetime.

By handcrafting FeelGood Care Packages for students on campus, we raise money to support the sustainable end of world hunger. Every penny we raise—100%—is invested in The Hunger Project, an international nonprofit with a proven track record of success.

Our goal is to support The Hunger Project while establishing a community of motivated altruists. We use our care package sales as a point of dialogue to increase awareness of global hunger and the hunger-ending strategies that really work.
Summary: FeelGood is the college branch of The Hunger Project, an international nonprofit. We are a youth-led social movement helping turn the campus community into an effective social enterprise, raising money to help reach the sustainable end of world hunger.

Name: Females Initiating Excellence Raising Cultural Competency Everywhere Multicultural Council
Description: FIERCCE is the multicultural council for Barbour and Newberry Residence Halls.  It is composed of residents in Barbour Newberry and serves to support the many cultures and identities of the students residing in the Barbour-Newberry communities.
Summary: Females Initiating Excellence Raising Cultural Competency Everywhere is an organization that serves to support the many cultures of the students residing in Betsy Barbour and Helen Newberry Residence Halls.

Name: Figma Learning for User Experience (FLUX)
Description:
The initiative to establish FLUX (Figma Learning for UX) at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor stems from a recognition of the evolving landscape in design education and the growing importance of proficiency in design tools such as Figma. Our primary objective is to address the existing gap in practical Figma skills among students by providing a platform for hands-on learning and engagement.

FLUX aims to serve as a catalyst for enhancing students' preparedness for careers in UX and related fields by offering workshops, guest lectures, and interactive sessions focused on Figma and its applications in design. Given the diverse academic backgrounds of our student body, many may not have had exposure to the latest design tools crucial for success in contemporary industries. By bridging this gap, FLUX endeavors to empower students across disciplines to develop essential skills in design and technology, thereby augmenting their professional readiness and competitiveness.

In alignment with the University of Michigan's commitment to holistic education and innovation, FLUX seeks to become a cornerstone student organization for Figma proficiency, catering to the needs of current and future students alike. Through collaborative learning experiences and community building, FLUX endeavors to foster a culture of creativity, innovation, and excellence within the university ecosystem.

In short, FLUX aims for students to have fun, share with their peers and learn hard skills for their career advancement.
Summary: FLUX at the University of Michigan bridges the gap in Figma skills among students through workshops and interactive sessions. We aim for participants to have fun, share with their peers, and learn hard skills for their career advancement.

Name: Filipino American Student Association
Description:
The Filipino American Student Association thrives on Filipino and Filipino American culture as the driving force behind its continuing efforts to educate others about the Filipino heritage.

 

CULTURE

To effectively and accurately communicate, cultivate, and exemplify Filipino culture and Filipinx/Filipinx American identities.

 

COMMUNITY

To foster an inclusive and welcoming space for all.

 

OUTREACH

To serve and connect with the University of Michigan, the Midwest, and the Philippines while expressing solidarity and engaging in advocacy with other organizations and marginalized communities.

 

Interested in becoming a member? Fill out this form!

Click here for the official website.
Summary: The Filipino American Student Association thrives on Filipino and Filipino American culture as the driving force behind its continuing efforts to educate others about the Filipino heritage.

Name: Film and Video Student Association
Description: Film and Video Student Association endeavors to enrich the educational and social atmosphere of the Film Television and Media department at the University of Michigan. By bringing together a multitude of talents in the pursuit of organizing workshops, movie nights, contests, field trips, networking with industry professionals, and other various activities, we seek to be a dynamic organization that is academically active and socially responsive.
Summary: FVSA aims to bring together students who love to watch and make movies. We hold screenings, social events, and career events. Lightworks, a student film festival at the end of the Fall and Winter semesters, is our biggest event.

Name: Filmic Productions
Description:
Back in 2010, a group of U-M students got together with a single goal: to tell the highest quality stories through video on the Michigan campus. Their majors were diverse, ranging from business to pharmacy to, of course, Screen Arts & Cultures (now FTVM). While their specific skill sets varied, they were collectively passionate about the moving image, and discovered that by working together they could make better films than each could alone. They called their collaboration “Filmic.”

Soon after its founding, Filmic was presented with the opportunity to start telling stories about Michigan, working with administrators across the University – in Student Life, Development, Athletics, and Admissions to name just a few – to chronicle the student experience through film. And thus, Filmic became U-M’s first student-led creative production company. We specialize in creative storytelling and are dedicated to developing unique ideas that stand out among typical commercial videos; from pre- to post-production we take a vision from concept to reality, while engaging diverse perspectives and embracing our motto of cinema everywhere. Filmic Productions has had the opportunity to work with notable clients including Lady Gaga’s Born This Way Foundation, The Michigan Dance Building, and OTZI Skin, a California-based cosmetics company.

Filmic’s core credo – “Cinema Everywhere” – stems from a collective belief that any story can be made cinematic and impactful, and its members bring that energy to every project they take on.

If you're interested in joining Filmic, our application is due on September 12th 2023 by 11:59pm! We are looking for Art Directors, Directors of Photography, Writers, Editors, Sound Engineers, and Producers! Further information can be found on our website or instagram.

Please email us with any questions.
Summary:
Cinema Everywhere.

Filmic Productions is a student-run, creative production agency, dedicated to producing the highest quality content for clients at The University of Michigan and beyond.

Name: FIRST Alumni and Mentors Network at Michigan
Description:
FAMNM is an on campus effort to unite all of the various departmental and individual student efforts that support FIRST® programs locally and throughout the state of Michigan. FAMNM supports FIRST teams with funds, mentors, volunteers, resources, and publicity, works to strengthen the relationship between the University of Michigan and FIRST programs, and supports robotics-focused STEM engagement efforts throughout the state.

FAMNM is a collegiate network for FIRST alumni and supporters. From mass-mentoring opportunities like Ri3D, opportunities to build personal connections with our corporate sponsors, and volunteer travel reimbursements FAMNM works to engage FIRST alumni and supporters from all backgrounds and levels of involvement. FAMNM provides professional development opportunities including leadership opportunities, resume critiquing, and corporate recruiting events.

More information and ways to get involved can be found at our website: famnm.club
Summary: The mission of FAMNM is to inspire K-12 students to pursue STEM, business, & community outreach opportunities; to support Michigan FIRST teams, mentors, & volunteers; and to develop a professional network of FIRST supporters at the University of Michigan

Name: First at Ross
Description:
Purpose: First at Ross is established to advance the community, awareness, and advocacy of first-generation college graduate students, staff, and members of the Ross School of Business and the broader professional business world. In addition, we promote allyship for this community by educating their fellow faculty, staff, and MBA peers about the challenges - in the classroom and the boardroom. 

Mission: Through campus involvement, our mission is to increase Ross community awareness of student/staff/faculty/business professionals that identify as first-generation college graduates through thoughtful programming, education, and events.
Summary: First at Ross is a affinity group that advances the community, awareness, and advocacy of first-generation college graduate students, staff, and members of Ross School of Business and the broader professional business world.

Name: First Generation Law Students
Description:
First Generation Law Students (FGLS) is focused on supporting first-generation college students and low income students at MLaw. First, we want to prepare first-generation law students for entering the legal profession. We do this by offering programming on networking, interviewing, and career planning. Second, we aim to create a supportive environment for first-generation law students. We create this space by organizing panels on grades, journals, and other academic topics, by hosting discussions on issues affecting first-generation students, and by maintaining a mentoring program comprised of 2Ls and 3Ls.

https://www.firstgenmlaw.com
Summary: First Generation Law Students (FGLS) is focused on supporting first-generation college students and low income students at MLaw.

Name: First Year Experience
Description:
First Year Experience (FYE) is an office that creates a welcoming community for students in their transition to campus by engaging them in programs related to personal and academic growth, navigating campus resources, building meaningful connections with others, and prioritizing well-being.

 

We offer programs on skill development and information sharing, including Time Management, Prioritize Wellness, Money Management, and more. These programs are peer facilitated - you can check out our website for a calendar of events and request our programs at a date and time that work for you.

 

We also offer programs on community building through Community Meet Ups and the Community Matters Cohort Program! Find the Meet Ups calendar on our website as well.
Summary: First Year Experience (FYE) is an office that creates a welcoming community for students in their transition to campus.

Name: First Year Information Program
Description: The First Year Information Program (FYI) helps new students adjust to life as a Michigan Law student. Upper-class FYI Leaders plan and host programs of interest for first-year students, including panel discussions on exam preparation, journals, and class registration. Through these events, FYI aims to prepare first-year students for law school and a career in the legal profession, to connect them to resources in the greater University of Michigan community, and to build collegiality and community.
Summary: Peer-advising program for first-year law students.

Name: First-Gen Public Health Pioneers
Description: First-Gen Public Health Pioneers (FGPHP) works with students, faculty, and staff within the School of Public Health and Departments university-wide. FGPHP aims to create a supportive environment for students within the School of Public Health that fosters community for first-generation public health graduate students and facilitates access to on-campus and off-campus resources.
Summary: FGPHP aims to create a supportive environment for students within the School of Public Health that fosters community for first-generation public health graduate students and facilitates access to on-campus and off-campus resources.

Name: First-Generation College Students @ Michigan
Description: In the Fall of 2007, with great assistance from UM Administration and Residence Education, a small team of undergraduate and graduate students created a program that hopes to eventually offer a variety of resources, advising, and outreach to current and future first generation university students and their parents. First-Generation College Students @ Michigan is a newly formed student organization dedicated to the goals of recognizing, raising awareness of, and resolving the unique needs of first generation college students at the University of Michigan. We are proud to announce that First-Generation College Students @ Michigan is the first student-lead organization of its type in the nation.
Summary: First-Generation College Students @ Michigan is a student organization dedicated to recognizing, raising awareness of, and resolving the needs of undergraduate first-generation college students on the University of Michigan's campus.

Name: First-Generation Pre-Health Association
Description: FGPA was established to provide additional support and guidance to those who identify as first-generation college students and intend to pursue a career in healthcare. The FGPA helps its members navigate the often overlooked challenges and circumstances that pre-health first-gen college students often encounter. By sharing resources, developing leadership skills, and establishing mentorship opportunities we aim to facilitate first-generation students’ preparation for future careers in healthcare.
Summary: By sharing resources, developing leadership skills, and establishing mentorship opportunities we aim to facilitate first-generation students’ preparation for future careers in the healthcare industry.

Name: FitX: Health and Wellness Professional and Innovation Club
Description:
FitX is a professional and innovation club focused on companies in the mental or physical fitness space that are changing how consumers access and/or track their health or wellness. The commonalities of the companies we are focused on are that they are tech-enabled or focusing on capturing/creating new consumer value. FitX lies at the intersection between fitness, health, wellness, innovation, and technology.

Our vision is to foster community amongst Ross business students looking to pursue diverse functional roles within the growing and tech-enabled Health & Wellness industry and establish Ross as a core school for these companies to recruit unique and quality talent. Our mission will be achieved by creating a connection between what is learned in the classroom with evolving industry trends and by facilitating engagement across the Michigan community, alumni, and industry professionals
Summary: FitX is a professional and innovation club focused on companies in the mental or physical fitness space that are changing how consumers access and/or track their health or wellness. We are a function-agnostic, industry-focused club!

Name: Fleece & Thank You
Description:
Fleece & Thank You at the University of Michigan is a student organization affiliated with the non-profit Fleece & Thank You. The mission of Fleece & Thank You is to provide comfort, hope, and connection to children admitted to Michigan hospitals by giving them a fleece blanket that comes with a personalized video message.

As a student organization on campus, our purpose is to facilitate the connection between Fleece & Thank You and our community. We give volunteers the unique opportunity further the mission of Fleece & Thank You by collaborating with other student organizations who are interested in hosting a blanket-making event on the University of Michigan's campus. We also work closely with Mott Children's Hospital to provide members with opportunities to see the benefits of blanket therapy and distribution first-hand.

Please read more about the mission of Fleece & Thank You below. 

https://fleeceandthankyou.org/our-story/

If you are a member of an organization interested in collaborating with us to host an event on campus, please send us an email.
Summary: Fleece & Thank You at the University of Michigan is a service and volunteer focused club affiliated with the non-profit Fleece & Thank You, an organization dedicated to providing fleece blankets for pediatric patients in Michigan Hospitals.

Name: Fletcher Organized Residents Celebrating Everyone
Description: Fletcher Hall Council is an opportunity for Fletcher residents to promote an environment of cultural and social awareness through activities and events which aim to unify all members of the Fletcher Hall Community. Fletcher Hall Council is the governing body of Fletcher Hall.
Summary: The purpose of this organization is to serve as the governing body of Fletcher Hall, as well as to promote an environment of cultural and social awareness through activities and events which aim to unify all members of Fletcher Hall community.

Name: Flowdom
Description: Established in 2015, Flowdom is a co-ed Hip Hop dance group that welcomes various genres of music and dance styles. We strive to deliver captivating choreographed performances, while fostering individual style and flow. Beyond our sessions, we engage in social activities, to create legitimate and long lasting friendships.
Summary: Flowdom is a co-ed Hip Hop group inspired by various types of music and dance. We showcase self-choreographed routines at campus events, fostering bonds within the dance community. The Flowdom Family cultivates enduring friendships, united by our passion

Name: Flywheel - Women's Ultimate Frisbee
Description: We are the University of Michigan's Women's Ultimate Frisbee team. Recognized by the university as a Club Sport, we travel across the country to compete against other high-level programs. Flywheel is made up of many different members, from freshmen who picked up their first disc at tryouts to grad students who have been playing for years. For six of the past ten years, we have qualified for Nationals, most recently placing 2nd in 2011, 3rd in 2012, 5th in 2014, and 9th in 2016, 2017, and 2018, 19th in 2021, and most recently 9th in 2024.
Summary: Women's Ultimate Frisbee

Name: Follies at Ross
Description: The mission of Follies is to provide students interested in comedy writing, stage performance, directing, choreography, improv, stand-up, and digital content creation a chance to learn and experiment, satirically at Ross
Summary: The mission of Follies is to provide students interested in comedy writing, stage performance, directing, choreography, improv, stand-up, and digital content creation a chance to learn and experiment, satirically at Ross

Name: Food Recovery Network at University of Michigan
Description:
The Food Recovery Network at the University of Michigan is an organization dedicated to fighting food waste, food insecurity, and hunger in the Ann Arbor region. To do so, students recover surplus food from campus dining halls and local farms and donates it to the food bank Food Gatherers and the university food pantry Maize & Blue Cupboard. FRN is also committed to raising awareness about the issues of community hunger and food waste through hands-on opportunities and educational outreach. The Food Recovery Network at the University of Michigan is part of an extensive network of FRN chapters that exist at a number of college campuses nationwide.

 

Check out our website: https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/frn-umich-website/home
Summary: The Food Recovery Network at the University of Michigan fights food waste and hunger in the Ann Arbor community by recovering surplus food from University of Michigan dining halls and nearby farms and donating it to local food banks.

Name: Food, Bev, and Ag Club at Michigan Ross
Description: The Food, Bev, and Ag (FB&A) club exists to serve the MBA students of the Ross School of Business by creating a community for students who are interested in exploring career opportunities in the food, beverage, and agriculture industries.
Summary: The Food, Bev, and Ag ("FB&A") club exists to serve the MBA students of the Ross School of Business by creating a community for students who are interested in exploring career opportunities in the food, beverage, and agriculture industries.

Name: Ford + Munk Conference Committee
Description:
The Ford+Munk Conference is an annual student-led policy conference among students at the University of Toronto Munk School of Global Affairs & Public Policy and the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy (the Ford School), one of America’s premier public policy institutions. Held in the Winter/Spring (Ford/Munk) semester, the event brings together students from both schools in a team-based learning environment where they are challenged to analyze, evaluate, and present key findings related to a current policy issue facing both sides of the border. It’s a great opportunity to further your understanding of multi-stakeholder and cross-border policy collaboration and implementation – and have fun in the process!   At the conclusion of the weekend, a panel of faculty judges will select the best proposal.

Organized as a case competition, Ford+Munk aims to achieve the following objectives:

  • Develops a policy student’s problem solving capabilities through a vehicle that is uncommon in policy programs;
  • Allows for Ford and Munk students to interact in a more intimate setting;
  • Acts as an exercise rooted in developing teamwork and presentation skills;

Students are placed into case teams ahead of time, and each team will feature a mix of Ford and Munk students.  No preparation is necessary leading up to the conferences.
Summary: This committee is run by graduate students from the Ford School of Public Policy and the University of Toronto's Munk School of Public Policy and Governance. We hold an annual case competition with participants from both schools.

Name: Ford Leadership Forum at the University of Michigan
Description: The purpose of the Gerald R. Ford Leadership Forum is to be a bi-partisan initiate of the Gerald R. Ford Presidential Foundation that promotes leadership development, civic engagement, & community betterment among a network of undergraduate students.
Summary: The purpose of the Gerald R. Ford Leadership Forum is to be a bi-partisan initiate of the Gerald R. Ford Presidential Foundation that promotes leadership development, civic engagement, & community betterment among a network of undergraduate students.

Name: Ford School Student Affairs Committee
Description: SAC is the liaison between Ford School graduate students, faculty, and staff.  Its members are chosen in biannual elections from the graduate student body.  We represent graduate student interests to the administration, and we disburse administration funds set aside for graduate student organization activities.  We are also responsible for graduate student engagement, host the Ford School Town Halls, as well as several other programs.
Summary: The Student Affairs Committee serves and advocates for the student community of the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy. We work to build community, create transparency, and respond to the needs of students.

Name: Ford School Undergraduate Council
Description: UGC is the Ford School student government. We act as a conduit between the administration and undergraduate students, and work to ensure that Ford undergrads have a great experience. To this end, we facilitate social, philanthropic, and other events for Ford students.
Summary: The primary purpose of this organization is to serve the undergraduate student body of the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy.

Name: Forensic/Speech Team
Description:
The Forensic/Speech Team was established to build a community of public speakers. Our team hosts high school speech tournaments and travels to various colleges to compete in dramatic interpretation, public address, and debate events.

Our general meetings are on Thursdays from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM. Times are subject to changes.

Visit our website for any updates and join our Discord to stay connected:

Website: https://osarius.github.io/Forensics/

Discord: https://discord.com/invite/SuEgRmjTT8
Summary: The Forensic/Speech Team is established to build a community of public speakers. Our team hosts high school speech tournaments and travels to various colleges to compete in dramatic interpretation, public address, and debate events.

Name: Foundation for International Medical Relief of Children
Description: The Foundation for International Medical Relief of Children (FIMRC) is a national non-profit organization whose mission is to provide access to medical care for underprivileged and medically underserved children and families around the world. Our chapter contributes to this mission by adopting fundraising projects at our many clinics abroad, while also advocating for and informing our members on relevant global health issues. We also offer the opportunity for service-learning trips at our clinics abroad, during which members gain insights into health care systems in other countries as well as make a difference within the local communities the clinics serve. At home, we fundraise for our clinical projects through events such as our Benefit Dinner. FIMRC is also dedicated to making a difference within the Ann Arbor community through participation in local volunteering events. We host a variety of social events throughout the semester, creating opportunities to connect, unwind, and enjoy each other's company. We pride ourselves on being a close-knit community of students united by a passion for global health and a shared commitment to making a meaningful impact!
Summary: Our mission is to provide access to healthcare for low-resource and medically underserved families around the world.

Name: Fraker Conference Planning Committee
Description: The Fraker Conference Organizing Committee is a group of graduate students in the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures. We organize, promote and participate in the Charles F. Fraker Conference, which hosts students from academic communities across the country as well as a selected keynote speaker.
Summary: Graduate student group in the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures charged with the organization and promotion of the Charles F. Fraker Graduate Student Conference.

Name: Free Yoga
Description: Free Yoga aims to provide a safe and nurturing space for students to practice mindful movement, yoga, breathwork, and other mind-body practices. It is open to all levels of practice. Students are encouraged to take initiative and lead classes, present their own practices, and share resources. Free Yoga is a collaborative project that aims to give students the opportunity to share knowledge, tune into their bodies during long school days, and empower them to take charge of their health and make movement part of their daily routine. Free Yoga is, as the name implies, free to all!
Summary: Free Yoga aims to provide a safe and nurturing space for students to practice mindful movement, yoga, breathwork, and other mind-body practices. It is open to all levels of practice and is, as the name implies, free!

Name: Friends for St. Jude at UMich
Description: St. Jude Children's Research Hospital is a non-profit that gets around 80% of its funds from donors, and uses those funds to pay for ALL patient's cancer treatments as well as the research that goes toward helping find cures. Since the hospital was founded a little over 50 years ago, the childhood cancer survival rate has gone from 20% to nearly 80%. Friends for St. Jude supports St. Jude Children's Research Hospital as they improve means of prevention and cures for pediatric cancer. We host an annual No More Cancer Rally and other fundraisers, to help pay for patients' treatments and advance research. We hope to develop your leadership and networking skills as we raise funds for the children of St. Jude, and ultimately, all the children who suffer from pediatric cancer.
Summary: We support St. Jude Children's Research Hospital as they improve means of prevention and research cures for pediatric cancer. We primarily host fundraisers to help pay for patient's treatments and advance research.

Name: Friends of Guatemala
Description:
Friends of Guatemala is a volunteer organization founded in 2023 at the University of Michigan with the goal of supporting the educational journeys of students in the Q'eqchi' Mayan village Seacacar, but also in other parts of eastern Guatemala. Through raising money for donations, gathering educational supplies such as books and technology, and establishing a tutoring relationship between UMich students and the young students of our partner communities, we aim to improve access to education for communities who have historically been denied such opportunities.

Friends of Guatemala provides members the opportunity to participate in international community service and take part in building important relationships with students abroad through fundraising and/or weekly tutoring sessions. Members are not required to be tutors, and members are not required to know Spanish or Q’eqchi'. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out!
Summary: Friends of Guatemala is an education-based organization focused on supporting rural, indigenous communities in Guatemala. We connect UM students to Guatemalan youth for virtual tutoring, raise donations, and contribute to community education projects.

Name: Friends of the Gargoyle
Description: We sponsor making people laugh. A lot.
Summary: We bring humor and joy to the university through our dedication to the Gargoyle.

Name: Friendship Circle at Umich
Description:
Friendship Circle provides assistance and support to 3,000 individuals with special needs and their families by providing recreational, social, educational and vocational programming. In addition to helping those in need, the Friendship Circle enriches its vast network of volunteers by enabling them to reap the rewards of selfless giving.

Friendship Circle also provides support to individuals and families struggling with isolation, addiction and other family-related crises.

Our Mission is to create friendship in the lives of individuals with special needs and those facing isolation while providing an opportunity to become a contributing member of the community. Through our programming, Friendship Circle aims to promote an inclusive community that values all individuals regardless of the challenges they face. Friendship Circle is founded upon the idea that within each person is a soul; and that soul is equal and worthy of boundless love. With this inspiration, the lives of the families we serve are enhanced while the volunteers reap the rewards of selfless giving.

Please register for volunteering on this form: https://docs.google.com/forms/u/0/d/e/1FAIpQLScxxcBM4-iVmQ8_qdCRHf3swGhmiK5gXA42VbhmzJPA9sO_GA/formResponse
Summary: Friendship Circle is today’s fastest growing organization for children with special needs. This organization, based out of West Bloomfield, MI aims to branch out into Ann Arbor and the surrounding area to enrich the lives of everyone involved.

Name: Fulbright Student Association at the University of Michigan
Description: The University of Michigan (UofM), boasts a rich tradition of welcoming a substantial cohort of Fulbright scholars and grantees, providing an array of research, study and teaching opportunities. The Fulbright Program stands as a cornerstone among various US Cultural exchange initiatives, dedicated to fostering intercultural understanding, enhancing diplomatic relations, facilitating research endeavors and promoting exchange of knowledge. The aim of the FSA is to gather Fulbright scholars and students, hailing from diverse corners of the globe, under one unified umbrella. This association aspires to establish a dynamic platform where all scholars and students, irrespective of their field of study or background, currently enrolled in any program at the University of Michigan can come together. By fostering collaboration, knowledge sharing and cultural exchange, the association seeks to create a vibrant community that enriches the academic and personal experiences of its members. Through various events, initiatives and networking opportunities, the FSA aims to facilitate meaningful connections, promote academic excellence, and celebrate the spirit of international cooperation embodied by the Fulbright program.
Summary: The Fulbright Student Association at the University of Michigan aims to create a vibrant community that enriches the experiences and ties among Fulbright grantees coming from all over the world.

Name: FunKtion
Description:
Since its inaugural performance at Festifall, 1999, FunKtion has been dedicated to bringing its talent and energy to the University of Michigan campus and beyond.

 

When the initial ten members of FunKtion first combined their forces like Voltron, they had a vision of a multi-cultural group that would bring family-style fun to the masses. Proving that "guys have rhythm" was not the hardest part however. It was the late nights (practicing at Angell Hall, the Diag, the CCRB, or anywhere with some space and an electrical outlet) and the early mornings squeezed in-between the crush of academic and social commitments that truly showed us the importance of dance and brotherhood. All the hard work paid off each and every year, as FunKtion quickly grew into a recognizable entity.

 

FunKtion has been invited to perform at various events such as Festifall, A Taste of Culture, Encompass, Dance Marathon, Michigan Homecoming, Greek Week, KSA, Sixth Day, Celebrasia, Noir Fashion Show, Pioneer High School, 58 Greene concerts, Dance Mix, and a Detroit Pistons game. In its short history, FunKtion has traveled from the Midwest (UIUC, GVSU, Northwestern, opening for Jocelyn Enriquez) to the East Coast (Columbia for ECASU), opening for JCole. and it only gets bigger as FunKtion continually works to expand its repertoire and its presence.

 

The FunKtion family is reaching towards you with open arms and shuffling feet. Come support us wherever the bass reverberates and the boys dance.


We dance. You scream. FunKtion on three...
Summary: We are FunKtion, University of Michigan's first all-male, multicultural, hip-hop dance group. Founded on the principles of brotherhood, dance, and entertainment, we promote the joy and the welfare of the University's diverse community.

Name: Fusion Dance
Description: Fusion Dance is a dance club dedicated to providing various styles for all levels of dancers. Our goal is to promote inclusion by holding classes of different dance styles, allowing dancers to grow, and creating a positive dance community.
Summary: Fusion Dance is a dance club dedicated to providing various dance styles for all levels of dancers. Our goal is to promote artistic inclusion by holding classes of different dance styles to allow dancers to grow.

Name: Future Educators at the University of Michigan
Description:
Future Educators aims to support students who are pursuing careers in education. We seek to create an environment in which our members are supported and able to grow in their education studies through Professional Development, Socialization, and Outreach.

Future Educators is open to all students at the University of Michigan. You do not have to be affiliated with the Marsal School of Education or have declared a major/minor related to education in order to become a member.

Please follow out Instagram @futureeducatorsatumich for more information!
Summary: Future Educators aims to support students who are pursuing careers in education. We seek to create an environment in which our members are supported and able to grow in their education studies through Professional Development, Socialization, and Outreach

Name: Futures in Research, Science, Teaching
Description: The mission of FIRST is to prepare undergraduate students for the graduate school application process, the transition to research at the graduate level, and future pursuit of PhD-based careers. FIRST will connect undergraduates with graduate student mentors and hold events on science-based professional development, in addition to informing them about career paths within the biomedical sciences.
Summary: The mission of FIRST is to prepare undergraduate students for the graduate school application process, the transition to research at the graduate level, and future pursuit of PhD-based careers.

Name: Futuros Abogados
Description: We are committed to providing opportunities for law students to practice Spanish in a legal context, with the understanding that a better ability to communicate will make us better advocates. We seek to do so by holding regular Spanish language meetups, hosting Spanish-speaking attorneys for talks about practicing with Spanish-speaking clients, and through regular social events centering on Spanish-language media and discussion.
Summary: A platform for law students to practice Spanish in a legal context.

Name: Galens Medical Society
Description:
Galens Medical Society, founded in 1914, is the largest and oldest student group at the University of Michigan Medical School, and is comprised of about 120 medical students and 13 faculty Honoraries. The organization raises >$80,000 in its annual Tag Days fundraiser, and distributes this money to organizations within Mott hospital and to charities that benefit the children of Washtenaw County. Galens members take an active role in volunteerism, and interact socially with faculty through activities such as the Smoker, Welcome BBQ, tailgate, and the year-end banquet. The Galens Loan Fund helps defray the cost of residency interviewing at subsidized interest rates. Additionally, students continue to recognize and award teaching and leadership excellence among Medical School basic science and clinical faculty, as well as house officers.

The traditions of community service, extracurricular socialization, faculty cooperation and recognition, and student advocacy have remained central objectives throughout the organization's long history. The success and duration of the organization is attributable not only to the commitment, passion, and charity of its students, but also to that of its alumni and honorary faculty members, who over the years have dutifully served as advisors, mentors, and advocates.
Summary: Galens Medical Society, founded in 1914, is the largest and oldest student group at the University of Michigan Medical School, and is comprised of about 120 medical students and 13 faculty Honoraries.

Name: Galens Medical Society Smoker
Description: Galens Medical Society Smoker is a medical student organization at UM which produces the annual musical comedy "roast" of the medical school faculty, also known as "The Galens Smoker" or "The Smoker."
Summary: Galens Medical Society Smoker is a medical student organization at UM which produces the annual musical comedy "roast" of the medical school faculty, also known as "The Galens Smoker" or "The Smoker."

Name: Gamma Phi Beta
Description: Gamma Phi Beta is an international sorority established to promote the highest type of womanhood through education, social life, and service to country and humanity. Gamma Phi Beta is more than 140 years old and has been dedicated to continuing the vision of our Founders since day one. Members of the Sorority are wholeheartedly invested in our sisterhood and believe deeply in our philanthropic mission, vision and focus. There is a quiet strength that is evident across the sisters and a desire to remain true and constant to the Sorority, the friendships, the opportunities and the values.
Summary: We build confident women of character who celebrate sisterhood and make a difference in the world around us.

Name: Gamma Sigma Alpha
Description: Gamma Sigma Alpha National Academic Greek Honor Society is the premier organization committed to the academic success of our members. Students are eligible for membership based on grade point average and membership in a Greek fraternity or sorority.
Summary: Gamma Sigma Alpha National Academic Greek Honor Society is the premier organization committed to the academic success of our members.

Name: Gear Up for Good
Description:
Our club is an organization that collects new or gently used sports equipment and donates it to individuals, teams, schools, and communities that are in need. The mission of the organization is to provide access to sports equipment and promote physical activity for youths and families.
The club typically accepts donations of various types of sports equipment, which is then sorted, cleaned, and distributed to those in need, based on the requests and needs of the recipients.
In addition to collecting and distributing equipment, Gear Up for Good may also hold events and programs to promote physical activity and provide educational resources on the benefits of sports and healthy living.
By collecting and donating sports equipment, our club is making a positive impact on the lives of individuals and families who may not have access to these resources. It helps to level the playing field and provides opportunities for everyone to participate in sports and physical activities, regardless of their economic status.
Summary: Our club is an organization that collects new or gently used sports equipment and donates it to individuals, teams, schools, and communities that are in need.

Name: Gender Minorities in Aerospace
Description: The organization of GeMA builds community, provides support, and facilitates opportunities for gender minorities in aerospace engineering at the University of Michigan with a focus on the experiences of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.
Summary: GeMA is a community for graduate and postdoc gender minorities in aerospace engineering.

Name: Gender Violence Project
Description:
(A) Who We Are

Gender Violence Project (GVP) is a coalition of law students advocating to prevent gender-based violence and to support survivors.. We use principles of substantive equality to achieve justice for people of all identities to eradicate gender-based violence on our campus and in our community. 

 

We value intersectionality -- taking into consideration how race, gender expression, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, religion, immigration status, and other axes of identity impact women and inform their lived experiences. 

 

(B) Mission Statement

We believe that every person has the right to feel safe and free from violence in their homes, communities, and workplaces. These rights are violated every day in a world where gender-based violence and sexual exploitation are common and commonly accepted occurrences. We seek to remedy this violation by supporting women, trans, and femme individuals at the Law School, while working to eradicate gender-based violence on our campus, and in our community.

 

(C) Functions

In pursuit of its goals, GVP will:

  • Hear, validate, support, and advocate for survivors of gender violence.
  • Articulate, through the use of community education, organization, and mobilization, that freedom from violence--particularly rape and sexual assault--is a basic human right.
  • Promote goals of total bodily autonomy; freedom from violence, exploitation, objectification, and oppression; and ending impunity for gender violence crimes.
  • Examine and cultivate a greater awareness of the relationship between the American legal system and gender violence.
  • Recognize the repercussions of gender-based discrimination as it intersects with other forms of oppression, including racial, religious, socio-economic, gender identity, sexual orientation, and cultural discrimination.
  • Change the systems of oppression that lead to gender-based violence for University of Michigan Law School students and the greater community.
  • Call for a greater focus on gender and feminist scholarship in the academic curriculum at the University of Michigan Law School.
Summary: Gender Violence Project is a Michigan Law student organization dedicated to advocating for victims of gender-based violence.

Name: General Management Club
Description:
The General Management club caters to students interested in pursuing career paths that are cross-functional in nature and that typically lead to general management positions. The club's focus is on entry points for general management internships and positions immediately after business school, rather than on the future general management positions.
