This typically includes but is not limited to leadership rotational programs that provide for an accelerated career growth in an organization. Additionally, we also focus on Internal Strategy and Business Development roles.

The mission of the General Management Club is two-fold. First, the club fosters interaction between Ross MBAs and companies that are seeking talented students; secondly, the club prepares its members for recruitment through educational and networking events.

 

Visit us at CampusGroups for more details.
Summary: The General Management Club focuses on providing its members with leadership skills, well-rounded management expertise, and critical business perspectives to launch a career in corporate leadership.

Name: Generate Real Opportunities and Wonder Tutoring Program
Description: "The more you know, the more you grow!" Since 2014, G.R.O.W., a non-profit, has been dedicated to expanding opportunities and resources in STEM for urban elementary students while also improving literacy skills with an emphasis on hands-on learning.
Summary: "The more you know, the more you grow!" Since 2014, G.R.O.W., a non-profit, has been dedicated to expanding opportunities and resources in STEM for urban elementary students while also improving literacy skills with an emphasis on hands-on learning.

Name: Generation Asian Pacific American
Description: Since 1995, GenAPA has hosted the largest annual Asian Pacific American cultural show at the University of Michigan. With over 1000 audience members and 250 performers, we strive to promote diversity and representation of A/PIA culture. GenAPA will host our show at the end of the Winter semester, showcasing the talents and culture of A/PIA students as well as a headliner. We advocate for social justice and to educate the community.
Summary: An organization devoted to hosting the largest A/PIA cultural show at the University of Michigan and promoting social justice and awareness throughout the community

Name: Genes in Diseases and Symptoms
Description: The University of Michigan chapter of GIDAS’s mission is to advocate genetic research for diseases through high school outreach and our own research! GIDAS engages in biology-focused educational programs in local high schools, some of which include teaching wet-lab techniques and computational biology/programming concepts. GIDAS members have the opportunity to learn computational biology skills from their peers and provide mentorship to high school students through the miRcore Volunteer Program. We also invite guest speakers involved in the computational biology and genetics fields to expose undergraduates to research and interdisciplinary career pathways in healthcare.
Summary: The University of Michigan chapter of GIDAS’s mission is to advocate genetic research for diseases through high school outreach and our own research activities.

Name: GeoClub
Description:
GeoClub is committed to providing graduate students and undergraduates a way to network both socially and professionally within the Earth science community at the University of Michigan and within the Earth science community at large,

   To developing field and technical skills tailored to the subject of Earth science that would otherwise not be learned in a classroom,

   To providing regional field trips for students, so that they may be able to experience a variety of settings that are not easily accessible due to the homogeneous, flat land of the lower peninsula of Michigan, 

   To keeping current students updated on the work of graduates and undergraduates with presentations of ongoing and past research, field experiences, and internships,   

   To participating in outreach programs that promote interest in Earth science,

   And lastly to providing career development and networking opportunities as well as resources to help students prepare for life after graduation.  

 

Homepage: https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/umgeoclub/home
Summary: GeoClub is a student organization for undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Michigan who are interested in Earth science.

Name: Geoguessr Club
Description: We meet on Mondays at 7pm on the 2nd floor of Shapiro Library in the west-facing study rooms.
Summary: We play the video game Geoguessr! We meet to discuss strategies and metas, have fun, and compete with other universities around the world!

Name: Geriatrics Interest Group
Description: The Geriatrics Interest Group (GIG) plans to introduce University of Michigan medical students to both geriatric medicine and geriatric psychiatry and the importance of these specialties. The organization will host seminars, facilitate faculty mentorship, and encourage students to shadow faculty who specialize in the fields of geriatrics. The goals of GIG are to foster a specific interest in geriatrics, while also emphasizing the wide-ranging nature that a background in geriatrics has for all medical professionals. Early exposure to the principles of geriatric medicine and psychiatry will create better future-physicians as they treat older adult patients.
Summary: The goal of the Geriatrics Interest Group (GIG) is to introduce medical students to the complexities and importance of geriatric medicine and geriatric psychiatry through a variety of educational experiences.

Name: German Club at the University of Michigan
Description: German Club's mission is to unite students with an interest in German culture and language and to promote this passion throughout campus, especially in the form of joint events and activities with other language clubs. In addition to hosting a special cultural event every month, we meet weekly at a time and location detailed by email and displayed on our website for an informal get-together called "Stammtisch" to speak in German (all levels welcome!) and increase our knowledge of German culture.
Summary: German Club's mission is to unite students with a passion for German culture and language and to promote the spread of German culture across campus, especially in the form of cross-cultural exchanges with other language clubs.

Name: German Peer Mentors
Description: We are an organization of German majors and minors who seek to help mentor other current and prospective students of German on everything from studying abroad to course selection, language learning, and more.
Summary: We are an organization of German majors and minors who seek to help mentor other current and prospective students of German on everything from studying abroad to course selection, language learning, and more.

Name: Gerontology Honor Society: Sigma Phi Omega
Description:
Sigma Phi Omega (SPO), the national academic honor and professional society in gerontology, was established in 1980 to recognize excellence of those who study gerontology and aging and the outstanding service of professionals who work with or on behalf of older persons. The formation of a society provides a much needed link between educators, practitioners, and administrators in various settings where older persons are served.

 
The goals of SPO are achieved primarily through activities of local chapters, and secondarily through efforts of the national office and officers. Local chapters serve as links within their respective communities to promote interaction between gerontology educators, students, alumni, and local professionals. The chapters provide opportunities for personal and professional interaction, sharing of concerns, discussion of issues, and service activities.
 
SPO seeks to promote scholarship, professionalism, friendship, and services to older persons, and to recognize exemplary attainment in gerontology/aging studies and related fields."
Summary: The purposes of the Chapter shall be to promote scholarship, research, professionalism, and excellence in gerontology and aging services, and to recognize high attainment in the pursuit of academic and clinical excellence in these areas.

Name: Gift of Life
Description: Gift of Life is a nonprofit organization dedicated to helping blood cancer patients find lifesaving marrow donors. Our mission is to educate students and the Michigan community about blood cancer and the importance of the donor registry. By participating, you can help grow the registry through donor recruitment events, spreading awareness, and swabbing potential matches. A simple cheek swab could lead to saving a life!
Summary: Gift of Life is a nonprofit organization dedicated to helping blood cancer patients find lifesaving marrow donors. The university chapter educates students and the community about blood cancer and recruits donors through swabbing events.

Name: Gimble A Cappella
Description:
It all began in early 1997 when a group of University of Michigan Arts Chorale members got together to sing some a cappella music. After much debate and many poetry recitations, the group adopted the name "Gimble in the Wabe" from Lewis Carroll's poem, Jabberwocky. Since first performing in April of 1998, the group’s name has been refined to Gimble A Cappella, and has evolved into the self-proclaimed quirkiest a cappella group on campus! Each year, Gimblers unite to host 3 concerts and can frequently be seen performing at various events on campus and around the country during their annual spring tour. 

Gimble released 7 studio albums on CD before their recent releases on streaming platforms. In 2017, they released a 4-song EP, “XX,” in celebration of their 20th anniversary. Featuring hits like “If I Go” and “I’m with You”, it motivated a wave of new releases. Singles “Dancing On My Own” and “715 - CR∑∑KS” debuted in 2018, followed by “Fallingwater” and “when the party’s over” late in 2019. In 2020, they released their 5-song EP “home,” aptly named both for the home they shared together and the unmistakable familial atmosphere of the group. Shortly thereafter, Gimble returned with powerhouse covers of Brandi Carlile's "The Joke" and Hozier's "Movement". Gimble is excited to continue recording their original arrangements for many years to come!

Going strong in its 27th year, Gimble A Cappella continues the tradition with a few fresh faces and a continued passion for a cappella music. Check out our Youtube channel and follow our Instagram page @gimbleacappella for up-to-date information!
Summary: Gimble is an all-gender a cappella group that sings music from a wide variety of genres. We love singing and entertaining while having fun!

Name: Girl Gains at the University of Michigan
Description: Our mission is to promote female weight lifting and empower women to feel strong and beautiful in a judgment free community. Whether you’re a dedicated gym goer or a curious beginner, Girl Gains is a college campus-originated organization and an evolving online community here to support you in every stage of your fitness journey.
Summary: Promoting female weight lifting and empower women to feel strong and beautiful in a judgment free community.

Name: Girl Up Michigan
Description:
Girl Up Michigan is a student chapter of the United Nations campaign, Girl Up. Launched in 2010, Girl Up, aims to ensure that girls in developing countries are educated, healthy, safe, counted, and positioned to be the next generation of leaders through five main pillars: education, health, freedom from violence, and count. At Girl Up Michigan, we host fundraisers, volunteering events, speaker series, socials, and a gala. Through each of these events, we aim to create a family in which anyone can feel safe to discuss important issues surrounding women and advocate for important causes. Girl Up Michigan aims to empower others to get involved and teach the Ann Arbor community that girls around the world matter while making an impact that is both local and global as we fundraise for issues around the world. 

Visit our website at https://girlupmichigan.org or our Instagram @girlupmichigan to learn more!
Summary: Girl Up Michigan aims to empower everyone to get involved, teach their communities that girls and women matter and make sure that girls in developing countries are educated, healthy, safe, counted and positioned to be the next generation of leaders.

Name: Girls in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
Description:
Girls in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (GEECS) is a student organization that encourages the professional, academic, and social development of women in technology. Founded in 2002, GEECS focuses on connecting women in tech and creating a supportive environment for all of its members and alumni. 

In an effort to promote the education and success of technologically inclined women, GEECS reaches out to individuals ranging from middle school girls to graduate students. Currently, the number of women in EECS is steadily declining, and we want to be a part of the change that we hope to see. 

GEECS organizes a variety of social, professional, and academic events for our members. To see what events we are holding, please take a look at the calendar below. For even more information, feel free to check out the GEECS Facebook page and subscribe to our weekly emails. 

To join, fill out this form to get added to our email list and start attending our events! Check out our website here: geecsumich.com 
Email us at geecs.officers@umich.edu for any additional questions!
Summary: GEECS is an organization dedicated to supporting female students pursuing degrees through the EECS department, including degrees in Computer Science, Data Science, Computer Engineering, and Electrical Engineering! Email geecs.officers@umich.edu for info!

Name: Girls Who Code at UM DCMB
Description:
Founded by current doctoral students in the Department of Computational Medicine and Bioinformatics (DCMB) at the University of Michigan, our Girls Who Code club seeks to provide a collaborative and supportive environment for high schoolers of all skills levels and backgrounds interested in learning how to code. Due to the research expertise of our graduate student Facilitators, our Club curriculum is focused on computational data analysis and the Python programming language. Participants will learn core coding concepts and implement their new skills in a data science capstone project of their choosing.

We also plan and volunteer at various science K-undergraduate outreach opportunities in the greater Ann Arbor area. We launched a Data Science Summer Experience in Detroit in summer 2019. For more information please visit our website http://umich.edu/~girlswc.
Summary: Founded by doctoral students in the Department of Computational Medicine and Bioinformatics (DCMB) at the University of Michigan, our organization runs a Girls Who Code Club, provides K-undergraduate outreach, and runs a Data Science Summer Experience.

Name: Girls Who Code Loop @ UM
Description: Girls Who Code Loop @ UM is an organization affiliated with the national nonprofit organization, Girls Who Code which is a nonprofit organization that aims to support and increase the number of women in computer science. We hope to help the process of closing the gender employment difference in technology and change the image of what a programmer looks like. We are here for anyone who is interested in tech, regardless of skill level, major, or experience.
Summary: GWC @ UM is an organization established in order to promote females and underrepresented folk in the computer science field.

Name: Global Dental Brigades
Description:
Our University of Michigan chapter aims to bring together student volunteers who are a dedicated group of individuals committed to making an impact on oral health disparities around the world.

With their skills, compassion, and cultural sensitivity, Global Dental Brigades volunteers work tirelessly to deliver preventive education, basic dental procedures, and oral hygiene supplies to communities that lack access to adequate dental care. They understand the profound impact that oral health has on overall well-being and strive to empower individuals to take control of their oral health through education and treatment.

These volunteers embody the spirit of collaboration and service, working alongside local healthcare professionals and community members to create sustainable solutions for improving oral health outcomes. As student volunteers, we embark on a 7 day brigade in countries, such as Honduras, Panama, or Guatemala. Whether they're conducting dental clinics in remote villages or implementing community-based oral health initiatives, Global Dental Brigades student volunteers are champions of dental equity, bringing smiles and transforming lives wherever they go.
Summary: Global Dental Brigades is an international movement of students and healthcare professionals working alongside local communities to implement sustainable health systems.

Name: Global Dental TeleBrigades
Description:
Global Dental TeleBrigades offers aspiring dental professionals hands-on experience through skill-based volunteering, virtual cultural immersion, and live dental clinics. Using secure telemedicine platforms and guided by local healthcare professionals, participants engage in mobile clinics, dentist interviews, and interactive case studies. This innovative program enhances dental knowledge, develops medical Spanish skills, introduces pharmacology concepts, and explores epidemiology

 

Join Global Dental TeleBrigades to gain hands-on dental experience, develop clinical skills, and make a real impact on underserved communities through virtual clinics and telemedicine.
Summary: Gain hands-on dental experience through live virtual clinics, telemedicine, and interactive case studies. Build skills in medical Spanish, pharmacology, and epidemiology while making a real impact on underserved communities.

Name: Global Fordies
Description: Global Fordies (GF) is a student organization of international students at the Ford School of Public Policy, focused on establishing a global and multicultural community of engaged public servants. GF is established to collaborate within the Ford School to ease the transition for international students, maximize their potential and career opportunities and encourage them to contribute to the Ford School community. We provide a unique platform for international students to engage with the Ford School community, voice their issues and bring positive change by promoting multicultural perspectives with their peers and colleagues at the entire Ford School.
Summary: Global Fordies is a student organization of international students at the Ford School of Public Policy,  focused on establishing a global and multicultural community of engaged public servants.

Name: Global Health Alliance at the University of Michigan
Description:
Our Model 

Global health equity starts within our local communities, which is why the Global Health Alliance at the University of Michigan (GHA) is proud to partner locally as well as globally. We and our partner organizations, Green Umbrella School in Cambodia and Avalon Housing and Washtenaw Literacy in Michigan, aim to maintain long-term partnerships in the name of sustainability to maximize impact. The rights to education, housing, and basic literacy are some of the most important health determinants, and their impacts can have generational effects. GHA aims to support our partner organizations through mutual learning, respect, and understanding. By engaging with self-sufficient local organizations, we gain valuable insights that help us support international partners, like Green Umbrella School, in their journey toward self-sufficiency.

 

About Us

Our chapter of the Global Health Alliance is an independent student-run organization and one of the nation's first to partner with three local and international non-profit organizations. Our first partner is Avalon Housing in Ann Arbor, MI. We work with them by helping run the front desk, beautification projects, and art events. Our second partner is Washtenaw Literacy, also in Ann Arbor, MI. With them, we teach English as a Second Language (ESL) to local community members. 

 

Our partner outside of the United States is Green Umbrella School in the Putsor Community near Phnom Penh, Cambodia, which believes in the potential of today's youth. Green Umbrella provides quality education to disenfranchised families to achieve sustainable development, facilitates leadership programs to enhance confidence and unity within the community, and leads livelihood workshops for adults and English classes for children. We raise an annual $5,000 for our international partner and assist with their assessment research and education modeling during our 3-week trip every summer. At our Monday night meetings, we plan fundraising and volunteer events and hold discussion-based lessons about public health issues.

 

Why we are a global health club:

GHA is a global health club because we understand that health does not follow political borders. Global health work is more than collaborating with partners in lower-income countries; it recognizes the local and international connection. Our work abroad informs us of how we solve complex challenges at home and vice versa. We aim to address some of the most significant social determinants of health: education, housing, and literacy rates. Our work involves fundraising efforts combined with co-designing programming with our partners and reflects our commitment to addressing the issues affecting billions of people worldwide. Through our annual efforts with our partners and our weekly club discussions on campus, we aim to understand the complexities of public health issues and take meaningful action to create lasting change—locally and globally.
Summary: Student organization bridging global health challenges through local-international partnerships, focusing on education, housing, and literacy by supporting communities in Michigan and Cambodia via fundraising, research, and volunteer work.

Name: Global Investments Committee
Description:
GIC is a close-knit student organization focusing on the global economy and financial markets. Using the diversity of our membership base as well as the resources in the Stephen M. Ross School of Business and Tozzi Trading Floor, we aim at providing an unparalleled hands-on learning experience to our fellow members by organizing valuation workshops, speaker series, trading simulations, etc. In addition, we utilize our network to organize recruiting events with companies in the financial services industry.

Diversity is a focal point of our club. With members from different countries and backgrounds, you will learn more about different cultures and get yourself more prepared for the rapidly globalizing world!
Summary: Close-knit student organization focusing on the global economy and financial markets. Using the diversity of our membership base as well as the resources in the Ross School of Business, we aim at providing an unparalleled hands-on learning experience.

Name: Global Market Innovators
Description: As club members, we can experience together how to build a small business from scratch. At this stage, we choose to sell bubble milk tea because this method is easier and less expensive, and is more in line with modern popular culture, allowing everyone to It is easier for members to have a sense of experience and participation.
Summary: This is a club open to all majors, giving many people more opportunities to actually sell things. This club not only allows many students to better understand what business is it but also allows students to learn about many Asian cuisines.

Name: Global Medical Brigades
Description:
Global Brigades is the world’s largest student-led global and sustainable development organization. Since 2004, Global Brigades has mobilized thousands of students and professionals through nine skill-based programs that work in partnership with community members to improve quality of life in under resourced regions while respecting local culture.

The mission is to resolve global and economic disparities by empowering student volunteers, local professionals, and community members in a collaborative holistic approach to sustainable development. 

The Global Brigades chapter at of Michigan has three of the eight brigades; Dental, Medical, and Public Health.
Summary: Our mission is to empower student and professional volunteers to offer a variety of clinics and consultations, facilitate sustainable solutions, and ultimately promote our holistic model in under-resourced communities in Central America and Africa.

Name: Global Medical Missions Alliance at Michigan
Description:
The purpose of GMMA at Michigan is to bring and promote Christ-centered missional life to the body of healthcare professionals, students, and its partners. We hope to foster relationships between students, aspiring professionals, and current professionals in, but not limited to medicine, law, business, education, and engineering. We aim to serve communities locally, nationally, and globally through different service opportunities.

Core Values:
-- Cultivating a heart of service, rooted in the love of Christ, seeking to both experience and reflect His love through our actions.
-- Help local churches to fulfill medical missions work around the world through connecting, teaching, and training.
-- Empower the next generation of healthcare professionals to advance into the medical mission field through mentoring, training, supporting, and providing mission opportunities.
-- Awaken mission-minded students and healthcare professionals to fulfill the great commission through networking and partnering.
-- Link students and healthcare professionals with global mission organizations.
Summary: The purpose of GMMA at Michigan is to bring and promote Christ-centered missional life to the body of healthcare professionals, students, and its partners.We aim to serve communities locally, nationally, and globally through service opportunities.

Name: Global Scholars Student Organization
Description: The Global Scholars Student Organization (GSSO) is an opt-in student organization available to current Global Scholars Program members. It organizes student member activities rooted in GSP's mission and values (below) and provides valuable student perspectives to guide the program forward. GSSO serves as a forum and site for student leadership independent from GSP.
Summary: The GSSO serves as an opt-in forum and site for student leadership among members of the Global Scholars Program, independently funded and run by students.

Name: Global Surgery Student Alliance
Description:
Global Surgery Student Alliance (GSSA) aims to educate undergraduate students about global healthcare inequities. GSSA has multiple chapters at different undergraduate universities and medical schools. The undergraduate U of M chapter will host events, workshops, seminars, and webinars with healthcare professionals. The chapter will also organize and facilitate resume workshops and study groups. The events that GSSA hosts will primarily be educational in nature, while also integrating service and research opportunities for impact in the community. For example, there are many activities we may host including but not limited to suturing events, hackathons, emergency medicine clinics, and panels. Members of GSSA also have the opportunity to foster connections with U of M medical school students and practicing medical professionals in the global health field.

Health care is a human right, and GSSA hopes to act as a resource for students to learn about providing care to patients. Though GSSA is a pre-health/med organization, it also highlights the multidisciplinary nature of healthcare. Healthcare is a complex topic that does not simply start with going into the doctor’s office. It also involves other disciplines, such as pharmacy, business, public policy, and engineering. We believe that students of differing academic and intellectual backgrounds are vital to the success of our organization. 

We hope to inspire future healthcare providers, encouraging them to think about healthcare and surgery from a broader, more global perspective.
Summary: Our mission, as the U of M chapter of Global Surgery Student Alliance, is to provide valuable resources about global surgery and related health inequities that will help engage, excite, and inspire our members in their healthcare aspirations.

Name: Go Blue Wear Pink
Description:
If you would like to become involved, please email awinner@umich.edu. We are not notified when you just press "join."

 

Go Blue Wear Pink is a student-run organization at the University of Michigan that raises money to fund breast cancer research at the U-M Rogel Cancer Center. Since 2007, students have raised over $400,000 to accelerate groundbreaking research at one of the nation’s leading cancer research centers. 

We all know someone who has been affected by cancer, whether a close friend, family member, or friend of a friend. And we have all seen the debilitating effect that this disease can have on patients and the people who are supporting them.

Please join us in easing the burden of cancer by making a donation. Your support will improve and save lives. No donation is too small, because every dollar represents the next step in the search for a cure.
Summary: Go Blue Wear Pink at the University of Michigan was founded in 2007 to help raise money and awareness for Breast Cancer Research at the University of Michigan Rogel Cancer Center.

Name: Golden Theatre Company
Description: Golden Theatre Company is a student-run organization created to expand the knowledge of and opportunity for musicals in the classical canon through the production and performance of a fully staged musical, while maintaining an environment that is safe, innovative, and diverse for each of the students involved. To accomplish our mission, we will produce one musical per semester in both the Fall and Winter. These will consist of shows written in the Golden Age era of musical theatre, as well as any and all musicals that are typically sung in the classical, or “legit” style.
Summary: Golden Theatre Company is a student-run theater organization that focuses on Golden Age Musical Theatre and musicals performed in the classical style.

Name: Good News Christian A Cappella
Description: We are a Christian organization on campus that is dedicated to spreading the gospel of Jesus Christ to this campus through music. We rehearse twice weekly and hold a concert each semester, in addition to performing at other smaller venues over the course of the semester. Good News is a wonderful community of fun people who love singing and are dedicated to serving Christ.
Summary: We are a Christian A Cappella group that is dedicated to bringing the good news of the gospel to the U-M campus through music.

Name: GradCru
Description:
GradCru is a graduate student chapter at U-M of the international mission organization “Cru”, which has a ministry presence on 2,696 campuses in the U.S. and 191 nations worldwide.

GradCru is for American and International Master, Ph.D., and Professional School graduate students. Our group is very diverse racially/ethnically, from around the U.S. and world, social/economic backgrounds, academic programs from across campus, and more ways. We think you’ll feel welcome and fit well.

We are active on campus in many different ways — and have a lot of fun together! You are welcome to participate to whatever extent you desire and what fits with your often rigorous schedule, with no pressure (you get enough pressure just being in grad school).

At our core (our mission statement), GradCru is a graduate community that seeks to stimulate and support each other to (1) live out authentically and (2) communicate meaningfully our faith in Jesus Christ in the midst of the University. We also want to think deeply about the integral relationship of our faith and our academics. We value and promote “4 E’s”:

• E1: Encounter Jesus fully. (Romans 1:16)
• E2: Establish Christian grad students in their faith. (Colossians 2:6-7)
• E3: Equip grad believers with effective ministry skills. (Ephesians 4:11)
• E4: Entrust Christian grads to reproduce these distinctives around the world. (2 Timothy 2:2)

Here is a listing of much of what GradCru provides:

• Bible Study Groups • Social Events (e.g., board game nights, dinners, sports) • Prayer • Campus and Individual Outreach • Spiritual Mentoring/Discipleship • Ministry Philosophy and Skills Training • International Lecture/Mission Trips (e.g., Filter of Hope to Cuba) • and More!
Summary: GradCru is a graduate student community that seeks to stimulate and support its members to live out authentically and communicate meaningfully their faith in Jesus Christ in the midst of the University.

Name: GradTONES
Description: The purpose of the GradTONES is to provide an opportunity for graduate students throughout the University of Michigan to rehearse and perform unaccompanied vocal music from a variety of popular musical genres, as well as to foster interdepartmental interaction and camaraderie across graduate programs.
Summary: GradTONES A Cappella is a co-ed singing group composed entirely of graduate students currently enrolled at the University of Michigan. The latter half of this name is an acronym standing for "Troupe Of Needlessly Educated Singers".

Name: Graduate Christian Fellowship
Description:
About GCF

Our Mission

We seek to be a vibrant and welcoming community through the study and application of God's word in our life together, faithfully praying for each other, our community, our departments, and our campus, fostering the growing and deepening of relationships with our Lord Jesus Christ and each other, and serving those in need.

In striving to do this Graduate Christian Fellowship provides a place for Christian dialogue and discipleship within the University community in order to bring a Christian perspective to the academic arena and to enable Christian graduate and professional students to become more effective witnesses to the glory and honor of Jesus Christ.

Our Objectives

As a group of committed graduate students, we seek to balance our calling to be a community of Christian disciples with our calling to reach out to the campus. We desire to spur one another on in our mutual journey of faith, to grapple seriously with the intellectual issues of our times from a Christian perspective, and to engage the campus with Jesus Christ. To that end, we have the following objectives:

  • Spiritual Formation

    GCF is committed to the ongoing development of faithful disciples of Jesus Christ. Through the disciplines of Bible study, prayer, and worship, we seek to become more Christ-like in all areas of our lives. Through small group Bible studies, prayer groups, large group speakers, retreats, and training opportunities, we strive to meet graduate students wherever they are in their spiritual journeys and to challenge them to continued growth and development.

  • Integration of Faith and Academics

    We believe that Jesus Christ is the Lord of our whole lives, including both the personal and public areas. As Christian graduate and professional students, Christ calls us to excellence in scholarship and career as well as unwavering obedience to His Word. GCF is committed to affirm the Christian worldview in the university culture by presenting Christian thought in ways that are meaningful to our colleagues and by supporting each other as we explore our call to be servants of Christ in our culture.

  • Evangelism and Service

    Our primary mission field is the university. We believe that God cares about the university, both the institution and the people who study and work there. Because we feel that the best way to reach other graduate students is through one-on-one relationships, we put emphasis on training and encouraging individuals to reach out to non-Christian friends and colleagues. In addition, we organize regular service opportunities for graduate students to help those in need in our community.

  • Fellowship

    As graduate and professional students, we are called to live out Christ's love as a community of believers. We desire to be known as a group that has genuine love for one another. Through our Bible studies and prayer groups, large groups, social events and retreats, we can develop friendships which serve as a base of support and encouragement during challenging times.

The Fellowship

Graduate Christian Fellowship is a Chapter of InterVarsity Christian Fellowship, which in turn is part of a world-wide, student-led Christian movement, active in colleges and universities, known as the International Fellowship of Evangelical Students (IFES). GCF seeks to minister to graduate students through a variety of student-led programs and activities:

  • Small Group Bible Studies

    Small groups are the heart of GCF. Meeting weekly for Bible study, prayer, worship, and outreach, these groups (usually 6-10 people) are a key source of support, fellowship, and study.

  • Large Group Meetings

    The chapter regularly gathers as a large group for corporate worship and either a speaker or a facilitated discussion.

  • Prayer Meetings

    GCF coordinates weekly prayer meetings.

  • Outreach

    GCF sponsors various programs to reach out to the University community. We seek to engage the campus with our faith on an intellectual level, as well as train and encourage others to do the same.

  • Other Activities

    GCF also organizes a variety of special activities, including reading or discussion groups, departmental prayer groups, and various social events, retreats, and conferences.

Basis of Faith

As a chapter of InterVarsity Christian Fellowship, Graduate Christian Fellowship is committed to the doctrinal basis of InterVarsity:

The only true God, the almighty Creator of all things, existing eternally in three persons - Father, Son, and Holy Spirit - full of love and glory.

The unique divine inspiration, entire trustworthiness and authority of the Bible.

The value and dignity of all people: created in God's image to live in love and holiness, but alienated from God and each other because of our sin and guilt, and justly subject to God's wrath.

Jesus Christ, fully human and fully divine, who lived as a perfect example, who assumed the judgment due sinners by dying in our place, and who was bodily raised from the dead and ascended as Savior and Lord.

Justification by God's grace to all who repent and put their faith in Jesus Christ alone for salvation.

The indwelling presence and transforming power of the Holy Spirit, who gives to all believers a new life and a new calling to obedient service.

The unity of all believers in Jesus Christ, manifest in worshiping and witnessing churches making disciples throughout the world.

The victorious reign and future personal return of Jesus Christ, who will judge all people with justice and mercy, giving over the unrepentant to eternal condemnation but receiving the redeemed into eternal life.

To God be glory forever.
Summary: Graduate Christian Fellowship: a group of Christian graduate students and professionals gathering together for spiritual formation, fellowship, outreach, and the integration of our faith and academic lives.

Name: Graduate Economics Society
Description: The Graduate Economics Society exists in order to promote a positive and productive environment for graduate students in the Department of Economics at the University of Michigan. To this end, we work to facilitate social events among graduate students and greater interaction among the students, and between students and faculty members. In addition, we help coordinate office allocations and other managerial responsibilities. Finally, we seek to represent the graduate students to the department, helping to engage the department on issues that may arise, and improvements to the policies and program of graduate study in economics.
Summary: The Graduate Economics Society exists in order to promote a positive and productive environment for graduate students in the Economics Department at the University of Michigan.

Name: Graduate Employees Organization
Description:
The purpose of the Graduate Employees' Organization is to improve the living and working conditions of graduate students at the University of Michigan through collective bargaining and grassroots activism.

The Graduate Employees' Organization is a labor union, founded by graduate students in 1970. Since winning our first contract in 1975, UM graduate workers collectively negotiate our employment terms which include salary, healthcare benefits and workplace protections.

Members run this union. The collective action of graduate students is responsible for many of the concrete benefits that graduate employees now enjoy. Over the last 50 years, victories have included tuition waivers, health benefits, child care waivers and a standard setting non-discrimination language. Graduate employees across the country look to GEO as an example of what can be accomplished when we work together. Become a member at bit.ly/GEOMembership
Summary: The Graduate Employees’ Organization is the labor union representing Graduate Student Instructors (GSIs) and Graduate Student Staff Assistants (GSSAs) at the University of Michigan.

Name: Graduate Rackham International
Description:
The mission of Graduate Rackham International (GRIN) student organization is to improve the experience of all graduate students, especially those who identify as international and/or multi-ethnic/cultural, at the University of Michigan. As an organization we support connections and social involvement among students across cultures and programs of study. Our programming supports professional development, mentorship, outreach, and other initiatives to benefit primarily graduate students - both international and domestic students with international interests at the University. 

To find more: http://www.grinrackham.com
Summary:
Graduate Rackham International (GRIN) is a student-run organization that aims to provide support for all graduate students, esp those who identify as international or multi-ethnic, at the University of Michigan.
Find more: http://grin.rackham.umich.edu/

Name: Graduate Research, Outreach, Workshops, and Evaluation
Description: GROWE is a student volunteer organization with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center at the University of Michigan. GROWE seeks to exist as a peer educator space for graduate students, who are interested in learning more about creating respectful spaces inside of their own learning communities.
Summary: GROWE is a student volunteer organization with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center at the University of Michigan. GROWE seeks to exist as a peer educator space for graduate students, who are interested in creating respectful communities.

Name: Graduate Society of Black Engineers and Scientists
Description:
The Graduate Society of Black Engineers and Scientists (GSBES), formerly known as The Society of Minority Engineers and Scientists – Graduate Component (SMES-G), serves as an academic and social network for Black graduate students within the University of Michigan's STEM community. GSBES's primary aim is to recruit and retain Black graduate students within engineering and science disciplines through outreach and advocacy.

We strive to meet real student needs and community demands, all whilst tackling issues centered on diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI). We provide a welcoming environment that is committed to personal, professional, and technical development while addressing critical graduate student issues. Through our programming, we help ensure that underrepresented students develop skills that contribute to scientific research and the University's learning environment, while positively impacting our communities. 

Our activities are focused on four main initiatives: 

Recruitment - Outreach - Advocacy - Retention
Summary: The Graduate Society of Black Engineers and Scientists primarily serves as an academic and social support network for Black graduate students in STEM at the University of Michigan.

Name: Graduate Society of Women Engineers
Description: GradSWE hosts events to help female graduate engineers thrive socially, academically, and professionally. For more information, visit our website and enter your email address to start receiving GradSWE's weekly event announcements.
Summary: GradSWE hosts events to help female graduate engineers thrive socially, academically, and professionally. For more information, visit our website http://www.gradswe.engin.umich.edu/

Name: Graduate Student Advisory Committee-ISD
Description: GSAC-ISD is established for the expressed purpose of: providing input and feedback to the ISD Administration, Program Directors and Staff from a student’s perspective; to listen to the needs and suggestions of our fellow students; to plan student events that foster a professional and engaging ISD community; to communicate to ISD students the priorities and plans of the ISD Administration and Programs; and to continuously brainstorm ways to foster an engaged ISD student community. The committee aims to strengthen the involvement of students in activities aimed to enrich their professional, academic, social and leadership skills.
Summary: This is the student council of the Integrative Systems + Design department of the College of engineering. The committee strives to convey students' inputs and feedback to the ISD Faculty and plan useful events to foster an engaged student community.

Name: Graduates Out in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics
Description:
Through organizing, mentorship, and networking, our mission is to provide a space for LGBTQ+ graduate students and post-doctoral researchers at the University of Michigan to connect, share experiences, and learn from one another. We have an active Discord server, with channels to discuss hobbies, interests, and events. To join the Discord and our email list, you can email us, at gostem-board@umich.edu.

 

Check out our website (click the world icon below). It includes our Google Calendar and a link to join our listserv!
Summary: Through organizing, mentorship, and networking, our mission is to provide a space for LGBTQ+ graduate students and post-doctoral researchers at the University of Michigan to connect, share experiences, and learn from one another.

Name: Greater China Association
Description:
Formed in 2002, the Greater China Association ("GCA") at the University of Michigan's Stephen M. Ross School of Business ("Ross") is committed to:

1. Bring together the greater China community at Ross business school

2. Support the professional development of its members

3. Increase the awareness of Chinese culture and business perspectives, and promote exchanges with the broader Michigan community

4. Promote Ross among applicants from Greater China areas

Over the last few years, GCA membership has grown, in tandem with the size of the Greater Chinese community at Ross, to include around 100 MBA1, MBA2, and Evening MBA members.
Summary: GCA is dedicated to connecting its members with the Michigan community, supporting professional development of its members and promoting cultural exchanges.

Name: GrEENPEAS
Description:
GrEENPEAS is the Graduate Environmental Engineering Network of Professionals, Educators and Students. Its purpose is to promote professional relationships among graduate students, staff, faculty, and alumni of the EWRE program. The organization hosts various events that develop students' networking skills and abilities in preparation for the field they will enter.

In addition, the organization serves to promote academic exchange between members of the environmental engineering and environmental sciences communities through collaboration with departments such as SEAS, EEB, and others.

Within the CEE department, GrEENPEAS serves to grow the sense of community of the EWRE program through the sponsorship of social activities and provides a voice to advocate for the individual and collective needs of graduate students within the EWRE program.
Summary:
GrEENPEAS Exists:

-  To promote professional relationships, networking and building community among graduate students, staff, faculty and alumni of the EWRE and CEE programs

Name: Groove Percussion Group/UAC
Description:
Groove is a comedic, high energy, non-traditional percussion and performance group at the University of Michigan with one goal: to rock the masses. We drum on anything and make music out of everything. (Think STOMP and Blue Man Group!)

Take a look at what we can do!

Website: umgroove.org
Summary: Groove is a comedic, high energy, non-traditional percussion and performance group at the University of Michigan with one goal: to rock the masses. We drum on anything and make music out of everything. (Think STOMP and Blue Man Group!)

Name: Gym Games the Club
Description: GGTC will offer students a chance to meet new people, make new friends and enjoy gym-based games and activities in our recreationally focused organization. The objective is to evoke the pure unadulterated joy of playing fun, stress-free games from our childhood.
Summary: GGTC will offer students a chance to meet new people, make new friends and enjoy gym-based games.

Name: H.O.P.E for a Cure at UofM
Description: H.O.P.E.’s mission is dedicated to Helping Outstanding People Everyday by organizing enriching events while actively raising funds to support organizations devoted to aiding sick children battling various illnesses. We host these heartwarming events in hope of bringing joy into the lives of these remarkable children. Our mission is to empower and inspire both kids and the community to make a meaningful difference in the lives of those facing health challenges, fostering hope and compassion every step of the way.
Summary:
H.O.P.E. is a nonprofit organization dedicated to Helping Outstanding People Everyday. We organize events and raise funds to support organizations devoted to aiding sick children, hoping to inspire and empower 
 both the children and the community.

Name: H2O Campus Ministries
Description:
The mission of H2O Campus Ministries, a Chi Alpha Campus Ministry, is to reconcile students to Christ; transforming the university, the marketplace, and the world.

The ministry centers around core groups, which are midweek small groups that meet throughout campus where students will wrestle with important issues in life with the goal of growing closer to God.

The ministry also hosts a weekly church service on campus to have fellowship as a group.


We would love to connect with you. If you are interested in more information, you can email us or DM us on Instagram!
Summary: Making disciples of Jesus Christ at the University of Michigan.

Name: Habitat for Humanity at the University of Michigan
Description:
Join our email list through MCommunity to receive updates!

Habitat for Humanity at the University of Michigan is committed to building simple, decent, and affordable housing for low-income families in our community and around the world. In support of this goal we will motivate and mobilize volunteers to raise money, build partnerships, and provide education about eliminating substandard housing. We strive to make a difference in the lives of those looking for a hand up, not a hand out.
Summary: Habitat for Humanity at the University of Michigan is committed to building simple, decent, and affordable housing for low-income families in our community and around the world.

Name: Handmade Cards at UMich
Description: The purpose of Handmade Cards at UMich is to make and donate thoughtful cards to organizations (e.g. Ann Arbor Meals on Wheels, Confetti Foundation, Bring Smiles to Seniors, Letters Against Depression, Birthday Cards for Foster Kids, and more) around the country. Our organization also aims to create time and space for students to relax and express their creativity as they work on card crafts with others!
Summary: Brighten someone’s day by making and giving handmade cards!

Name: Hands-On Health
Description: The Hands-On Health organization exists to provide pre-health students with hands-on experiences to further support each member's pre-health interests and develop a deeper understanding of each pre-health field.
Summary: The Hands-On Health organization exists to provide pre-health students with hands-on experiences, including suturing and CPR/AED, to further support each member's pre-health interests and develop a deeper understanding of each pre-health field.

Name: Harm Reduction at University of Michigan Medical School
Description: Harm reduction refers to policies, programs, and practices that aim to minimize negative health, social and legal impacts associated with drug use, drug policies, and drug laws. Grounded in justice and human rights, it focuses on positive change and on working with people without judgement, coercion, discrimination, or requiring that they stop using drugs as a precondition of support. Co-founded by UMMS medical students Jessie Dalman, Reni Forer, and Amy Kwarteng, this group will host educational lectures and community outreach work in the local community, namely high schools.
Summary: Harm Reduction at UMMS is a student group dedicated to harm reduction education. This group is designed to illuminate the ways in which these methodologies can be implemented into medical practice in addiction medicine and beyond.

Name: Hawaiʻi Club at UM
Description: The Hawaiʻi Club at UM strives to increase the presence of Hawaiʻi culture and students from Hawaiʻi. We will do so by creating a space for students from Hawaiʻi, establish a stronger presence for Hawaiʻi in Michigan, promote Hawaiʻi culture and lifestyle, and educate people about the history and contemporary issues of Hawaiʻi through various inclusive and engaging events. This organization is inclusive and open to any students regardless of their background. Whether you are from Hawaiʻi wanting to find a community of people from home, or someone who simply loves Hawaiʻi and wants to learn more about it through fun events, there is a place for you!
Summary: The Hawaiʻi Club aims to promote the presence of Hawaiʻi in Michigan by amplifying Hawaiʻi culture and the people from Hawaiʻi, as well as connect Hawaiʻi-affiliated and non-affiliated people together through various campus events.

Name: HBHEDoc
Description: Our mission is to support the academic experience and professional success of the University of Michigan HBHE doctoral students through a forum that provides opportunities to dialogue, exchange resources and information, and enhance social interactions among the students of the organization.
Summary: HBHEDoc supports the academic experience and professional success of the University of Michigan HBHE doctoral students through a forum that provides opportunities to dialogue, exchange resources and information, and enhance social interactions.

Name: Headnotes Law School A Cappella Group
Description: The Headnotes are the Law School's a cappella group. The Headnotes perform at a variety of Law School events, and give two free concerts each year. Through music, The Headnotes aim to contribute to the Law School's sense of communality and positivity.
Summary: The Headnotes are the Law School's a cappella group. The Headnotes perform at a variety of Law School events, and give two free concerts each year. Through music, The Headnotes aim to contribute to the Law School's sense of communality and positivity.

Name: Heal-Move-Shift
Description: Heal-Move-Shift comprises a team of passionate innovators, all of whom recognize the utmost responsibility they take on when working with students. Facilitating topics on drug education, nutrition, identity, and self-confidence are not only impactful but also extremely sensitive among certain individuals. Because of this, we train our facilitators to work with students and employees in schools to impart the most impactful conversations, share the most necessary stories, and connect with students with the most wellness-based goals.
Summary: To Heal​ the community, Move the conversation towards a healthier direction, and Shift the stigma away ​from pressing cardiovascular, nutritional, and mental health concerns.

Name: Health Behavior Health Equity Student Association
Description: Health Behavior Health Equity Students Association (HBHESA) works with students, faculty, and staff within the Department of Health Behavior & Health Equity (HBHE) in the School of Public Health. HBHESA aims to create an environment amenable to a high quality of learning by serving as a vehicle through which HBHE students can communicate with departmental administration on policies affecting their academic and professional interests. HBHESA will also foster social cohesion amongst the HBHE cohorts.
Summary: Health Behavior Health Equity Student Association (HBHESA) encourages students within the department to become involved in their community and participate in events throughout the year to promote departmental cohesiveness.

Name: Health Horizons
Description: Using the framework of Whole Health implemented at the VA hospital, we are trying to reduce burnout for undergraduates. We are using techniques such as physical activity, social events, and professional development to provide opportunities to get to know people at the university better, improve the community, and be involved in activities relating to future career goals.
Summary: We are a pre-health based club focused on professional development, social, and physical activity aimed to reduce burnout.

Name: Health Informatics Student Organisation
Description:
HISO is established for the purpose of providing official representation for students in the Masters of Health Informatics program at the University of Michigan. HISO is meant to ensure consistent and regular communication between Masters of Health Informatics (MHI) students and the faculty, staff, and administration of the University of Michigan. HISO seeks to establish a singular voice and point of contact for the student body of the MHI program.

HISO also strives to be an organization devoted to fostering a community of common interest, increasing awareness of the field, and providing opportunities for professional development and networking.
Summary: We’re the representative organization for the MHI program, but we’re also open to all graduate students at the University of Michigan who are interested in health informatics.

Name: Health Management and Policy Class Representatives
Description:
Class representatives of Health Management and Policy graduate student program in the School of Public Health. This consists of 4 representatives from each year, plus additional student leaders. 

The Class Reps work with HMP faculty, staff and alumni to represent student interests at meetings. Additionally, they plan department-wide student events.
Summary: Class representatives of the Health Management and Policy graduate student program in the School of Public Health. The Class Reps work to enhance the student experience through social and academic events.

Name: Health Policy Student Association
Description:
The Health Policy Student Association (HPSA) provides and supports educational and professional development opportunities for all students interested in health policy. 

Our members come from many disciplines and degree programs including public health, public policy, law, social work, business, medicine, dentistry, and nursing. HPSA is a place for students to participate in health policy related events including guest speakers, local and national level meetings, panel discussions, policy outreach efforts, and a variety of social activities. 

We're a growing organization with opportunities for leadership roles, career enhancement, skill development and networking in the health policy and public health world. 

We are a student chapter of AcademyHealth.
Summary: The Health Policy Student Association (HPSA) provides and supports educational and professional development opportunities for all students interested in health policy.

Name: Health Promotion at UM
Description:
[Click this link to join our email list for more information about HPUM and current events!]

Health Promotion at UM (HPUM) is a health-oriented service organization providing long-term and short-term volunteering opportunities primarily for Pre-Health (pre-med, pre-dentistry, pre-pharm, etc.) students, but we are inclusive of all majors and academic interests. Our volunteer programs are diverse, but mainly focus on serving underserved populations in Southeast Michigan in the areas of Education, Geriatrics, Medicine, and Social Services. Our program's aim is to create a communal philanthropic experience in a specialized area of medicine or public health for our members to make an impact in their community while learning and developing perspectives in health in a team-based environment.

 

In addition to our deep commitment to service learning, HPUM serves its members by offering professional development, healthcare professional shadowing and mentorship, and social justice activism opportunities to help our members develop as individuals and aspiring mindful professionals.

 

HPUM is a unique pre-health oriented organization because we emphasize the importance of long-term volunteering and use reflection as an important tool to learn more from our service experiences with our team members. Our goal is to help students truly learn from their extracurricular service commitments and help them develop a more mindful, compassionate mindset for the future.
Summary: Health Promotion at UM (HPUM) is a health-oriented service organization providing long and short-term volunteering opportunities primarily for Pre-Health (pre-med, pre-dentistry, pre-vet, pre-pharm, etc.) students, but we are inclusive of all majors.

Name: Health Sciences Scholars Program Events Planning Council
Description:
The Health Sciences Scholars Program (HSSP) is a pre-professional Michigan Learning Community that introduces first-year students to key issues and the breadth of careers in the health sciences by bringing together students and faculty from a broad range of backgrounds, interests, and experiences. 

 

Membership in HSSP provides students with a more sophisticated understanding of opportunities in the health sciences, connects members to valuable resources that help define their pre-health journeys, and allows participants to share perspectives and learn from one another in a supportive living-learning environment.
Summary: The Health Sciences Scholars Program (HSSP) is a pre-professional Michigan Learning Community.

Name: Health-System Student Pharmacists at the University of Michigan
Description: The student society shall adopt the mission and objectives of the American Society of Health-system Pharmacists (“ASHP”), the Michigan Pharmacists Association (MPA), and the Michigan Society of Health-system Pharmacists (“MSHP”).
Summary: The mission of HSP is to make students aware of pharmacy practice in health systems; provide information to students about career directions in and credentials needed for pharmacy practice in health systems; and encourage membership and participation

Name: Healthcare & Life Sciences Club
Description:
HLS will complete this mission through pursuing the following initiatives:

  • Recruiting support: Engage industry and increase career opportunities
  • Leadership training: Provide opportunities to develop leadership skills
  • Industry education: Train members on industry through speakers, workshops, and experiences
  • Networking opportunities: Build contacts, establish mentors, and develop networks
  • Inter-disciplinary outreach: Provide broad exposure to all industry facets
Summary: The mission of the Healthcare & Life Science Club is to provide Ross MBA students with the education, networking, and career preparation to train the next generation of healthcare-industry leaders.

Name: hEARt Listens @ Michigan
Description:
Interested in mental health or providing peer support? hEARt Listens @Michigan is a mental health organization that hosts an anonymous peer support line that U of M students are encouraged to text for emotional support, for something as simple as a rough day to something more difficult. hEARt also provides a training program for students who want to learn how to support others. hEARt Supporters on the line are trained in skills such as empathetic listening, crisis management, and smart referral. Our goal is to build a compassionate community of supporters who can help students around them build resilience, and prioritize wellbeing. 

Students can text the hEARt Line at 734-292-8006, and within 36 hours, we will connect them with a student peer supporter. The whole process is free, anonymous, and available to all UM-Ann Arbor students.
Summary: hEARt Listens @Michigan provides an anonymous peer support line that U of M students are encouraged to text for emotional support, for something as simple as a rough day to something more difficult.

Name: Heartbeat: Philanthropic A Cappella
Description:
Heartbeat is the only philanthropic a cappella group at the University of Michigan.

Each year, Heartbeat raises money for a charity chosen by its members. We perform on and off-campus at private and public events for donations. To build relationships with our community, we regularly perform at the U of M hospital and make a concerted effort to work with other charitable student organizations on campus, such as Dance Marathon, DoRAK, and DP Day. We also partner with local businesses such as Poke Poke and host semesterly concerts for charitable contributions. Check out our Instagram @heartbeat_acappella for event details, membership bios, audition information, and more!
Summary: As the University of Michigan's only philanthropic a cappella group, Heartbeat strives to give back through performances at charity-based events and for donations to charitable organizations.

Name: Heartfulness Meditation at UMich
Description:
Curious about meditation and looking for a calm and welcoming space to start? 

Finding it challenging to incorporate meditation into your daily routine?

Having trouble concentrating during meditation? 

In our fast paced world of distractions, it’s crucial to find ways to center yourself. Whether you are new to meditation or have experience, join our club!

 

Why meditate?

Meditation can have many benefits such as reducing stress and anxiety, increasing your focus and concentration, improving your sleep quality, and more.

 

How to join?

Check out our website and fill out our interest form to be subscribed to our email list and get notified whenever we have a meeting. We are a casual club with no required attendance policies so drop ins are highly encouraged! There is no cost to join, in other words, we do not have a membership fee.

 

What is Heartfulness Meditation?

A meditation practice where you sit quietly with your eyes closed and focus on your heart with the intent of clearing your mind and body of stress and anxiety.

 

Check out our website: https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/heartfulness-meditation/home
Summary: Heartfulness Meditation at UMich provides a welcoming space to learn about heart-centered meditation. Our meetings consist of guided sessions with the goal of making meditation accessible and easy to incorporate into your everyday life.

Name: Helicon History of Art Undergraduate Society
Description: A student organization dedicated to supporting the artistic culture at the University of Michigan. Helicon Haus curates exhibitions, publishes an annual magazine, travels for further art exploration, and works to incite conversations about art on campus. Learn more and see what we're up to at @Heliconhaus on instagram.
Summary: A student organization dedicated to supporting the artistic culture at the University of Michigan. Helicon Haus curates exhibitions, publishes an annual magazine, travels for further art exploration, and works to incite conversations about art on campus.

Name: Hellenic Student Association
Description:
Hellenism describes the Greek cultural heritage. The Hellenic Student Association aims to represent and showcase Hellenism on the University of Michigan campus, to encourage a diverse student membership, and give members the opportunity to be immersed in Hellenic culture. 

Our organization hosts a variety of events, ranging from social, cultural, professional, and philanthropic, aimed to create connections among UofM students.
Summary: Our organization hosts a variety of events, ranging from social to cultural to professional. These include social events with other cultural clubs, Greek dance lessons, tavli nights, networking events, & a semi-annual club night fundraiser.

Name: Helping Hands- A Students for Students Movement at U of M
Description: Through our efforts to partner with schools in disadvantaged communities, we use tutoring and mentorship of students to improve the accessibility to high-quality education and to help students become excited about learning.
Summary: Through our efforts to partner with schools in disadvantaged communities, we hope to improve the accessibility to high-quality education and to help students become excited about learning.

Name: Helping Hearts at The University of Michigan
Description: Helping Hearts at the University of Michigan is dedicated to enhancing accessibility to mental health and wellness resources for chronically ill pediatric patients and their families during prolonged hospitalizations. Our initiative seeks to alleviate the burden posed by illness through volunteer-driven programming, fundraising efforts, community outreach, and the provision of essential resources. Our mission is to bring moments of joy to the medical environment and provide emotional support to those impacted by chronic health conditions.
Summary: Helping Hearts at the University of Michigan is dedicated to enhancing accessibility to mental health and wellness resources for chronically ill pediatric patients and their families during prolonged hospitalizations.

Name: Her Campus at the University of Michigan
Description:
Her Campus at the University of Michigan is a contributing Platinum Level chapter for the National Her Campus online magazine, which is a popular online publication geared toward collegiate women worldwide. Members are required to produce at least one article per month on any topic of their choice. Members are also encouraged to promote the organization through events, working with community and campus organizations, and reaching out to readers through social media. Within the HC UMich, there are opportunities to be a Feature Writer, Feature Editor, or Social Media Representative. 

HC U Mich strives to create a welcoming and energetic community where those interested in writing and journalism can express their talents both individually and collaboratively.  We continually strive to garnish more participation and publicity of the magazine on campus.

Please email hcumich@gmail.com for an application.
Summary: Her Campus at the University of Michigan is an online publication written by and for collegiate females. We are a Platinum Level chapter with writers who create content about diverse and relevant arenas for our readers.

Name: Here Earning a Destiny through Honesty, Eagerness, and Determination of Self
Description: It is our mission and responsibility to be passionate in our pursuit of intellectual growth, leadership, development, and unity among all who identify as Black. By extension, H.E.A.D.S seeks to engage with the Black community as a whole and positively influence the collective culture. In particular, we seek to provide a safe and protected space for all Black male-identifying people on campus. Our highest priorities pertain to embracing and providing for all Black people on campus.
Summary: It is our mission and responsibility to be passionate in our pursuit of intellectual growth, leadership, development, and unity among all who identify as Black.

Name: Hindu Students Club
Description: Hindu Students Club (HSC) is an independent, non-affiliated religious and cultural student organization at the University of Michigan. HSC is dedicated to creating an atmosphere conducive to worship, education, cultural experience, and service, as it relates to the Hindu faith. We primarily organize festivals on campus like Diwali and our famous Holi celebration.
Summary: HSC is dedicated to creating an atmosphere conducive to worship, education, cultural experience and service as it relates to the Hindu faith.

Name: Hindu YUVA @ U of M
Description: Hindu YUVA aims to organize activities for community service in the spirit of Sewa (Hindu conception of service to humanity) and celebrate Hindu festivals. In our weekly meetings, we play traditional team-building games, practice yoga and meditation, and study Hindu scriptures. The above initiatives will serve the purpose of creating a vibrant Hindu presence on campus, and will aid in providing a home-away-from-home feeling to incoming and existing Hindu students. To keep up with our events, follow us on Instagram! Our handle is @umichhinduyuva
Summary: Our goal is to help students understand more about Hindu culture and their own Hindu identity while making friends and having fun as one big universal family!

Name: His House Christian Fellowship
Description: His House is currently active at 12 universities in Michigan. We have main meetings each week, bible studies, a state-wide retreat each semester, volunteer opportunities, and many other different fun activities throughout the semester. His House welcomes Christians, those looking to learn more about Christ, and those looking for a welcoming community to be a part of. We seek to be the church in everyday life.
Summary: His House is a Christian campus ministry at the University of Michigan.

Name: Hispanic Business Students Association
Description: The Hispanic Business Students Association (HBSA) provides professional development opportunities, and a strong community for its members to transition and thrive in the Ross MBA program. HBSA serves as a platform for all students at Ross to engage with the greater Latinx community at the University of Michigan while taking advantage of unique club resources and leaning on its current student and alumni network. HBSA achieves its mission of empowering Latinx and allies with academic workshops, mentoring, community service events, and social opportunities, providing an environment rich in Latinx culture and traditions for its members and greater Ross community. HBSA is also active in the recruitment of incoming Latinx students and supports the Consortium for Graduate Study in Management activities.
Summary: The Hispanic Business Students Association provides academic support and professional development opportunities to US-based Hispanics at the Ross School of Business. We are committed to the recruitment of prospective Hispanics interested in business.

Name: Historically Black Colleges and Universities Alumni Association at The University of Michigan
Description: HBCU Alumni Association is established for the expressed purpose of enhancing the HBCU-alum graduate student’s learning environment and lived experience. Though tailored for students who are HBCU alumni, all UM students are welcomed.
Summary: The HBCU Alumni organization mission is to bring together students from varied academic backgrounds to create meaningful experiences, a vibrant community, and lifelong memories for University of Michigan students.

Name: HomeFree Initiative
Description:
We have established an official partnership with the Shelter Association of Washtenaw County. Our mission is to eradicate the stigma surrounding the homeless population in Ann Arbor and address the housing crisis. Through education, advocacy, and community outreach, we aim to raise awareness, foster understanding, and support those affected by homelessness.

We hope to form this club at U-M to connect students with this cause and help us support our partner!
Summary: With an official partnership with the Shelter Association of Washtenaw County, our mission is to eradicate the stigma surrounding the homeless population in Ann Arbor and address the housing crisis. Through education, advocacy, and community.

Name: Hong Kong Student Association
Description:
The University of Michigan Hong Kong Student Association is a student organization that aims to strengthen the Hong Kong community on UM campus, as well as preserve and celebrate our culture and heritage to any and all students that are interested! We typically hold monthly events open to anyone, including food (for a specific festival/celebration), bonding activities, and collaboration. However, we are looking to expand our offerings with growing student interest. This is particularly important for international students, who form a big part of our student organization, as we try to provide a space - a home away from home - where they can be in a more familiar environment. The events held by HKSA are aimed at strengthening camaraderie among members, assisting members in problem-solving, and helping members in understanding the academics, culture, and community of the University of Michigan and of Ann Arbor. 

Our goal during this collaboration is to 1) help our organization develop and grow on campus, 2) encourage cultural exchange between members of the organization, 3) increase awareness of Hong Kong traditions and culture and 4) provide an event where we can reminisce on favorite family dishes while away from home.
Summary: HKSA is a student organization at the University of Michigan. The objectives of HKSA are: 1. Connect and serve our members 2. Strive for the benefits of our members 3. Encourage academic, cultural, and social environment at the University of Michigan

Name: Honors Resident Advisors
Description:
What is the Honors Program?

The Honors Program is a four-year program that provides an especially rich and challenging set of academic offerings to talented and highly motivated students in the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts. Through special courses, research with faculty, and a vigorous intellectual community that includes Honors faculty fellows, the Honors Program enables students to identify their intellectual interests and to pursue them deeply. 

Honors Curriculum

The Honors Program's curriculum offers a wide range of challenging courses in almost every department, with majors in every field in the College. We offer special seminars, courses, and direct involvement with faculty from the start of students' lives at Michigan. Students are expected to elect half their course work in Honors; many do more. Many Honors students participate in research during their first two years, and almost all Honors seniors pursue their own independent research projects under the guidance of a faculty mentor, leading to an Honors senior thesis.

To help students take the greatest advantage of the rich opportunities at Michigan, Honors advisors meet with them individually, beginning at Orientation and continuing throughout their time here.

Honors Community

A vibrant community, no single experience unites all Honors students, yet all are connected through a wide range of activities that enable students to choose what interests them.
