The Perlman Honors Commons is an intellectual hub, located on the ground floor of Mason Hall (above the Honors offices) where students and faculty come together for study, conversation, and a variety of intellectual and cultural events in truly beautiful surroundings. Organized by the Honor's Resident Advisors (HRAs), you will find students attending musicals, sports events, and visiting coffee hours. Faculty Fellows engage Honors students in a wide variety of ways outside of formal classes. There's something for everyone and all are invited.
Summary: The Honors RAs work to build an inclusive and vibrant community where students can thrive both academically and socially. This includes planning events and developing opportunities to expand the academic and cultural horizons of Honors students.

Name: Hoops for Hope
Description:
Hoops for Hope hosts a number of basketball-related fundraiser events each year, including tournaments and youth-training events on the University of Michigan campus. We work with students from local schools and encourage them to be active and play basketball! Our outreach includes bimonthly visits to local elementary schools and student visits to campus. Ultimately, we work to inspire students educationally and athletically!

Learn more at our website: https://michiganhoopsforhope.com/
Summary: We focus on students from local schools and encourage them to be active and play basketball! We hold clinics at local schools and share our passion for basketball, coaching, and community out reach. Our goal is to inspire kids in the Ann Arbor area.

Name: HOPE
Description: HOPE (Health of People Everywhere) is a student-run organization founded by students dedicated to addressing health inequities among uninsured and underinsured populations. The mission of HOPE is to improve health outcomes and reduce disparities in Michigan’s disadvantaged communities. HOPE achieves this by partnering with free clinics, community organizations, and local leaders to connect individuals with essential healthcare resources, Medicaid registration assistance, and health literacy initiatives. Through outreach efforts, educational programs, and direct service, HOPE empowers underserved populations to navigate the healthcare system and access the care they need.
Summary: HOPE, acronym for "Health of People Everywhere", is a student-run organization with the goal to help reduce health disparities amongst uninsured populations in Michigan.

Name: Hopelessly Yellow
Description: Hopelessly Yellow is a digital brand that highlights mental wellness and positivity through writing, design, music, and media. In a world that, at times, feels hopeless, learning to love the littlest joys makes life feel more full…More yellow. Hopelessly Yellow is a feeling, a mindset, and a community: it is a golden lifestyle.
Summary: Hopelessly Yellow is a digital brand that highlights mental wellness and positivity through writing, art, music, and media.

Name: Houkago Circle
Description: At Houkago Circle (HKC), we’re passionate in providing a platform for students to experience aspects of Japanese university culture and interact with Japanese students in real time. Our immersive events will go beyond traditional cultural exchanges and appreciation with activities including debates, games, student seminars, and other joint collaborative activities with Japanese students. We welcome all who are interested in Japanese student life and making international friends!
Summary: Houkago Circle is a student-led organization which offers unique experiences, cultural understanding and traditional exchanges with Japanese university students through a variety of engaging events and real-time interactions.

Name: HSOP Social Committee
Description: The HSOP Social Committee exists to support an collegial atmosphere in the HSOP department through social events that allow faculty, staff, and PhD students to get to know each other in a relaxed, informal, atmosphere. The Social Committee sponsors at least two family friendly events per semester such as in-office trick or treating, apple picking, and bbq/field day.
Summary: This organization supports social and networking events within the HSOP Doctoral Program community at the School of Public Health.

Name: HuJews on Campus
Description: a network of college activists working to create spaces of inclusivity and acceptance, openness about our beliefs, social change, and positive connections for fellow secular/atheist/agnostic/freethinker/skeptical/humanistic Jewish students and allies
Summary: HuJews on Campus is an initiative providing campus clubs for college-aged secular and Humanistic Jews to find meaning in their heritage. We celebrate multiculturalism including mixed heritages, advocate for LGBTQ equality, and value science.

Name: Human Capital Club
Description:
The Human Capital Club (HCC) is a student professional development organization that focuses on building the capabilities of our members in the organizational strategy, human capital and human resources fields.  We achieve this goal through education, career development, networking, and curriculum development at the Ross School of Business (RSB) at the University of Michigan (UofM).

The HCC fulfills its mission by:

  • Developing and facilitating educational opportunities for its members to learn about organizational strategy and relevant areas of interest, both in theory and practice.
  • Providing members with career resources to guide them through career development while at Ross.
  • Establishing a network of resources both within and beyond the university community through which its members may help further professional knowledge and understanding beyond their formal education.
  • Serving as the conduit between individuals passionate about organizational strategy and faculty, to ensure that the university environment supports engagement in the field throughout the curriculum and campus.
Summary: The Human Capital Club (HCC) promotes the understanding and integration of human capital and other organizational strategy issues in business practice through education, professional development, and networking.

Name: Human Factors & Ergonomics Society
Description: HFES at UM is organized to serve the needs of the human factors profession at the University of Michigan. Its purpose is to promote and advance the understanding of the human factors involved in the design, manufacture, and use of machines, systems, environments and devices of all kinds through the interchange of knowledge and methodology in the behavioral, biological, and physical sciences and in industrial, computer science and other relevant engineering disciplines.
Summary: HFES at UM is organized to serve the needs of the human factors profession at the University of Michigan.

Name: Human Powered Submarine Team
Description:
The mission of the Human Powered Submarine Team is to foster advances in subsea vehicle propulsion, hydrodynamic, and life support systems, creating more awareness of the challenges and results of working at various aquatic depths. In doing so, our team gains hands-on experience that cannot be learned in a lecture hall, and we showcase our skills as a team by racing the University of Michigan submarine at competitive international competitions.
HPS is an extracurricular student project team, so membership is voluntary. Students join our team because of their passion for submarines, the challenge of the design process, the prospect of winning international honors at the races, or simply for the excitement of belonging to an engineering team and working towards a common goal.
In addition to design and manufacturing, we are also self-funded. We work with companies to get sponsorships and have a business and marketing group. We also do high school outreach to share our love of science and engineering with the next generation.

For info on how to join HPS, please complete our interest form.
Summary: Our goal is to design, build, test, and race a fully-flooded submarine propelled by a single human. We compete in the International Submarine Races in Washington DC, and in the European International Submarine Races in England.

Name: Humanity First
Description:
What is Humanity First?

Humanity First is an international NGO dedicated to advocating for human life around the world. Humanity First USA works together with global expertise and local leadership to empower communities to become self-sufficient. Humanity First USA was established as a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization in 2004 and is active in 64+ countries and has served 4,895,000+ people thus far.

 

Our Initiatives @ U-M

Humanity First Student Organizations (HFSO) have a host of initiatives to serve others locally, nationally, and internationally. 

HFSOs organize on their campuses and serve locally and abroad in underserved communities. We raise awareness, raise funds, and collaborate with other organizations for direct service. HFSOs have cared for people experiencing homelessness, older adults, refugees, students who need academic support, and countless others in local communities. Students grow their understanding of complex social issues and build leadership skills to make a difference.

 

 

What is Gift of Health?

Humanity First's medical programs are designed to improve the health and medical services in some of the world's most underserved communities, and our one-week Gift of Health trips allow volunteers to do just that. Gift of Health is an initiative that allows high-school, undergrad, and medical students to get hands-on experience working to alleviate global health disparities in rural communities in Mexico, Central America, and South America while providing free health care services, education, and medicines. 

Since our launch in 2012, we have provided primary care, pediatric and dental services, and medicines to 77,000+ adults and children. This trip is part of a broader vision of reaching out and providing health care in remote villages, where people in addition to other basic life necessities, are also deprived of preventive and medical needs. We are fortunate that some experienced healthcare professionals will be accompanying us, as well as a group of enthusiastic volunteers, including students from various universities across America.

GOH Clinical Recap 12/17-23/23

- Past Trip Reports - 

Guatemala 2023

Guatemala 2018

Guatemala 2017

 

What is The Education Project?

The Education Project is an organization currently aligned under Humanity First USA, a 501c(3) non-profit. They are essentially a branch of Humanity First's education initiatives. For more info, please visit https://theeduproject.net/

  • The project has developed an online platform that has provided 1000+ K-12 students with free individualized tutoring. 
  • Over 1,100+ Volunteer tutors from 26 states who are students/alumni of some of the best universities across America. 
  • Provided thousands of tutoring hours to students and families most affected by COVID-19. 

 

What is Gift of Sight?

According to the World Health Organization, 1.3 billion people have vision impairment, and for 188.5 million that impairment is severe. With the Gift of Sight program, Humanity First USA has assisted in restoring the vision of people living in Mali, Burkina Faso, Guyana, and Guatemala. 

At U-M, our goal with Gift of Sight is to collect used eyeglasses from our local community. This is a sustainable solution for alleviating a global lack of supplies for those who have vision impairment but don’t have access to corrective lenses. The glasses will be shipped to a team of experienced medical professionals who work as part of the Gift of Sight initiative to be distributed to vulnerable communities internationally. 

We plan to set up donation boxes in common meeting places and eye clinics on/near campus and monitor them every month. Each month, we collect the glasses, ship them to a nearby processing center partnered with HF that measures them using a lensometer free of charge, and package the frames to be shipped.

 

Our Mission at The University of Michigan

We are a platform that provides students with the opportunity to work with underserved communities both locally and abroad. To this end, we offer a variety of clinical and non-clinical volunteer opportunities to students on campus to get involved with what they are passionate about. Additionally, we aim to provide students with invaluable skills and experiences to develop into tomorrow’s leaders through services aimed towards social and professional development, skills enhancement programs, and recognition for their services. 

Our current goals as a student organization are to:

  1. Conduct local volunteering events, both clinical and non-clinical, in the greater Ann Arbor area
  2. Fundraise for and coordinate a trip to Chiapas, Mexico under the Gift of Health initiative scheduled for January 2025
  3. Recruit more undergraduate tutors for the Education Project
  4. Create donation boxes for used glass frames/lenses in the local Ann Arbor community

 

If you are interested in joining our team, please email omarchow@umich.edu
Summary: The primary goal of HFSO at the University of Michigan is to advocate for human development projects for socioeconomically disadvantaged communities with local and international collaborators.

Name: Ice Hockey Club at Ross
Description: The Ross Hockey Club promotes competitive Ice Hockey. The Club also acts as a forum for likeminded individuals to meet, play, and network.
Summary: The Ross Hockey Club promotes competitive Ice Hockey. The Club also acts as a forum for likeminded individuals to meet, play, and network.

Name: If/When/How: Lawyering for Reproductive Rights
Description: The University of Michigan Law School’s chapter of If/When/How: Lawyering for Reproductive Justice advocates for reproductive freedoms for all through community education, organizing, and mobilization. We believe that reproductive care is healthcare, and that healthcare is a human right. We strive to do this through events related to reproductive justice that seek to educate and involve the community. We are an inclusive space committed to the freedoms of all people, and particularly those marginalized from the traditional reproductive rights movement. Our bodies, our choices.
Summary: The organization's goal is to protect and expand reproductive rights as basic civil and human rights through community education, organization and mobilization.

Name: Illuminate
Description: Illuminate is an organization which serves as a beacon in the fog of healthcare confusion for the underserved, casting a wide and penetrating light that scatters the shadows of patient education gaps. We guide individuals through the complexities of the healthcare system, ensuring their understanding and empowerment with confidence. With a foundation built on student innovation and a spirit of volunteerism, Illuminate stands as a testament to the power of youthful determination in tackling global health challenges. This dynamic, student-run beacon of hope is more than an organization; it's a movement. Illuminate brings together young minds dedicated to making a tangible difference, proving that with compassion, collaboration, and education, we can transform the healthcare landscape, one enlightened step at a time.
Summary: Illuminate is a non-profit that guides the underserved through healthcare complexities, empowering them with education and student-led innovation.

Name: Illuminating Recovery
Description: Throughout the immense healthcare industry, we are a community devoted to expanding the resources and help available to people struggling with addiction recovery. The combination of diverse backgrounds, knowledge, and experience make us an innovative team that is breaking ground on new devices. Our aim is to work together to educate, address, and make an impact on the recovery community and create devices that will change how addiction is perceived and treated. Through projects and education, we hope to create societal change in underserved communities, with our focus on the Detroit community. Illuminating Recovery aims to be both an idea generating and product developing community that works together to solve a major health issue prevalent in low income communities.
Summary: Illuminating Recovery is an organization dedicated to educating people about addiction recovery and developing products to help people with addiction with their recovery.

Name: Immersive Live
Description: Immersive Live is established for the purpose of introducing performing arts to umich campus. We focus on immersive theater and drama performance. We hope the production can encourage meaningful cultural exchange through the medium of performing arts.
Summary: Immersive Live is immersive theater club.

Name: Impact Arts
Description: Impact Arts presents a variety of artistic programming at the University of Michigan, with the goal of sparking social change through these presentations.
Summary: Presenting socially conscious art.

Name: Impact Dance/UAC
Description:
Impact Dance is a dance company open primarily to non-dance majors. The company's members choreograph and perform pieces of a variety of styles, especially contemporary and jazz, that are performed in two of our own shows and in many guest performances.

 

Website: http://impactdanceumich.wix.com/impactdance
Summary: Impact Dance is a dance company open primarily to non-dance majors. The company's members choreograph and perform pieces of a variety of styles, especially contemporary and jazz, that are performed in two of our own shows and in many guest performances.

Name: Impact Graduate Student Fellowship
Description:
Impact Graduate Student Fellowship is the graduate student branch of Harvest Mission Community Church focused on providing graduate students with Biblical community and life-on-life relationships of care, commitment, and challenge through the ups and downs of graduate student life. As our name suggests, our mission is to edify and empower graduate and professional school students to make an impact in all spheres of life with their education, future career, and relationships, so they can live boldly as followers of Jesus Christ. This is done through weekly LIFE Group, which comprises of Bible study, theological discussion, personal sharing, praying, and worship.

Events are open to anyone, regardless of religious background. Although Impact Graduate Student Fellowship is affiliated with Harvest Mission Community Church, members of other churches or organizations who are looking for a graduate student community are welcome! International students are also welcome and encouraged to come out!
Summary: Impact Graduate Student Fellowship is a group of graduate students who meet in weekly LIFE Groups, where we are committed to learning from, supporting, and challenging one another in Bible studies, discussions, and sharing.

Name: Impact Investing Group
Description: IIG aims to support equitable community revitalization in our local communities. With this goal in mind, IIG strives to motivate, empower, and educate undergraduate students about Impact Investing. Specifically, through our Microfinance Fund, we will be providing low-interest loans to micro businesses in the Ann Arbor and Metro Detroit area in order to fight unequal economic opportunities disproportionately faced by minority business owners. Furthermore, our consulting branch works with these local business owners, along with other impact-focused companies. Through these experiences and with a strong focus on professional development, our members are exposed to business and impact with first-hand experience and learning opportunities.
Summary: IIG strives to motivate, empower, and educate undergraduate students about Impact Investing. IIG also aims to support equitable community revitalization in communities throughout Michigan through our Microfinance Fund and pro-bono consulting services.

Name: Inclusive Healthcare for Children
Description:
We recognize the significant healthcare disparity that children with disabilities face. As an organization, we are committed to taking proactive steps to bridge this gap in health care.

What do we do?

We collaborate with schools across Metro Detroit to provide comprehensive health care and hygiene education programs through interactive activities. We emphasize practical skills that the children can incorporate into their daily lives to promote physical fitness and well-being tailored to each child’s ability. Dental hygiene is a critical component of overall well-being. We offer specialized oral hygiene sessions, teaching children with disabilities how to care for their teeth and gums, and the importance of regular dental check-ups.

We work to foster a culture of inclusivity and empowerment. We believe in the strength of community support. Our organization actively engages parents, caregivers, teachers, and healthcare professionals, fostering a collaborative environment that ensures children receive the care and support they need.
Summary: Inclusive Healthcare for Children is dedicated to bridging the healthcare disparity gap for children with disabilities. Our mission is to empower these children with skills to take care of their well-being + ensure equal access to healthcare and hygi

Name: Indian American Student Association
Description: The Indian American Student Association is a space for members to create friendships and bonds that will last a lifetime. We seek to preserve and celebrate Indian and South Asian culture while forging ahead and evolving as a community. The organization allows members to become active in social, cultural, and professional arenas. We provide opportunities for students to connect with each other, while building bridges with other student groups and the broader university community. Above all, IASA is an organization that holds the interests of its members at heart, and strives to create a genuine sense of inclusion.
Summary: IASA serves to promote various aspects of Indian and South Asian American culture and heritage through an assortment of events that raise social, and cultural awareness, as well as fulfill goals aimed at community building and community service.

Name: Indian Muslim Student Association
Description: The Indian Muslim Student Association (IMSA) is an organization that raises awareness to the struggles that Muslims in India today are facing. IMSA intends to start conversations and educate its members about these important issues.
Summary: The Indian Muslim Student Association (IMSA) is an organization that raises awareness to the struggles that Muslims in India today are facing. IMSA intends to start conversations and educate its members about these important issues.

Name: Indian Student Association
Description:
The Indian Student Association is a community of graduate and undergraduate students of Indian origin who are pursuing their academic degrees at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. Our primary objective is to foster a welcoming social network amongst the Indian community on campus. We proudly serve as a valuable resource for incoming Indian students, offering guidance and support with regard to navigating the complexities of student life in a new environment. Our commitment to the well-being of our members is demonstrated by our efforts to address a wide range of needs such as housing, networking, and general inquiries.

Our association also strives to be an active participant in various University activities, as well as a partner of student organizations to contribute to the rich diversity of our campus community. The day-to-day operations of the association are managed by a team of dedicated volunteers who serve as the board.

As an organization, we take great pride in offering a vibrant cultural experience through a diverse array of events. These events include the celebration of Indian national holidays such as Republic Day, Diwali, and Holi, as well as activities such as Indian movie screenings, cricket screenings, potlucks, and welcome events for incoming students.
Summary: The Indian Student Association is a community of graduate and undergraduate students of Indian origin studying at the University of Michigan. Our primary objective is to foster a welcoming social network amongst the Indian community on campus.

Name: Indian Subcontinent Business Association
Description:
The Indian Subcontinent Business Association (ISBA) is a student organization that focuses on education, career development and networking primarily for students from the Indian Subcontinent. In addition, ISBA organises social and educational events to enrich the cultural experience of all students and foster a close-knit community.

Mission statement, purpose, and goals

The Indian Subcontinent Business Association is a student club dedicated to

  • Helping students of Indian subcontinent origin transition into and traverse through business school life
  • Promoting awareness about the subcontinent among the larger business school community
  • Encouraging social and professional interaction among students and alumni from the subcontinent
Summary: The Indian Sub-Continent Business Association is a student organization that focuses on education, career development and networking primarily for students of Indian Sub-continent, i.e. the countries – Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Pakistan, Nepal

Name: Indus Hospital & Health Network - University of Michigan Chapter
Description: As students of the University of Michigan, we are partnered with Indus Hospital & Health Network and centered around fundraising and supporting their work. Indus is a nation-wide network of hospitals across Pakistan providing quality, free-of-cost, comprehensive healthcare accessible to all. We work with Friends of Indus Hospital to plan events and support specific projects and departments within the health network. Along with fundraising efforts, we host events and opportunities for our campus community to learn more about healthcare in Pakistan, and the work that Indus does to provide healthcare to citizens across the nation despite their life circumstances.
Summary: Focused on raising funds to support Indus Hospital & Health Network while educating our campus community about global healthcare, specifically in Pakistan

Name: Industry Pharmacists Organization
Description:
IPhO is the only universally recognized professional organization for industry-based pharmacists. Student members of IPhO are recognized within the pharmaceutical industry as being the most professionally equipped to contribute to the development, commercialization, promotion, and optimal use of medicines. As a student chapter, our main goal this year is to bring greater industry opportunities to the college in order to prepare students with the resources, marketable skill sets, and valued experiences necessary to be a competitive candidate in any industry setting.

As a local or national member of IPhO, our organization offers membership to current pharmacy students and PhD candidates. Membership offers unique opportunities to gain first-hand insight on the diverse functional areas of industry and develop meaningful networks with established industry-professionals.
Summary: IPhO is the organization whose pharmacist members are universally recognized within the pharmaceutical industry as being the most professionally equipped to contribute to the development, commercialization, promotion, and optimal use of medicines.

Name: Information and Technology Services
Description:
Information and Technology Services (ITS) provides technology and communications services designed to ensure students' academic success and support U-M Ann Arbor's academic and research needs. Visit its.umich.edu/tech-guide for an overview of many of the IT services and resources available to students while at Michigan.

 

Need help with IT issues or have questions about our services contact the ITS Service Center at its.umich.edu/help or call 734-764-4357.
Summary: Information and Technology Services (ITS) provides technology and communications services designed to ensure students' academic success and support U-M Ann Arbor's academic and research needs.

Name: INFORMS at the University of Michigan
Description:
We are the student chapter of the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS) at the University of Michigan.

Join us!
Summary: INFORMS at University of Michigan is an organization for students interested in using mathematical optimization, statistical analysis, mathematical modeling, and other analytical methods to find better solutions to complex decision-making problems.

Name: Initiative for Inclusive Design
Description:
Through active participation in the architecture community  (Lectures, workshops, events, etc.)  at the University of Michigan and through group research, this independent student advisory board will:

-Initiate conversation among students and faculty regarding disability and design.

-Empower students to recognize and problematize the current limitations that contemporary design discipline/practice presents, and to encourage them to work and think progressively.

-Foster an open network of dialogue within the architecture program, respecting every voice.

-Diversify, strengthen, and expand students’ design skills through research, site visits, lectures, workshops, interdisciplinary design charrettes, and student-led projects.
Summary: We work to raise awareness of creating accessible and inclusive spaces, by striving to educate ourselves on matters of inclusivity and working to dismantle exclusivity and ableism in the context of architecture and design.

Name: Inner Balance Collective
Description: A mental health club for all UofM students to help take their minds off the pressure of class and give them something to do to help them destress, as well as monthly presentations from different professionals like personal trainers or health expert
Summary: A mental health club for all UofM students to help take their minds off the pressure of class and give them something to do to help them destress, as well as monthly presentations from different professionals like personal trainers or health expert

Name: Innovation for Impact
Description: Innovation for Impact is a technical consulting group with members who study Computer Science, User Design, Data Science, Business, and other similar fields. The purpose of this organization is to emphasize skill development for our members through hands-on projects and continuous learning. We offer opportunities for practical client engagement by taking on pro bono consulting projects. Our work empowers our members to expand their coding skills while connecting with our community. We also collaborate with other clubs and organizations to facilitate cross-disciplinary learning and knowledge exchange.
Summary: The purpose of Innovation for Impact is to emphasize skill development for our members through hands-on projects and continuous learning. We empower our members to expand their coding skills while connecting with our community.

Name: Innovation in Motion
Description: This club provides a space for students at any stage of the entrepreneurial journey to develop their ideas and take them to the next level. Inspired by the Shark Tank model, we recognize prototypes and existing initiatives while emphasizing mentorship to refine business structures. Beyond pitching, the club fosters an entrepreneurial mindset by encouraging creativity, problem-solving, and real-world business development.
Summary: I-MO is an entrepreneurship club open to all undergrads! We provide a platform for students exploring or launching business ideas, offering mentorship, financial support, and guidance to develop strong pitches and bring their ideas to life.

Name: InspirED Detroit
Description: InspirED Detroit strives to support high school students in Detroit to achieve their post secondary goals. InspirED aims to help students with their college applications, as well as provide resources to better prepare for the admissions process
Summary: InspirED Detroit strives to support high school students in Detroit to achieve their post secondary goals. InspirED aims to help students with their college applications, as well as provide resources to better prepare for the admissions process

Name: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
Description:
We are the Student Branch affiliated with IEEE. We connect students with companies, the international IEEE organization, and the university.

IEEE's core purpose is to foster technological innovation and excellence for the benefit of humanity.

IEEE will be essential to the global technical community and to technical professionals everywhere, and be universally recognized for the contributions of technology and of technical professionals in improving global conditions.
Summary: IEEE promotes the development and application of electrotechnology and allied sciences for the benefit of humanity, the advancement of the profession, and the well-being of our members.

Name: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Nuclear & Plasma Sciences Society
Description: The IEEE Nuclear and Plasma Sciences Society is devoted to the dissemination of theory, experiments, educations methods, and applications of nuclear and plasma sciences.
Summary: The IEEE Nuclear and Plasma Sciences Society is devoted to the dissemination of theory, experiments, educations methods, and applications of nuclear and plasma sciences.

Name: Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineers
Description: The Institute of Industrial & Systems Engineers strives to provide an awareness of the Industrial and Operations Department and its resources. IISE works to develop interdepartmental relationships as well as present insight into career opportunities. By maintaining a strong relationship with the IISE National Chapter, an industry network is sustained.
Summary: The Institute of Industrial & Systems Engineers strives to provide an awareness of the Industrial and Operations Department and its resources. IISE works to develop interdepartmental relationships as well as present insight into career opportunities.

Name: Institute of Nuclear Materials Management at the University of Michigan
Description: The student chapter of INMM at the University of Michigan is interested in promoting the field of nuclear materials management through increased awareness and research efforts. We host visiting research scientists, professors, and professionals in the field to give presentations to students and staff and to visit our facilities.  We encourage student members to become part of the national INMM organization and to attend the annual INMM conference.
Summary:
INMM at the University of Michigan is interested in 
promoting the field of nuclear materials 
management through increased awareness 
and research efforts.

Name: Intellectual Property Students Association
Description: The Intellectual Property Students Association (IPSA) was founded in the fall of 1988 to educate law students and other interested members of allied fields about intellectual property law. IPSA members explore career opportunities in a variety of legal practice areas, including: patents, copyright, technology transactions, trademarks and unfair competition, software protection, and trade secrets. We provide students with the means to keep abreast of developments in law and related technologies, the opportunity to develop important connections with practitioners, and the chance to participate in projects offering practical experience and training!
Summary: The Intellectual Property Student Association aims to develop and further the community of law students interested in practice areas related to intellectual property by organizing academic, career-related, and social events.

Name: Inter-Cooperative Council
Description:
Cooperative movements, including the ICC, have a long history. Here (http://www.icc.coop/story/history/) you can find more information about the Inter-Cooperative Council in Ann Arbor as well as links to other cooperatives. We suggest that you use the official ICC website (http://www.icc.coop/) to find information beyond the brief description below. 

We are the ICC, one of the largest student housing cooperatives in the country. We were established in 1932 by students and since that time we have successfully provided affordable, quality housing to thousands of students from around the world.

Today approximately 550 members belong to our co-op and they collectively own and manage 21 properties. The properties are comprised of 16 houses, of these properties are the houses that we live in and the the Moses Coady/Paulo Friere Education Center for our members and the community and the Rochdale Center office space for both our members and staff.

Students created the co-ops to meet their own needs, thus the ICC offers eight month Fall/Winter, 4 month Fall or Winter, and 2 or 4 month Spring/Summer contracts. Our houses range in size from 12 to 180 members. The average Central Campus house holds about 30 people.

Escher Co-op on North Campus attracts a large graduate student population and a sizable international student population. The Central Campus co-ops are home to is a large, diverse crowd. Because co-ops are open to all students, each house is made up of members from a  wide variety of backgrounds, interests, and academic programs. What brings us together is our dedication to create the best living atmosphere possible.

Most houses are quite social. There are often ICC-wide parties at one house or another. Houses get together to play IM soccer, go apple picking, bowling, or ice skating—the list goes on and on.

The ICC houses are more than just places to sleep and eat.  Though our mission commits us to affordable housing, for many of our members it is the community that makes all the difference.
Summary:
The Inter-Cooperative Council and its 550+ members provide affordable
housing and an inclusive community to college students. The ICC is comprised of 16 unique housing communities located on both Central and North Campus.

Name: Interfraternity Council
Description: The Interfraternity Council (IFC) is the local governing body for National Interfraternity Conference fraternity chapters at the University of Michigan. IFC works to promote the highest ideals of scholarship, leadership, service and fraternalism among its member organizations. IFC provides educational programming on a variety of topics to fraternity chapters and their members including leadership, risk management, alcohol awareness and scholarship. IFC consists of a 10-member elected executive council and a legislative body of fraternity representatives.
Summary: The Interfraternity Council (IFC) is the local governing body for National Interfraternity Conference fraternity chapters at the University of Michigan.

Name: Internal Medicine Interest Group
Description: The goals of the Internal Medicine Interest Group (IMIG) are to increase Internal Medicine (IM) related mentoring, educational seminars, and awareness of research and other scholarly opportunities within the University of Michigan Medical School (UMMS) community. We aim to help UMMS students explore their interest in IM as a specialty.
Summary: The goals of the Internal Medicine Interest Group (IMIG) are to increase Internal Medicine (IM) related mentoring, educational seminars, and awareness of research and other scholarly opportunities within the University of Michigan Medical School (UMMS).

Name: International Center
Description: The International Center provides a variety of services to assist international students and students from the U.S. at the University of Michigan. We organize a wide range of social, cultural and educational events, such as our monthly international coffee hour, the Intercultural Leadership Seminar, Travel Basics workshops, and the Global Wolverines program, which is a preparatory series of events geared towards students interested in interning abroad. In addition, we offer individual advising on opportunities to study, intern, or travel internationally - including resources on post-graduate options such as teaching English abroad. For those interested in global service work, the International Center also houses the University of Michigan's Peace Corps office and administers the Peace Corps Prep certificate program for undergraduate students. We are here to provide you with opportunities to have a global education, whether you stay in Ann Arbor or decide to travel abroad!
Summary: The International Center provides a variety of services to assist international students and students from the U.S. at the University of Michigan.

Name: International Law Society
Description:
The International Law Society (ILS) is devoted to promoting a greater understanding of international and comparative law and the role they play in the world today. ILS sponsors a variety of events throughout the year aimed at bringing students, faculty, and other interested people together to learn more about this exciting and important area of law. Speakers include faculty members from universities around the world, government experts, visiting scholars, and students with particular areas of expertise. Settings include lectures, panel discussions, informal lunchtime meetings, and evening talks. 


In addition to hosting events covering substantive contemporary international issues, ILS also organizes various career panels and other social activities between JD candidates, LLM students, and faculty members.
Summary: The International Law Society (ILS) is devoted to promoting a greater understanding of international and comparative law and the role they play in the world today. ILS sponsors a variety of events throughout the year aimed at developing this mission.

Name: International Policy Students Association
Description: International Policy Student Association (IPSA) is a student-led organization at the Ford School of Public Policy that works to build a community, strengthen and supplement international course and lecture offerings on relevant issues, and expand career options for students interested in international policy issues.
Summary: IPSA's mission is to promote, facilitate, sustain, and provide opportunities for the study of international policy issues at the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy and the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor.

Name: International Refugee Assistance Project: Michigan Chapter
Description:
The International Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) is a global legal aid and advocacy organization working to create a world where refugees and all people seeking safety are empowered to claim their right to freedom of movement and a path to lasting refuge.

Since its founding in 2008, IRAP has provided free legal aid to over 40,000 displaced people from over 100 different countries and has trained over 6,000 law students and lawyers in the process. University of Michigan Law school is one of IRAP’s 26 student chapters across the United States and Canada.
Summary: IRAP provides comprehensive legal representation to individual refugees seeking resettlement. Law students work in pairs under the supervision of pro pro bono attorneys and prepare visa applications, appeals, and help clients negotiate resettlement.

Name: International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research / Academy of Managed Care Pharmacy
Description: ISPOR/AMCP is a multidisciplinary, professional organization aimed at exposing healthcare students to non-traditional career paths in fields such as the pharmaceutical industry, managed care, contract research organizations, and academia. Housed in the College of Pharmacy, the organization sponsors speakers, competitions, and professional skill development opportunities to supplement classroom learning and enhance student’s knowledge base and skillsets.
Summary: ISPOR/AMCP is a multidisciplinary, professional organization aimed at exposing healthcare students to non-traditional career paths in fields such as the pharmaceutical industry, managed care, contract research organizations, and academia.

Name: International Youth and Students for Social Equality
Description: The International Youth and Students for Social Equality hopes to foster discussion and political mobilization against social, political and economic inequality. Equality is a fundamental right of humankind, denied almost universally to the people of this earth under the economic system of capitalism. While our organization encourages various means of promoting equality, our program aspires towards a socialist transformation of society.
Summary: The IYSSE hopes to foster discussion and political mobilization against social, political and economic inequality. While our organization encourages various means of promoting equality, our program aspires towards a socialist transformation of society.

Name: InterVarsity Christian Fellowship (Multi-Ethnic)
Description:
Mission:

In response to God's love, grace, and truth:
The Purpose of InterVarsity Christian Fellowship/USA
is to establish and advance
at colleges and universities
witnessing communities of students and faculty
who follow Jesus as Savior and Lord:
growing in love for God,
God's Word,
God's people of every ethnicity and culture
and God's purposes in the world.

Programs:

We gather weekly for community, prayer and to put what we're learning about Jesus from scripture into practice. We also have weekly student-led small groups that meet on campus and community events.
Summary: InterVarsity Multi-Ethnic ("IVME") is a student group at UofM that seeks to know and follow Jesus.  We are open to anyone (Christian, seeker, or skeptic)!

Name: INvent
Description:
Since 2017, INvent has been a platform for students who wish to do collaborative work at High Schools in Peru and Colombia by implementing STEM Programs during a volunteer summer abroad experience. Members of INvent travel to Peru or Colombia for 3 weeks during the months of May-June to be instructors of an after school program in collaboration the Peruvian non profit UTK United Technologies for Kids. The technologies taught are 3D printing, design in CAD, electronics with Arduinos and basic programming. These may be extended to robotics, drones, etc. During winter semester selected U of Michigan students prepare the lessons and projects that they will teach to high schoolers.

INvent partners with a mirror program at UC Berkeley and MIT that will give Umich students further opportunities to share experiences and deliver joint projects at the high schools besides building relationships with university students during the summer abroad program. *Travel expenses covered

As a response to COVID-19 and the obstacles it created to travel, we have started implementing online workshops. We created a platform called INvent Academy and have offered workshops over Zoom to connect with students. Also, we plan to continue our work for STEM education locally in the upcoming year. 

INvent Academy: https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/invent-academy/home

News Report on INvent: http://ns.umich.edu/new/releases/25010-teaching-love-of-science-from-the-ground-up
Summary: INvent develops and offers STEM workshops to high school kids that have limited access to hands-on engineering experiences. Throughout the school year, we develop online workshops. During the summer, selected students travel to South America to teach.

Name: Iota Iota Iota National Women's and Gender Studies Honor Society
Description: Iota Iota Iota (Triota) is a National Honor Society for Women's and Gender Studies students. Triota aims to encourage and support scholarship and excellence in women's and gender studies as well as foster an inclusive community on campus at the University of Michigan. This organization is open to both undergraduate and graduate students within the WGS department. The requirement for membership includes maintaining a 3.4 GPA or higher in your declared major or minor during the duration of your membership.
Summary: Iota Iota Iota (Triota) is a National Honor Society for Women's and Gender Studies Students. Triota aims to encourage and support scholarship and excellence in women's and gender studies as well as foster feminist values on campus.

Name: Iota Omega Epsilon
Description:
Iota Omega Epsilon is a co-ed professional fraternity at the University of Michigan operating at the intersection of business and STEM-focused on shaping the leaders of tomorrow.


Through engaging events, workshops, a diverse community, and meaningful networking opportunities, IOE equips students with the skills, knowledge, and connections necessary to thrive in the ever-evolving STEM and business worlds.

Learn More Here
Summary: Iota Omega Epsilon is a co-ed professional fraternity at the University of Michigan operating at the intersection of business and STEM focused on shaping the leaders of tomorrow through social, academic, and professional development.

Name: Iranian Graduate Student Association
Description:
As stated in IGSA constitution Article 1-B-1 "IGSA is a non-partisan volunteer student organization committed to supporting and serving the needs and interests of the Iranian community at the University of Michigan.” In addition, IGSA strives to introduce Iran to the UM community. To address the needs of UM Iranian community and achieve our objective of introducing our country, IGSA organizes:

1) Special events to honor national Iranian festivities such as Mehregan , Yalda, Nowrooz, etc.

2) Regular social and cultural events such as movie nights, game nights, etc.

3) Educational seminars by invited speakers on Iran’s culture, history, arts, etc. such events act as mediums through which the Iranian community at large could keep in touch, while effectively introducing Iranian culture to other nationalities at UofM.
Summary: IGSA is a non-partisan volunteer student organization committed to supporting and serving the needs and interests of the Iranian community at the University of Michigan.

Name: Iraqi American Union at the University of Michigan
Description: The Iraqi American Union at the University of Michigan (IAU- UM) shall serve as an organization that promotes and raises awareness of the history, culture, and contemporary issues of Iraq and the communities of its diaspora in a secular manner. The mission of the IAU-UM is to foster an inclusive environment for Iraqi students on campus and beyond.
Summary: The Iraqi American Union aims to celebrate Iraqi culture and raise awareness of contemporary issues surrounding the community while bridging the gaps between the Arab and non-Arab communities on campus.

Name: Islamic Society of AhlulBayt
Description: The mission of the Islamic Society of AhlulBayt (ISA) at the University of Michigan is to provide a welcoming space for Muslims and other interested individuals to learn, connect, and serve according to the teachings of the Quran, the Prophet, and the AhlulBayt.
Summary: The mission of the Islamic Society of Ahlulbayt is to provide a welcoming space for Muslims and other interested individuals to learn, connect, and serve according to the teachings of the Quran, the Prophet, and the Ahlulbayt.

Name: Italian Student Association
Description: Italian Student Association, the University of Michigan’s only Italian club, provides students the opportunity to learn more about Italian culture while practicing their speaking skills in a relaxed and enjoyable setting. Some of the events we host include game nights, movie screenings, cooking demos, soccer tournaments, club outings to nearby cities and towns, and more! The Italian Student Association also organizes exam reviews and tutoring sessions for Italian 101 and 102 students. Suggestions for other events you’d like to see happen are more than welcome! The club aims to serve as a resource to students interested in any opportunity related to Italian language and culture – whether it be academic or out of personal curiosity – and also to serve as a liaison between students and the Italian department and faculty. We can help with homework, give study abroad advice, or, in general, help you find what you’re looking for. During the winter 2024 semester ITSA will meet on Tuesdays from 6:00 - 7:00 pm in East Quad room 1505. If you are interested in tutoring, please reach out and we can help set you up with Italian tutors! See you at our next event!
Summary: Italian Student Association (ITSA) is a resource for all things Italian! Through weekly meetings, game nights, movies, potlucks & more, ITSA offers a fun environment in which students can practice their Italian and learn more about Italian culture!!

Name: J Street U
Description: J Street UMich is the U of M chapter of the national organization “J Street U”.  We are a group of students who recognize that it is challenging to have conversations about Israel that include meaningful criticism of the Israeli government while respecting its right to exist. J Street U seeks to create spaces for these nuanced conversations. We provide a voice for the majority of American students to engage meaningfully in anti-occupation organizing, and working towards the goal of a negotiated two-state solution. We provide guidance, education and resources to students who seek to impart a progressive voice into the campus debate on Israel/Palestine. If you are interested in J Street U at Michigan, email us at jstreetumich@gmail.com or message us on instagram @jstreetumich.
Summary: Our primary mission is to promote a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by advocating for a two-state solution. As a student organization, we host educational events and open dialogues throughout the year to work toward this goal.

Name: Jain Students Association
Description:
Jain Students Association (JSA) was created with the intention of fostering a sense of community between Jain students and those interested in Jainism at the University of Michigan. We hope to also provide opportunities for our members to socialize, network, observe Jain holidays and practices, discuss religion/philosophy, and participate in community service (seva). Whether you're here from abroad, bought up in the US, or just interested, we welcome you join us!

Jainism, one of India’s oldest religious traditions, has become a way of life for numerous people across the world.  It is a monastic religion based on the principles of non-violence, truthfulness, non-possession, karmic cycle, reincarnation of the worldly soul, and liberation through understanding and realization.
Summary: Jain Students Association (JSA) was created with the intention of fostering a sense of community between Jain students and those interested in Jainism at the University of Michigan.

Name: James Van Veen Squadron, Arnold Air Society
Description:
Type of Organization. The Society is primarily a professional, honorary, service organization advocating the support of aerospace power. 

1.3.1. Professional. AAS is “professional” because of the established intent of its members to become officers in the USAF and USSF. AAS strives to instill an attitude of selfless dedication to and responsibility for fulfillment of the mission of the USAF, USSF, AFROTC, and AAS. 

1.3.2. Honorary. AAS is “honorary” because of the obligation of all Active Members to honor and remember all those who have gone before and served this country. 

1.3.3. Service. AAS is a “service” organization because of the contributions and assistance provided to the community, campus, and officer commissioning programs. 

1.4. Vision Statement. “Develop proactive leaders; remain loyal to the ideals of the Arnold Air Society; foster a synergistic society through selfless service of our dedicated members.”
Summary: The Society is primarily a professional, honorary, service organization advocating the support of aerospace power.

Name: Japan Business Association at Ross
Description:
Japan Business Association serves as a bridge between Japan and the Ross School of Business. Specifically, the stated goals of this club are:
a) Raise awareness and understanding within the Ross community of Japan, its culture, and its business norms;
b) Provide opportunities for cultural exchange between Japanese and non-Japanese Ross students;
c) Support those who pursue career opportunities pertaining to Japan, as well as those who pursue global career opportunities from the Japanese community; and
d) Propagate Japanese prospective students’ interest in Ross and aid in their application process where possible.
Summary: Japan Business Association seeks to promote a deeper understanding of Japan, its culture, and its business norms throughout the Ross community.

Name: Japan Student Association
Description:
The Japan Student Association (JSA) is a vibrant, multicultural organization committed to sharing Japanese culture with the University of Michigan campus and the broader community. We provide a welcoming space for individuals with shared interests to connect, organize engaging social events featuring Japanese culture, and host career opportunities with Japanese companies. JSA is open to students of all cultural and ethnic backgrounds!

 

Check out our Instagram for the most recent updates on events!
Summary: Join us at the Japan Student Association (JSA), where we celebrate and promote Japanese culture across the University campus! Our cultural events are filled with fun activities, delicious food, and great company. Everyone is welcome in this organization!

Name: Japanese Language Circle
Description: The Japanese Language Circle is for those interested in the Japanese language. Open to students of all levels, native speakers included, we seek to support language learners and provide a space where they may engage with Japanese, practice, and improve.
Summary: The Japanese Language Circle is for those interested in the Japanese language. Open to students of all levels, native speakers included, we seek to support language learners and provide a space where they may engage with Japanese, practice, and improve.

Name: Jeopardy Club at The University of Michigan
Description:
Jeopardy at University of Michigan is a low-commitment club that holds weekly viewings of Jeopardy! as well as occasional, low-stakes competitions. It is meant to foster enjoyment of trivia without stress.

Fill out this form to join our mailing list and stay updated: https://forms.gle/GxqdYj9VvTGGfT1b6
Summary: Jeopardy at University of Michigan is a low-commitment club that holds weekly viewing of Jeopardy! as well as occasional, low-stakes competitions. It is meant to foster enjoyment of trivia without stress.

Name: Jewish Business Association
Description: JBA stands for the Jewish Business Association and we are student group on campus that is directly affiliated with the Hillel on campus! We pride ourselves on being an inclusive environment for University of Michigan students to explore careers in business and to expand their Jewish network!
Summary: JBA’s mission is to connect Jewish business students through social and professional events.

Name: Jewish Engineering Association
Description: The Jewish Engineering Association (JEngA) is a student-run organization sponsored by Hillel in the College of Engineering that provides a community for Jewish undergraduate students while promoting the awareness and development of Jews in the field of Engineering. JEngA organizes and co-sponsors many social and volunteering events throughout the year. It also serves as a resource for a variety of issues affecting Jewish Engineers at Michigan. We welcome all students who are interested.
Summary: The Jewish Engineering Association (JEngA) provides a community for Jewish undergraduate students while promoting the awareness and development of Jews in the field of Engineering.

Name: Jewish Law Students Association
Description: The Jewish Law Students Association (JLSA), a student organization at the University of Michigan Law School, is dedicated to providing a wide variety of religious, social, and cultural programming for the entire student body of the Law School. The group presents speakers, panel discussions, and films dealing with issues of interest to Jewish law students, as well as professional networking opportunities. We also sponsor social events within the law school and with other Jewish student organizations at the University. Members also have the opportunity to participate in regional and national Jewish law student conferences and events.
Summary: JLSA is focused on promoting friendships between Jewish law students as well as the law school community at large while providing opportunities for students to participate in social, educational, and community service events.

Name: Jewish Medical Student Association
Description:
JeMSA provides a welcoming environment for the community of Jewish medical students, or those wishing to learn more about Judaism, to meet one another and to develop their passions and find community as future physicians together.

We hold events such as Shabbat dinners, holiday celebrations, and mixers with faculty.
Summary: JeMSA provides a welcoming environment for the community of Jewish medical students, or those wishing to learn more about Judaism, to meet one another and to develop their passions and find community as future physicians together.

Name: Jewish Pre Law Association
Description: Our mission is to cultivate a space for members of the Jewish community to learn, grow, and enhance their knowledge in the field of law and public policy. Our goal is to enrich student life by providing a community of individuals who are diverse, inclusive, and respectful of others’ views. In addition, we want to foster professional development, embody Jewish values, facilitate interpersonal connections, and establish leadership opportunities.
Summary: The Jewish Pre Law Association is an organization for pre-law students to participate in events and gain insights into the field of law and public policy.

Name: Jewish Resource Center
Description: The Jewish Resource Center is a community center for learning about Judaism and interacting with other community members over special meals and holidays.
Summary: Dedicated to the community and to learning and teaching values of Judaism and its history.

Name: Jewish Voice for Peace at the University of Michigan
Description: Jewish Voice for Peace organizes for Palestinian liberation and Judaism beyond zionism. We aim to create a space where Jewish students from all backgrounds and traditions can celebrate our culture and advocate for the national liberation of Palestine. JVP aims to educate students and the wider community about the ongoing displacement and genocide of Palestinians by the Zionist occupation. It advocates for a more just U.S. foreign policy that does not support the occupation of Palestine, as well as advocating for our university to divest from any and all companies that invest in and/or profit from the genocide of Palestinian people. JVP’s mission is to create a strong Jewish anti-Zionist institution on campus by hosting cultural events inspired by Jewish traditions promoting justice for all, as well as participating in actions led by Palestinian activists to show Jewish solidarity with the Palestinian movement (which includes our membership in the TAHRIR Coalition).
Summary: Jewish Voice for Peace organizes for Palestinian liberation and Judaism beyond zionism. We aim to create a space where Jewish students from all backgrounds and traditions can celebrate our culture and advocate for the national liberation of Palestine.

Name: Jordanian Student Association at the University of Michigan
Description: The Jordanian Student Association is a vibrant and inclusive community dedicated to celebrating Jordanian culture while fostering a sense of belonging and togetherness among students. Our organization serves as a cultural bridge, connecting Jordanian students and those interested in Jordanian heritage. Through a variety of engaging activities and events, we aim to promote cultural awareness and exchange, ultimately cultivating a strong and supportive community.
Summary: The Jordanian Student Association is a vibrant and inclusive community dedicated to celebrating Jordanian culture while fostering a sense of belonging and togetherness among students.

Name: Judaic Studies
Description: The undergraduate degree in Judaic Studies offers students a unique opportunity to explore the diverse histories, traditions, languages and cultural expressions of Jews living across the globe. The major and minor are flexible and individualized which provides opportunities for in-depth language studies, experiential learning, study abroad and personal connections with faculty. Students gain transferable skills in research and writing, critical and creative thinking, and public and persuasive speaking. The diverse curriculum allows for exploration of any aspect of the Jewish experience, from Israel to America, spanning the biblical era to the present. Judaic Studies explores its key themes in an interdisciplinary fashion, looking at history, law, literature and culture to investigate the broad sweep of nationhood, religion, language and space. Students use the tools of Jewish textual studies and source analysis to contend with contemporary political and social issues: social justice and migration; antisemitism and persecution; gender, racial, and sexual identities; religious faith and diversity. Students develop individual responses to these complex issues and others while working closely with distinguished faculty and prominent visitors.
Summary: The undergraduate degree in Judaic Studies offers students a unique opportunity to explore the diverse histories, traditions, languages and cultural expressions of Jews living across the globe.

Name: Jump Rope Club
Description: With benefits ranging from reduced risk of cardiovascular disease to increased bone density, jumping rope is an extremely valuable tool for improving overall health. Jumping rope with others also allows jumpers to connect with fellow students interested in fitness, create enjoyable memories, and promote positive changes in the community. As the first and only student organization centered around jumping rope, Jump Rope Club is a unique space for students to experience the innumerable benefits of the sport through weekly practices, social events, and fundraising opportunities.
Summary: Jump into health and happiness with Jump Rope Club!

Name: K-Grams (Kids' Programs)
Description:
The mission of K-grams is to establish a strong community of learning for a wide range of college and elementary students, educators, and families by developing positive relationships and experiences that extend beyond the classroom.

If you are interested in joining our organization, please join our interest list or visit our website!

Email any questions to Kgramsexec@umich.edu!
Summary:
Pen Pal: Students who live in residence halls or Greek houses exchange letters monthly with an elementary student. 
BookMARK: A mentoring program open to any U-M student. Sessions happen throughout the week; mentor and read with a child one-on-one

Name: K-Motion
Description:
K-Motion is the only unaffiliated all female K-pop dance group at the University of Michigan. Founded in 2013, the group’s mission has always been to create meaningful relationships through a shared passion for dance. Through performances, videos covers, and practices, K-Motion aims to form a community where members can comfortably express themselves. In addition to performances, we aim to promote every members’ growth in dance and leadership while creating long-lasting relationships between our dancers and the greater UM A/PIA community. 

 

Follow us on instagram for the most up-to-date information on our auditions, shows, and other events! @kmotion_

Celebrasia 2024

KASA 2024
Summary: K-Motion is the only unaffiliated all-female Korean pop dance group on campus. We primarily cover popular K-pop choreographies and hip-hop pieces. Our mission is to create lasting relationships through our shared passion for dance.

Name: Kalam Arabic Debate Society
Description:
The Arabic Debate Society (ADS) is an organization that aims to facilitate debates in the Arabic language, based on the guidelines set by the Qatar Debate championship. While participation in the championship is not required, speakers of all Arabic levels are welcome to participate, from beginners to natives.

The ADS provides a platform for individuals to develop their public speaking skills, critical thinking, and argumentation skills in Modern Standard Arabic. The organization offers workshops and training sessions to help participants develop these skills, and they have a team of experienced coaches who provide guidance and support throughout the process.

One of the goals of ADS is to train a team of Arabic speakers to participate in the international Qatar Debate championship, in which participants debate hot-topic motions in Arabic at universities all around the country. While our debate style is largely based on Qatar Debate rules and guidelines, joining our official debate team is not mandatory, and members can still learn valuable skills from this style of argumentation.  

The ADS also emphasizes the importance of respectful and constructive dialogue, where participants engage with each other in a spirit of openness and mutual understanding; debates are not only a way to develop critical thinking and public speaking skills, but also a way to foster empathy and respect for diverse perspectives.

Whether you are a native Arabic speaker, a first-year learner, a seasoned debater, or have never debated, everyone is welcome to be a part of ADS and join the discourse!
Summary: Our organization aims to facilitate debate in the Arabic language based on Qatar Debate championship guidelines. Participation in the championship is not required; speakers of all Arabic levels, whether beginners or natives, are welcome to participate.

Name: Kappa Alpha Pi Pre-Law Fraternity
Description:
Kappa Alpha Pi Pre-Law Co-Ed Fraternity was founded on October 9th, 2007 at the University of Michigan. Favoring the safety of its members as well as a close-knit community, a group of students formerly associated with the Phi Alpha Delta Pre-Law Fraternity International disbanded and established Kappa Alpha Pi in order to preserve the integrity and best interests of its membership.

The purpose of this Fraternity shall be to foster knowledge of the law for undergraduate students; to provide service to the greater community and campus; to promote a strong sense of fraternalism among members; to uphold the ideals and integrity of Kappa Alpha Pi Pre-Law Co-ed Fraternity; so that each member may advance his and her intellect while contributing actively to the well-being of others. Members of Kappa Alpha Pi not only have the opportunity to attend weekly meetings with a wide array of speakers from various areas of the law, but also to engage in other professional development activities such as resume and personal statement workshops, dean panels, and mentorship programs with students from the Law School. Kappa Alpha Pi also works extensively with the Career Center, Kaplan, and Princeton Review to ensure our members affordable and valuable support in their law school endeavors. Furthermore, Kappa Alpha Pi believes that it is important to enrich our understanding of the law through community involvement, and members are able to participate in a variety of service events such as the Relay for Life, food and clothing drives, and doing projects for the children at the C.S. Mott’s Children’s Hospital at U of M.

Kappa Alpha Pi now spans from coast to coast, with chapters at the University of California, Los Angeles; the University of California, Riverside; Cornell University; and many more. Growing each semester as new pledge classes emerge, Kappa Alpha Pi remains dedicated to advancing members’ understanding of the law and providing a robust fraternal community in which our members can thrive.

Learn more at kappaalphapi.com.
Summary: Kappa Alpha Pi is a co-ed Pre-Law fraternity that focuses on educating its members about potential careers in the field of law, while promoting fraternalism and working to benefit the community.

Name: Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity Incorporated—University of Michigan
Description: Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity Inc is a collegiate Greek-letter fraternity with a predominantly African-American membership. Since the fraternity's founding on January 5, 1911 at Indiana University in Bloomington, IN, the fraternity has never limited membership based on color, creed or national origin. The fraternity has over 150,000 members with 721 undergraduate and alumni chapters in every state of the United States, and international chapters in the United Kingdom, Germany, Korea, Japan, United States Virgin Islands, Nigeria and South Africa. The Sigma Chapter of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraterinty Inc was founded on February 22, 1922 at the campus of the University of Michigan. Principle members in the founding of the Sigma Chapter are Hurlong Scott, Rudolph T. Ashe and George R. Dorsey.
Summary:
Uniting college men of culture, patriotism and honor in a bond of fraternity, eternally striving for achievement in every field of human endeavor.

Sigma Chapter est. Feb 22, 1922

Name: Kappa Delta
Description: Kappa Delta Sorority is committed to providing opportunities and experiences that build confidence and inspire women to action. Kappa Delta offers lifelong support for leadership development, personal growth, academic success and community service, all in the context of friendship.
Summary: Kappa Delta Sorority is committed to providing opportunities and experiences that build confidence and inspire women to action. KD offers lifelong support for leadership development, personal growth, academic success and community service.

Name: Kappa Kappa Gamma
Description: As members of Kappa Kappa Gamma, we pledge to embody the purposes our founders laid before us at the establishment of the Fraternity in 1870. As our Fraternity bylaws state, our organization's purpose is to unite women, through membership, in a close bond of friendship, seeking to instill in them a spirit of mutual love and helpfulness to the end that each member and the Fraternity-at-large may attain social, moral, and intellectual excellence. To establish chapters at various colleges and universities, provide for their proper organization, installation, and operation, with each chapter having the right and responsibility to select members of its choice in accordance with Fraternity standards and procedures. To cooperate with colleges and universities where chapters of the Fraternity are established, advance academic interest, and promote higher standards of social conduct. To cooperate with other organizations in solving mutual problems and building higher standards of womanhood. To advocate for and seek to address issues of concern for members and women in general; To promote the establishment and growth of alumnae associations and encourage participation of alumnae in the Fraternity programs; and to have and protect a distinctive and exclusive badge and other insignia of membership and office and keep secret the ritual.
Summary: Our sorority unites a diverse group of women in bonds of friendship and sisterhood that continue for a lifetime. We participate in a variety of UM student organizations, achieve academic excellence, and encourage community philanthropic involvement.

Name: Kappa Kappa Psi / Tau Beta Sigma
Description:
Kappa Kappa Psi and Tau Beta Sigma are the national honorary co-ed band fraternity and sorority, respectively. We support bands on Michigan's campus, and music in our community. We collectively focus on service, musicianship, and leadership. Our bonds of brotherhood and sisterhood are what enable us to be effective at supporting bands nationwide.

Prospective member meetings take place every fall semester. While KKY and TBS have slightly different requirements and approaches to service, our chapters on campus do much of our work together. View our websites for additional information. Please contact us at nulambdaJointOffice@umich.edu if you have any questions.
Summary: We serve band programs at the University of Michigan, as well as promote the existence of bands and music programs nationwide.

Name: Kappa Omega Alpha
Description: We are a Co-ed professional fraternity for pre-law and public policy students. Our membership is divided into an elected Executive Board, members, and potential members. All are welcome to rush either in the fall or winter semester.
Summary: The purpose of this Fraternity shall be to acknowledge undergraduates in pursuing their interests in the fields of law, public policy and criminal justice on both a social and professional scale.

Name: Kappa Phi Lambda
Description: Kappa Phi Lambda is an Asian-Interest (NOT Asian exclusive) Sorority that strives to strengthen sisterhood amongst women by providing service and promoting cultural diversity to our members and our community. We pride ourselves in our diversity, coming from all sorts of cultural backgrounds and interests, that have come together to work toward the goal of promoting service and cultural diversity to the community around us. While each woman is unique, we all have the network and bond of sisterhood within our organization on campus and of those throughout the country that keeps us together that helps us achieve our goals.
Summary: Kappa Phi Lambda, Phi Chapter at The University of Michigan is an Asian-interest sorority, not Asian-exclusive. Our chapter is over 60 sisters strong. Together we stand by the pillars of sisterhood, service, & cultural diversity.

Name: Kappa Theta Pi
Description:
In 2012, this co-ed professional fraternity was founded by a group of Informatics students at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. From business students to computer scientists and user experience designers to young entrepreneurs, Kappa Theta Pi is bonded by a passion for technology. Whether it's forming a startup, developing professional skills, or simply making new friends, Kappa Theta Pi offers a tightly knit community bringing together fresh ideas, perspectives, and experiences.

 

Please do not request to join Kappa Theta Pi on Maize Pages. To join our organization, come to our rush events and apply here.
Summary: The first and only professional co-ed technology fraternity.

Name: Kelsey Museum of Archaeology
Description: The Kelsey Museum of Archaeology supports teaching and research on Classical, Egyptian, and Near Eastern archaeology through stewardship of its rich collections, an active exhibitions program, and sponsorship of ongoing field research. The Kelsey houses a collection of more than 100,000 artifacts, of which approximately 1,500 are on permanent display; in addition, the Museum mounts 2–3 special exhibitions annually. As an exhibiting museum at a public university, the Kelsey embraces a vigorous public outreach mission, engaging with local residents and visitors of all ages, from kindergarten through retirement. It also serves as the headquarters of the University of Michigan’s graduate program in Classical Art and Archaeology.
