Summary: The Kelsey Museum of Archaeology supports teaching and research on Classical, Egyptian, and Near Eastern archaeology through stewardship of its rich collections, an active exhibitions program, and sponsorship of ongoing field research.

Name: Kendo Club at the University of Michigan
Description:
Originally developed as one of the combat skills among the ancient samurai warriors, Kendo has evolved into a modern-day Japanese martial art and competitive sport which is widely practiced around the world. Our club's mission is to provide an opportunity for students and the University community to learn and to enjoy Kendo.

 

Website: michigankendo.com
Summary: Originally developed as one of the combat skills among the ancient samurai warriors, Kendo has evolved into a modern-day Japanese martial art and competitive sport which is widely practiced around the world.

Name: Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Program
Description: KDSAP has two key objectives: student career development and community outreach. KDSAP offers several speaker series and programs each semester that expose students to the scientific and medical professions while facilitating the development of mentor-mentee relationships. KDSAP members may also participate in the community outreach branch, Community Kidney Disease Detection (CKDD). CKDD runs screenings in medically underserved communities per request by the community leaders. KDSAP members have opportunities to develop leadership skills through the organization and management of CKDD screenings while providing kidney health screenings.
Summary: The University of Michigan Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Program provides student members the opportunity to participate in hands-on health screenings in medically underserved communities in order to provide health care to those in need.

Name: Kids in Science at UM
Summary: Kids in Science is an organization dedicated towards conducting science experiments with elementary-age students to enrich their science literacy and interest. Events will consist of a mix of in-person and online formats to engage with children.

Name: Kids' Kitchen
Description: Kids' Kitchen uses cooking as a platform for education and community action towards social change. We promote health and nutrition education through enriching after-school activities for children from under-resourced school districts and low-income neighborhoods in Washtenaw County. We are an organization comprised of University of Michigan students who lead baking activities with the youth at Community Action Network, Mentor2Youth, and Foundations Preschool. During these workshops, we teach developmentally appropriate cooking skills and nutrition to children ranging from ages 3-14. We develop lesson plans using recipes with ingredients that are familiar, nutritious, and inexpensive. Our lesson plans generate excitement for healthy food, as well as curiosity about what makes food good for us and why we need to eat healthfully. We plan hands-on activities that allow the children to do the preparation and cooking themselves. This independence and agency empowers the kids to become engaged in and take ownership of what they are putting into their bodies. Kids' Kitchen recognizes the importance of instilling healthy habits at young ages that will last for a lifetime, and we aim to capitalize on this to improve long-term health behaviors and outcomes.
Summary: Kids' Kitchen uses cooking as a platform for education, health promotion, and community action. We promote health and nutrition education through after-school activities for youth in low-income neighborhoods in Washtenaw County.

Name: KINECTABILITY
Description:
Community Engagement Events: Host events like adaptive sports tournaments, awareness campaigns, or fitness challenges. These events can raise awareness about disabilities and promote community involvement.

 

Online Resource Hub: Create an online platform offering resources, guides, and educational content related to disability, exercise, and wellness. This could include workout videos, nutrition tips, and articles on mental health.

 

Peer Support Networks: Establish peer mentorship programs where individuals with disabilities can connect, share experiences, and offer support to each other.

 

Professional Development Workshops: Offer workshops for students and professionals in kinesiology, focusing on career paths in disability sports, rehabilitation, and therapeutic exercise.
Summary: KINECTABILITY empowers those with disabilities via community events, an online resource hub, peer support networks, and professional development in kinesiology and wellness

Name: Kinesiology for Awareness and Resilience through Exercise
Description: The club brings together University of Michigan Kinesiology students passionate about making a difference in underserved communities. Through mentorship, outreach, and service projects, we aim to educate and inspire kids to embrace exercise, healthy habits, and overall wellness. By fostering meaningful connections, we strive to create a positive impact on their physical and mental health, while also giving our members the opportunity to apply their knowledge and grow as leaders
Summary: The club unites students passionate about helping underserved communities. Through mentorship, outreach, and service, we inspire kids to embrace exercise, healthy habits, and wellness. Members apply knowledge, foster connections, and grow as leaders.

Name: Kinesiology Student Government
Description: Kinesiology Student Government (KSG) strives to better every student’s experience within the School of Kinesiology. In addition to funding Kinesiology student organizations, KSG is constantly working to improve the academic and non-academic life for Kinesiology students. Events range from providing free breakfasts during exam time, to career networking events and panels, to financial literacy courses, and to our annual MLK day symposium. KSG serves to represent and amplify the student voice in order to communicate with administration and create the best experience and opportunities within the school of Kinesiology.
Summary: Kinesiology Student Government (KSG) strives to improve every student’s experience within the School of Kinesiology, serving as a liaison between students and faculty.

Name: Kings 4 Christ
Description: A Christ-led organization dedicated to empowering young men through faith, love, community and biblical teachings
Summary: A Christ-led organization dedicated to empowering young men through faith, love, community and biblical teachings

Name: Konnect
Description: Through campus involvement, our mission is to create an open and fun environment for people interested in learning K-pop dances. Each week is a different dance tutorial alternating between boy groups and girl groups. Additionally, we have a more committed subunit that performs around campus. We welcome anyone of any skill level or experience! Join our email list and follow our socials: https://linktr.ee/konnect_umich
Summary: We are a co-ed K-pop dance group committed to connecting individuals through their love of Korean pop music (K-pop) and dancing. Every week, we have dance workshops on various K-pop, and throughout the year we have a subunit devoted to performances!

Name: Korea Business Club
Description: Korea Business Club at Ross is a graduate student organization open to all MBA students who are interested in Korean cultures, communities and businesses. We provide information, resources, tools and guidance to members for careers in Korea and promote a deeper understanding of Korean business culture within the Ross community.
Summary: To provide information, resources, tools and guidance to members interested in careers in Korea and to promote a deeper understanding of Korean business culture within the Ross Business School community.

Name: Korea Leadership Group
Description:
The Korea Leadership Group aims to connect the various Korean communities at the University of Michigan by increasing interactions with our Alumni, hosting fun social networking events, and serving as a stepping stone for those interested in developing professional skills and personalized career opportunities. Furthermore, we focus on spreading awareness of Korean culture and the recognition of influential Korean leaders in and out of Michigan through our various career fairs, our final summit event, and social networking events. Students will gain insights into Korean business, politics, technology, entertainment, and various other industries of interest from both Michigan Alumni, as well as international speakers.

​

Since our establishment in 2018, we have raised over $40k from our incredible sponsors, and we're honored to host career fairs and summit events with SeAH Holdings, Samsung SDS, Google, Facebook, the Ford Motor Company, the U.S. FDIC, CJ E&M, SM Entertainment, Hanwha, Detroit KOTRA, Groovo, Several Tech Startups, Peaches, and more!

 

Here is a link to our application! 

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScNzWJsTLMMUnpk_6BXUDmBMtEoeTLreocznMXSWblrLA3q8Q/viewform
Summary: KLG was established to build a strong community between students/alumni through both social and academic events. We focus on professional development through career opportunities such as networking sessions, speakers summits, and career workshops.

Name: Korean American Student Association
Description: This association exists to establish and maintain a community that promotes cultural awareness of Korean and Korean American culture at the University of Michigan. Our mission is to empower, inspire, and challenge Korean, Korean American, and non-Korean students to develop an appreciation for cultural diversity and their own heritage through educational, artistic, and social activities with the surrounding communities both on and off the UofM campus.
Summary: KASA is an organization that provides a community to foster friendship between Koreans, Korean-Americans, and non-Korean students while promoting awareness of Korean culture on campus. Check out our linktree to learn more: https://linktr.ee/umich_kasa

Name: Korean Church of Ann Arbor Campus Ministry
Description: The Korean Church of Ann Arbor Campus Ministry is a faith-based organization dedicated to supporting young adults and students in their spiritual journeys. Our mission is to create a welcoming and inclusive community where individuals can explore and deepen their relationship with God. Through regular worship services, engaging Bible studies, and various fellowship and service activities, we aim to foster a nurturing environment that encourages both personal and communal growth in faith. We welcome people from all backgrounds to join us in our mission of spiritual enrichment and communal support, and to be part of a network that strives to make a positive impact on the Ann Arbor campus and beyond.
Summary: The Korean Church of Ann Arbor Campus Ministry fosters spiritual growth and community among young adults and students through worship, Bible studies, and service activities. Join us to deepen your faith and build meaningful connections.

Name: Korean International Student Association
Description:
The Korean International Student Association (KISA) is an organization that promotes the unity and well-being of Korean students at the University of Michigan. KISA is committed to inform and assist incoming students so they can have a smooth adjustment to their new collegiate environment. In order to achieve this goal, we hold a series of cultural and social events that bring incoming and current students together.
 
Please visit our Official Website and Instagram found under the "Contact Information"
Summary: The Korean International Student Association (KISA) is an organization that promotes the unity and well-being of Korean students at the University of Michigan.

Name: Korean Student Association Graduate
Description:
Korean Student Association - Graduate (KSAG) at the University of Michigan is a nonprofit organization for Korean graduate students, visiting scholars, research fellows and faculty community on campus, which add up to approximately 1000 people, to generate greater interaction within the community and to increase awareness about the Korean culture outside the community. Established in 1988, KSAG has vigorously made its effort over the years, to accomplish the following three main goals:

a. To foster and maintain a supportive community of Korean and Korean-American graduate students at the University of Michigan

b. To articulate and promote the needs and goals of Korean and Korean-American graduate students at the University of Michigan

c. To cultivate a greater awareness of Korean Culture and promote its interrelation with other cultural groups and organizations in the University society
Summary: Korean Student Association Graduate at the University of Michigan is a nonprofit organization for Korean graduate students, fellows, and faculty to generate greater interaction within the community and to increase awareness about Korean culture.

Name: Korean Studies Graduate Fellows
Description: This is an interdisciplinary group of graduate students interested in Korean Studies.
Summary: This is an interdisciplinary group of graduate students interested in Korean Studies.

Name: Korean-American Scientists and Engineers Association
Description:
Korean-American Scientists and Engineers Association(KSEA) was established in 1971 as a non-profit professional organization. Today, it has grown to over 3000 registered members with 67 local Chapters (including four branches) and 14 technical groups across the United States (www.ksea.org). 

KSEA YG group at the University of Michigan was established by groups of students back in 2011 to give young, intelligent students opportunities to connect with professionals and develop a broader career foundation as scientists and engineers. 

KSEA at the University of Michigan strives to achieve these objectives by:
1. Promoting academic networking and fellowship among Korean-American students and professionals engaged in engineering, science, and related fields.
2. Providing job and internship opportunities to prepare young professionals for a successful career.
3. Promoting the application of science and technology for the benefits of society
4. Building up international cooperation among Korean-Americans.

KSEA has prepared several events for members to participate in. These events include: 
1. National conferences to provide an opportunity to extend personal networkings with renowned speakers and professionals. 
2. Scholarship and internship programs in the United States and Korea.
3. Activities to promote friendship and fellowship among the members.
4. Joint Conferences with other KSEA YG groups.
5. Career workshops and seminars with professors to reach a better understanding of ways to succeed in related fields.

*Membership is open to any interested undergraduate students who are currently/planning to major/minor in science, engineering, and related fields at the University of Michigan.*
Summary: Korean-American Scientists and Engineers Association (KSEA) YG Group at the University of Michigan is an organization that promotes academic networking and professional development among Korean-American students in the Science and Engineering fields.

Name: Kung Fu Club
Description: Kung Fu is a type of Chinese martial arts and has been part of Chinese culture for thousands of years. Currently, it is a style of performing art as well as a form of exercise. It not only trains every part of the body but also teaches discipline and builds character. At Kung Fu Club, we do traditional style Kung Fu as well as Wushu and Chinese Kickboxing.  There is NO EXPERIENCE NEEDED to join!
Summary: Kung Fu is a type of Chinese martial art that has been part of Chinese culture for thousands of years. It is currently a style of performing art. At the Kung Fu Club, we do traditional style Kung Fu as well as Wushu and Chinese Kickboxing.

Name: La Casa
Description:
La Casa's mission is to promote the advancement and well-being of the Latine community at the University of Michigan through the development of cultural, educational, professional, and social programs and initiatives.

Mass meetings are held every Thursday from 6:30-8PM in the basement of Trotter Multicultural Center.
Summary: Unite, empower, and holistically support members of the Latinx community at the University of Michigan while striving to represent the voice and issues of our community at large.

Name: La Salud
Description:
La Salud is a multicultural student organization at the University of Michigan’s School of Public Health that is passionate about the promotion of and advocacy for Latinx cultures and health. All students who share these interests are welcome to join our organization.

We participate in community events, service activities, networking opportunities and support for students.

Our main objectives are:

  • To serve as a resource to current Public Health students with Latinx health interests as well as to facilitate the transition of incoming Latinx students upon their arrival at the School of Public Health (SPH)
  • To develop a link between SPH students and Latinx communities
  • To serve as a vehicle for leadership development and building the capacities of members to become Public Health professionals.
  • To engage in community service and events
  • To raise awareness about Latinx health issues
Summary: La Salud is the Latinx student organization at the University of Michigan School of Public Health.

Name: Lambda Chi Alpha
Description: Lambda Chi Alpha is an international social fraternity that has been affiliated with The University of Michigan since 1913.  We strive to provide a well-rounded lifestyle for our brothers that holds true to our core values: Loyalty, Duty, Respect, Service and Stewardship, Honor, Integrity, and Personal Courage. All the while providing them with the necessary resources to grow socially, professionally, and personally throughout their collegiate careers.
Summary: Lambda Chi Alpha is a social fraternity that is located at 1601 Washtenaw, diagonal from the Rock.

Name: Lambda Chi Alpha Beta Chapter, Chi Eta Phi Sorority Incorporated
ShortName: CHI ETA PHI SORORITY, INC./LAMBDA CHI ALPHA BETA CHAPTER
Description: International, nonprofit, professional service organization for registered nurses and student nurses, representing many cultures and diverse ethnic backgrounds, with programs focusing on health promotion/disease prevention, leadership development.
Summary: International, nonprofit, professional service organization for registered nurses and student nurses, representing many cultures and diverse ethnic backgrounds, with programs focusing on health promotion/disease prevention, leadership development.

Name: Lambda Phi Epsilon
Description: Lambda Phi Epsilon is the first and only internationally recognized Asian-interest fraternity. Our fraternity's motto is "To Be Leaders Among Men" and we are dedicated to creating such individuals by promoting brotherhood, academics and professional achievement, social interaction, and community service. Although Lambda Phi Epsilon is an Asian-interest fraternity, it is comprised of a diverse group of individuals.
Summary: Lambda Phi Epsilon is an internationally-recognized Asian-interest fraternity in the United States and Canada. Being the largest Asian-interest fraternity, Lambda Phi Epsilon continues to expand to other campuses every year.

Name: Lambda Theta Alpha Latin Sorority, Inc. - Beta Omicron Chapter
Description: We provide social and cultural activities, and carry on charitable and educational programs.
Summary: The purpose of Lambda Theta Alpha shall be to provide a sisterhood based on unity, love, and respect. To promote leadership, maintain high academic standards, and serve as a voice for the Latino community.

Name: Lambda Theta Phi, Latin Fraternity Inc. Alpha Omicron Chapter
Description:
On December 1, 1975, history was made – history on a college campus, which would transcend other colleges/universities throughout the United States; history which would have a positive impact on the Latino community and our nation; history which would forever change the Greek system, more specifically, the entity known as a fraternity. On December 1, 1975, Lambda Theta Phi was founded on the campus of Kean College in Union, New Jersey.

In 1975, there were no Latino fraternities in existence in the United States. The Greek-letter organizations of the time primarily catered to Anglo and African-American students and graduates. Lambda’s founders, as men of vision, realized there was a need to unite the Latino students, develop their leadership skills, impart upon them the value of an education, and instill in them a commitment to their community and culture. The traditional student club would not suffice to accomplish such lofty goals. Hence, Latino unity and brotherhood would be achieved through a long recognized institution – the fraternity. This newest addition to the Greek system would be the first in the nation, by identity and by name: Lambda Theta Phi Latin Fraternity, Incorporated.

The ideals of this brotherhood are the following: Academic Excellence; Brotherhood; Leadership; Latino Unity; Service. On a daily basis, our brothers live up to these ideals, as set forth by fourteen young Latino men decades ago. 

At the undergraduate level, our brothers are active within the Fraternity and in other student organizations. Our brothers perform community service, promote our culture by sponsoring events which highlight and celebrate our heritage, participate in educational workshops, and enjoy many social programs. As a result of their active participation in every aspect of college life, our undergraduates are developing their organizational, communication, and leadership skills, all while pursuing the coveted diploma. Our younger Lambdas are receiving the training and competence to serve as the future leaders of our brotherhood, community, and nation. 

At the professional level, among our ranks you will find attorneys, doctors, and engineers. Our brothers are shaping young minds as educators and as dedicated fathers. The men in brown and white are defending this country at home and abroad in the area of law enforcement and in the armed forces. We are strengthening our country’s economy as entrepreneurs. Our brothers are teaching leadership as coaches, mentors, and community activists. The Lambdas are affecting policy and change as elected officials serving on City Councils, Boards of Education, U.S. House of Representatives, and U.S. Senate. In short, Lambdas are contributing and excelling in every facet of human endeavor. 

Since our founding, Lambda Theta Phi has established chapters in every region of the country at both the undergraduate and professional levels. Our brotherhood continues to provide the necessary skills and resources for the advancement and empowerment of our people and for the betterment of this nation. 

Our illustrious history is not only our past but our guiding light to the future. As the first, we overcame many obstacles. Not having much guidance in our formative stages, we persevered and became stronger. Lambda is the product of vision, strength, and unity. Our history serves as a legacy and testament to our accomplishments and greatness.

Lambda Theta Phi … Academic Excellence – Brotherhood – Leadership – Latino Unity -Service.
Summary: The ideals of this brotherhood are the following: Academic Excellence; Brotherhood; Leadership; Latino Unity; Service. On a daily basis, our brothers live up to these ideals, as set forth by fourteen young Latino men decades ago.

Name: Language Matters
Description:
Language Matters is an interdisciplinary initiative at the University of Michigan to increase recognition of the role of language diversity in creating inclusive classrooms and an inclusive campus climate more generally.

We aim to build knowledge on campus about language variation and change, providing new understandings of our everyday experience of language and of each other as speakers, writers, and signers. Through the creation of outreach programs and online resources, Language Matters is geared toward creating an empathetic and inclusive atmosphere between students, staff, faculty, and surrounding communities.

The purpose of this initiative is to promote a recognition that “grammaticality and and communicative effectiveness are distinct and independent issues” (Lippi-Green 2011) and that all speakers utilize valid — if varied — systems of communication. We seek to encourage a celebration of linguistic diversity in all of its forms, and to discourage widespread practices of linguistic discrimination that engender disparities at the personal and group level across institutions of higher education.
Summary: Language Matters is an interdisciplinary initiative at the University of Michigan to increase recognition of the role of language diversity in creating inclusive classrooms and an inclusive campus climate more generally.

Name: Late Night
Description: Late Night is the University of Michigan’s first Live! Late Night talk show beginning fall of 2024. Inspired by the likes of Conan O’Brien, David Letterman, and Seth Meyers-d amongst many others. Each semester will be spent carefully preparing one 60-minute show to be put on mid week at the end of each semester. The show requires teamwork on all levels, and we would be happy to have you!
Summary: Late Night is the University of Michigan’s first Live! Late Night talk show beginning fall of 2024.

Name: Latin American Business Student Association
Description: The Latin American Business Students Association is a graduate student organization open to all MBA students who are interested in Latin cultures and communities. Our goal is to provide a stimulating and supportive network to LABSA members by: 1) Building and fostering the network among current students. 2) Advancing the awareness of Latin culture at Ross Business School. 3) Supporting students interested in careers in the US and Latin America. 4) Assisting international student's transition into Ross Business School life. 5) Facilitating communication among Ross alumni and current students. 6) Enhancing Ross brand in Latin America and within Latin communities in the US.
Summary: The Latin American Business Students Association is a student organization open to all graduate students who are interested in Latin cultures and communities. Our goal is to provide a stimulating and supportive network to LABSA members.

Name: Latin American Native American Medical Association
Description:
LANAMA was founded in 1985 to provide a more welcoming and supportive environment for our Native American and Latino/a medical students at the University of Michigan Medical School (UMMS). We recognize the pressing need to address the alarming health disparities of the Latino and Native American communities, and are therefore committed to increasing awareness and promoting service in these communities among all students at the University of Michigan Medical School. In addition, we aim to increase the enrollment, graduation, and future leadership of Latino/a, Native American, and allied medical students through an academic, social, and professional network, as well as a nurturing atmosphere of la familia. We have identified the following key efforts as necessary to accomplishing these goals:

  • To recruit Latino/a and Native American students and allies to UMMS by promoting the interests of LANAMA through admissions efforts during the application process and once admitted
  • To retain Latino/a and Native American students at UMMS by providing an academic, social and professional support network and development for its members
  • To provide health outreach in our Native American and Latino communities through health fairs and volunteering at clinics
  • To improve faculty and alumni relations in order to foster mentor relationships with current medical students
  • To increase awareness and discussion of Latino/a and Native American health issues amongst members and the greater medical school community through speakers, conferences and consistent curriculum improvement
  • To celebrate the Latino and Native American cultures through social and educational events
  • To increase outreach to Latino and Native American high school students and undergraduates to foster interest and leadership in the medical professions
Summary: We recognize the pressing need to address the alarming health disparities of the Latino and Native American communities, and are therefore committed to increasing awareness and promoting service in these communities among all students at the UMMS.

Name: Latinos/Hispanics United in Aerospace
Description: Established in March 2023, LUNA is dedicated to fostering a greater sense of community within the Aerospace Engineering Department, the greater Aerospace Industry and improving the retention of Latino/Hispanic engineering students at the University of Michigan.
Summary: LUNA is dedicated to fostering a sense of community and improving the retention of Latino/Hispanic engineering students focusing on Aerospace/Space Engineering at the University of Michigan.

Name: Latinx Indigenous Social Work Alliance
Description: The mission of the Latinx Social Work Coalition is to promote the academic and social well-being of the Latinx and Indigenous community at the School of Social Work including Afro-Latinx, as well as the Latinx community at large, through the praxis of social justice, cultural empowerment, and community building.
Summary: The mission of LISWA is to promote the academic, social, and mental well-being of the Latinx community, including Afro-Latinx and and Indigenous students, at the School of Social Work.

Name: Latinx Law Students Association
Description: LLSA is a place for Latinx law students to socialize together, provide support, mentorship, and community, as well as work hard to increase awareness of the Latinx community and recruitment.
Summary: LLSA is a place for Latinx law students to socialize together, provide support, mentorship, and community, as well as work hard to increase awareness of Latinx issues and recruitment.

Name: Latinx Student Psychological Association
Description:
The Latinx Student Psychological Association (LSPA) is a graduate student organization at the University of Michigan that strives to increase the recruitment and retention of Latinx students in the fields of psychology. As such, LSPA’s mission is threefold: to provide a supportive and diverse learning environment for its graduate student members, to serve as advocates for the Latinx community, and to educate the greater academic community on issues that affect Latinx and other ethnic minority groups. Throughout the year, LSPA holds several events for its members and for the larger campus and Latinx community, including lectures.

Although a Latinx-oriented psychology organization existed briefly in the 1980's it became defunct a few years later. In 1996, a group of students who believed in the importance of creating a supportive community for Latinx students formed The Latinx Student Psychological Association, which has been active since then.

Membership is open to graduate students, faculty, and staff at the University of Michigan who self-identify as Latinx and/or are committed to supporting the Latino community. LSPA invites participation from all members of the University of Michigan community and abides by the University of Michigan's non-discrimination policy.
Summary: The Latinx Student Psychological Association (LSPA) is a graduate student organization at the University of Michigan that strives to increase the recruitment and retention of Latino students in psychology.

Name: Latinx Undergraduate Legal Association
Description: LULA was established with the aim of catering to the needs of Latinx undergraduate students at the University of Michigan who aspire to pursue a legal education (pre-law) or work in the legal sector. The primary objective of LULA is to strengthen and assist Latinx students as they pursue a career in law, foster a sense of community among Latinx individuals both on and off campus, and promote advocacy for the Latinx community within the legal field.
Summary: LULA was established with the aim of catering to the needs of Latinx undergraduate students at the University of Michigan who aspire to pursue a legal education or work in the legal sector.

Name: Latinx Undergraduate Medical Association
Description:
LUMA was formed to address the needs of Latinx undergraduate prehealth students at the University of Michigan. The mission of LUMA is to empower and support Latinx students on their journey toward a healthcare career and encourage health and wellness within the Latinx community. 

 

Our immediate objectives include:

  1. Encouraging Latinx individuals who exhibit the potential to benefit their community to enter the health professions programs.
  2. Retaining our members' commitment in the health professions programs by supporting academic and social support activities and by fostering close ties among members.
  3. Educating ourselves in areas of concern to our communities which may not be part of the school’s curricula, such as preventive and community medicine, politics of health care systems, mechanics of urban city primary care, and family practice.
  4. The orientation of our members towards actively accepting our principles of unity and aims of our organization.
  5. Community involvement for the purpose of strengthening working relationships with community groups and the overall aim of benefiting the community. 
  6. Support and encourage prospective health professions school applicants throughout the admissions process.
  7. Writing and circulating our ideas and fostering the refinement and development of research skills among our members.
  8. Sensitizing and educating our undergraduate community to the specific needs and differences of the Latinx community regarding health and human well being.
  9. Fostering opportunities for mentorship from medical students in order to provide guidance to members.
Summary: The purpose of LUMA is to acknowledge the health needs of the Latinx community, as well as to promote the interests and support of those undergraduate healthcare students who identify themselves as Latinx students of the University of Michigan.

Name: Law and Economics Society
Description: The Law and Economics Society (LES) at the University of Michigan Law School exists to facilitate engagement with law and economics at the University of Michigan Law School by allowing and encouraging student inquiry, discussion, and debate about canonical and novel topics in the law and economics school of thought. LES seeks to host speaker events, reading and discussion groups, and generally promote law and economics as a mode of legal analysis and thought at the Law School.
Summary: The Law and Economics Society (LES) at the University of Michigan Law School aims to foster an inclusive, accessible, and welcoming environment while facilitating open and constructive dialogue revolving around the intersection of law and economics.

Name: Law School Hockey Team
Description: The hockey team is an excellent way to meet a great group of your fellow law students, to get involved with a team, to ensure you are getting some good, regular exercise, to network with graduate students in other programs, and to have a lot of fun during your time at Michigan Law School.
Summary: The Law School Hockey Team provides an opportunity to students who have an interest in playing ice hockey during the academic year while enrolled at the law school.

Name: Law School Student Senate
Description: The Law School Student Senate is the elected student government of the University of Michigan Law School. We engage in policy advocacy and host various events for all Law students, including socials, networking opportunities, and academic programming. We empower and enhance law student wellness, engagement, education, accessibility, and inclusion.
Summary: The Law School Student Senate is the student government at the University of Michigan Law School.

Name: Law Students for Justice in Palestine
Description: LSJP advocates for Palestinian liberation academically and legally. In doing so, we aim to combat human rights-abusing and anti-Palestinian voices within legal and academic spheres.
Summary: LSJP advocates for Palestinian liberation academically and legally. In doing so, we aim to combat human rights-abusing and anti-Palestinian voices within legal and academic spheres.

Name: Le Comité Francophone
Description:
Le Comité Francophone, the French club at the University of Michigan, aims to create an inclusive space for French speakers of all levels to practice their French and connect with others of different backgrounds, as well as to foster the learning of French and Francophone cultures in a flexible and fun environment. Join us for relaxed conversations to develop your speaking skills while also learning about different experiences and possibilities through French. Some yearly event staples include outdoor walks and picnics, French movie screenings, game nights, cooking soirées, as well as soccer tournaments and Yost Skating outings. We would also love to hear your ideas about other events we could host! LCF further provides members with opportunities through which to exercise their skills, such as becoming a tutor for other French students. 
 
Conversation Hours: Wednesdays 7-8pm @ Amer's on State St.  
 

Tutoring Hours: 

Here is our list of tutors and their availabilities for winter 2025: 

  • Clara Borie - cborie@umich.edu (Monday 9-11am; Wednesday 9-11am; Friday 2pm-5pm) 

  • Mariam Mandwee - mmandwee@umich.edu (Monday from 10-11am or 1-5pm; Tuesdays 1-2pm; Wed from 10-11 or from 1-5pm; Thurs 1-2pm; Fri 10-11am or 1-3pm; Sat noon-6pm)

  • Nat Johnson - nataljo@umich.edu (Week-ends, fridays, tue/thurs afternoon through evening, mon/wed after 5:30)

  • Rowan Hillegeist - rowanmgh@umich.edu (Wednesdays after 1, thursday between 10-1, friday after 2)

  • Yashvi Shukla - yshukla@umich.edu (Monday 3-5 pm; Tuesday 5-6 pm; Wednesday 1-4 pm; Friday 2-4 pm)

Follow us on Facebook, our Instagram (@lcfumich), and join our GroupMe!
Summary: Le Comité Francophone seeks to unite francophiles across campus for conversation hours and French cultural events.

Name: Leaders for Ethical A.I. Development Now
Description: This organization will mobilize around the adverse social, economic, and geopolitical consequences of unregulated AI development. We will explore potential policy regulations through article readings, speaker events, documentary screenings, and more. Interested parties can contact amelillo@umich.edu for more information.
Summary: This organization will mobilize around the adverse social, economic, and geopolitical consequences of unregulated AI development. We will explore potential policy regulations through article readings, speaker events, documentary screenings, and more.

Name: LEAPS Socials and Services
Description: LEAPS Socials and Services is a student organization that aims to create a diverse, equitable, and inclusive community targeted for both Learning, Equity, and Problem Solving for the Public Good (LEAPS) students and Ann Arbor students through various community bonding events on both the Marygrove and Ann Arbor campuses at the University of Michigan. Most events will take place on the Marygrove campus. These events include cultural dinners where students of all backgrounds can learn about their fellow members’ cultural upbrings and identities. Trips to Downtown Detroit to learn more about the city LEAPS students live in, as well as more laid-back meetings where we can play sports or board games around the Florent-Gillet Hall. Members will also participate in different activities to learn more information about each other’s cultural background.
Summary: LEAPS Socials and Services is a student organization that aims to create relationships between both Learning, Equity, and Problem Solving for the Public Good (LEAPS) students and Ann Arbor students through various community bonding events.

Name: Learning, Empowerment, and Achievement Program
Description:
LEAP (Learning, Empowerment, and Achievement Program) is a volunteer organization committed to serving underprivileged members of our community and reducing disparity in college admissions between low and high-income students. America's higher education system is often a major step in creating a professional career, but differences in income between applicants to colleges and universities can give major advantages to some, including personal college advisors, standardized test tutors, and application essay help.

LEAP's mission is to offer many of these advantages to students who may otherwise not be able to afford them by providing free college counseling and standardized test tutoring services. Volunteers with LEAP will meet virtually or in person with students in the program and help them with whatever college-admissions related questions or services they may need. We are in connection with local (Ann Arbor, Ypsilanti area) schools and community centers who pass along this information to students who may need it.

Getting involved in LEAP is a great way to earn volunteer hours in a meaningful way! The relationships created with students and the opportunities tutors offer to these students are truly incredible. Tutoring guidelines, resources, and contacts will be provided by LEAP, and at least one hour of tutoring each week (virtual or in person) is required as a member. Schedules for tutoring are arranged with the tutor and their student. 

LEAP is continuously accepting applications. Please submit an application if you are interested in getting involved, or use the email listed below to request more information!
Summary: LEAP is a volunteer organization that provides free-of-charge college counseling and standardized test tutoring services to local high school students in order to reduce disparity in college admissions between low and high-income students.

Name: Lebanese Diaspora Relief Organization at Umich
Description: Our mission is to provide essential food, medical aid, and financial support to vulnerable families in Lebanon and Palestine, especially those without the backing of government or political groups. For years, we have been committed to ensuring access to basic necessities, offering consistent aid to families facing economic hardships and those impacted by ongoing conflicts, particularly in South Lebanon and Gaza.
Summary: We are a service based organization with the aims of expanding the current LDRO to the University of Michigan, to continue the efforts of the late Hajj Kamel Jawad by raising money for aid and other necessities for displaced families across Lebanon.

Name: Lebanese Student Association
Description: The Lebanese Student Association is an organization aiming to unite and serve the Lebanese community on campus while educating the general student body of the University of Michigan about Lebanese culture and society. The association is committed to benefiting the Lebanese, the non-Lebanese and non-Arab communities while promoting Lebanese culture and heritage, thus adding to the diversity of the campus, as well as increasing public awareness about Lebanese. This organization is neither religious, nor political.
Summary: To promote Lebanese heritage and culture on campus, and unite students with an interest in Lebanon or who are of Lebanese descent. To be the voice of Lebanese students on campus and serve our community.

Name: Legal Alternative Winter Breaks
Description:
Legal Alternative Winter Breaks (LAWBreaks) offers service-learning experiences for Michigan Law students during the traditional Winter Break of the academic calendar (usually beginning of March). The trips are designed to provide a brief immersion into the human side of a pressing legal or social justice issue. Students meet and work together with actors on many sides of the relevant issues, contribute to important social justice work, and have a chance to bond with fellow students outside of the law school.

LAW Breaks began in 2011, when a small group of 1Ls decided to spend their spring breaks helping immigrants in Arizona. The following year, our organization returned to Arizona and added trips to New Orleans and South Dakota. Since that time, we have traveled to different sites in the US and around the world, and the program continues to grow!
Summary: Legal Alternative Winter Breaks (LAW Breaks) offers service-learning experiences for Michigan Law students during the traditional Spring Break of the academic calendar.

Name: Letters of Love Club at the University of Michigan
Description: The Letters of Love chapter at the University of Michigan strives to provide emotional support to children battling chronic illnesses in long-term care with hand-made cards filled with love and kindness. We want to make sure that every child feels loved and supported and knows they have a whole team fighting for them each and every day.
Summary: The Letters of Love chapter at the University of Michigan strives to provide emotional support to children battling chronic illnesses in long-term care with hand-made cards filled with love and kindness.

Name: Letters That Lift
Description: Letters That Lift is an organization dedicated to supporting and empowering individuals through the power of handwritten letters. We focus on providing uplifting, positive messages to people who may be experiencing challenging circumstances, such as those facing illness, loneliness, or personal struggles. We believe in the impact of a heartfelt, handwritten note to inspire hope, strength, and positivity in others. Through its network of volunteers and donors, Letters That Lift sends messages of encouragement, love, and solidarity to individuals, helping them feel seen, valued, and supported.
Summary: Letters That Lift is an organization dedicated to supporting and empowering individuals through the power of handwritten letters.

Name: Let’s PLAY at University of Michigan Medical School
Description: Let’s PLAY is a medical student run organization that provides after school programming for elementary students in local under resourced schools. Our goal is to promote physical activity and healthy lifestyles to help lower obesity rates in children.
Summary: Let’s PLAY is a medical student run organization that provides after school programming for elementary students in local under resourced schools. Our goal is to promote physical activity and healthy lifestyles to help lower obesity rates in children.

Name: LGBTQ+ Nursing
Description: LGBTQ+ Nursing is a student-led organization focused on building connections among LGBTQ+ nursing students, faculty, and other healthcare students and professionals to foster an inclusive environment and improve nursing practice and education.
Summary: LGBTQ+ Nursing is a student-led organization focused on building connections among LGBTQ+ nursing students, faculty, and other healthcare students and professionals to foster an inclusive environment and improve nursing practice and education.

Name: LIFE Campus Ministry
Description:
LIFE is an acronym for Living In Faith Everyday!

 

This organization is a Christian group that aims to challenge modern religious ideology and facilitate critical thought for students of every background. There are two main ways by which this is done:

 

1. Non-partisan, open group discussions

These last anywhere from 15-30 minutes and are open to those of any background (religious or not). It includes examining a biblical passage(s) and its application to our world today.

 

2. Personal Bible Studies

Since these are individualized, the timeframe varies. There is a set Bible study series through which people learn to deepen their faith and spiritual journey.

 

Come join us to learn more about us as well as yourself!
Summary: LIFE is a Christian student organization that provides personal Bible studies to help develop an individual's faith and contribute to community faith. There are non-partisan discussions held too, open to people of any religious/non-religious background.

Name: Lifestyle Medicine Interest Group
Description:
A group of prevention-oriented medical students focused on the following objectives:

  • Provide educational opportunities for students interested in Lifestyle Medicine to
  • Learn about the profession in practice.
  • Increase student awareness of the latest advances and research in LifestyleMedicine.
  • Expose students to career opportunities in Lifestyle Medicine.
  • Inform students at all stages of training about the activities of ACLM and encourage outreach activities that foster the goals and objectives of the ACLM.
  • Provide students interested in Lifestyle Medicine with opportunities for professional advancement and leadership development.
  • Establish or improve Lifestyle Medicine curriculum at medical and health professions schools through faculty and student advocacy.
  • Cultivate multi-institutional, student-initiated programming.
  • Promote a healthier and happier lifestyle for student members of each chapter and lead by example for local communities and the world at large.
  • Develop Lifestyle Medicine initiatives that support healthy habits for medical students, residents, and attending physicians, as well as the local community.
  • Collaborate with other ACLM LMIG groups to share best practices.
Summary:
A group of prevention-oriented medical students interested in the field of Lifestyle Medicine (LM). This group meets on a regular basis to learn more about LM, work towards increasing awareness on
campus, share best practices, and gain exposure to LM.

Name: Lift the Mask Club at UMich
Description: We want to “Lift the Mask” on the stigma of mental health. The Quell Foundation is dedicated to providing awareness, access and training around mental health subjects. Lift the Mask Club provides resources (hotline, websites, organizations) to the members of our club that relate to that topic of the meetings. The club is sponsored by the Quell Foundation. The first step is conversation. Following that we want to promote psychological first aid (appropriate recognition and response).
Summary: Improving student wellness and recognition/response to signs of mental distress.

Name: Linguistics Department
Description: Language plays a central role in human development, cognition, interaction, and activity. The discipline of linguistics takes this central role of language as its starting point. Some of the most important developments in the field involve a deepening understanding of human cognitive abilities, a stronger reliance on models of natural language in computer science, a better awareness of the place of language in matters of social justice and equality, and an increased integration of interdisciplinary scholarship about language. The Department of Linguistics at the University of Michigan is one of the few departments in the United States that captures the inherent breadth of the discipline by exploring the cognitive, interactional, cultural, and developmental aspects of language. Faculty and students explore language structure, history, knowledge, behavior, and use.
Summary: The Department of Linguistics at the University of Michigan is one of the few departments in the United States that captures the inherent breadth of the discipline by exploring the cognitive, interactional, cultural, and developmental aspects of language

Name: Lions Club International
Description: Lions Club is established for the expressed purpose of developing community leaders of University of Michigan students. Lions Club is to empower student leaders to serve their communities, meet humanitarian needs, encourage peace, and promote international understanding. All Lions clubs around the world strive to be global leaders in the community and humanitarian service. We do community service around Ann Arbor working with organizations, such as Special Olympics, Eversight Eye Bank, Ronald McDonald House, Food Gatherers, and many more.
Summary: We are a service-learning club that develops projects and activities to meet the unique needs of our campus, local and world communities. We are a passionate group of students devoted to serving their community.

Name: Living Business Leadership Experience
Description: Living Business Leadership Experience (LBLE) is a 3.0 credit-hour action-based elective course that aids students in enhancing their leadership and project management potential within a real-world business environment. LBLE provides students with an opportunity to work in a cross-functional team of graduate and upper-level undergraduate students from across the University to shape, implement, and lead high-impact business initiatives alongside company founders and senior leaders.
Summary: Living Business Leadership Experience (LBLE) is a 3.0 credit-hour action-based elective course that aids students in enhancing their leadership and project management potential within a real-world business environment.

Name: Living Grace Ministry
Description: Living Grace Ministry strives to live out grace practically in the Ann Arbor community. In the world today, grace is often in short supply. Even in churches, we do not always reflect the radical grace of Jesus Christ that would welcome ANYONE to come and that would call us to value even the least amongst us. Living Grace Ministry is a community where we want to see true transformation so that we can love God and love neighbor perfectly, and we want to encourage people to do so through love, forgiveness, and grace, not through judgment or guilt. Living Grace Ministry is one ministry of the Korean United Methodist Church of Ann Arbor. On Sundays, we worship together with other age-groups at our physical church building which is a short five-minute drive from campus. Our campus ministry has a number of events and activities that take place on and around campus, including a vibrant network of small groups. We are Christ-centered, outreach and mission-minded, and dedicated to training and equipping disciples and leaders. All are welcome to join our growing community of Christ. You are not alone!
Summary: Living Grace Ministry is a branch of the Korean United Methodist Church. We are an organization that strives to live out grace practically in the Ann Arbor community.

Name: Living PROOF at the University of Michigan
Description: PROOF is a faith-based group of Jesus followers and seekers investigating the scientific, archeological, logical, and historical evidence that supports the accuracy of the Bible, and a Biblical worldview regarding God, Jesus Christ, and all related issue
Summary: PROOF is a faith-based group of Jesus followers and seekers investigating the scientific, archeological, logical, and historical evidence that supports the accuracy of the Bible, and a Biblical worldview regarding God, Jesus Christ, and all related issue

Name: LNF User Committee
Description: The LNF User Committee is a group of LNF lab users who advise and give feedback to the LNF staff from a student/lab user perspective, and work on ways to improve the lab, promote student camaraderie, stimulate professional interactions among users, and improve the lab community and environment for LNF users.
Summary: LNF lab users who advise and give feedback to the LNF staff from a student/lab user perspective, and work on ways to improve the lab, promote student camaraderie, stimulate professional interactions among users, & improve the lab community for LNF users.

Name: Lord of Light Lutheran Campus Ministry
Description: Lord of Light - Lutheran Campus Ministry is a campus congregation serving students, faculty, and staff at the University of Michigan, as well as our wider neighborhood. Deeply rooted in a tradition of social justice, we are committed to showing God's love to all people. We are openly and intentionally welcoming and affirming of everyone as beloved creations of God: Of any gender identity or expression, sexual orientation, ethnicity, denomination, or faith. We explicitly reject systems of white supremacy, and we are committed to working for racial justice and equality. In our dual role as campus ministry and congregation, we gather undergraduate and graduate students, faculty, staff, and local community members together for worship, fellowship, and service activities.
Summary: Deeply rooted in a tradition of social justice, we are committed to showing God's love to all people. We are openly and intentionally welcoming and affirming of everyone as beloved creations of God.

Name: Los Salseros Azules
Description:
Los Salseros Azules is a salsa dance team at the University of Michigan that focuses on teaching the basic steps/moves for salsa dancing and student-choregraphed routines for performances (although members will not be forced to perform, and can come just to learn). Other Latin dances (bachata, merengue, etc.) may also be taught and performed.
NO DANCING EXPERIENCE is necessary in order to participate! The club is also a great way to meet new people and form connections with teammates and other members. There are many performances over the year at a variety of events, and practice is 2 days a week.
Summary: Los Salseros Azules is a Latin dance team focusing on salsa and other partner dances. Members learn how to dance in both performative and social aspects, and performances exhibiting student-made and student-taught choreography happen throughout the year.

Name: LSA Student Government
Description:
The Mission of LSA Student Government is to;

"actively seek the voices of LSA students and advocate their interests to improve academic and non-academic life," - LSA Student Government Constitution, Article II.

LSASG has four main responsibilities to LSA students:

  1. Changing Policy: LSA SG will seek a continuous role for LSA students in College policy and decision-making when student interests are involved.
    For example: LSA SG has lobbied on behalf of student interest on such issues as setting a precedent of exam-free election days.
  2. Improving Well-Being: LSA SG works to improve the quality of both academic and non-academic life for the students of LSA.
    For example: LSASG hosts a Study Break event during exam weeks, offering free items, including Green Books and food. 
  3. Protecting Rights: LSA SG protects the rights of LSA students.
    For example: LSA SG advocated on behalf of a Gender-Neutral Housing option.
  4. Representing Students: LSA SG serves as the representative voice of LSA students pertaining to academics and their general welfare both on and around campus.
    For example: LSA SG worked with administration to create the International Studies Minor due to growing demand from LSA students.
Summary: The Government shall serve as the representative voice of the Student Body of the College of LS&A on issues that pertain to academics and the general welfare of the students of the College and the University, both on and around the campus.

Name: LSA Student Honor Council
Description:
The LSA Student Honor Council is a council of students that promotes a culture of integrity on campus by encouraging the practice of academic integrity. We partner with other students, faculty and staff to facilitate understanding of the College’s academic integrity standards. Honor Council holds campus events throughout the year to spur dialogue about integrity, engages academic departments and faculty in discussion about promoting academic integrity and preventing academic misconduct, and collaborates with other College offices and programs to instill the values of integrity in all aspects of University life.

 

Some things we do:

• Provide student voice at hearings for students alleged for academic misconduct
• Present seminars about academic integrity to students, faculty, campus leadership, etc.
• Discuss ethics and integrity at meetings
• Collaborate with academic leadership about LSA policies and initiatives
• Host an annual speaker event

The LSA Student Honor Council meets every Monday from 7-8pm. 

 

Admission to the Council is rolling.
Summary: The LSA Student Honor Council exists to promote a culture of integrity in our academic community.  We work with faculty, students and administration to encourage those at University of Michigan to uphold community standards and do their best work.

Name: Lunar Doula Support Network
Description: LDSN supports and complements the work of the Lunar Doula Collective, which provides emotional, physical, and informational support to those undergoing reproductive loss in Southeast Michigan. LDSN serves to educate and train LDC volunteers as well as community members on how to provide support for those experiencing miscarriage, stillbirth, or pregnancy termination. We strive to honor the reproductive justice framework by creating a nonjudgmental space in which sexual and reproductive health equity is essential for all human beings regardless of sexual, racial, and gender identities.
Summary: LDSN's mission is to normalize social discourse surrounding reproductive health through community education and training on how to support individuals through pregnancy loss and abortion.

Name: Léim Irish Dance
Description:
The University of Michigan's first Irish Dance group was started in 2000 by a group of five students. Having been trained in Irish Dance at various levels, they sought to create an opportunity for others like them to continue dancing upon arriving at the University and to teach those who had never had the chance to do so before.

The group has since progressed to a full-fledged performance group, gaining an official name and recognition both on and off campus. We put on an annual show which has been showcased at the Michigan Theater and the Mendelssohn Theater, along with various events on campus, including Springfest and the Parent's Weekend Tailgate. But our performances aren't just limited to on campus events- Léim Irish dancers enjoy performing at events like Midnight Madness in downtown Ann Arbor, and collaborating with local schools and assisted living facilities. We also compete in intercollegiate Irish dance competitions against other university teams from across the country. Members have various ability levels ranging from years of training to those just having begun in college.
Summary: Léim Irish Dance is a student-run performance group. Our goal is to bring the fun of Irish dancing to the University of Michigan and Ann Arbor community. Any student is welcome to join, regardless of previous experience!

Name: M-agination Films/UAC
Description:
M-Agination is a student-run film production group at the University of Michigan. In production, students are responsible for writing, directing, camera work, and everything in between. This is a group that welcomes all kinds of creativity and experience level. We select projects from student submissions throughout the year for our Annual M-agination Film Festival at the Michigan Theater in April. For more information, contact us at magquestions@umich.edu

Interested in our past work? Check out our Vimeo page! https://vimeo.com/user1636777
Summary: Provides an opportunity for students in and outside the film school to write, direct, edit, and produce their own and other students' work, culminating in a final showing at the end of winter semester at the Michigan Theater.

Name: M-durance
Description:
M-durance is an engineering design team, driven by a passion for motorsports, to compete in endurance races throughout the year. The club will focus on building skills required to work on real cars, which are absent for most students, thus giving students an appreciation for auto technicians and mechanics.

The club's strategy will be driven by a core principle: '$ spent per lap,' and students will get to best optimize multiple elements of the vehicle, including suspension, powertrain, exhaust, aero, etc. to build a safe and reliable performance car.
Summary: M-durance aims to develop a race car out of an older model-year vehicle and test the equipment's and the team's durability.

Name: M-Engin Academy
Description:
WHAT IS M-ENGIN?

M-Engin is the Michigan-Engineering-specific program within the university’s M-STEM Academies. Our goal is to maximize the academic, personal, and professional success of our students and prepare them for the global workforce.

M-Engin students form a community within Michigan Engineering with shared activities. The 2-year program begins with a pre-freshman six-week summer transition program and includes customized advising, career guidance, learning enrichment activities, and assistance in obtaining a paid professional summer internship or research opportunity.

 

WHAT IS M-SCI? 

M-Sci is a two-year program for students interested in any of the natural sciences and mathematics and who have been admitted to the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts of the University of Michigan.  The sciences and mathematics at LSA include a wide range of majors offered through the departments of Astronomy; Biophysics; Chemistry; Earth and Environmental Sciences; Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Mathematics; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; and Statistics.

The program begins with an intensive summer residential academic program followed by two years of special programming. The M-Sci Program is designed to strengthen and diversify the cohort of students who will receive their degrees in science or mathematics from the University of Michigan. Upon graduation, students who participate in M-Sci will be exceptionally well prepared to seek career opportunities or to attend graduate or professional school in the sciences or mathematics.

For more info check out the M-STEM Academies Website
Summary: The M-STEM (Michigan Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) Academies is a joint program between the College of Engineering and the College of LSA designed to provide students a foundation to be the future leaders and contributors to the world

Name: M-Flicks/UAC
Description:
• M-Flicks is a student run organization that hosts big-name screenings, sneak previews, and trivia nights in collaboration with Film and Television distributors for Michigan students free of charge. They aim to create a community on campus for those who love video and film entertainment.
  • https://www.facebook.com/mflicks/
  • https://www.instagram.com/umflicks/
  • https://www.linkedin.com/company/65710963/admin/
Summary: We provide free screenings of feature films on campus, ranging from exclusive sneak previews to recent blockbusters.

Name: M-Fly
Description:
M-Fly is a student design team that designs and builds airplanes. We design airplanes from scratch, build them by hand, flight-test them, and then compete with teams from around the world. Our members, from freshmen to seniors of all academic backgrounds, are involved in every step along the way, from a crude whiteboard sketch to a soaring RC airplane.

M-Fly competes in 3 competitions: SAE Regular Class, SAE Advanced Class, and the SUAS Autonomous Competition. That means 3 planes! We do aerodynamic simulations, structural analysis, flight hardware integration, autopilot path planning, computer vision, and much more. As a member of M-Fly, you'll learn the practical details of designing and building your own aircraft. You'll apply what you learn in the classroom to complex, real-world, engineering challenges.

M-Fly is open to students of all majors and class standings. There are also opportunities for those seeking experience in business operations, and graphic design. No application and no previous experience is required! Contact us if you have any questions!
Summary: The goal of M-Fly is to design, build, test, and fly aircraft in a collaborative, hands-on learning environment. We compete each year in the SAE International Aero Design Competition and the SUAS Autonomous Competition.

Name: M-HEAL
Description: M-HEAL's mission is to use education, needs assessment, design innovation, and social entrepreneurship to improve access to health care in underdeveloped communities. We envision a world where every person has access to appropriate, affordable, and high-quality health care. Learn more on our website!
Summary: M-HEAL is a global health innovation organization that hosts robust interdisciplinary project teams to develop sustainable healthcare technology to improve health outcomes in diverse communities. Please check out our website to learn more!

Name: M-HEAL CSF Global
Description:
As a new student-led project team within M-HEAL, we are in the process of defining and assessing the need presented to us by CSF Global, a NGO in Bangladesh. At present, the primary goals of our partnership are to develop a speech therapy program and a model for affordable and sustainable assistive devices for children with cerebral palsy (CP) in Bangladesh.

We will be traveling to Bangladesh in August 2019, and will redefine our project goals when we return to campus in the fall.
Summary: We strive to improve the quality of life of children with cerebral palsy in Bangladesh.

Name: M-HEAL EHCO
Description: Empowering Health and Community Outreach (EHCO) is an initiative designed to engage students in meaningful healthcare service and advocacy work. Through HOAP, members will have the opportunity to work with local health organizations in Ann Arbor and Memphis, Tennessee, to develop sustainable community health projects and gain a deeper understanding of health equity issues.
Summary: EHCO is an initiative designed to engage students in meaningful healthcare service and advocacy work. Members will work with local health organizations in Ann Arbor and Memphis to develop sustainable community projects and understand health equity issues

Name: M-HEAL Leveraging Inclusive Functional Transfers
Description:
LIFT (Leveraging Inclusive Functional Transfers) is a biomedical engineering project team under the umbrella organization M-HEAL, started up during the Fall 2017 semester. The team’s primary focus is on developing a wearable device for older adults to help minimize damage / injury during a fall incident. In the United States, fall trauma in hospitalized environments is a large issue that current infrastructure only passively addresses. Relevant current solutions include remote presence devices, bedside alert systems, and strength reliant assistive devices such as walkers and canes. While these product do a good job of mobilizing hospital infrastructure in response to a fall incident, they depend on caregivers and do not mitigate the damage already done.

Although we are focused primarily on hospitalized, high-risk patients, although options with more autonomous elderly individuals / rehabilitation devices are also being explored. Alongside advising physicians in both U of M Geriatrics and U of M Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, our team emphasizes working closely with patients and caregivers to solidify the needs of these key users to help drive and engage our own design process. We hope to provide students opportunities to participate in all parts of the design process from needs assessment to prototyping, as well as chances to work side by side with healthcare partners and patients. Our goal is to ultimately design a device that not only makes life safer for older adult patients, but also to make caregivers’ jobs easier.
Summary: LIFT is a biomedical engineering project team focused on developing a device to help minimize the damage to older adults during fall incidents. Our mission is to develop a device that better the lives of both older adult patients and their caregivers.

Name: M-HEAL Neonatal Asphyxia Project
Description: The Neonatal Asphyxia Project, referred to by its members as NAP, was founded in 2016 by a group of students with a passion for applying their Michigan educations to combat high infant mortality rates in underserved regions. They chose to focus on hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), more commonly referred to as neonatal asphyxia; a condition that is one of the leading causes of death for newborns. Research identified hypothermia therapy as the only medical intervention shown to improve infant brain function, and so they set a goal: to design a device that would safely and effectively apply the therapy to mitigate the complications associated with the condition. Since then, NAP has grown into a multidisciplinary team of students who continue to work to achieve this goal. We are currently designing and building different device prototypes.
Summary: An M-HEAL team committed to designing an innovative device that will apply hypothermia therapy to infants with neonatal asphyxia in low-resource settings.

Name: M-HEAL PACT
Description:
Team PACT stands for Preventive and Accessible Cervical Cancer Testing and we are an M-HEAL project team partnered with Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital in Ghana.  We have a Research and Development sub-team and a Business sub-team.

 

According to Dr. Asah-Opoku, our clinical advisor who works at Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital, “Cervical cancer is the commonest gynecological malignancy seen at the Korle Bu Teaching hospital, being reported to make up 64% of gynecological malignancies seen at the hospital.” In Accra, Ghana, only about 2.1% of women have ever had a pap smear.

 

Ghana does not currently have an officially recommended screening measure for HPV testing. Some common testing methods include visual inspection with acetic acid and cytology screenings. However, HPV DNA screenings like our device specifically test for high-risk HPV strains to catch their prevalence before they manifest into cervical cancer. The World Health Organization recommends HPV DNA screenings as the superior method, due to its ease, sensitivity, and preventative nature.

 

Our mission is to develop a method for cervical cancer screening that is effective, non-invasive, and cost-efficient. Our device accomplishes this by collecting urine to be screened for high-risk HPV strains.



Our R&D subteam is focused on developing and executing a testing procedure for a device and making improvements to our prototype. Our business subteam is focused on forming new mentor relationships, working with our current partnerships in Ghana, applying for grants, social media, and forming future travel plans. 

 

Our team is made up of incoming sophomores, juniors, seniors, and graduate students from LSA, Engineering, and Ross. Our meetings typically involve designing new iterations of our device, reaching out to our mentors, and learning about socially engaged design to make sure that we are positively affecting the community of our end users. We often bring in speakers to host workshops in both technical and non technical aspects of engineering. Last semester, we had a CAD workshop and a workshop on needs assessments from the Center for Socially Engaged Design. Our goal is to help our members progress in all aspects of their engineering so that we can parallelly produce the best product for the community that we work with in Ghana.
Summary: Team PACT (Preventive and Accessible Cervical Cancer Testing) is an M-HEAL project team partnered with Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital in Ghana. We aim to develop a method for cervical cancer screening that is effective, non-invasive, and cost-efficient.

Name: M-HEAL PeriOperative
Description:
Under anesthesia required for surgical procedures, a patient experiences vasodilation and loses the ability to properly regulate their body temperature, causing a core-to-peripheral redistribution of body heat. If core body temperature drops below 36.0 ℃, it becomes perioperative hypothermia, which may lead to cardiac events, impaired pharmacodynamics, increased risk of infection, excess blood loss, and even organ failure. In turn, this creates worsened patient outcomes, prolonged hospitalization time, and increased medical expenses. Perioperative hypothermia has been reported to affect about 70% of surgical patients, thus establishing a need for an active warming system to prevent it from occurring. Through a needs assessment conducted in the Dominican Republic in Spring 2022, our team found that many healthcare systems across the country lack effective methods for maintaining patient core body temperature during surgeries. Current solutions used in the United States are expensive, non-reusable, and require manual controls, making it difficult to implement them in the Dominican Republic. Thus, based on our needs assessment and additional feedback from advisors, our team is currently developing a reusable, low-cost heated mattress element with an automatic control system to adjust mattress temperature in response to feedback from non-invasive core body temperature readings.

 

There is a need for a method of regulating patient core body temperature during surgery to prevent perioperative hypothermia and the ensuing complications that arise in low-resource hospitals. Thus, our team’s mission is to provide a safe, effective, affordable, and reusable solution to allow healthcare systems across the Dominican Republic to effortlessly maintain patient core body temperature during surgery, resulting in improved patient outcomes and a reduced financial burden for both hospitals and patients. Specifically, our team strives to give operating rooms the ability to monitor core body temperature and maintain normothermia in patients during surgical procedures to prevent complications and discomfort that may arise as a result of perioperative hypothermia.
Summary: Our team is working with hospitals in the Dominican Republic to develop a reusable, low-cost heated mattress element with an automatic control system to adjust mattress temperature in response to feedback from non-invasive core body temperature readings.

Name: M-HEAL Project Alivio
Description:
Project Alivio is a multidisciplinary global health project team that is a part of Michigan Health Engineered for All Lives (M-HEAL). Our project team currently has nineteen members from various departments, including biomedical engineering, public health, chemical engineering and many more. Project Alivio works as a co-design team with the Students Association of International Medical Research (SAIMER), a student organization from the Universidad de San Carlos in Guatemala City.

Our project is focused on reducing the incidence rate of pressure ulcers in San Juan de Dios hospital. Pressure ulcers, also known as bedsores, form when a patient is exposed to pressure for a prolonged period of time. This pressure restricts proper blood flow to a certain area on the body, usually the coccyx, heels, back of head, or elbows, causing skin and tissue damage. To prevent pressure ulcers, nurses turn patients to offload the pressure exerted on the body. Pressure ulcers have high incidence rates in Guatemala City due to the understaffing of nurses. Current solutions are scarce and ineffective because hospitals not sufficiently funding the prevention of pressure ulcers.

We work with physicians, engineers, and researchers from the United States and Guatemala to design a solution to the high rate of pressure ulcer formation.
