Spark Speaker Podcast: a podcast and in-person event series where we speak with entrepreneurs and gain a better understanding of their journey while also discussing topics relevant to entrepreneurship.

 

Marketing & Creative: a team that builds the MPowered presence across campus, online, at all of our events, and beyond

 

We have something for everyone! All members benefit from professional development and learning opportunities including the chance to build out their own idea with the support of MPowered.

For information on how to join, check out our website: https://mpowered.umich.edu/
Summary: The goal of MPowered is two-fold: one, to bring out the courageous self-starters among us to begin their entrepreneurial journey through project based work, and two, to spread their passion to the rest of the U-M community

Name: MRacing Formula SAE
Description: Founded in 1986, the MRacing SAE team at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor gives engineers the knowledge and teamwork experience critical to excelling in any field. Each year we design, build, and race a formula-style car against other college teams worldwide. We have a long-standing legacy of high-performing vehicles, great success at competitions, and a team that exemplifies the high level of commitment and focus needed to build a winning car. In the past four competition seasons, we placed 1st in the United States and are currently ranked 5th in the world out of over 600 teams. Our most recent achievement includes 1st Overall at Formula SAE Michigan, the biggest collegiate formula competition in the world.
Summary: The University of Michigan - Ann Arbor's Formula SAE Team

Name: MRun – Michigan Running Club
Description:
MRun (as we call ourselves) is a super active club that offers way more than just running. In addition to daily practices, cross country meets, and track meets, we also have numerous social events and charity events throughout each semester! We have about 200 dues-paying members so there's always someone to run with! In the past we've traveled everywhere from Hershey, Pennsylvania, to Richmond, Virginia, for meets.


Getting involved with MRun couldn't be easier--all you have to do is start showing up! During the fall we compete in Cross Country meets, and in the Winter/Spring, Track and Field. Beginning the first day of school in September we hold daily practices that offer a variety of running routes and distances. We meet outside the Central Campus Recreation Building (CCRB) on the walking bridge over Washtenaw Ave. every weekday at 4:15 PM where we will have usually a 3 mile, 5 mile, and 7 mile group go out for runs! We go to races about every other weekend during the Fall, and travel to locations anywhere from East Lansing, Michigan to Anderson, Indiana to Hershey, Pennsylvania. We also have a very successful Track and Field program so if you are not interested in long distance running, there are great opportunities for sprinting, jumping and throwing throughout the entire school year. There are track facilities available and practices and workouts for these events as well. 


However, the absolute best thing about MRun is that every practice, event, or anything is completely optional. You can come as much as you want! We have people who show up every day, and others once a month--it's entirely up to you!


As for social events and charity events, nobody does them better than MRun. During the beginning of the year, we have a bunch of events to help new members (especially Freshmen) get to know everyone in the club. We often joke that we're really just a giant "MRun family" and we've been told that we're one of the most welcoming clubs on campus. Keep in contact with the club as the school year gets closer so you'll know more specifically when these events are! There will be a mass meeting, social events, and many other fun things going on first semester to make the transition into the club as easy and fun as possible!
Summary: The Michigan Running Club (MRun, as we call ourselves) is a very active club that offers more than just running. In addition to daily practices, cross country meets, and track meets, we also have social events and charity events throughout each semester.

Name: MTrek
Description: MTreks are adventure trips around the country and globe designed to foster friendships among classmates, promote leadership development, and introduce incoming MBA students to the team-based environment at the Ross School of Business. Trips take place in after MBA1 orientation in late-August and are open to all incoming students. Small groups of incoming MBA1s students are led by rising MBA2 mentors. Trips vary in location and activities. MTrek is more than a club - it is honored tradition and key point of differentiation for Ross.
Summary: MTrek organizes trips for incoming full-time MBA1s at the Ross School of Business that are led by MBA2s to various destinations before the start of the MBA program.

Name: Mu Epsilon Delta
Description:
We are a co-educational, pre-health fraternity whose mission is to prepare our members on their journey to careers in the health field through professional and academic development, service opportunities, and building a support system of lifelong friendships. MED is a family of students who will both celebrate each other's accomplishments and guide each other through the difficulties of the pre-health path. We foster a community of growth and are committed to the betterment of our brothers to create better future leaders in healthcare. 

 

For questions relating to Fall 2026 Rush, please contact MEDrecruitment@umich.edu.

 

Visit our website www.medumich.com or our Instagram @medumich for more information on our organization and our recruitment process!
Summary: We are a Pre-Health Fraternity at the University of Michigan dedicated to service, medicine, and brotherhood.

Name: Muay Thai at the University of Michigan
Description:
Come learn, train, and practice the art of Muay Thai! Whether you are learning for self defense, sport, or fitness, there are many reasons to learn the art of 8 limbs.

 

Muay Thai is a martial art that comes from Thailand and emphasizes striking with the fists, elbows, knees, and legs. Due to its versatility, it is a very popular striking base!
Summary: Come learn, train, and practice the art of Muay Thai! Whether you are learning for self defense, sport, or fitness, there are many reasons to learn the art of 8 limbs.

Name: Multicultural Greek Council
Description: The Multicultural Greek Council, 12 organizations, consisting of both fraternities and sororities, was established at the University of Michigan in 2002. With a focus on specific ethnicities, cultures, and/or multiculturalism. In general, these organizations are united to serve as a unique voice and advocate for their respective communities. Service and education are of primary importance, and social activities complete a well-rounded experience for these students.
Summary: The mission of the Multicultural Greek Council shall be to serve all MGC organizations as a support group in their events and communities, to promote multiculturalism and to improve relations between all campus Greeks.

Name: Multicultural Pharmacy Student Organization
Description:
The Multicultural Pharmacy Student Organization of the University of Michigan College of Pharmacy (COP) aspires to:

  • Promote a climate within the COP that supports diversity, equity, and inclusion.
  • Educate the COP community on issues related to diversity, equity, and inclusion.
  • Provide an environment that serves as a platform for COP students (PharmD, PhD, BS, etc.) to express their identities and cultures in a safe and inclusive space.
  • Advocate for the awareness and appreciation of different cultures, ethnicities, and identities of students, faculty, staff, and all members of the COP community.
  • Empower the expression of diverse groups within our local community and beyond.
Summary: The Multicultural Pharmacy Student Organization (MPSO) promotes and appreciates the values of diversity, equity, and inclusion.  MPSO supports all members within and outside of the College of Pharmacy and encourages the expression of all identities.

Name: Multicultural Youth Striving to Incorporate Cohesiveness
Description:
MYSTIC is a multicultural council that strives to initiate community building programming, as well as social and cultural events for Alice Lloyd residents, in order to foster increased social and cultural awareness and acceptance within our community.

We seek to help create a safe and inclusive community where residents can learn to understand and accept their own and others' identities by promoting an awareness and appreciation of multiculturalism and diversity, by educating others (and ourselves) about social justice issues, and by celebrating the diversity of our community.
Summary: MYSTIC is a multicultural council that strives to initiate community building programming, as well as social and cultural events for Alice Lloyd residents, in order to foster increased social and cultural awareness and acceptance within our community.

Name: Multiculturalism of Stockwell Advancing Identities and Cultures
Description: This multicultural organization is to provide social and political support for minority and underrepresented groups of residents in Stockwell Residence Hall.
Summary: Resident multicultural council of Stockwell Hall

Name: Munger Graduate Residences
Summary: Munger Graduate Residences

Name: Music AI Club at the University of Michigan
Description:
We are the Music AI Club at the University of Michigan, a vibrant community of students passionate about the fascinating intersection of music and artificial intelligence. Our group is dedicated to exploring and understanding how AI technologies can transform and enhance the creation, performance, and appreciation of music.

 

By joining us, you'll have the opportunity to delve into the evolving landscape of AI in music, where innovative minds come together to push the boundaries of what is possible. Whether you're interested in backend algorithms, music production, or the ethical implications of AI in the arts, our community offers a supportive environment for learning and growth.

 

We're committed to creating a harmonious future where technology and creativity coexist, bringing forth new possibilities and enriching the musical experience for everyone. Through collaborative projects, workshops, and discussions, we aim to foster an inclusive space for students to share their knowledge, experiment with cutting-edge technologies, and develop solutions that bridge the gap between artificial intelligence and music.

 

Join us on this exciting journey as we work towards a future where AI not only complements but also elevates the creative spirit of music. Whether you're a seasoned musician, an aspiring AI developer, or simply curious about the potential of this interdisciplinary field, we welcome you to be a part of our mission.
Summary: We're a community of students passionate about the intersection of music and artificial intelligence. Join us as we navigate the evolving landscape of AI in music and work towards creating a harmonious future where technology and creativity coexist.

Name: Music For Dementia
Description: This is the University of Michigan Chapter of Music for Dementia (MFD), founded in 2019. MFD aims to help nursing home residents suffering from dementia cope with memory loss and find more joy in everyday life through a personalized music program. Familiar music helps them become more present and connected to their environment, so the program focuses on each individual by providing live performances and personalized playlists on digital devices. The club relies on volunteers to inquire about residents’ musical preferences and perform songs they would enjoy. All levels of expertise in instrument/vocals are welcome. MFD is a venue for volunteers to meet, form musical groups, and perform in front of an audience. UofM students mainly volunteer at the Brookdale and Orchard Hills care facilities in Ann Arbor, but we hope to expand to other facilities as well! Other sites are also available for those residing outside of Ann Arbor. Volunteer orientation is offered at the beginning of the semester and online workshops are provided throughout.
Summary: Music for Dementia is a volunteer-based student org that aims to help nursing home residents suffering from dementia cope with memory loss and find more joy in everyday life through live musical performances and a personalized music program.

Name: Music For Medicine
Description: Music For Medicine provides opportunities for students with any kind of musical background to perform, from classical pieces to covers to even original works. All skill levels are encouraged! We will host workshops (run by members), recitals, and fundraisers, with all profits donated to local healthcare institutions such as Michigan Medicine, the VA Hospital, and Trinity Health. In the process, we aim to raise awareness and empathy for healthcare issues.
Summary: M4M aims to use performances, workshops, and other music-related presentations to fundraise for and donate to local medical institutions. Students with musical backgrounds have the opportunity to showcase their talents for charitable causes.

Name: MUSIC Matters
Description: We are one of the largest student organizations at the University of Michigan. Every April we host SpringFest: a full-day lifestyle and music festival run by students, for students. Our proceeds from SpringFest and other concerts showcasing local talent throughout the year allow us to fund our three Social Ventures: The Big Thinkers Scholarship and The CoMMunity Partnership. These Social Ventures and our year-round events allow us to create educational opportunities and celebrate the vibrant Michigan community. Through our collective passion for music and social activism, we intend to make a tangible and positive impact on our community.
Summary: MUSIC Matters is a student-run non-profit organization that aims to use the unifying power of music to drive social impact in our community.

Name: Music Meditation Club
Description:
---EVENTS---

We meet on Wednesdays at 6:30 PM in East Quad Room 1511! Check out our Instagram for our latest events and meetings!

Click this link to view our Instagram Page

---DESCRIPTION---

Music Meditation Club wishes to facilitate as a meeting place, where we can provide an open, soothing and enriching environment to escape from stress and anxiety; building a community diverse, balanced and supportive. Our key objectives are: 

  • To encourage the student community to appreciate and understand higher dimensions of knowledge as given in the Vedic scriptures.
  • To systematically propagate spiritual knowledge to the student body and to educate all people in the techniques of spiritual life in order to check the imbalance of values in life and to achieve real unity and peace, individually and collectively.
  • To discuss modern issues in the light of the ancient Vedic literatures and encourage modern thinkers to appreciate and apply these ideas.
  • To encourage all youth to espouse eternal principles as given in the Vedic literatures that would help them develop stable, well-rounded personalities.
  • To help all people to discern reality from illusion, spirit from matter, the eternal from the temporary.
  • To develop character and qualities, by incorporating a regulated schedule in our daily lives by efficient time management, stress management and cultivating healthy habits.
  • To help youth to become strong and effective leaders in the society by inculcating the qualities such as humility and compassion towards others.
  • To encourage people in simple living and high thinking.
  • To provide opportunities for involvement and to bring out our inherent skills.
Summary: Through discussion groups, yoga, guided & music meditation, the Music Meditation Club encourages a shift in consciousness and spiritual growth to help students uncover meaning and depth in everyday life. We meet on Wednesday @ 6:30PM, East Quad Room 1511

Name: Music Teachers National Association Collegiate Chapter
Description: Founded in 1876 by Theodore Presser and sixty-two of his friends, the Music Teachers National Association is currently the largest professional, non-profit music teachers organization in the world. More than 26,000 members—comprised of independent and collegiate music teachers—are committed to furthering the art of music through teaching, performance, composition and scholarly research. This collegiate chapter aims to be active in five key areas: Recruitment and Exposure, Community and Teacher Service, Research and Presentations, Collaboration and Networking, and Fundraising.
Summary: More than 26,000 MTNA members worldwide—comprised of independent and collegiate music teachers—are committed to furthering the art of music through teaching, performance, composition and scholarly research.

Name: MUSKET/UAC
Description:
MUSKET is the only completely student run musical theatre company on the University of Michigan's campus. Whether it be as an actor on stage, a crew member behind the scenes, or an audience member in the distinguished Power Center venue, there are many opportunities for University of Michigan students to become involved. Each year, MUSKET presents two musical productions: one in the fall semester and one in the winter semester.  

MUSKET has presented a wide variety of shows ranging from classics like WEST SIDE STORY and OKLAHOMA to more contemporary works such as IN THE HEIGHTS and LEGALLY BLONDE and continues to explore ways in which quality theatre can be presented to the University of Michigan and Ann Arbor community. MUSKET is also proud to lay claim to many alums working in the industry, such as Benj Pasek, Justin Paul, Andrew Lippa, Taylor Louderman and many more.
Summary: MUSKET is the only completely student run musical theatre organization, running for almost 100 years. We produce two large-scale musicals per year in the Power Center, and both theatre and non-theatre majors are encouraged to participate.

Name: Muslim Business Students' Association
Description: MBSA is a career-oriented community of Muslim students interested in the various areas of business. We primarily focus on networking, socials, application assistance, interview preparation, and a host of other activities.
Summary: A student organization dedicated to preparing pre-business Muslim students for business school and Muslim students interested in business for a prosperous career through networking, information workshops, and personalized coaching.

Name: Muslim Engineering Society
Description:
MES complements STEM education with professional development to build strong careers. We have a diverse and talented network, with experience at Fortune 500 companies and hot startups. Contact us for coding interview prep, resume advice, courses, & more.

We are much more than just an org, as we are branching further into hosting large events, personal help sessions, and a breadth of many more ideas. Join the MES to become a part of an org making strides in upholding the Muslim and greater Engineering student community at the University of Michigan!
Summary: MES complements STEM education with professional development to build strong careers. We have a diverse and talented network with experience at Fortune 500 companies and top startups. Contact us for coding interview prep, resume advice, courses, & more.

Name: Muslim Fitness Club
Description: MFC exists to help create a safe space for people in the muslim community to not only look for health and fitness knowledge, but also to workout and exercise with a supportive group of peers that share the same fitness and spiritual goals.
Summary: MFC exists to help create a safe space for people in the muslim community to not only look for health and fitness knowledge, but also to workout and exercise with a supportive group of peers that share the same fitness and spiritual goals.

Name: Muslim Graduate Students Association
Description:
The Muslim Graduate Students Association seeks to serve the interests of Muslim graduate students and researchers at the University of Michigan. Specifically, we seek to reach connect graduate students across the various graduates programs, including LSA, Engineering, Ross, dental school, medical school, and the law school. We organize various educational and social events centered around building community. We also collaborate with other organizations such as the Muslim Students Association and the various graduate school specific MSA's (e.g. AMMSA, MLSA, MSDA). 

If you would like to be added to our contact list, please reach out to mgsaboard@umich.edu.
Summary: The Muslim Graduate Students Association seeks to serve the interests of Muslim graduate students and researchers at the University of Michigan.

Name: Muslim Law Students Association
Description: The MLSA is dedicated to raising awareness regarding legal matters related to American Muslims and Muslims around the world. It also aims to create a community where Muslim law students and other law students interested in learning more about issues affecting Muslim communities and the law can come together.
Summary: MLSA is dedicated to raising awareness regarding legal matters related to American Muslims and Muslims around the world.

Name: Muslim Student Dental Association
Description: The Muslim Student Dental Association is an organization serving Muslim dental students and anyone interested in learning about the Islamic faith and culture within the University of Michigan School of Dentistry. We engage in religious, social and community activities with efforts of promoting the field of Dentistry, supporting educational and intellectual pursuits of dentistry and continue to promote the goals of Muslim students in the School of Dentistry, and thus serve our faith as best we can. Our efforts coincide with that of the School of Dentistry, in facilitating a better environment for Muslim dental students on campus, educating both Muslims and people of other faith about the religion of Islam, allowing the building of bridges and understanding in our diverse community through dental services and activism.
Summary: The Muslim Student Dental Association is an organization serving Muslim dental students and anyone interested in learning about the Islamic faith and culture within the University of Michigan School of Dentistry.

Name: Muslim Students in Public Health
Description:
In Muslims Students in Public Health our focus is to create an inclusive organization that focuses on professional development, community service and building bridges with our cultures. We are hoping to connect people from different backgrounds as well as those who share our commonalities. Our meetings will focus on networking, volunteering, advocacy and alumni engagement. 

Our hope is to create a diverse organization that enables University of Michigan students to create a positive impact in Ann Arbor and to build lasting connections with alumni and current students. We hope to facilitate events that create a positive difference through direct community involvement.
Summary: Our purpose is to help build a strong Muslim community here on campus to help them pursue a career in Public Health. Through professional development and networking, we hope to encourage students to be engaged with fellow peers and network with alumni.

Name: Muslim Students' Association
Description:
Assalamu Alaikum Warahmatullahi Wabarakatuhu,

Welcome to the Muslim Students' Association at the University of Michigan! Established in 1952, U-M MSA is one of the oldest MSA chapters in the country and has developed into one of the most active and vibrant student organizations on campus. Since then, the MSA has undergone tremendous growth and progress as its members continuously strive to be the Leaders and Best in strengthening faith, knowledge, and community. We invite you to join us in building on the thrilling and unique Michigan Muslim experience, as well as in promoting the spirit of diversity and dialogue of the Michigan and Ann Arbor community. We welcome everyone to become involved, join our meetings, and stay connected with us. Please browse through our webpage or visit our Facebook page, and feel free to get in touch with us at any time!

With peace,
Your MSA Board

Contact Us

About Us

Our Services

Our Committees
Summary: Welcome to the MSA! We are one of the most active and vibrant student organizations on campus. We strive to be the Leaders and Best in strengthening faith, knowledge and community. We invite you to join us in building onto the Michigan Muslim experience.

Name: Muslim Tech Collaborative @ Michigan
Description:
Muslim Tech Collaborative (MTC) is a vibrant, entrepreneurship-focused organization dedicated to empowering the next generation of Muslim innovators and leaders in the technology industry. Our mission is to bridge the gap between technology and the Muslim community by fostering a deep passion for coding, innovation, and entrepreneurship. Through partnerships with startups and growing businesses, we provide our members with hands-on project experience, equipping them with the tools to solve real-world problems.

We are also deeply committed to nurturing young Muslim youth by offering workshops, mentorship programs, and skill-building opportunities that prepare them to thrive in the rapidly evolving tech landscape. To further our mission, we host hackathons, networking events, and speaker series that bring together students, professionals, and thought leaders to explore cutting-edge technologies and collaborative solutions.

At MTC, we aim to create a thriving community that inspires innovation, promotes leadership, and drives positive change through the power of technology. Whether you're a student passionate about technology, an aspiring entrepreneur, or simply curious about the tech industry, we invite you to join us and be part of this transformative journey.
Summary: A home for Muslims in tech to collaborate on solving problems, educating our youth, and leveling up their careers through entrepreneurship.

Name: Narrative Medicine Interest Group
Description: In this group, we aim to create a space for medical students to share and discuss narrative medicine pieces, work on their own writing, engage in activities such as group book clubs, and find community among fellow medical students who enjoy reading and writing.
Summary: This is a space for medical students to share and discuss narrative medicine pieces, work on their own writing, engage in activities such as group book clubs, and find community among fellow medical students who enjoy reading and writing.

Name: National Arab American Medical Association NextGen
Description: The National Arab American Medical Association (NAAMA) is a nonprofit, nonpolitical, educational and humanitarian organization of medical and dental professionals of Arab descent. NAAMA was incorporated in California in 1975 and became a national organization in 1980. Currently, 27 chapters of NAAMA are established in the United States and Canada.  This year, current President-elect Dr. Rouba Ali-Fehmi and the board of NAAMA decided to expand the influence of NAAMA to benefit students who are both interested in their culture as well as have an affinity for the medical sciences. The University of Michigan chapter of the NAAMA NextGen is the debut on-campus NAAMA-affiliated organization, and hopefully the first of many nationwide. Our mission is to help students explore their interest in medicine by providing opportunities to observe or shadow physicians, assisting them with resumes and the medical school application processes, and incorporate the charitable goals of NAAMA by organizing volunteer trips to communities in need both domestically and internationally.
Summary: The NAAMA NextGen is a collective of Arab American students who are interested in medicine. Through their affiliation with the organization, they receive mentorship from esteemed physicians as well as contribute to charitable causes.

Name: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
Description:
Celebrating 111 Years of Youth Leadership and Activism

The NAACP believes strongly that future leaders must be developed today, and such development is ongoing in the Youth & College Division, created in 1936. Today there are more than 25,000 young people, under the age of 25, representing 700 Youth Councils, High School Chapters and College Chapters actively involved in the fight for civil rights. The NAACP has one of the largest organized groups of young people of any secular organization in the country.

MISSION

The mission of the NAACP Youth & College Division shall be to inform youth of the problems affecting African Americans and other racial and ethnic minorities; to advance the economic, education, social and political status of African Americans and other racial and ethnic minorities and their harmonious cooperation with other peoples; to stimulate an appreciation of the African Diaspora and other people of color’s contribution to civilization; and to develop an intelligent, militant effective youth leadership.

VISION

Developing a New Generation of Civil Rights and Community Leaders

OBJECTIVES

  • Provide young people with personal and leadership development training
  • Proactive political and community activism
  • Public awareness of the necessity of positive youth engagement

ISSUES

Students have always been at the forefront of most major social movements. From the Civil Rights Movement of the 60’s to the anti-apartheid movement of the 1980’s, student activism has forced society and the world to change. NAACP youth units across America are engaged in social justice activism addressing issues at the local, state and national level. The primary focus issues for the Division are the following:

  • Economic Development
  • Education
  • Health & Awareness
  • Juvenile Justice
  • Political Action
  • Voter Empowerment
Summary: Founded in 1909, the NAACP has been the forefront in Civil Rights struggles. The U of M chapter aspires bring together students of color and their allies on campus. Join us today as we make tomorrow's history and try to right yesterday's wrongs.

Name: National Council of Negro Women at The University of Michigan
Description: The National Council of Negro Women, Inc. (NCNW) is an "organization of organizations", campus sections, community and 38 national women's organizations. Founded in 1935 by Dr.Mary McLeod Bethune, and later led by the iconic Dr. Dorothy Height for over 50 years. NCNW focuses on key priorities: promoting education, fostering entrepreneurship and financial literacy, improving healthcare access, and advocating for civic engagement and social justice. Our organization is a vital resource to unite and support women of color on this campus.
Summary: The National Council of Negro Women, Inc. (NCNW) aims to lead, advocate, and empower women of African descent and their families.

Name: National Lawyers Guild at Michigan Law
Description:
We exist to provide a home for truly progressive law students. We train law students to be legal observers whose presence may serve as a deterrent to unconstitutional behavior by law enforcement during protests and demonstrations. We also host panel lunches, collaborative events, and networking opportunities for students to meet truly progressive attorneys across the public and private sectors. 

We are a law student chapter of the National Lawyers Guild, the nation’s oldest and largest progressive bar association and the first one in the US to be racially integrated. NLG's mission is to use law for the people, uniting lawyers, law students, legal workers, and jailhouse lawyers to function as an effective force in the service of the people by valuing human rights and the rights of ecosystems over property interests. NLG is dedicated to the need for basic change in the structure of our political and economic system. Our aim is to bring together all those who recognize the importance of safeguarding and extending the rights of workers, women, LGBTQ people, farmers, people with disabilities and people of color, upon whom the welfare of the entire nation depends; who seek actively to eliminate racism; who work to maintain and protect our civil rights and liberties in the face of persistent attacks upon them; and who look upon the law as an instrument for the protection of the people, rather than for their repression.
Summary: A group of truly progressive law students.

Name: National Organization for Business and Engineering
Description: The National Organization for Business and Engineering is dedicated to bridging the gap between business savviness and technical acumen, by providing professional development resources, real-world projects and upperclassmen mentorship.
Summary: The National Organization for Business and Engineering is dedicated to bridging the gap between business savviness and technical acumen, by providing professional development resources, real- world projects and upperclassmen mentorship.

Name: National Organization of Minority Architecture Students at the University of Michigan Chapter
Description: The National Organization of Minority Architecture Students at the University of Michigan Chapter (NOMAS) aims to create a community that explores, promotes and supports academic understanding, professional development and the overall advancement of diversity and inclusion in architecture, urban planning and allied design fields. We are a student chapter of the National Organization of Minority Architects (NOMA) and we participate in their events including the annual student design competition and conference. Locally, we host campus-based discussions, networking events, and career development opportunities with professionals. We are based within the Taubman College School of Architecture and Urban Planning, but engage with the entire University of Michigan community. Ultimately, we seek to establish connections between our members and experienced professionals belonging to NOMA, which embrace cultural diversity and inclusion in the design fields.
Summary: Our mission is to explore, promote and support academic understanding, professional development and the overall advancement of diversity and inclusion in architecture, urban planning and allied design fields.

Name: National Pan-Hellenic Council
Description:
The Divine 9

Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity Inc. 1906

Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc. 1908

Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity Inc. 1911

Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc. 1911

Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc. 1913

Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity Inc. 1914

Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Inc. 1920

Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority Inc. 1922

Iota Phi Theta Fraternity Inc. 1963
Summary: The NPHC is a national organization comprised of the divine nine historically African American sororities and fraternities.

Name: National Security Law Society
Description: The National Security Law Society aims to foster interest in and understanding of the legal aspects and ramifications of national and international security by sponsoring speakers and programs concerning the many topics within this area of law. We also work to aid members in their pursuits of careers in these fields and to contribute to the development of the law as it relates to national and international security.
Summary: The National Security Law Society aims to foster understanding of the legal aspects and ramifications of national and international security by sponsoring speakers and programs dealing with this area of law.

Name: National Society of Black Engineers
Description:
NSBE's mission is "to increase the number of culturally responsible Black engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally and positively impact the community."  We represent one of the largest student-run organizations in the  country, with over 30,000 active members. Our membership spans not only states, but countries.  

The University of Michigan's NSBE chapter was chartered in 1984 and has become very active in the College of Engineering. NSBE sponsors community outreach projects, social gatherings for members, and brings company representatives to general body meetings for networking opportunities. General body meetings are held bi-weekly throughout the year. NSBE members span the entire engineering spectrum.  Each program is designed to encourage Pre-College students to get involved and interested in the Engineering field at the Elementary school level, Middle school level, and the High school level.  We've had social events such as bowling and movie nights to help our members connect with one another.  Before the engineering career fair we have professional development week so our members are prepared for the career fair.  For more information check out our website: nsbe.umich.edu
Summary: NSBE's mission is "to increase the number of culturally responsible Black engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally and positively impact the community."

Name: National Society of Black Physicists - Willie Hobbs Moore Student Chapter
ShortName: NSBP Willie Hobbs Moore Student Chapter
Description:
Please visit our main webpage here!

The purpose of this chapter is to promote the professional development and well-being of blacks pursuing degrees in physics within the local scientific community and region at large. This chapter seeks to develop and support efforts to increase opportunities, activities, and programs for blacks in physics. The Chapter seeks to provide a non-partisan platform for major issues of scientific and cultural significance to its membership. Most importantly, the Chapter aims to establish a more connected, personal, and engaged community for the student members of the National Society of Black Physicists (NSBP).
Summary: The organization seeks to develop and support efforts to increase opportunities for African Americans in physics and to increase their numbers and visibility of their scientific work.

Name: Native American Law Students Association
Description: The Native American Law Students Association (NALSA) is a student organization at the University of Michigan Law School. NALSA's purposes are threefold: to increase awareness of federal Indian and tribal law; to provide support for Native students and non-native students interested in Native American issues; and to foster community among Native law students.
Summary: NALSA is a student organization dedicated to increasing awareness of federal Indian and tribal law; providing support for Native and non-Native students interested in Native American issues; and fostering community service towards Natives and non-Natives

Name: Native American Student Association
Description: The Native American Student Association fosters community among Native students on campus through weekly meetings, cultural initiatives, and academic support.
Summary: NASA fosters community among Native students on campus and those interested in Native American/First Nations/Indigenous political issues, cultural practices, and language. NASA holds multiple events each semester, we invite you to join us!

Name: Net Impact @ Ross
Description: Net Impact is an international network of business leaders committed to responsible business models, policies and practices. Net Impact members seek to integrate this commitment into the mission, values, strategy and operations of organizations in which they are involved. At Ross, Net Impact's focus is two-fold: First, to create an active community of students who are passionate about making a social impact, whether through their professional or personal endeavors. Second, to provide resources and support for MBAs who are exploring careers in social impact. We meet those objectives through a variety of programming through the year that engages our members across the spectrum.
Summary: Net Impact @ Ross is a student organization that focuses on social impact and sustainable development by education, career development, networking, and curriculum development at the Ross School of Business (RSB) and the University of Michigan (UofM).

Name: Net Impact Undergrad
Description:
We are a collaborative, engaging club of diverse undergraduate students passionate about the intersection of business with social impact and sustainability. We hold weekly educational, professional development, and community-building events for our members and host university-wide symposiums and panels.

Co-Presidents 2025: Carlie Peterman (pcarlie@umich.edu) and Taylor Peterson (taylorvp@umich.edu)

For any questions reach out to the Co-Presidents or Eboard (niugboard@umich.edu)

Website: https://www.netimpactumich.com/
Summary: We are a club of diverse undergraduate students passionate about the intersection of business, social impact and sustainability. We hold weekly educational, professional development, and community-building events for our members.

Name: NeuroFit Connections
Description:
Welcome to NeuroFit Connection! We believe that everyone has the power to be the healthiest version of themselves, that comes with understanding the strong interconnection between physical and mental health. NeuroFit Connection focuses on fostering a holistic approach to being healthy, a healthy mind to think in and a healthy body to move in. 

 

We celebrate the amazing capabilities of the human body, from the power of the brain to the amazing movements our muscles allow. NeuroFit Connection will combine physical experiences and practices with scientific exploration of current research on the connection between mental and physical health.

 

Please fill out the interest form found at this link if you would like to join the journey!
Summary: We empower students to become the healthiest versions of themselves, physically and mentally. We focus on fostering a holistic approach to being healthy, a healthy mind to think in and a healthy body to move in.

Name: New Beat Happening
Description: At NBH, we strive to expand the student culture by curating concerts of up and coming artists from around the world. We are music lovers and we aim to share our passion with other students.
Summary: New Beat Happening is a student-run concert booking organization within the Center for Campus Involvement that brings talented local, rising, or established musicians to University of Michigan venues for students to enjoy.

Name: New Life Students
Description: As the student group affiliated with New Life Church in Ann Arbor, we seek to be a vibrant, reproducing church who lives out the Greatest Commandment and the Great Commission. We seek to be vibrant through the fellowship and spiritual guidance provided through on campus home groups, and through deeper relationships and spiritual strengthening that occurs in smaller discipleship groups. We seek to be reproducing through outreach opportunities provided by New Life Church. New Life Students also aims to give students relevant information about New Life Church. We hope to see you soon!
Summary: New Life Students is the student ministry of New Life Church. We are a non-denominational Christian group dedicated to reaching out to students and providing a spiritual community on campus.

Name: New Movement
Description:
If you are interested in joining us in Fall 2024 please email us to be added to our email list.

New Movement provides dancers of all levels on the University of Michigan campus with a non-competitive space to learn a variety of dance techniques, as well as opportunities to perform the work they learn throughout the semester. Even if you have never danced before we would love to have you! New Movement provides a judgement free space for anyone to learn to dance or continue dancing. Through dance, New Movement aims to promote good mental health practices and break the stigma that only dancers with extensive training can engage in and perform this art form.

New Movement has two semesters of small group dances in which dancers meet weekly to learn choreography. In April, we host our annual showcase where all of our groups perform. All dancers will also have the opportunity to perform a solo/duet/trio if they would like!

New Movement has taught and performed a variety of dance styles including Ballet, Contemporary, Jazz, Hip-Hop, Lyrical, Pointe, Modern, and Musical Theatre. We are always open to incorporating new styles of dance into our repertoire. If you have a style that you would like to teach or have us add to our organization, please let us know.

New Movement is also open to providing all members with the opportunity to choreograph. Even if you have never led a rehearsal or choreographed before, you are eligible to choreograph after one semester in New Movement!
Summary: New Movement is a dance group that provides all levels of dancers on the University of Michigan campus with a non-competitive space to learn a variety of dance techniques. There will be opportunities to perform the pieces they learn during the semester.

Name: Nexecon Consulting Group
Description:
Please learn more about our organization here: https://www.nexeconconsulting.com/

In the summer of 2008, two friends from the University of Michigan came together to establish a student-run consulting organization that would help businesses with any strategic needs. Their careful planning and extensive research led to the founding of Nexecon Consulting Group (NCG), a student-run consulting group that works with clients ranging from Fortune 500 companies to local startups. NCG aims for the betterment of its direct community by helping businesses and non-profit groups that lack the resources for costly consultancy through providing services in strategy, marketing, and management consulting. With the support of numerous professionals, faculty, and a diversified pool of curricula and expertise, NCG uses a team approach when assisting clients. Our rich history and club culture allows us to provide our members with the personal and professional growth they seek.
Summary: Nexecon is a student-run consulting organization that works on projects with clients ranging from local startups to Fortune 500 companies. Our goal is to ensure members get the most realistic consulting experience through our diverse array of projects.

Name: NextGen America at The University of Michigan
Description: In the realm of youth activism and political engagement, we envision a dynamic community youth-driven and youth-focused dedicated to mobilizing and empowering their peers to drive meaningful change. NextGen America brings together passionate individuals to embark on a collective journey of advocacy and impact. Our mission is rooted in harnessing the courage and imagination of the largest and most diverse generation in American history to tackle critical challenges such as climate change, racial injustice, economic inequality, and the preservation of democracy itself. Through shared efforts, collaboration, and a commitment to addressing the issues that matter most, we aim to create a powerful movement where every young voice contributes to shaping a better future. Together, we foster an environment where engagement and action lead the way toward lasting progress.
Summary: NextGen America @ UMich is a youth-driven and youth-focused organization dedicated to mobilizing and empowering their peers to drive meaningful change through voter registration and innovative grassroots organizing to tackle critical issues.

Name: NMDP at the University of Michigan
Description:
Thousands of people with blood cancers like leukemia, lymphoma, sickle cell anemia and other life-threatening diseases, depend on a bone marrow or cord blood transplant (also called a BMT) to save their life.

Most patients (about 70 percent) in need of a transplant do not have a matching donor in their family. They depend on the NMDP’s registry to find an unrelated donor or cord blood unit. More people are needed to join the registry so patients have a greater chance of finding a match.

Please join us on our mission to give life to those who suffer from illnesses requiring them to need a bone marrow transplant. Throughout the semester, we run swabbing events where we recruit people to join the NMDP registry, where they could be tapped to consider donating cells.
Summary: The National Marrow Donor Program (NMDP) is a global nonprofit that works to cure blood cancers and disorders. As the UofM chapter, we run events to grow NMDP's registry of tentative donors. Learn more at bethematch.org

Name: NOBCChE at the University of Michigan
Description: The National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE) at the University of Michigan is dedicated to developing the skills of those in chemistry, chemical engineering, and the related fields. We aim to create a sense of community, highlight and increase the engagement of Black people in the sciences, and enact social change through outreach activities.
Summary: NOBCChE at the University of Michigan dedicates itself to the development of and advancement of academic and professional skills of Black students in chemistry, chemical engineering, and related fields.

Name: Noir Runway Fashion
Description:
NOiR is a community service-based fashion organization at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. Since its inception in the fall of 1999, NOiR has established itself as the premier fashion organization. In an effort to bring together Michigan’s diverse community, NOiR annually combines the essence of runway fashion and community service. Each year NOiR re-introduces style, creativity, and individuality to the University of Michigan with an annual fall project and Spring fashion show, procured from local and student designers and artists. NOiR is spearheaded by an executive board comprised of dedicated individuals with diverse career aspirations including fashion, entertainment, public relations, and business affairs.

 

Each year NOiR chooses a charitable cause to direct volunteering and financial efforts towards. NOiR believes that fashion can be used as an avenue to educate as well as encourage others to become aware of the importance of community involvement.

https://noirrunway.org/
Summary: NOiR is a community service-based fashion organization at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. We spread campus awareness of diversity and inclusion, showcase fashion styles, and create a positive impact on the local community through philanthropy.

Name: North African Students Association
Description: The North African Student's Association at the University of Michigan serves North African students and enthusiasts alike. NASA contributes to the richness and diversity of the campus environment by organizing activities and events that revolve around the region and its rich culture. We are an apolitical and non-religious organization open to all those identifying with the region and enthusiasts alike. NASA organizes various social and community service events as well as educational panels pertaining to events in the region.
Summary: A cultural organization focusing on the North African region and its culture.

Name: North Quad Hall Council
Description: The North Quad Hall Council is a diverse team of motivated residents who are concerned with unifying North Quadrangle Residential Community and making positive dorm experiences for the body governed through successful funding initiatives, activities, and events; all while following the Residence Hall theme of International Impact.
Summary: Hall Council for the North Quad Residence Hall works to improve residents living experience within the hall.

Name: North Quad Multicultural Council
Description: North Quad Multicultural Council is a diverse team of motivated residents concerned with unifying North Quad Residential Community and making positive dorm experiences for the body governed through successful funding initiatives, activities and events. The Council is formed by and for North Quad residents, ensuring all students' safety and representation in our community. All meetings are open to the entire Hall.
Summary: North Quad Multicultural Council is a diverse team of motivated residents concerned with unifying North Quad Residential Community and making positive dorm experiences for the body governed through successful funding initiatives, activities and events.

Name: Not Even Really Drama Students
Description:
In 2016, a group of non-theatre students created NERDS as a way to continue their passion for musical theatre without the pressure or time commitment demanded of other groups on campus. Since then, NERDS has grown to over 100 active members who write, compose, direct, and perform original student work by our very own members. NERDS also focuses on uplifting traditionally underrepresented groups in musical theatre and creating a safe, welcoming, and accepting environment for all students with all levels of theatrical experience. Want to learn more? Email us at nerdsdotheatre@gmail.com. 

Interested in some of our previous shows? Check out Time and Time Again from March, 2023: Time and Time Again

And Aliens in Aisle 9 from December, 2022: Aliens in Aisle 9
Summary: NERDS is a low-commitment musical theatre organization for non-drama majors focusing on representation of LGBTQ+ and marginalized groups. Our members create and perform original student work. Contact us at nerdsdotheatre@gmail.com for more information!

Name: Notably Black and Gay
Description: Notably Black and Gay is founded on three tenets: fellowship, education, and activism. Notably Black and Gay is committed to creating an inclusive community, queering our university’s space, and creating cross-campus relationships.Notably Black and Gay acknowledges the importance of education in constructing and understanding your racial and sexual identity. It is not enough to simply be gay so Notably Black and Gay recognizes education as a core tenet.Notably Black and Gay strives to equip our members with accurate history, language, and everyday tangible ways to make social change to further improve the black queer community.
Summary: Notably Black and Gay was founded by Alexxus Lige, Kayla Tate, and Laila Kitchen in 2023 to create fellowship and change for and among black queer students, faculty, and staff at the University of Michigan.

Name: Nourished at the University of Michigan
Description: Our goal is to raise awareness about eating disorders, provide a supportive community for those affected, and promote education on healthy relationships with food and body image. We aim to break the stigma surrounding EDs and advocate for recovery.
Summary: Nourished aims to raise awareness about eating disorders, provide a supportive community for those affected, and promote education on healthy relationships with food and body image. We aim to break the stigma surrounding EDs and advocate for recovery.

Name: Nu Rho Psi
Description:
The purpose of Nu Rho Psi shall be to: (1) encourage professional interest and excellence in scholarship, particularly in neuroscience; (2) award recognition to students who have achieved such excellence in scholarship; (3) advance the discipline of neuroscience; (4) encourage intellectual and social interaction between students, faculty, and professionals in neuroscience and related fields; (5) promote career development in neuroscience and related fields; (6) increase public awareness of neuroscience and its benefits for the individual and society; and (7) encourage service to the community. 

Through activities and workshops on campus, the chapter aims to spread public awareness about the field of neuroscience, and the ways it can benefit the individual and society. Particularly, the chapter will promote research and help motivate educational and professional development between students, faculty, and professionals in neuroscience. The chapter will also be involved with community outreach by connecting with local schools, hospitals, and community groups.
Summary: Nu Rho Psi at the University of Michigan is a chapter of the National Honor Society in Neuroscience that aims to encourage professional interest and excellence in scholarship in neuroscience.

Name: Nursing Student Government
Description:
NSG seeks to unify all undergraduate nursing classes into a functioning student body, and provide leadership and philanthropic opportunities. These opportunities include:

  1. Representation of each class by bringing forth opinions voiced by classmates and peers
  2. Working with faculty and administration to collaborate about steps that can be taken to improve communication for the good of the School
  3. Involvement in volunteering and fundraising for local and national organizations
  4. Providing free events for students, faculty, and administration
Summary: NSG is nursing student organization focused on coordinating and facilitating communication between faculty, administration, and the student body.

Name: Nursing Student Innovation Ambassadors
Description: The purpose of the Nursing Student Innovation Ambassadors is to promote innovation among nursing students using curricular recommendations and extracurricular activities. Founded in the fall of 2019, the University of Michigan School of Nursing Student Innovation Ambassadors came together to identify key priorities to foster innovation specifically among nursing students.
Summary: The purpose of the Nursing Student Innovation Ambassadors is to promote innovation among nursing students using curricular recommendations and extracurricular activities.

Name: Nutritional Sciences Student Association
Description: NSSA is the student organization that represents graduate students in the Nutritional Sciences Department in the School of Public Health. As we represent a graduate program, we are focused on offering opportunities for professional development as well as hosting events to encourage networking and discussion of news and current events related to nutrition. We also aim to provide a variety of social opportunities for our members in order to facilitate collaboration and community engagement.
Summary: NSSA represents the students of the Nutritional Sciences Department at the School of Public Health by planning community service, professional development, and social events for its members.

Name: OB/GYN Interest Group
Description: The purpose of the OB/GYN Interest Group is to offer students the opportunity to explore and appreciate the field of Obstetrics and Gynecology. We aim to provide medical students, at any stage of training, with exposure to this field while also allowing for the chance to meet physicians in general OB/GYN and its subspecialties. Events throughout the year will include a faculty-student dinner, shadowing and research opportunities, and more!
Summary: This group is the medical student OB/GYN interest group. We organize events for medical students to learn about the field of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

Name: Oceania Student Association
Description: OSA is comprised of undergraduate and graduate students, staff, and faculty who have affiliations with the Pacific Islands and/or interests and commitment to Oceania and its peoples. We are dedicated to building community, talking story, promoting wellness, and increasing visibility for the south seas islands. OSA is connected with other Pacific Islander student organizations across the United States and is an affiliate of PISA National and YouTube Academy.
Summary: The Oceania Student Association is dedicated to building community Pacific Islander students, students from Oceania, and/or students with interest and commitment to Oceania and its peoples. OSA is focused on creating a safe, inclusive environment for all

Name: ODESI Research Lab
Description:
ODESI (Organizational Development through Employing Strategic Initiatives) is a multidisciplinary research group at the University of Michigan - Ross School of Business. Led by Ph.D. candidate, Elizabeth Trinh, the ODESI group consists of both undergraduate and graduate students who seek to apply their research expertise to solve real-world challenges across a wide array of industries.
 
The ODESI group has partnered with organizations in the public, private, and non-profit sectors ranging in size from a few dozen employees to 70,000+. During each collaboration, our team works closely with executive teams and ground-level employees ensuring that we fully understand the complexities of the challenges we are attempting to solve. Our team has worked with organizations to boost employee retention, improve organizational performance, and contribute to a growing body of literature on creating and cultivating meaning in the workplace.
 
As we are an entirely student-led organization, all our services are offered to our partner organizations at no cost. In addition, our partners remain anonymous and proprietary information is treated as confidential. At the end of each collaboration, we provide our partners with detailed reports of our findings and recommendations for future developments.
Summary: ODESI (Organizational Development through Employing Strategic Initiatives) is a multidisciplinary research lab at the University of Michigan, Ross School of Business.

Name: Office of Academic Multicultural Initiatives
Description: OAMI works collaboratively with campus and external partners to develop strategic programs that provide you resources, opportunities and experiences that enrich your academic, social, cultural, and personal development at the University of Michigan.
Summary: OAMI works collaboratively with campus and external partners to develop strategic programs that provide you resources, opportunities and experiences that enrich your academic, social, cultural, and personal development at the University of Michigan.

Name: Office of Fraternity & Sorority Life
Description: Fraternity & Sorority Life is a University department within Student Life charged with supporting the fraternity and sorority community. The three full-time and three part-time staff members work closely with the four councils and the affiliated organizations to aid students with recruitment, intake, event planning, educational programming, social, philanthropic and logistical needs. Staff members also serve as facilitators and educators at retreats and other forums and workshops. They act as liaisons to alumni, parents, City of Ann Arbor officials, Inter/National headquarters, and University faculty and staff. Additionally the staff assists individual chapters with their programming ideas, problem solving and leadership development. The Office of Greek Life is primarily funded through dues paid by fraternity and sorority collegiate members.
Summary: Fraternity & Sorority Life at the University of Michigan is dedicated to the development of its diverse student body through close collaboration with the University Community, Greek Alumni, International organizations, and Ann Arbor Community.

Name: Office of Multi-Ethnic Student Affairs (MESA)
Description: Using the lens of race and ethnicity, MESA engages the campus community and transforms the student experience to build inclusive spaces and equitable opportunities for all. MESA is a department within Student Life at the University of Michigan. Learn more about us by visiting our website and signing up for a virtual appointment to connect directly with our staff. We look forward to meeting you!
Summary:
Using the lens of race and ethnicity, MESA engages the campus community and transforms the student experience to build inclusive spaces and equitable opportunities for all. 

Learn more about our programs and support by connecting with us.

Name: Office of Student Publications
Description: U-M's Office of Student Publications houses the Michigan Daily, Michiganensian, SHEI Magazine and the Gargoyle Magazine. Our unit is located at 420 Maynard Street, Ann Arbor MI.
Summary: U-M's Office of Student Publications houses the Michigan Daily, Michiganensian, SHEI Magazine and the Gargoyle Magazine. Our unit is located at 420 Maynard Street, Ann Arbor MI.

Name: Office of Undergraduate Admissions - Campus Day
Description:
The Campus Day program is a structured campus visitation program that provides groups of admitted students and their parents the opportunity to see our campus, speak with currently enrolled students (Campus Day Leaders), and have questions answered as they are considering enrolling at Michigan. Students and parents attend presentations, engage in panel discussions, tour campus, and visit their admitting college or school. A key element of the program is the opportunity for admitted students and their parents to interact with current Michigan students (Campus Day Leaders). Our students can talk about their classes and the things they are involved with, share some of their experiences, and give families first-hand perspective about what it is like to be a student here. Besides providing campus tours and answering questions as panelists, they also assist with registration and helping our guests have a positive experience.

 

To learn more about Campus Day, come chat with us at Festifall or Northfest, or check out the video below! If you're interested in applying, you can do so through our online application. Go Blue!

 

video
Summary: The Campus Day program is a structured campus visitation program that provides groups of admitted students and their parents the opportunity to see our campus and speak with currently enrolled students (Campus Day Leaders).

Name: Office of Undergraduate Admissions Tour Guides
Description: Our campus tour guides are strong public speakers who are punctual, reliable, and passionate about the university. Every year, more than 45,000 people visit campus for tours and other programs offered at the Huetwell Visitors Center. Tour guides show prospective students around Central Campus, answer questions about student life, and share their personal experiences at Michigan. They also display pride and professionalism while representing themselves and U-M.
Summary: Our campus tour guides are strong public speakers who are punctual, reliable, and passionate about the university. Every year, more than 45,000 people visit campus for tours and other programs offered at the Huetwell Visitors Center.

Name: Older Wiser Law Students
Description: A law student does not need to be particularly old or particularly wise to join OWLS. Though primarily focused on serving as a resource for students with substantial life experience between undergrad and law school (e.g. previous careers, spouses and/or children, and those who have had a nontraditional educational path) we welcome anyone who is old or wise at heart or is curious about those who are.
Summary: An organization for older and/or wiser law students

Name: Olive Tree Ministry
Description: We are an affiliated student organization of Olive Tree Campus Church (OTCC). Our main purpose is to expand OTCC’s outreach to University of Michigan’s campus and better serve its student body. Our mission is to spread Jesus' s love and truth to Chinese students at U of M and raise bold disciples of Christ among them. In studying the gospel, imitating Jesus, and obeying His word accordingly, we support students both spiritually and physically. We desire to establish a loving community, help students witness God's love and power, and inspire them to impact more people around them.
Summary: Olive Tree Ministry is an affiliated student organization of Olive Tree Campus Church (OTCC). Its main purpose is to expand OTCC’s outreach to University of Michigan’s campus and better serve its student body.

Name: Omega Beta Eta, Arab Fraternity, Inc.
Description:
Omega Beta Eta (ΩΒΗ) is one of the first Arab fraternities in the world that intends to not only bring together Arab Brothers to empower each other, but also build necessary inclusion into a University space that often dissenters our Arab voice, presence, history, and contributions to diversity on campus. The Arab community is plagued by an educational system that does not teach us our history or contributions to society. The beauty and purpose of ΩΒΗ is sought to engage the Michigan community on our identity, struggle, and existence on campus, in the United States, and in the world. Our Brotherhood is a catalyst for social change and motivates Arab Brothers to feel pride in their culture as they deal with broader societal oppression, while also empowering these Brothers to learn to engage the Arab community at large, and collaborate with other communities of color and underrepresented communities.

ΩΒΗ is a support system and platform for Arab Brothers to: 1) excel academically; 2) develop personally and professionally; 3) build long-lasting relationships; 4) learn to navigate their Arab identity; and 5) be politically-minded. The dire need for a peer-to-peer structure of this sort highlights the need for more intentional efforts to mentor Arab Brothers, regardless of nationality and hometown. Students across the world also lack understanding of Arab history as well as contributions made to the country and to University campuses, and because of this, ΩΒΗ will challenge these misconceptions.
Summary: Omega Beta Eta (ΩΒΗ) is one of the first Arab fraternities in the world that intends to not only bring together Arab Brothers to empower each other, but also build necessary inclusion in spaces that often dissenter our Arab voice, presence and history.

Name: Omega Chi Epsilon, Chemical Engineering Honor Society
Description:
Omega Chi Epsilon is the national honor society for chemical engineering. This society promotes high scholarship, encourages original investigation in chemical engineering, and recognizes the valuable traits of character, integrity, and leadership. It serves both undergraduate and graduate students and fosters meaningful student-faculty dialogue. 

Omega Chi Epsilon is a member of the Association of College Honor Societies. The Society also has many common goals with the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE); we support the AIChE with funds for student awards. We further share many goals with the American Society for Engineering Education. Omega Chi Epsilon has over 60 active university chapters and total membership of nearly 20,000. While the chapters are primarily composed of Junior and Senior students, it is open to graduate students and faculty as well. In recent years, 2-4 new chapters have been chartered each year.
Summary: OXE is the chemical engineering honor society at U of M. We pride ourselves on the service that we provide to the community through various philanthropic events and tutoring. We also have social gatherings as a society for bonding between members.

Name: Omega Omega Omega
ShortName: OOO, Tri-O, Tri Omega, Tri-Omega, Trio
Description:
OOO is a social organization known as a "Wellness Fraternity" or "Mental Health Fraternity," with the core mission of highlighting the importance of mental health alongside rigorous academic pursuits. We focus on professional development, charitable activities, community outreach, and social events. OOO provides members with opportunities to de-stress, engage in personal and professional growth, and prepare skills for managing their mental health and wellness in a post-college setting. Through our events, members will develop leadership, interpersonal, and interview skills while learning mental health coping strategies to ease the pressures of schoolwork and career planning.

 

Our mission is to offer students at the University of Michigan a supportive social community where they can form lasting friendships, thrive academically, and smoothly integrate into both the university and OOO kinship. We aim to enrich our members’ lives by demonstrating that academic excellence and mental well-being can coexist. Join our family and learn that academic success does not come at the cost of self-care.
Summary: OOO is the premier Mental Health Fraternity on campus, dedicated to offering students an exceptional social community where they can build friendships, excel academically, and enhance their professional growth, all while prioritizing mental well-being.

Name: Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc. PHI Chapter
Description: Fraternal social organization that aims to uplift the community by briniging awareness to social issues, as well as being active in the community through service and mentorship.
Summary: Fraternity organization that seeks to unify the community with the presentation of programs and events, and community service, and bring together men who are of high character and academic achievement.

Name: On the Board
Description: On the Board helps Michigan Law students to connect and de-stress alongside their peers from different sections and classes by providing a regular forum for tabletop gaming, allowing for new friendships and community building within the law school.
Summary: Michigan Law's tabletop gaming club. In addition to board games, DnD / RPG games, card games, and related extracurricular activities are offered, typically every Friday at 4:00pm in the Lawyers Club. Guests are welcome.

Name: One Health Student Consortium
Description:
The One Health Student Consortium (OHSC) is a student-run organization that spans across several graduate schools here at the University of Michigan, including the School of Medicine, School of Public Health (SPH), and the School for Environment and Sustainability (SEAS). "One Health” is an approach to health that aims to integrate the health of people, animals, and the environment, in order to tackle complex health issues both locally and globally. This is especially relevant to….

  • Antibiotic resistance

  • Diseases that might cause the next global pandemic

  • Zoonotic diseases

  • Mosquito-borne diseases

  • Climate change’s impacts on health

  • Mental health

  • And more…

We are hoping that OHSC will bring together students across different disciplines in order to foster genuine interdisciplinary conversations and collaboration. OHSC will be organized into three committees focused on different types of projects: Advocacy Committee, Research Committee, and Outreach Committee.

 

For more information, please visit our website.

If you would like to join us, please fill out this form.
Summary: The One Health Student Consortium's mission is to advance One Health work through collaboration, education, research, and community engagement. We are a diverse group of students across various graduate schools, include SOM, SPH, and SEAS.

Name: One Love at Michigan
Description: One Love club originated from the death of Yeardly Love, a UVA lacrosse player whose life was tragically ended by domestic violence. This organization works to prevent avoidable deaths like Yeardly's by teaching young kids what healthy love looks like, and to see the early signs of an unhealthy relationship. Through videos, workshops and information sessions we work to educate youth in hopes of creating a generation with healthier relationships.
Summary: One Love empowers young people with the tools and resources they need to see the signs of healthy and unhealthy relationships and bring life-saving prevention education to their communities.

Name: One Thousand Schools
Description:
One Thousand Schools (OTS), previously Students Helping Honduras (SHH), was founded in 2007 by Shin Fujiyama. One of our main initiatives is funding the construction of 1,000 schools in Honduras. This is the number of schools that will allow every child in Honduras to have access to a quality education. Since its founding, OTS has completed 67 schools.

Honduras is the home of major cities like San Pedro Sula, where the murder rate and gang populations are high enough to consistently make them front page news on the New York Times and other prestigious US news sources. In 2009, Shin Fujiyama received a CNN Heroes award for his work in Honduras and appeared on shows like Larry King Live to explain the groundbreaking work One Thousand Schools was facilitating in Honduras. 

OTS is only able to build schools in Honduras through the fundraising and volunteering provided by high school and collegiate chapters in the United States. 100% of funds donated by a chapter goes directly towards funding the construction of schools in Honduras. Members of those chapters have the opportunity to travel to Honduras and help build the schools they worked hard to raise money for. This is both an incredible learning experience for people and a great motivator for students to continue their fundraising efforts. OTS has a perfect safety record, and each member comes back with a changed perspective and enriched knowledge of life very different from theirs, as well as true hope for what can be accomplished through continued hard work in Honduras building schools and in the United States building chapters.

The University of Michigan chapter of One Thousand Schools looks to build a community of passionate, strong-willed University of Michigan students who can help (1) build knowledge and awareness of the University of Michigan campus of the current issues being faced by Honduras and, as a consequence, how those issues translate to current border disputes and international politics, (2) raise money to build schools and donate school supplies to the communities working with SHH in Honduras, and (3) send volunteers on a safe and empowering service trip to Honduras at least once per year to participate in the building of these schools and to learn about the culture and people of Honduras. 

This organization hopes to build a movement of young UM leaders with the collective goal of empowering and providing fundamental human needs to impoverished children and families in Honduras by promoting awareness through volunteerism and global responsibility.
Summary: One Thousand Schools (OTS) is an international non-profit organization whose mission is to combat gang violence and extreme poverty in Honduras through education and youth empowerment.

Name: One Year Masters Programs- Ross School of Business
Description: The One-Year Master's Programs offer 4 different programs that can enhance both your undergraduate degree and your recruiting efforts! Master of Management (MM) This 10-month program for recent non-business graduates enhances your bachelor’s degree with a mastery of business fundamentals. Master of Accounting (MAcc) This 8-month program prepares students from any background for a career as a CPA and beyond. Master of Supply Chain Management (MSCM) This 10-month program provides the business acumen and technical expertise required to master the global supply chain. Master of Business Analytics (MBAn) This 10-month program equips students with the expertise needed to transform data into impactful business solutions. Each degree offers a wealth of career opportunities and a powerful network of support.
Summary: The One-Year Master's Programs offer 4 different programs that can enhance both your undergraduate degree and your recruiting efforts!

Name: Online MBA Council at Michigan Ross School of Business
Description: The purpose of this organization shall be to further the mission of the Stephen M.
