Ross School of Business by representing the needs and interests of all Online MBA (OMBA) students, promoting OMBA student involvement in the school’s decision-making process, serving as a liaison between the OMBA student body and the Ross administration, and driving positive change by learning and evolving to meet the unique needs of current and future cohorts.
Summary: The OMBA Council represents the needs and interests of all Online MBA students at the Stephen M. Ross School of Business.

Name: Operation Smile at the University of Michigan
Description: Operation Smile is an international children’s medical charity that heals children’s smiles by providing reconstructive surgery and related medical care for children born with cleft palates and cleft lips. While you may think children with cleft lips and cleft palates only face issues socially, when really the children that do survive are unable to eat, speak, or smile. Operation Smile mobilizes a force of medical professionals globally for medical missions.
Summary: Operation Smile will act to raise awareness for cleft palate and cleft lip conditions in addition to fundraising for medical mission trips to treat them safely around the globe.

Name: Opportunities to Educate Children
Description:
Opportunities to Educate Children is a nonprofit student organization, founded in 2006 by students at the University of Michigan who believe that every child has the right to an education. 
 
OEC strives to promote and provide access to education for children locally by means of weekly tutoring and mentoring. OEC provides members with a chance to participate in community service and leadership. OEC partners with community centers, schools, and hospitals to develop effective tutoring programs.
Summary: Opportunities to Educate Children (OEC) seeks to promote and provide educational access for children in the Ann Arbor area by means of weekly tutoring and mentoring from University of Michigan Students. Visit oec.studentorgs.umich.edu for more info.

Name: optiMize
Description:
We unite students who are passionate about social change and want to take action. Our supportive community provides students with resources that make it possible to turn ideas into impact.

Through our Social Innovation Challenge and Summer Fellowship Program, we annually provide over $200,000 in funding which allows our teams to continue innovating toward a better world.

We encourage ourselves to push boundaries and take on new challenges by always asking, "Why not me?"
Summary: optiMize motivates students to turn their ideas for social change into real world impact.

Name: Org Essentials (TEST)
Description: Org essentials
Summary: The org essentials test org

Name: Organ Transplant and Health Awareness
Description: OTHA (Organ Transplant and Health Awareness) is a student-led initiative at the University of Michigan dedicated to promoting awareness and education around organ health and transplantation. Our mission is to foster a community of informed advocates who support organ donation and understand the critical importance of maintaining organ health. Through workshops, guest lectures, and community partnerships, OTHA strives to inspire positive change and provide support for individuals affected by organ transplantation. We welcome all students interested in making a difference in this vital area of health care to join our efforts in educating and advocating for lifesaving organ donations.
Summary: OTHA at the University of Michigan promotes organ health and transplantation awareness through educational workshops, advocacy, and volunteer services. Join us in making a meaningful impact on health and lives.

Name: Organization of Public Interest Students
Description: OPIS aims to support and advocate for law students who desire to pursue a career in public interest law. We aim to provide a support network for those students at the law school, both through our social events and career-oriented programming.
Summary: OPIS provides a positive atmosphere for law students who desire to pursue a career in public interest law. We also aim to advocate for better funding, faculty, and programming for students who want to pursue public interest careers.

Name: Organizational Studies
Description: Organizational studies is built on a foundation of three disciplines--sociology, economics, and psychology. Each discipline contributes a unique lens through which to see organizations, their forms, and their processes. These three perspectives together give students broad scope for understanding an organizational world. The Interdisciplinary Program in Organizational Studies provides students with grounding in each of these disciplines and allows them to create new ways of seeing and understanding organizations. Organizational Studies prepares students in new ways about how organizations influence our lives and our world.
Summary: Organizational studies is built on a foundation of three disciplines--sociology, economics, and psychology. Each discipline contributes a unique lens through which to see organizations, their forms, and their processes.

Name: Origami Club at the University of Michigan
Description:
Origami Club at the University of Michigan is a club for people who enjoy making origami, from beginners to pros. We hope this club will be a space for students to take time out of their busy schedules and relax with friends while creating art.

Fill in this form to become a member: https://forms.gle/KsEVaAxLKndjXzeD8

Join our Discord here! https://discord.gg/zQEWtqDYQX
Summary: Origami Club at the University of Michigan is a club for people who enjoy making origami, from beginners to pros. We hope this club will be a space for students to take time out of their busy schedules and relax with friends while creating art.

Name: Orthodox Christian Fellowship at the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor
Description:
To support fellowship on campus, to experience and witness the Orthodox Christian Church through community life, prayer, service to others, and to study the Faith (Acts 2:42).

Join our mailing list to be notified of upcoming events!

Visit our website!
Summary: To support fellowship on campus, to experience and witness the Orthodox Christian Faith through community life, prayer, service to others, and study of the Faith (Acts 2:42).

Name: Orthopaedic Surgery Student Interest Group at the University of Michigan
Description: The goal of OSSIG is to expose medical students who have an interest in orthopaedic surgery to different facets of the field. Meetings will explore the field at all levels of training and work to expose pre-clinical students to current literature and surgical techniques/approaches. In addition, medical students will have the opportunity to listen to and solicit information from both current orthopaedic surgery residents and attendings.
Summary: OSSIG is a medical student interest group that explores the field of Orthopaedic Surgery as a potential career path

Name: Out For Business
Description: Out For Business's (OFB) mission is to build community among the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) members of the Ross School of Business community and to raise awareness among all Ross faculty, staff and students of the issues facing LGBT individuals in society.
Summary: The mission of Out For Business (OFB) is to build community among the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender members of the Ross community and to raise awareness among all faculty, staff and students of the issues facing LGBT individuals in society.

Name: Out For Business Undergraduate
Description: Out For Business Undergrad's mission is to build community among LGBTQ+ students at the University of Michigan and Stephen M. Ross School of Business and to connect students to opportunities in business. We are open to all undergraduate students at the University.
Summary: Out For Business Undergrad's mission is to build community among LGBTQ+ students at the University of Michigan and Stephen M. Ross School of Business and to connect students to opportunities in business. We are open to all undergraduate students.

Name: Out in Public
Description: Out in Public (OIP) is a social, educational, and professional organization within the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy at the University of Michigan. Working with allies at the Ford School and on campus, OIP raises awareness of policy issues affecting the LGBTQ community. We sponsor seminars and workshops, hold academic events, and host social gatherings to promote communication, education, and support. Our social gatherings are to bring like minded people together to build an inclusive community of students, staff, and faculty.
Summary: Out in Public is the Ford School's LGBTQ+ student organization committed to convening professional and academic activities that support queer and allied students of public policy.

Name: Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
Description:
Our mission is to provide professional development, and social support for undergraduate and graduate LGBTQ students in STEM fields. We do this through networking opportunities, mentorship programs and social activities.

We are ACTIVE! We hold weekly meetings on Fridays 5-6:30PM in Mason Hall, for our members to spend time together, with themes ranging from discussion of identities to leadership. Community and peer support are fundamental aspects of our organization, based in open discussion and effective communication. We hold social events including dinners, cider and doughnuts, board game nights, and more to allow members to get together and bond outside weekly meetings. 

We also host larger scale events such as Pride Outside, company dinners and professor panels. Our members learn about others' experiences being out in the workplace and build connections with LGBTQ professionals.

For information and reminders about our events, join our email list by filling out this form and join our Discord server!

Our events are open to allies, though support and resources are very focused toward the LGBTQIA2S+ community.

Check out our website!
Summary: Our mission is to provide professional development and social support for undergraduate and graduate LGBTQIA2S+ students through networking opportunities, mentorship programs and social activities. Check out our website at ostem-um.carrd.co

Name: Outdoor Club at Ross School of Business
Description: The mission of Outdoor Club is to organize outdoor events that educate and enrich the lives of graduate MBA students at Ross. The Outdoor Club will facilitate events that promote spending time in the outdoors while forming connections with fellow students and Ross community members. Students are required to sign up using this Google Form: https://forms.gle/WkfzoTHC3KPjmq3d7
Summary: Ross Outdoor Club promotes outdoor activities for grad students at Ross. We believe an active lifestyle allows an individual to be well rounded and leads to a happier, healthier, and more successful life. Sign up here: https://forms.gle/WkfzoTHC3KPjmq3d7

Name: Outlaws
Description: Outlaws is a student group at Michigan Law that advocates for the inclusion of LGBTQIA+ perspectives within the law school, and works with allies within the school and beyond to end discrimination in all its forms. We sponsor numerous educational and social events throughout the year, keep the law school community informed on legal issues affecting LGBTQIA+ rights, and raise the visibility of LGBTQIA+ people within the legal profession. Outlaws pursues its educational efforts in solidarity with other student organizations. Outlaws also provides a dynamic social space for members of the LGBTQIA+ community at the law school.
Summary: Outlaws is a social and political organization that serves the needs of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, and asexual community at the University of Michigan Law School.

Name: OutMD
Description: OutMD seeks to create a safe space for LGBTQ-identified persons and allies within the medical school and to bring awareness to the disparities that LGBTQ-identified persons face in the healthcare arena as both patients and providers. We support these aims by hosting regular meetings, organizing lectures and panels, and sponsoring students to attend conferences related to LGBTQ health disparities. For the school, our activities will create an inclusive atmosphere and provide important knowledge for future physicians when caring for this population.
Summary: OutMD is a student-run organization that raises awareness of LGBTQ health-related issues in the medical school and UM Health System.

Name: Outrage Dance Group
Description:
Outrage dance is a dance performance team that specializes in jazz and contemporary. We perform at UM sporting events, Dance Marathon, other events on campus, and an annual end of year showcase.

Check out our Instagram for the latest updates about auditions and performances!
Summary: Outrage dance is a jazz and contemporary dance group that holds several practices during the week and performs at shows/events throughout the semester.

Name: Oxford Ahimsa Multicultural Council
Description: Oxford's Ahimsa Multicultural Council works to enrich the lives of all Oxford residents by creating opportunities for positive community development; fostering a safe and welcoming environment in recognition of the variety of identities in our community; and advocating on behalf of historically underrepresented communities at the University of Michigan. All in all, we envision an Oxford community that is united in a common cause and reflective of the change we wish to see in the world.
Summary: The mission of Oxford's Ahimsa Multicultural Council is to build community among Oxford residents, while also promoting diversity and social justice within the residence hall through events that are inclusive and welcoming for all residents

Name: Oxford Hall Council
Description: The mission of the Oxford Community Council is to build community among Oxford residents, while also promoting diversity and social justice within the residence hall. The Oxford Community Council works to enrich the lives of all Oxford residents by creating opportunities for positive community development; serving as a liaison to Dining, Facilitates, and the Residence Hall Association (RHA); fostering a safe and welcoming environment in recognition of our intersecting identities; and advocating on behalf of historically underrepresented communities at the University of Michigan. In short, we envision an Oxford community that is united in common cause and reflective of the change we wish to see in the world.
Summary: The Oxford Hall Council is a group within the residence hall that is dedicated to building community among the Oxford residents, while also promoting diversity and social justice within the residence hall.

Name: PACCAR: Program Advancing Coding Comfort for Aspiring biomedical Researchers
Description: Our organization’s general goal is to advance comfort with coding/programming among biomedical researchers. Current advancements in technology put biomedical researchers with an understanding of coding at a large advantage in terms of job success and research yield. Without programming, researchers often need to resort to time-consuming and error-prone quantification methods that deter potentially influential research. However, university-level biology and related programs often do not enforce programming requirements, yielding graduate and even post-graduate researchers with minimal coding comfort. To combat this, we want to teach medical researchers or those considering that career field enough coding skills to create basic programs and be able to apply those skills to their research.
Summary: Our organization’s general goal is to promote programming comfort among students interested in medicine and biomedical research through coding lessons/projects and lessons about relevant technological applications in medicine.

Name: Pages for Pediatrics at the University of Michigan
Description: We create stories that reflect our patients’ experiences and empower them to embrace their differences. Through relatable characters and engaging plots, our goal is to instill hope, comfort, and solidarity in our readers and promote representation of pediatric illness in the broader community. We also donate our books to children’s hospitals nationwide and local elementary schools.
Summary: Pages for Pediatrics at the University of Michigan is a local chapter of the nonprofit organization Pages for Pediatrics which aims to write, illustrate, and publish children’s storybooks with representation for pediatric illness and disability.

Name: Paid Research Pool
Description:
The Paid Research Pool is a group that is eligible to participate in online paid experiments and surveys. Any student, staff, or faculty member is welcome to join. Studies are regulated by the U-M IRB (Institutional Review Board) and are designed by Ross School of Business researchers. Typical experiments involve online surveys, taste tests, product testing, focus groups, and decision making related to marketing, teamwork, strategy, leadership, management, etc. Visit http://rosspaidpool.bus.umich.edu/ for more information on how to join.

In-person studies typically pay you in cash $$$ and online studies typically pay by virtual gift cards or checks sent to your home.
Summary: When you join the Paid Research Pool, you get access to opportunities to get paid for participating in online experiments and surveys. Any student, staff, or faculty member is welcome to join.

Name: Palestinian American Medical Association UM Chapter
Description: We strive to provide immediate medical relief to Palestinians living in Gaza and the West Bank and to establish and support programs, education & training that foster the future of Palestinian health care and advance healthcare experience of UM students.
Summary: We strive to provide immediate medical relief to Palestinians living in Gaza and the West Bank and to establish and support programs, education & training that foster the future of Palestinian health care and advance healthcare experience of UM students.

Name: Palestinian Empowerment Foundation
Description: The Palestinian Empowerment Foundation stands in solidarity with Palestine and is dedicated to promoting the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination, spreading awareness about Palestine and raising funds to uplift Palestinian students through the power of education.
Summary: The Palestinian Empowerment Foundation stands in solidarity with Palestine and is dedicated to spreading awareness and promoting the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination.

Name: Palliative Care Skills for All Physicians
Description: The goal of PalMD is to create a dynamic and multifaceted platform in order to provide skills and knowledge to students on palliative and end-of-life care, regardless of desired specialty, through three main initiatives: shadowing, education, and advocacy for the incorporation of primary palliative care training to all MD students. PalMD connects medical students with shadowing opportunities to gain insight into palliative medicine in clinical settings and to establish relationships with healthcare providers in those settings.  PalMD helps educate students on issues surrounding palliative and end-of-life care through a diverse range of experiences, such as through skills sessions and a dynamic lecture series. PalMD will additionally work with the medical school to incorporate formal education around palliative care concepts into the MD curriculum. Finally, PalMD works to help empower students to cope with difficult encounters on and off the wards through a palliative care lens, simultaneously helping to promote the wellness of the medical student community in facing such encounters.
Summary: Group based at the medical school to provide primary palliative care skills and knowledge to all students.

Name: Palmer Commons
Description: Palmer Commons is a Conference and Community Center located in the University of Michigan Life Sciences Complex. Positioned at the intersection of Central and Medical Campuses, this multifunctional facility provides a convenient location for all members of the University and surrounding community to make connections for meals, meetings and events.
Summary: Positioned at the intersection of Central and Medical Campuses, this multifunctional facility provides a convenient location for all members of the University and surrounding community to make connections for meals, meetings and events.

Name: Panel For Your Thoughts
Description:
Panel for Your Thoughts is a discussion-based club where students can philosophize on various topics relating to philosophy, politics, and more. We also hold philosophical discussions in the form of british parliamentary style debates.

 

-

Get in touch!

Mailing List | MCommunity | GroupMe

-
Summary: Panel For Your Thoughts is a discussion-based club where students from all backgrounds can share their thoughts on various topics relating to philosophy, politics, and more.

Name: Panhellenic Association
Description: Promote academic excellence of every member, promote ethnic, cultural, and racial awareness and interaction, promote social interaction, in a responsible, safe atmosphere, promote community service and philanthropic endeavors.
Summary: The Panhellenic Association is the organization that strives to unite National Panhellenic Conference sororities and work for their common goals. Meetings are held weekly with a delegate from each sorority to share information and discuss concerns.

Name: Pantanal Partnership
Description:
Pantanal Partnership uses sustainable technology and community-oriented design as a medium to improve quality of life for residents and expand research and environmental stewardship in the Pantanal region of Brazil. This, in turn, equips our members with a broad range of technical skills and a unique experience collaborating with and visiting other cultures.

 

U-M students partner with Brazilians to light up rural schools, design innovative incinerators
Summary: Pantanal Partnership uses sustainable technology and community-oriented design as a medium to improve quality of life for residents and expand research and environmental stewardship in the Pantanal region of Brazil, equipping members with relevant skills

Name: Parents in Medical School
Description: Parents in Medical School is an organization formed by medical students for the purpose of providing a close-knit and supportive community for fellow medical student parents. The organization also provides resources and information to navigate parenthood while simultaneously having responsibilities as a medical student. All individuals who identify as a parent are welcome. This includes but is not limited to mothers, fathers, step-parents, adoptive parents, foster parents, parents expecting a child, and individuals hoping to become parents while in medical school. Together, we aim to instill important policy changes, raise awareness, build a community, provide educational and personal support, and advocate for parents in medical school.
Summary: An organization for parents and parents-to-be who are medical students at the University of Michigan Medical School. This inclusive organization aims to provide a supportive community for parents.

Name: Partners in Health Engage at the University of Michigan
Description:
Partners in Health Engage (PIH Engage) exists to foster a grassroots campaign for the right to health for all people, worldwide, at the University of Michigan. We are a chapter of the larger, national movement Partners in Health Engage — a community partner who works in solidarity with Partners in Health (Boston) and their sister organizations around the globe to provide healthcare services to underserved populations.

PIH Engage at the University of Michigan has three primary goals: 1) to raise awareness about health equity and public health as fundamental human rights among the university’s community; 2) to lobby members of Congress to expand political support and financial resource allocation for policies supporting and improving healthcare for the most underserved populations globally; and 3) through fundraising and community service, to help actualize the public health projects Partners in Health and its sister organizations operate in partnership with local communities around the globe. Our chapter includes passionate premed and public health students dedicated to volunteering and making a difference in the world of health equity and public health!

 

Here's how you can join PIH UMich:

  1. Join the GroupMe: Click here to join.
  2. Complete the PIH Member Application: Fill out this form.
  3. Attend the Next Mass Meeting:
    • Date: February 18
    • Time: 7-8 PM
    • Location: Room 2437, Mason Hall
  4. Add the Google Calendar: Click here to add
  5. Visit our Website: https://www.pihengageumich.org/home
  6. Visit our LINKTREE: https://linktr.ee/partnersinhealthengageumich
Summary: PIH Engage at UMich fosters a grassroots campaign for health equity and public health. Our premed/public health/ and all students volunteer, raise awareness, lobby Congress, and fundraise to support global healthcare services for underserved populations.

Name: Pashtun Cultural Association
Summary: PSA works as a community to create a diverse, equitable, and inclusive environment for Pashtun descendants.

Name: Path to White Coat
Description: Our mission is to provide advising and mentorship services to pre-medical undergraduate students and to improve students’ ability to access information and resources critical to the medical application process. We intend to accomplish this goal by hosting monthly workshops, panel discussions, and mentoring sessions where students can access and discuss specific information about topics relevant to their pre-medical journey. These topics include planning pre-medical prerequisite courses, taking the MCAT, writing a personal statement, preparing for interviews, finding passions and values, and understanding the joys and challenges of being a medical trainee. Our vision is that every pre-medical undergraduate student at the University of Michigan will have access to advising and mentorship support from medical students at the University of Michigan.
Summary: Student organization ran by medical students at University of Michigan Medical School to provide advising and mentorship to pre-medical students, especially those who are low resourced/first in family in medicine.

Name: Pay It Forward!
Description: Through our mentorship program, we hope to inform and encourage students about steps they can take to get accepted into the college/university of their choice. Our aim is to serve as mentors and host workshops for high school students so they are comfortable asking academic and personal questions related to their college transition. The Pay It Forward mentors are a diverse group of students that include undergraduate, transfer, and graduate students immersed in diverse fields of study.
Summary: A mentorship organization that aims to inform and encourage students about steps they can take to get accepted into the college/university of their choice

Name: Payment for Placements at the University of Michigan
Description: Payment for Placements at the University of Michigan is a student lead advocacy organization fighting against student poverty due to the financial obligations of the MSW program, particularly the lack of payment for work done through our degree required internships. We believe all labor is deserving of just compensation and work toward making this a reality through organized action.
Summary: Payment for Placements at the University of Michigan is a student lead advocacy organization pursuing fair payment for students with required fieldwork experiences.

Name: Peace Corps Office
Description: The University of Michigan Peace Corps Office is conveniently located on campus to help students prepare for Peace Corps service. During the Fall and Winter terms, the Peace Corps office routinely organizes information sessions, panels with returned Peace Corps Volunteers, application workshops, and more. The Peace Corps office is staffed by Returned Peace Corps Volunteers who are graduate students at U-M. They are available to meet with you one-on-one during regular office hours to answer questions about the application process, how to prepare yourself for Peace Corps service, and life as a Peace Corps Volunteer. More information about the Peace Corps office can be found here: https://internationalcenter.umich.edu/abroad/peace
Summary: The University of Michigan Peace Corps Office is conveniently located on campus to help students prepare for Peace Corps service.

Name: Pediatric Pharmacy Association at The University of Michigan
Description: LittleVictors is a College of Pharmacy (COP) volunteer student organization and a student group recognized by its national organization, the Pediatric Pharmacy Association (PPA). It is comprised of elected board members and general members from the student body of the University of Michigan (COP) committed to improving the health of children. One of the main efforts of the group will focus on advocating for health education through philanthropic events. The mission of LittleVictors will be to unite health care professional students at the University of Michigan in a joint effort to improve the wellbeing of children in our community while emphasizing the nature of pediatrics as a specialty. The purpose of a student group includes sharing effective and best practices, developing future leaders, creating localized student support, developing ambassadors for pediatric pharmacy, and developing a local grassroots network for national public policy initiatives.
Summary: LittleVictors is a College of Pharmacy (COP) volunteer student organization and a student group recognized by its national organization, the Pediatric Pharmacy Association (PPA).

Name: People's Michigan
Description: People’s Michigan seeks to build an America that is run by and for working people. We will fight for a socialist economic system, an end to imperialism and corporate corruption, and a re-investment in infrastructure. We believe these goals can best be met by creating strong working-class institutions. Based on our principle of class unity, we strive to create a multi-cultural coalition committed to uplifting the American people.
Summary: People’s Michigan seeks to build an America that is run by and for working people. To best achieve this we must build class unity, establish a socialist economic system, and fight for an end to political and economic oligarchy.

Name: Perfect Pair
Description: Perfect Pair is a program that creates one-on-one connections between older adults in assisted-living facilities and college students. Student volunteers and older participants are paired based on similar hobbies and interests. Through shared laughs, conversation, and fun activities, our members will have the opportunity to foster meaningful and long-lasting relationships with their Perfect Pair partner. Perfect Pair is unique in that it is largely individualized: meetings and activities will not look the same for every pair participating in our program. This allows for both the older adult and the student to organize their meetings in a way that is best tailored to their needs and interests.
Summary: Perfect Pair supports one-on-one connections between seniors in assisted-living facilities and student volunteers. Through personalized meetings, our perfect pairs will have the unique opportunity to foster meaningful and long-lasting relationships.

Name: PERIOD at UMICH
Description:
PERIOD at UMICH is a chapter of PERIOD INC, founded by Nadya Okamoto. The organization is committed to period equity on campus and in the community. We host product drives and educational sessions. Each year, the students involved will work together to choose their specific advocacy focus. 

As of right now, I am currently working underway to get registration complete and will update this page once it has happened. I look forward to meeting everyone! -- Tara
Summary: Make every day a menstruation celebration! PERIOD @ UMICH is a group focused on advocacy, education, and service surrounding periods.

Name: PERMIAS
ShortName: Indonesian Students of American Universities Association
Description: PERMIAS is short for Persatuan Mahasiswa Indonesia di Amerika Serikat, or the Indonesian Students' Association in America. We are a supportive community for fellow Indonesian students and families in the Ann Arbor and Ypsilanti area, as well as an agent to promote Indonesian culture. PERMIAS consists of eight executive board members that function, facilitate, and oversee events that help Indonesian students adjust to American culture like the Thanksgiving Dinner, Factory Outlet Trip, and Graduation Night, celebrate traditional Indonesian festivals like Batik Day, Indonesian Independence Day, and Chinese New Year, and display our unique culture to the U of M community through our annual Indonesian Cultural Night. PERMIAS is also part of the Southeast Asian Network, which aims to foster good relationship with other Southeast Asian student organizations and promote our collective culture.
Summary: PERMIAS aims to promote Indonesian culture at U of M and  provide a home away from home for Indonesian students.

Name: Persian Student Dental Association
Description: PSDA is both a social and cultural organization established for the expressed purpose of developing a community of Persian students within the University of Michigan School of Dentistry. This community will serve to act as a space for Persian students to express their cultural identities and celebrate traditional holidays. PSDA also seeks to raise awareness surrounding Persian culture. PSDA aims to develop community, friendship, and support networks during and after academic pursuits at the University of Michigan School of Dentistry in the hopes of creating PSDA Alumni for future endeavors.
Summary: The Persian Student Dental Association (PSDA) at the University of Michigan School of Dentistry is a vibrant community of students who share a connection to Iranian/Persian culture, fostering both social and professional growth.

Name: Persian Students' Association
Description:
The Persian Students Association is a non-partisan and non-religious volunteer student organization devoted to celebrating and raising awareness of the Persian culture around the University of Michigan campus. We aim to support and partake in Persian culture and heritage by organizing and sponsoring social events and activities that promote an understanding of our culture. PSA strives to build and maintain an environment of friendship and support for our students at the University of Michigan as well as in the greater community. Despite the name, membership is not restricted to students of Iranian descent, rather students of all ethnicities, cultures, religions, and ideas are more than welcome to join PSA.

Follow us on Instagram for updates about our events and follow our YouTube channel for videos of our culture show!

https://www.youtube.com/@michiganpersians/videos
Summary: The Persian Students Association is devoted to celebrating and raising awareness of the Persian culture. Students of all backgrounds are more than welcome to join. Visit our Instagram page! facebook.com/michiganpersians

Name: Pets Are Wonderful Support of Ann Arbor
Description:
PAWS stands for Pets Are Wonderful Support. Pets and animals are an important part of people’s lives, so we focus on connecting people with them in a variety of ways.  In the past, PAWS has volunteered at Leuk's Landing, gone to visit the Creature Conservancy of Ann Arbor, and volunteered at Starry Skies Equine Rescue. 

 

If you are interested in joining our email list, please fill out this form:

https://forms.gle/WUUg83cLBGNJDYm79
Summary: PAWS strives to develop and facilitate animal interests and the human-animal bond for students, by volunteering at animal rescue organizations in the community.

Name: Pharmacy Christian Fellowship
Description: PCF is an interdenominational group of Christian pharmacy students who exist for the central purpose of glorifying Jesus Christ in pharmacy education and practice. PCF strives to provide activities for the refreshment and encouragement of members, prayer and meditation on Scripture, education and discussion of current issues in pharmacy, service and missions, and networking with Christian health professionals. PCF is open to people of all religious backgrounds.
Summary: PCF is an interdenominational Christian fellowship at the College of Pharmacy.

Name: Pharmacy Student Government Council
Description: We work as liaisons between the students and faculty of the College of Pharmacy. We advocate for the interests of the students and create a richer student experience.
Summary: We are the student government of the College of Pharmacy

Name: Phi Alpha Kappa
Description:
Phi Alpha Kappa is a fraternity of men who are unified in their desire to walk with God. It is the mission of Phi Alpha Kappa to provide for the needs of these men as they attend college. This includes the provision of a safe and clean living environment, which will serve as their home. More importantly, Phi Alpha Kappa aims to promote the growth of its members, as individuals and members of the fraternity, through a central focus on God.


College is a place where diverse people with unique perspectives come together. Phi Alpha Kappa sees this diversity as strength and seeks to foster in it an attitude of Christian acceptance. Phi Alpha Kappa is a place where members have the freedom to make choices under the loving guidance of their fellow brothers. It is this atmosphere which fosters growth in the members while they assist each other in the pursuit of Godly wisdom.
Summary: Phi Alpha Kappa is a Christian fraternity of men living together to pursue their studies and further their walk with God.

Name: Phi Beta Lambda
Description:
Phi Beta Lambda is a co-ed professional business fraternity dedicated to providing college students an opportunity to improve their business acumen, develop valuable leadership skills, network with top business and student leaders across the country, and build an outstanding resume.

With a 100% post-graduation brother employment rating, our growing alumni base continues to be leaders in the business world! Ultimately, our mission is to bring business and education together in a positive working relationship through innovative leadership and career development.

Check us out our website: https://pblumich.com
Summary: Phi Beta Lambda is a co-ed professional business organization and community that transforms students into business professionals through education and career development including networking with top firms, workshops, and more.

Name: Phi Beta Professional Fraternity
Description: The object of the Phi Beta Fraternity shall be to promote the best in creative and performing arts; foster service in these arts within the collegiate and community area; advance the members both intellectually and professionally; develop the highest type of individual expression.
Summary: The object of the Phi Beta Fraternity shall be to promote the best in creative and performing arts; foster service in these arts; advance the members both intellectually and professionally; develop the highest type of individual expression.

Name: Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc.
Description:
Fraternity Motto: "Culture for Service, Service for Humanity"

The brothers of Phi Beta Sigma are the Fraternity's most valuable resource and strength. They are the primary means by which the Phi Beta Sigma objectives will be achieved. In order to accomplish the Fraternity's objectives, it is essential that systems are instituted that effectively embody "Culture For Service and Service For Humanity" and promote brotherhood, scholarship and service.

To optimize Phi Beta Sigma's effectiveness, the Fraternity will:

  • Strengthen and serve proactively the brotherhood, as a supportive resource that positively impacts the Fraternity's growth and financial solvency.
  • Reaffirm and maintain a strong commitment to brotherhood, scholarship and service.
  • Ensure that the Fraternity programs are focused and committed to serving humanity.
  • Create an environment that respects the dignity and worth of each brother.
  • Exhibit integrity and ethical behavior in conducting the Fraternity's business. serving as a model for all Greek-letter organizations.
  • Maintain and improve the Fraternity's technological literacy, in order to better service its members and the community at large.
  • Foster and nurture our constitutional bond with Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc.
  • Encourage a closer and mutually beneficial working relationship with fellow Greek-letter organizations, other community service organizations, businesses and government.
  • Select leaders who are committed and have demonstrated their ability to lead.
Summary: Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc. is a nonprofit organization dedicated to strong bonds of brotherhood, living with integrity, serving humanity, promoting quality education and developing leaders in our communities.

Name: Phi Chi Pre-Medical Fraternity
Description:
A co-ed pre-medical fraternity seeking to provide a forum wherein physicians and students of medicine may come together, to their mutual benefit, in a brotherhood seeking the development of the higher qualities of medicine; of nobler impulses of heart; of more profound scholastic achievement; of devotion to the art and science of medicine; and of a communion of kindred hearts pledged to support each other in times of joy, as well as adversity.

If interested in becoming a member, please take a look at the FAQ on our website, https://www.phichiumich.com/ , and make sure to join our rush email list to receive information and updates!
Summary: A premier, co-ed pre-med fraternity committed to academic excellence, brotherhood, service, and medicine.

Name: Phi Chi Theta
Description:
Phi Chi Theta is a co-ed professional business and economics fraternity. Nationally, our mission is to promote the cause of higher business education and training for all individuals, to foster high ideals for individuals in business careers, and to encourage fraternity and cooperation among individuals preparing for such careers. We also aim to improve business and professional knowledge, foster close bonds with all brothers and sisters, and prepare one another for success in the business world. Through our various events each semester, we create unique friendships that will last a lifetime.

We hold six main types of events throughout the semester, which are all representative of the various aspects of the fraternity: professional, community service, membership, fundraising, networking, and social. Here is a sample of what a typical semester can include: -Professional: corporate events, business school application workshops, career prep workshops, industry overviews, stock trading competitions, trips to Chicago -Community Service: Detroit park cleanup, food/clothing drives, awareness walks, community outreach -Membership: Whirlyball, mini golf, bowling, group dinners, relay games -Fundraising: Restaurant fundraisers, dodgeball tournaments, raffles, bar nights -Networking: Alumni tailgate, NYC Alumni reunion event -Social: Themed gatherings, trips to Canada, formal
Summary: Phi Chi Theta is a co-ed professional business and economics fraternity. We are made up of undergraduate students of who share a passion for the world of business. We bond through professional and social activities to form a tight-knit family at Michigan

Name: Phi Delta Chi
Description: Phi Delta Chi is a national professional pharmacy fraternity that promotes and fosters brotherhood and leadership among its members to advance the field of pharmacy. The first chapter was founded here at the University of Michigan on November 2, 1883. Now, there are over 80 collegiate chapters across the country. Our chapter (the Alpha chapter) is comprised of over 140 pharmacy students.
Summary: Phi Delta Chi is a national professional pharmacy fraternity that promotes and fosters brotherhood and leadership among its members to advance the field of pharmacy. The first chapter was founded here at the University of Michigan in 1883.

Name: Phi Delta Epsilon International Medical Fraternity
Description: We are Michigan Delta, the Phi Delta Epsilon pre-medical chapter at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. PhiDE at U of M Ann Arbor accepts applications for membership from any University of Michigan Ann Arbor undergraduate student at the beginning of each fall and winter semester. Requirements for membership include a demonstrated dedication to pursuit of an MD or DO degree, a minimum GPA, and a demonstrated interest in helping the PhiDE community continue to grow. Once a member, you will join one of four committees: Recruitment, Advertising/Public Relations, Programming, or Fundraising. Members in good standing attend a minimum percentage of fraternity events each semester. These events include biweekly chapter meetings, committee meetings, professional development events, and fundraising events. PhiDE is nationally partnered with the Children's Miracle Network, and our local affiliate is Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak. We hold several fundraisers each semester to support their efforts. We also organize educational, cultural, social, service, and professional events each semester to facilitate development of our members as both future and current applicants to medical school, and future physicians. We have MI Delta alumni at medical schools and other graduate programs nationwide, as well as access to the connections of the entire international medical fraternity. Most of all, our members talk about the sense of community and support within PhiDE, the friendships made, and the mentors connected with through the organization.
Summary: We are a co-ed fraternity of pre-medical students. We facilitate professional development, meant to make our members better medical school applicants and future physicians. We also hope to provide a community of peers for support and mentorship.

Name: Phi Epsilon Kappa
Description:
Phi Epsilon Kappa (PEK) is a professional co-ed fraternity for Kinesiology students. The focus of this organization is to enhance the awareness, benefit, and appreciation for health and fitness, dance, athletic training, exercise science, sport management, and related fields.

PEK provides students with leadership opportunities, access to knowledgeable upperclassmen, networking opportunities, and a lasting brotherhood. Members of this fraternity are provided with a unique opportunity to work and interact with peers in all areas of Kinesiology, each having different professional aspirations and experiences to share from their time at the University of Michigan.
Summary: Phi Epsilon Kappa is a professional kinesiology fraternity for students pursuing careers in Movement Science, Applied Exercise Science, and Sport Management.

Name: Phi Eta Psi Fraternity Inc.
Description:
Phi Eta Psi Fraternity Incorporated was founded in Flint, Michigan in 1965 during the civil rights movement. These determined African-American men set out on the mission of establishing a fraternal brotherhood of men. The Imperial Man combines the opportunity for lifelong friendship and service to others with academic excellence, cultural awareness, and community involvement. The founding fathers Based the solidarity of the Fraternity on three main tenants:

  • To strive for and achieve academic excellence.
  • To instill and maintain a strong sense of brotherhood, self-pride, cultural growth, and awareness.
  • To foster economic growth, social balance, and community engagement.
Summary: Phi Eta Psi combines the opportunity for lifelong friendship and service to others with academic excellence, cultural awareness, and community involvement.

Name: Phi Gamma Delta
Description:
History

Founded

May 1, 1848, at Jefferson College in Canonsburg, Pennsylvania

Founders

The “Immortal Six”: John Templeton McCarty, Samuel Beatty Wilson, James Elliott Jr., Ellis Bailey Gregg, Daniel Webster Crofts and Naaman Fletcher

Our Greek Letters

Members of Phi Gamma Delta hold our Greek letters in reverence.
Therefore, we limit their display to a select number of places, such as the front of the chapter house, the fraternity flag, class rings, and the member badge. When our Fraternity is named in campus or interfraternity publications, we prefer the full spelling of Phi Gamma Delta rather than use of the Greek letters or the nickname FIJI.

Nicknames

FIJI or Phi Gam

 

 

Phi Gamma Delta exists to promote lifelong friendships, to reaffirm high ethical standards and values, and to foster personal development in the pursuit of excellence. Phi Gamma Delta is committed to provide opportunities for each brother to develop responsibility, leadership, scholarship, and social skills in order to become a fully contributing member of society.
Summary: Phi Gamma Delta exists to promote lifelong friendships, to reaffirm high ethical standards and values, and to foster personal development in the pursuit of excellence.

Name: Phi Gamma Nu
Description: Phi Gamma Nu is a premier professional development organization that prides itself on members who strive to develop skills for the business world. Phi Gamma Nu provides an environment outside the classroom where students can broaden their understanding of business while developing lasting relationships. Standing on its three pillars of Professionalism, Philanthropy, and Social Engagement, PGN offers an abundance of opportunities to promote professional and personal development.
Summary: Phi Gamma Nu is a premier professional business organization. Standing on its three pillars of Professionalism, Philanthropy, and Community, PGN offers an abundance of opportunities to promote professional and personal development.

Name: Phi Iota Alpha Fraternity Inc.
Description:
The Beta Upsilon Chapter of Phi Iota Alpha Fraternity, Inc. has the objective to create a lighthearted yet professional environment for men across the masculinity spectrum who are interested in Latin America. The BY chapter achieves this by cultivating spaces that allow for conversations around masculinity. During these talks, we come face to face with ourselves and our members to break down the toxic traits we internalized. We practice patience, communication, and respect with one another to provide a space where honest mistakes turn into learning experiences.

The goal is to have these well-rounded and motivated members produce unique events that support the community in new and innovative ways. The members accomplish this by allowing their personal interests to integrate into the events. This allows each member’s personality and passion to shine through their hard work.
Summary: The Beta Upsilon chapter of Phi Iota Alpha is a work-hard, play-hard Latino-based fraternity that focuses on cultivating trailblazers, professionals, and intercultural thinkers. Brothers strive to embody our 3 ideals: Fuerza, Integridad, y Amistad.

Name: Phi Lambda Sigma
Description:
Phi Lambda Sigma is the Pharmacy Leadership Society, with its members consisting of the foremost leaders in the field of pharmacy.  At the University of Michigan, the Delta Kappa Chapter has the following mission and vision for its organization:

Mission: To empower the next generation of pharmacy leaders by providing innovative opportunities for growth and promoting the recognition and development of leadership

Vision: To become recognized, both locally and nationally, as a premier leadership group by challenging the status quo and driving positive change in the student body, community, and profession
Summary: Phi Lambda Sigma is the Pharmacy Leadership Society.  The Society has a mission to encourage, recognize, and promote leadership in pharmacy.  Special attention shall be given to the development of leadership qualities.

Name: Phi Sigma Pi
Description:
Phi Sigma Pi National Honor Fraternity is a member of the Professional Greek Council and focuses its efforts on increasing the knowledge of its Brothers, providing service to the community, and creating a positive social environment for its members.  

Phi Sigma Pi is a fun, welcoming community that gives you the best of all that social, professional, and service fraternities have to offer. 

Please reach out to us as pspbetaalpha@gmail.com if you have any questions or are interested in joining!
Summary: Phi Sigma Pi National Honor Fraternity aims to promote the acquisition and dissemination of information and knowledge through scholarship, leadership, and fellowship.

Name: Phi Sigma Rho - Eta Chapter
Description:
Phi Sigma Rho is a social sorority for women in engineering and technical science fields. Our chapter values are friendship, scholarship and encouragement, and we strive to embody those values is everything we do, both as a chapter and as individuals. Our National Philanthropy is The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, and we work locally with the Girls Scouts of America.

Interest form: https://bit.ly/PhiRho24-25
Summary: Social sorority for women in engineering and STEM.

Name: Philosophy and Law Society
Description: The Philosophy and Law Society brings together undergraduates who are passionate about exploring the intersection of legal frameworks and ethical principles. Through monthly in-person and virtual meetings, members engage in thought-provoking discussions examining the tensions between moral and legal obligations in contemporary society. We dive deep into philosophical foundations that shape legal systems while analyzing real-world cases where ethics and law converge or conflict. The society hosts events featuring legal scholars, philosophers, and practitioners who share insights on critical issues in jurisprudence. Open to all interested undergraduates, we welcome new member applications at the beginning of fall and winter semesters.
Summary: The Philosophy and Law Society brings together undergraduates who are passionate about exploring the intersection of legal frameworks and ethical principles.

Name: Photonix/UAC
Description:
We use glowsticks as our primary medium to create exciting visual art in live performances. We utilize glowsticks along with strings, staffs, and any other implement we can find to manipulate light in a fascinating way. We glowstick in order to express ourselves and to create a sense of wonder in our audiences, and to establish camaraderie with all club members as we pursue our shared goal. Self-discipline, self-reliance, and self-expression applied in a team-oriented setting is what Photonix is all about :D

https://youtu.be/sEboII2AyHc
Summary: Photonix is a flow arts group at the University of Michigan. We use glowsticks as our primary medium to create exciting visual art in live shows. We look to amaze audiences with mind-blowing performances around campus!

Name: Physics Graduate Council
Description: Grad Council was established for the express purpose of bringing students and faculty together for department-wide events, and collaborating with the U-M Physics leadership to strengthen the graduate program. Grad Council seeks to facilitate communication between graduate students and other members of the department, including faculty and administration. Above all, Grad Council serves as a resource for the graduate students in the Physics Department and works towards implementing suggestions and addressing concerns that are brought up by graduate students.
Summary: Grad Council seeks to improve the graduate experience in the Physics Department, both academically and socially, encouraging camaraderie and providing a confidential avenue for students to make suggestions and voice concerns.

Name: Pi Beta Phi
Description:
MISSION, VISION, CORE VALUES

MISSION

The mission of Pi Beta Phi Fraternity for Women is to promote friendship, develop women of intellect and integrity, cultivate leadership potential and enrich lives through community service.

VISION

The vision of Pi Beta Phi Fraternity for Women is to be recognized as a premier organization for women by providing lifelong enrichment to its members and contributing to the betterment of society.

CORE VALUES

  • Integrity
  • Lifelong Commitment
  • Honor and Respect
  • Personal and Intellectual Growth
  • Philanthropic Service to Others
  • Sincere Friendship
Summary: The mission of Pi Beta Phi Fraternity for Women is to promote friendship, develop women of intellect and integrity, cultivate leadership potential and enrich lives through community service.

Name: Pi Chapter of Alpha Epsilon Phi Sorority, Incorporated
Description: Alpha Epsilon Phi inspires exemplary women who are enriched by sisterhood and unconditional friendships, dedicated to selfless service and inspiring others, and committed to intellectual growth and personal development.
Summary: Alpha Epsilon Phi is a sorority whose goal is to foster lifelong friendships and sisterhood, achieve academic excellence, and encourage social involvement and community service while providing a home away from home to their members.

Name: Pi Kappa Alpha
Description: Pi Kappa Alpha is a social fraternity with the purpose of bettering the lives of its members through various activities within the community.
Summary: The Pi Kappa Alpha Beta Tau chapter is located on 1004 Olivia Avenue, Ann Arbor, Michigan. Beta Tau is a member in good standing with the University of Michigan Interfraternity Council, and is a recognized University student organization.

Name: Pi Sigma Alpha (Political Science Honor Society)
Description:
Pi Sigma Alpha is the National Political Science Honor Society open to juniors and seniors in the Political Science department. We work with the Department to provide our members with opportunities to grow professionally and academically. These events include our Professor-Student dinner, career workshops, lectures, as well as more casual events. Membership is extended to applicants who fit the criteria set forth by Nationals and our local chapter.


The current requirements for membership are:

  1. Completion of at least half the credits required for the bachelor's degree (i.e. junior or senior standing)
  2. Completion of at least 4 courses for juniors and 5 courses for seniors, and of work in political science, including at least one upper-division course (you do not have to have declared a political science major as long as this requirement is met).
  3. A GPA of 3.5 in all courses in political science
  4. Maintenance of general scholarship sufficient to place the student in the top one-third of the class
  5. An overall GPA of 3.5
  6. Transfer students must have completed four courses in political science at the time of application

Would you like to partner with Pi Sigma Alpha to host an event? Please contact Aleksandra Kole at akole@umich.edu.
Summary: Alpha Upsilon Chapter of Pi Sigma Alpha, the National Political Science Honor Society

Name: Pi Sigma Epsilon
Description: Pi Sigma Epsilon, is a community of motivated individuals who strive to support one another develop the business acumen required to be successful after college. We are constantly working to better ourselves, each other, and the world around us. This brotherhood reflects a bond unlike any other on campus -- a family.
Summary: Pi Sigma Epsilon is a professional business fraternity that prepares individuals for success in their business careers through professional, social, and philanthropic experiences.

Name: Pi Tau Sigma
Description: PI TAU SIGMA members are chosen on a basis of sound engineering ability, scholarship (upper 25% of Juniors and upper 33% of Seniors), personality, and probable future success in their chosen field of Mechanical Engineering. There are three grades of membership: Honorary, Graduate, and Active. Honorary members are technical graduates actively engaged in engineering work; or members of mechanical engineering faculties. Graduate membership is conferred upon persons who would have been eligible had Pi Tau Sigma been established earlier in schools not having chapters, or upon those continuing graduate study. Active members are selected from the junior and senior mechanical engineering classes at their respective schools whose mechanical engineering curriculum must be accredited by ABET.
Summary: Pi Tau Sigma (PTS) is the International Mechanical Engineering Honor Society and is a member of the Association of College Honor Societies. There are chapters at universities in almost every state of the United States.

Name: Pinky Swear PACK at the University of Michigan
Description:
Since 2003, Pinky Swear Foundation has supported families with a child battling cancer through direct financial aid for basic needs, as well as experiences that create emotional support including:Orange Envelope Program—For families with a child who has been newly diagnosed with cancer, providing a virtual ‘hug’ and small financial gift delivered right to their mailbox. All-Star Fund—A fund that covers a mortgage or rent payment, pays for gas or groceries, or other non-medical needs a family may have while caring for a child with cancer. Memorable Family Experiences—All-Star
Weekends and other unique activities that provide emotional support and quality time together out of the hospital. Pinky Swear Pantry—On-site food pantry at children’s hospitals with grab-and-go options for families so they can stay near their child with cancer and ease their financial burden.
Summary: Pinky Swear PACK is an organization that helps support children diagnosed with pediatric cancer and their families emotionally and finically. As a PACK on campus this includes Card Making, Fundraisers, spreading awareness, and All-Star engagement.

Name: Planning and Architecture Research Group
Description: The Planning and Architecture Research Group (P+ARG) was created in 2009 by and for the doctoral students at the Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning. Our mission is to enhance the academic and social experiences of students engaged in research across the college’s programs through collaboration. We seek to foster community among planning and architecture students in order to sustain an exchange of ideas within and between our disciplines and subfields. We are open to all students at the University of Michigan who are interested in engaging with issues of the built environment. To sustain our interdisciplinary conversations, we receive funding from both Rackham and Taubman College with which we hold regular workshops and events throughout the year as well as our bi-annual conference.
Summary: P+ARG is composed of students of the built environment, mainly in Urban Planning and Architecture but also open to students in all disciplines. We organize forums for sharing research across disciplines plus casual and social events. Let's collaborate!

Name: Plant Futures at the University of Michigan
Description: Plant Futures at the University of Michigan is open to students of all levels and academic programs. The University of Michigan Chapter focuses on education and multi-disciplinary learning around building sustainable, just, and plant-centric food systems. Beyond education and community building, another core focus of the chapter is to serve as a space for members to secure meaningful professional development opportunities, mentorship, and career opportunities within plant-centric food systems. Students will be able to connect with non-profit and for-profit organizations addressing exciting opportunities within the sector.
Summary: Plant Futures at the University of Michigan focuses on education and multi-disciplinary learning around building sustainable, just, and plant-centric food systems while serving as a space to explore opportunities with organizations in the sector.

Name: Plastic Surgery Interest Group
Description: The Plastic Surgery Interest Group (PSIG) allows medical students at the University of Michigan to learn about and experience the ever-growing field of plastic surgery. PSIG hosts events, many coordinated with the M1 anatomy sequence, to supplement learning and stimulate interest in plastic surgery. Michigan boasts one of the top plastic surgery programs in the country, and our team of accomplished mentors will help to set up advising and shadowing opportunities so that students may experience the field and develop competitive applications for the match process.
Summary: PSIG is a medical student interest group that provides medical students with opportunities to learn about the field of plastic surgery and to develop competitive applications for the match process.

Name: Poetry Slam
Summary: Poetry Slam at the University of Michigan

Name: Pointless Debate Club
Description:
Do you prefer hotdogs or hamburgers? Cats or dogs? Do you think the rainbow should include pink? Do you have a strong argument for it? Do you want to come and prove yourself? Join us at the Pointless Debate Club. In classic back and forth debate style, we argue topics that at the end of the day mean absolutely nothing. We’re a casual club for people that just want to debate in a more relaxed fashion.

Be sure to be on the email list to get any and all updates about the happenings; either by filling out this form or joining the org on maize pages!
Summary: Hotdog or hamburger? Cats or dogs? You have an argument for it? In classic back and forth debate style, we argue topics that at the end of the day mean absolutely nothing. We’re a casual club for people that just want to debate in a more relaxed fashion.

Name: Pokémon Go UMich
Description: Since 2016, people all over the world have enjoyed Pokémon Go for its combination of bringing the magical world of Pokémon into the real world. Yet, the greatest aspect of the game was its ability to bring people together and enjoy each other's presence in the outside world. Ever since its debut, Pokémon Go has dedicated itself to focusing on its community and how every member interacts with one another while playing the game. Even with the pandemic, Pokémon Go was still about exploring the world and being with one another. Our mission is to make our own community at the University of Michigan, to make new friends and enjoy new places in Ann Arbor, together.
Summary: A club designed for players of Niantic's 2016 phenomenon Pokémon Go, or any fans of Pokémon or going outside and exploring Ann Arbor. Our club's mission is to make a strong community of Pokémon Go players in Ann Arbor through the University.

Name: Portrait of South Asia
Description: POSA (Portrait of South Asia) is a South Asian focused magazine with a purpose to help shine light on continuously neglected narratives of the South Asian student population at the University of Michigan. As we see more South Asian representation in all forms of media, various stereotypes become reinforced through editing and refining South Asian stories to fit Western aesthetics. Through elaborate photoshoots and recording stories, POSA aims to create a physical relic of the South Asian experience in a way that is inclusive, authentic, and fulfilling. POSA’s goal is to capture the essence of being South Asian to help build a tangible history for the South Asian community at U of M.
Summary: Our goal is to help capture the multilayered essence of being South Asian. What it means to be South Asian is unique to everyone, and we want to capture what that means for you. Through photographic narratives, we hope to authentically amplify previous.

Name: Portuguese Club at the University of Michigan
Description:
The Portuguese Club will provide a space in which undergraduate and graduate students of all fluency levels can practice the Portuguese language and explore the cultures of Lusophone countries. Portuguese Club shall do the following to achieve its mission:

  1. Hold mass meetings in September and January
  2. Facilitate conversation hours monthly 
  3. Offer walk-in tutoring for large projects and tests in UM Portuguese classes
  4. Send out biweekly listserv emails to disseminate to club members opportunities to engaging with the Portuguese language
  5. Host Portuguese-language movie nights monthly
  6. Throw end-of-semester celebrations in December and April

Conversation Hour (Bate-Papo): 12:00pm-12:50pm in RLL Commons (MLB 4314) on 2/21, 3/21, 4/7

Tutoring/Homework Help: email PortugueseClub@umich.edu for more information!
Summary: We want to amplify the presence of the Portuguese language at UM!

Name: Poverty Solutions
Description: Poverty Solutions is a University of Michigan initiative that aims to prevent and alleviate poverty through action-based research that informs policymakers, community organizations, government entities, and practitioners about what works in confronting poverty. Students bring new insight, knowledge and opinions to our work, enhance our interdisciplinary and collaborative approach, lend support and capacity to our projects and activities, and help to promote campus-wide engagement.
Summary: Poverty Solutions is a University of Michigan initiative that aims to prevent and alleviate poverty through action-based research that informs policymakers, community organizations, government entities, and practitioners about what works in confronting p

Name: Pre-Anesthesiologist Assistant Association
Description:
• An Anesthesiologist Assistant or AA works in an Anesthesia Care Team and provides anesthesia under the supervision of a licensed anesthesiologist. The care team may also consist of CRNAs or Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetists, in which they share a similar role to AAs and assist physician anesthesiologists. Anesthesiologist Assistants have a master's level education, meaning they go to graduate school for 2-3 years following undergrad. 
  • To find more information about Anesthesiologist Assistants, visit American Academy of Anesthesiologist Assistants and American Society of Anesthesiologists 
  • As a member of this organization, you will benefit from:
    • Volunteering at Michigan Medicine, blood drives, and at the World Medical Relief Headquarters 
    • Research opportunities; Attending conferences and getting the opportunity to present your research there
    • Shadowing Anesthesiologists, CRNAs, AAs and networking with them
    • Resume and cover letter building workshops
    • Panels with Anesthesiologists, CRNAs, AAs where they discuss tips for the interview process, enhancing your CASAA application, personal statement, and more
    • Chance to meet with admissions officers for AA schools

Fill out the Member Interest Form to be added to the email list!

Join the GroupMe

Follow our Instagram for updates!
Summary: Pre-AA or CAA organization that aims to help and unite aspiring anesthesiologist assistants to gain valuable experiences, while also promoting the profession to a large community to those interested in the healthcare field.

Name: Pre-Dental Association
Description:
Our goal is to assist students of all ages and interest levels to better understand current oral healthcare issues, dental school admission processes, and dental school itself. Through volunteer activities, social outings, and mass meetings, each member also receives many opportunities to meet and network with dental school professors and students, admissions representatives from various schools, and fellow pre-dental students.

We provide information on the many dental careers, the various details of the application process, and how to get more involved as pre-dental student. We also work to provide a multitude of opportunities such as open house visits, talking with a panel of dental specialists, and outreach events in the local community. To learn more about our upcoming events, please sign up for our weekly email list at https://pdaumich.weebly.com/
Summary: An organization for students interested in a career in the dental field. We seek to provide leadership, social, and educational opportunities for our members. We are committed to aiding prospective dental students throughout their undergraduate years.

Name: Pre-Health Volunteer Outreach Program
Description: The purpose of this organization is to provide undergraduate students with the opportunity to immerse themselves in the healthcare field. If a student is currently on the Pre-Dental, Pre-Medical, Pre-PA, Pre-Pharmacy, and/or Pre-Nursing track, this club has opportunities available. By becoming a member of this organization, students will be directly connected with a variety of the clinical and non-clinical volunteer opportunities available. We hope to make it easier for students to find volunteer opportunities in the area.
Summary: Help connect pre-health umich students to volunteer opportunities and help them to gain valuable healthcare experience.

Name: Pre-Med Hub
Description:
Pre-Med Hub seeks to serve the University of Michigan’s competitive pre-med community by providing easy-to-access advice and resources for course selection, MCAT preparation, and more. Our advisors are juniors and seniors who have gone through the difficult weeder courses and are passionate about their goal of becoming a physician. We would love to guide and encourage you as you pursue your pre-med journey as well.  

Ask us a question, visit  our facebook page, read our Q/A archives and blog posts (and subscribe here for notifications), or talk to us privately through peer advising! Regardless of how you connect with us, we hope you leave with less confusion and panic than you came in with. We’ve been there. You’re going to be just fine.
Summary: We are a student-run platform at the University of Michigan that seeks to serve students by providing a space to ask and answer questions pertaining to all things pre-med. WE DO NOT HAVE A MEMBERSHIP, PLEASE VISIT OUR WEBSITE TO USE US AS A RESOURCE.

Name: Pre-Medical Club
Description:
Please refer to our Canvas page to join PMC! To be added to our Canvas page, please use this link: https://umich.instructure.com/enroll/EYWXPP. To be added to our Groupme for regular updates, please use this link: https://groupme.com/join_group/97879765/0OaVZPcs (Password on Canvas!) Follow us on Instagram @pmc_um!

The mission of the Pre-Medical Club at the University Of Michigan is to maintain an outstanding and diverse student body that has a strong interest in the health sciences and a demonstrated commitment to service and continued learning.  

The Pre-Med Club at the University of Michigan consists of active members and an executive board. One may attain active membership by completing the following requirements: (1) Paying dues ($10 New Members, $5 Returning Members), (2) Earn 5 points by the end of the semester through participating in various events. Participating in the PMC Mentorship program, attending the Alternative Spring Break trips, or volunteering in the WHSP program will grant members 4 points. Active members can apply for eboard positions, participate in the physician shadowing program, receive free Access to Medical School Admissions Requirements (MSAR), and receive a 20% discount on all Princeton Review MCAT classes.

We offer the following opportunities for all members:

Philanthropy partnerships with Wigs 4 Kids, Freedom House Detroit, Center for Success, Mothers2Mothers, Autism Awareness
Volunteering opportunities with the Wolverine Health Sciences Program, Food Gatherers, Relay for Life, Detroit Partnership Day, VA Hospital, Hope Clinic, Glacier Hills
PMC Formal
Alternative Spring Break 
Medical School Training and Exploratory Program (M-STEP) medical school visits and tours 
Mass Meetings with special guest speakers
Mentorship program 
Physician shadowing with local physicians  
Social events
and many more!

For more information please refer to our Canvas page or follow us on Instagram @pmc_um! To be added to our Canvas page, please use this link: https://umich.instructure.com/enroll/EYWXP. To be added to our Groupme, please use this link: https://groupme.com/join_group/88926217/6ZViVZja

For specific questions, contact us at premedclub@umich.edu.
Summary: By providing numerous medically related opportunities, our club takes pride in supporting every individual to reach his or her potential, and to become the leading physicians of tomorrow. Come join one of the biggest Pre-Med Clubs in the country!

Name: Pre-Optometry Club
Description:
Our goal is to educate those interested in Pre-Health careers on the benefits in the field of Optometry. We provide peer support, presentations from accredited optometry schools, meetings with optometrists, and much more!

Zainab Ahmad - President - zai@umich.edu

Ritika Chhina - President - rchhina@umich.edu

Nicolle Reid - Vice President - rnicolle@umich.edu

Raya Jaber - Community Outreach - rayaj@umich.edu
Summary: Our goal is to educate those interested in Pre-Health careers on the benefits of Optometry! We provide support from peers, presentations from accredited optometry schools, meetings with optometrists, and much more!

Name: Pre-Pharmacy Student Organization
Description:
You must email us at ppsoexecboard@umich.edu if you are interested in joining. 
 
Pre-Pharmacy Student Organization (PPSO), the only pre-pharmacy organization at the University of Michigan, is a student-run club for undergraduate students interested in careers in pharmacy. Whether you’re interested in working at your neighborhood pharmacy, in a health care system, or researching the latest drugs, PPSO can help you get there. 

Through a combination of professional development, career exploration, academic success, social, and networking activities, we work together to make the most of our undergraduate years and prepare for the next steps in our education and our eventual place in the exciting and dynamic field of pharmacy. 
We are future pharmacists, preparing for the future of pharmacy.
 
 

2024-2025 Executive Board Members
President: Lauren Cupchak
Vice President: Sydney Barnes
Secretary: Lanny Lo
Treasurer: Kylie Schramke
Service Coordinator: Noelia Dulo
Membership Coordinator: Samantha Watson
Social Events Coordinator: Alexa Seklovski
Summary: Our goal is to create a network of pre-pharmacy students to help each other prepare for pharmacy school, the application process, and a future career in healthcare.

Name: Pre-Physical and Occupational Therapy Club
Description:
Our mission is to foster a community of Pre-Physical & Occupational Therapy students to establish support, resources, and assistance in the quest to enter the fields of Physical & Occupational Therapy.

Commitment to the organization includes attending monthly meetings, participating in fundraising events for the club, and engaging in community service and shadowing events.

Monthly meetings feature guest speakers such as current physical & occupational therapists (as well as speech-language pathologists, strength & conditioning coaches, & more!), current graduate students, academic advisors, graduate school admissions officers and representatives from GRE prep services.

We offer job shadowing opportunities that connect students with physical therapists around the Ann Arbor area and through the University of Michigan Health System.
