Our organization is an outlet for networking with peers and alumni, allowing you to gain advice from upperclassmen regarding schools, applications, & PTCAS/OTCAS, as well as allowing you to collaborate with other students in Kinesiology & pre-health courses.

For more information, you can send our co-presidents Carly Anschuetz and Madison Bray a message at anscarly@umich.edu and mebray@umich.edu. You can also check us out on Facebook and Instagram at @preptotclub or by searching "Michigan Pre-Physical and Occupational Therapy Club"!
Summary: The Pre-Physical and Occupational Therapy Club is a pre-professional organization that supports and encourages undergraduate students interested in pursuing Physical & Occupational Therapy and related fields as a career.

Name: Pre-Physician Assistant Club
Description:
If you wish to be added to the email list and/or club roster, please email Lindsey Zousmer at lzousmer@umich.edu. The roster on MaizePages is outdated.

~

What is a Physician Assistant?

Physician Assistants (PAs) are healthcare professionals who practice medicine under the supervision of a licensed physician.  PAs provide physical exams, order and administer tests, diagnose, and treat illnesses and injuries.  PAs work in various settings including hospitals, long-term care facilities, private practices, and surgical centers.  They are qualified to practice in virtually every specialty area and can prescribe medicine in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. 

~

About the Club

The Pre-PA Club aims to consolidate information and resources concerning physician assistant program admission requirements, application procedures, and health experience opportunities. Our goal is to inform members about the history and purpose of the profession while providing familiarity with the healthcare system.

The Pre-PA Club intends to provide all members with opportunities to meet with professionals in the field, tour local Physician Assistant Programs, and discuss issues regarding the profession.  The club also intends to hold social events for members and fundraising events to aid in our local philanthropic efforts.

We hold approximately 7 meetings per semester.  Meetings are typically held at 7pm, bi-weekly on Wednesdays.

As a member, you will benefit from:

  • Meeting workshops regarding prerequisite classes and the CASPA application
  • Discounts on GRE Prep Courses and Materials through the Princeton Review

  • Interview and Personal Statement tips and practice

  • E-mails about job openings

  • PA panels and speakers

  • Participation at the Ronald McDonald House, local blood drives, Adopt-a-Family and more

  • Networking for summer opportunities ie. summer camps, patient care, mission trips, etc.

  • Restaurant fundraisers

  • Program directors from regional PA programs and much much more!

Dues are only $10 per year or $5 per semester 

Active members are identified as anyone who has paid their dues for that academic year or semester and has accrued 5* attendance points (per semester) by attending meetings and participating in volunteer events. Note that at least 2 of the 5 points MUST come from participation in volunteer events. Each meeting and volunteer event count as 1 point each. 


*This number is subject to adjustment based on the number of volunteer events offered each semester; volunteer activity points are adjusted to accommodate the duration of the event.

You can access our Notion with all of our resources and information here: UMich Pre-PA Club Notion 

or with this link: https://developing-paper-2a0.notion.site/Pre-PA-Club-at-UMich-43473689b6fa487d9f07b3b6ef7ada99 

For more information, please email the Pre-PA Eboard at umich-prepa@umich.edu

~

Executive Board

President: Laura Nowicki - lauranow@umich.edu

Vice President: Sawyer Darish - sndarish@umich.edu

Secretary: Lindsey Zousmer - lzousmer@umich.edu

Treasurer: Maggie Kase - mjkase@umich.edu

Communications Chair: Citlalli Villagomez - citlalli@umich.edu

Activity Directors: Molly Zidar - mqzidar@umich.edu, Lauren Whitall - lwhitall@umich.edu

Phlebotomy Class Coordinator: Megan Gibson - megagibs@umich.edu

Advisor: Megan Morsi, PA-C - megrum@med.umich.edu

Advisor: Natalie Nichols, PA-C - nnatalie@umich.edu
Summary: The mission of the Pre-Physician Assistant Club is to provide students aspiring to be Physician Assistants the means to reach their goals. The club aims to bring Pre-PA students, community PAs, and a variety of PA schools together.

Name: Pre-Speech and Hearing Club
Description: The purpose of the Pre-Speech and Hearing Club at the University of Michigan is to provide members with resources and various forums to expand their knowledge of the Speech and Hearing Sciences Field. The club aims to provide members with information and opportunities regarding graduate school requirements, field options, course options, current studies, etc. We organize events with guest speakers and Question-and-Answer sessions with people who have experience with Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology schooling and within the field of Speech and Hearing Sciences. We also strive to create a community in which Pre-Speech and Hearing students feel supported in their professional journeys, not isolated by the lack of a university department.
Summary: The purpose the Pre-Speech and Hearing Club is to provide members with resources and various forums to expand their knowledge of the Speech and Hearing Sciences Field.

Name: Pre-Surgical Club
Description: The undergraduate Pre-Surgical Club aims to provide students with exposure to a career in surgery within the various specialties and enable them to delve into the field of medicine at a deeper level than otherwise offered through traditional undergraduate opportunities. Through offering a variety of speakers, panels, and workshops for the undergraduate community and organization members, the Pre-Surgical Club aims to develop an individual’s passion for discovery within and knowledge of surgery and medicine as a whole. Further opportunities include viewing of surgical procedures as well as the ability to attend lectures and conferences detailing their advancement in the field. Students expressing interest in research related to surgery may potentially pair with a surgeon to work alongside them and present their research in an annual event. Lastly, the club aims to start an outreach program to youth in high school in order to spark their interest in a health career, specifically related to surgery.
Summary: The organization provides members with significant exposure to the field of surgery through providing a variety of speaker panels, workshops and shadowing opportunities.  Our mission is to empower students to explore their passion at a meaningful level.

Name: Pre-Vet Club
Description:
On a campus full of pre-med students, the Pre-Vet Club intends on increasing the opportunities available to pre-vet students. Volunteer opportunities will be facilitated both for animal and veterinary experiences. Members will learn both about the veterinary field as well as the application process and requirements. The Club intends on giving members a thorough knowledge of the veterinary field by visiting and learning about many types of veterinary medicine ranging from small animal to wildlife. Additionally, members will network and provide the necessary resources to adequately prepare for veterinary school.

For more information about our club or future careers in veterinary medicine, feel free to reach out to Josie Anderson our Events Director, Ava Freimark our Treasurer, Adriel Amador our Vice President, or Jordan Knight our President.
Summary: The Pre-Vet Club is for students interested in pursuing a career in veterinary medicine. The Club focuses on providing volunteer opportunities, networking, updated veterinary information, and pre-vet advising.

Name: Prenatal Partners
Description: Prenatal Partners aims to connect medical students with expectant patients who do not have a social or familial support system in place during pregnancy. Medical students accompany their partner to prenatal appointments and can provide support for mothers during the birthing process as well. The overall goal of Prenatal Partners is to improve maternal-fetal outcomes by strengthening social support systems during the prenatal period, as well as provide medical students an opportunity to learn more about the social, economic, and medical aspects of pregnancy.
Summary: Prenatal Partners is a club that pairs medical students with pregnant patients who may be lacking a social or familial support system. Students accompany patients to their appointments at the hospital and act as a support system during this time.

Name: Prison Birth Project
Description: Prison Birth Project is a student organization at the University of Michigan that operates at the intersection of reproductive and restorative justice. We aim to ensure legal reproductive healthcare access inside and outside of the carceral system. We also advocate for humane conditions of confinement and smooth reentry to society. Using anti-racist and inclusive practices, PBP engages in research projects, educational initiatives, community outreach, and political organizing. Sign up for our newsletter here.
Summary: Prison Birth Project is a student organization at the University of Michigan that aims to inspire students and community members to advocate for incarcerated mothers and birthing people.

Name: Privacy and Technology Law Association
Description:
The Privacy & Technology Law Association (PTLA) focuses on technology policy issues, including security and surveillance, privacy rights in the digital sphere, and internet openness.

In addition to hosting events to foster a vibrant intellectual dialogue on how technology affects the legal framework in which we live, we organize various career panels and other social activities for JD candidates, LLM students, faculty members, and individuals from throughout the University of Michigan community.
Summary: The Privacy & Technology Law Association (PTLA) focuses on technology policy issues, including security and surveillance, privacy rights in the digital sphere, and internet openness.

Name: Private Banking Era
Description: The Private Banking Era (PBE) provides unparalleled technical aspects of private banking knowledge, helping students understand the most elite services in the banking industry. We aim to equip our members with skills and expertise that help them serve high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) and ultra-high-net-worth individuals (UHNWIs). The goal is achieved through education sessions regarding the private bank’s special services (trust fund, family office, and evaluation of source of wealth), professional development sessions (wine knowledge, sporting pursuit, and wellness retreats), and guest speaker events. The strength of the Private Banking Era comes from members’ strong desire for continuous improvement and internal bonding. The Private Banking Era values members’ voices and ideas. We are committed to building a supportive and diverse community that assists each member in gaining personal and professional growth.
Summary: The Private Banking Era focuses on teaching the technical skills needed to serve high-net-worth clients, covering professional private banking knowledge with required personal training in luxury expertise and networking sessions.

Name: Product Motion
Description: Product Motion is a dynamic product management community at the University of Michigan, committed to empowering students with the skills and connections needed to excel in product-focused careers. Our mission is to bridge the gap between academic learning and real-world product management by offering hands-on workshops, guest lectures from industry experts, and collaborative project experiences. We emphasize key aspects of product management such as market analysis, user research, product development, and strategic planning.
Summary: Product Motion is a student-driven community at the University of Michigan that helps members develop essential product management skills. Through workshops, mentorship, and real-world projects, the community offers resources and connections for students

Name: Program in the Environment
Description: Program in the Environment (PitE - like might) has one major, Environment BA/BS, and five minors - Environment, Sustainability, Food & the Environment, Energy Science & Policy, and Water & the Environment. The PitE major and minor(s) give students the ability to explore the natural sciences (biology, ecology, and geology), humanities (literature and philosophy), and social sciences (policy, activism, and business) under the umbrella of environment. The program’s interdisciplinarity allows students to discover and connect how each of these disciplines shapes the human relationship to our planet. PitE gives each student the choice to pick their own adventure, selecting courses that are of particular interest to them. Our program allows students to go into the field for engaged learning experiences, including internships, field stations, and study abroad, which will prepare them for future employment and graduate school.
Summary: Program in the Environment has one major, Environment BA/BS, and five minors - Environment, Sustainability, Food & the Environment, Energy Science & Policy, and Water & the Environment.

Name: Program in the Environment Club
Description:
PitE Club is an enriching community for students interested in environmentalism, especially PitE students. Together we learn about environmental topics, participate in sustainability focused volunteering, and provide valuable resources toward professional development both at UofM and in the broader workforce. Specific events include the SEAS student mentorship event (BEAR), No Impact Challenge, Pizza with the Professors, themed workshops, and sustainable based social events (like environmental student conferences, hiking, and camping).

Our weekly meetings include environmentally themed presentations, planning for events, and the occasional potluck. Past events have included a beeswax wrap making event, a trail-mix bar, documentary screenings, and a plant propagation workshop. 

Additionally, the club coordinates volunteer opportunities in Ann Arbor for PitE Club members such as volunteering at the Campus Farm, Recycle Ann Arbor, the Maize and Blue Cupboard, the Creature Conservancy, Huron River Watershed Council, and more.

In short, PitE Club seeks to connect its members to enriching environmentally-focused experiences and education on campus and in the greater Ann Arbor community.
Summary: PitE Club functions as the liaison between PitE students and the academic department. Together we host events centered around topics like environmental learning, volunteering and professional development.

Name: Project HEAL at the University of Michigan
Description: The mission of Project HEAL at the University of Michigan is to deliver prevention, treatment financing, and recovery support for individuals with eating disorders through training and education. We will promote the mission and values of Project HEAL: Help to Eat, Accept and Live, a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization that has over 40 Chapters throughout the United States, Canada, and Australia. Through speaker events, fundraising, and spreading eating disorder treatment awareness we hope to reduce the stigma surrounding eating disorders and direct others to resources for recovery.
Summary: The mission of Project HEAL at the University of Michigan is to deliver prevention, treatment financing, and recovery support for individuals with eating disorders through training and education.

Name: Project MED
Description: Project MED is a 501 (c)(3) non-profit, originally started at Northwestern University, that focuses on educating and preparing high school students for careers in healthcare, particularly in underserved communities. The two main goals are exposure: providing students with insights into the wide range of healthcare professions, using hands-on workshops and peer mentorship programs, and preparation: providing students with the necessary skills and knowledge as a gateway to pursue successful careers in health. Our organization consists of three pillars: MEDLearn (workshops and speakers), MEDLead (peer mentorship), and MEDLaunch (database of opportunities for careers in health). As a whole, Project MED helps bridge the gap in healthcare career disparities and promotes diversity in healthcare.
Summary: Project MED, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit, helps underserved high school students pursue healthcare careers. Through MEDLearn (workshops), MEDLead (mentorship), and MEDLaunch (opportunity database), it bridges healthcare disparities and fosters diversity.

Name: Project Nutrition
Description:
Project Nutrition is established with the purpose of increasing awareness of healthy eating. College students often struggle with finding accessible, healthy recipes. We aim to create a platform for students to share healthy recipes in order to promote healthy eating.

We also collaborate with nutritionists and dietitians to host educational sessions covering topics such as macro- and micronutrients, meal planning, and strategies for healthy eating on a budget.
Summary: College students often struggle with finding accessible, healthy recipes. Project Nutrition was established to raise awareness of healthy eating. We will meet weekly to share resources related to nutrition, and we have created a virtual platform as well.

Name: Project RISHI at University of Michigan
Description: Project RISHI (Rural India Social & Health Improvement) is a non-profit organization whose mission is to promote the sustainable development and growth of rural Indian communities. In partnership with local community members and social enterprises, we identify issues central to our target communities and provide the resources to implement solutions through extensive field research and on-campus initiatives.
Summary: Project RISHI is a national non-profit organization whose mission is to promote the sustainable development and growth of rural Indian communities.

Name: Project Save Our Skin at Michigan
Description:
Founded in 2022, Project Save Our Skin (PSOS) has grown into a nationwide charity with a mission to improve skin health and disease awareness.
Our organization is dedicated to two primary objectives: providing essential skincare products to marginalized communities and educating the public
about skin health. Shockingly, 20% of Americans will face skin cancer in their lifetime, a statistic we are committed to reducing.
Over the past two years, PSOS has partnered with numerous institutions to organize city-wide skincare product donation drives and skin cancer
education workshops. Collaborating with schools, fitness centers, corporations, and more, we have donated over 1000 products to homeless
shelters, women’s shelters, children’s shelters, and other community organizations. Additionally, we have introduced skin cancer education
resources into schools and hosted fundraising events and pop-ups to promote healthy skin practices.
In 2024, PSOS opened a second chapter in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Between the Chicago chapter and Ann Arbor Chapter, PSOS has expanded to
include over 20 dedicated members across the United States. We invite you to join our growing community and contribute to our mission of ensuring
everyone has access to resources for healthier skin.
Summary: Founded in 2022, Project Save Our Skin (PSOS) has grown into a nationwide charity with a mission to improve skin health and disease awareness. Shockingly, 20% of Americans will face skin cancer in their lifetime, a statistic we are committed to reducing.

Name: Project Smile - Ann Arbor
Description:
Our chapter aims to make oral hygiene products accessible and organize free dental screening events for underprivileged communities. PSAA combines community action, advocacy, and collaboration to promote proper dental care and restore confidence.

Our mission is rooted in the belief that oral health is fundamental to overall well-being. Through our partnerships with local organizations, volunteers, and dental professionals, we address oral health disparities and ensure individuals in underprivileged communities receive the care they deserve.
Summary:
This organization focuses on fighting oral disparities worldwide and improving oral health in under-resourced communities. 
Through our volunteer efforts, donations, outreach programs, we strive to make a difference in the lives of those who lack access

Name: Project Sunshine
Description: Project Sunshine aims to spread sunshine to pediatric patients to restore a sense of normalcy to the pediatric healthcare environment, and make sure that kids have their childhood.With over 40 established chapters across the US and internationally, Project Sunshine at the University of Michigan will train you to volunteer with children at St. Joe's Hospital and beyond! All majors are welcome, as long as you have a passion to help kids be kids, regardless of the condition of their health!
Summary: Project Sunshine at the University of Michigan aims to spread sunshine to pediatric patients to restore a sense of normalcy to the pediatric healthcare environment, and make sure that kids have their childhood.

Name: Project WriteOn
Description: Project WriteOn seeks to create a community of writers from varying backgrounds. Our purpose is to employ writing as a medium of self and group healing. Our organization hopes to promote writing in various forms outside of academic uses through individual and group activities geared towards populations at the VA Hospital, C.S. Mott Children's Hospital, Nursing Homes, elementary schools, other student organizations etc. We are driven by the idea that writing is not an innate skill, but rather an art and practice that simultaneously stimulates our minds and enhances our communication skills. We, the members of Project WriteOn, do hereby establish this constitution.
Summary: Project WriteOn seeks to create a community of writers from varying backgrounds. Our purpose is to employ writing as a medium of self and group healing and promote writing in various forms outside of academic uses.

Name: Promoting Awareness of Teen Health and Safety Initiative
Description: The PATHS initiative is a student-formed mental health curriculum designed to address the pressing mental health needs of high school students across Michigan. This organization utilizes a near-peer education model, where trained college student volunteers engage high schoolers in meaningful discussions and learning activities about a wide range of mental health issues.
Summary: The PATHS initiative is a student-formed mental health curriculum designed to address the pressing mental health needs of high school students across Michigan.

Name: Propel Impact Consulting Group
Description: Propel Impact Consulting Group is the leading impact and startup consulting organization at the University of Michigan affiliated with the Stephen M. Ross School of Business. At Propel, we believe that business works to serve community. Our members are educated on the intersection between positive business and social impact to work alongside businesses and organizations ranging from local nonprofits and startups to national and multinational corporations. We provide enduring, innovative and effective business solutions and build impactful programs, initiatives, and projects to maximize the impact of our partners and to serve our greater community.
Summary: Leading impact and startup consulting organization with members educated on the intersection between positive business and social impact to work alongside local startups, nonprofits, and other organizations, developing initiatives to maximize impact.

Name: Protect Life at the University of Michigan
Description:
Protect Life at the University of Michigan is an inclusive organization that advocates for the value and protection of all human life. We are a diverse and open community, united in our commitment to fostering a culture that upholds the dignity of every individual.

 

As a non-partisan, non-sectarian, and non-profit group, we seek to educate and raise awareness about various issues related to life, such as unplanned pregnancy, adoption, abortion, euthanasia, infanticide, embryonic stem cell research, and the death penalty. Through informative resources and discussions, we aim to promote understanding and empathy among our peers.

 

At Protect Life UM, we engage with students and the wider public, encouraging dialogue and reflection on pro-life matters. Additionally, we provide support to pregnant and parenting students, ensuring they have access to resources and assistance throughout their journey. By fostering connections and building a supportive community, we aim to cultivate a campus atmosphere that values and respects the inherent worth of every human being.
Summary: We are the leading pro-life group on campus. We are devoted to having conversations with students about life issues, educating our campus, and offering our support to pregnant and parenting students so they are empowered to choose life in their lives.

Name: Proyecto Avance, Latino Mentoring Association
Description:
We are PALMA! As a student-run organization here at the University of Michigan, our primary focus is providing mentoring to all ages of our Hispanic Latinx Community here in Ann Arbor/Ypsilanti. We have three different programs within our organization: Pre-K, K-12, and Adult. 

What we do:

Our Pre-Kindergarten program focuses on younger children and helping them prep for school. Our Pre-K program uses lots of resources from the AADL such as games, children's books, and online learning games. 

Second is our K-12 program. In this program we focus on helping the kids with the schoolwork that they bring with them to our tutoring sessions. The amount of work they have varies by student, therefore tutors are also ready to work with their students on the subjects they may have a more difficult time with... extra practice is always good! 

Finally, we also have an adult ESL program. This program focuses on helping parents and other community members with their English. For this program, we like to have tutors who are proficient in Spanish. 

With all three of our programs, we pair one or two students with a tutor. We welcome anyone who wishes to be a tutor or a student with us. We especially love getting new tutors as we have a long list of students awaiting a placement. The bigger our organization, the more good we do.

If you are interested in joining PALMA, contact Victoria Mago (vicmago@umich.edu.edu) or Ellen McDonough (ellenmcd@umich.edu)!
Summary: PALMA is a free, bilingual, twice-weekly, student-run education promotion organization that serves the Latinx  community of greater Ann Arbor.

Name: Psi Chi Honors Society in Psychology
Description:
Psi Chi is an international honor society whose purpose is to encourage, stimulate, and maintain excellence in scholarship of the individual members in all fields, particularly in psychology, and to advance the science of psychology.

There is an application process to become a member. Learn more at our website.
Summary: Recognizing and promoting excellence in the science and application of psychology.

Name: Psi Upsilon
Summary: The Phi Chapter of Psi Upsilon Fraternity at the University of Michigan

Name: Psychiatry Student Interest Group
Description: PsychSIGN is a student organization for University of Michigan Medical Students. Our mission is to promote the field of psychiatry and psychiatric education among UMMS students.
Summary: Psychiatry Student Interest Group (PsychSIGN) is a student organization for University of Michigan Medical Students. Our mission is to promote the field of psychiatry and psychiatric education among UMMS students.

Name: Psychologically Empowered Business Leaders
Description: The Psychologically Empowered Business Leaders Organization (PEBL) is dedicated to cultivating a vibrant community where individuals with an interest in both psychology and business can empower themselves as leaders. Our mission is to provide a collaborative platform for students to develop essential skills for personal and professional growth so members can learn how to utilize their brain and bodies to become the most productive, and fulfilled, version of themselves, and so they may learn the ability to negotiate the reality they want to create in their life by understanding human nature as they navigate the professional world. Through a social impact lens, we actively engage with companies and organizations to build a better future while simultaneously fostering technical skills through hands-on projects. PEBL offers diverse opportunities for members to enhance self-confidence in leadership, connect with empowered professionals, and gain a deeper understanding of their role in the business landscape. Our organization achieves this through impactful events, including speaker sessions, networking, social gatherings, professional development education, and collaboration with businesses, especially startups. Ultimately, our goal is to equip members with the knowledge, skills, and connections needed to excel as effective business leaders, fostering a community where individuals can thrive and make meaningful contributions to the business world while becoming their best selves. We want to create an uplifting community where students can gain the technical skills needed to succeed in the business world--similar to other business clubs--while also fostering a community of self improvement and psychological understanding.
Summary: Committed to illuminating the intersect of business and psychology so individuals can become their best selves in a supportive community, and find success by understanding human nature. Members will also develop their technical skills through projects.

Name: Public Benefits Advocacy Project
Description:
PBAP is a law school student organization. Under the supervision of attorneys from Legal Services of South Central Michigan (LSSCM), we help Washtenaw County community members apply for and maintain public benefits including food assistance, cash assistance, state emergency relief, and Medicaid through the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services' MiBridges website. We also field questions about other public benefits-related issues. 

We help folks determine if they are eligible for benefits, why their benefits may have been cut off, or why they were denied.

Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, we have helped clients over the phone. In the 2023-24 school year we also re-launched our in-person volunteer efforts at the Ann Arbor District Library and the Delonis Shelter. We look forward to continuing our in-person efforts at various District Library branches (including Ann Arbor and Ypsilanti), Delonis, and other sites in 2024-25.

We provide training for new and returning members at the start of each semester to acquaint them with our services and the MiBridges website.  

PBAP provides law students with a valuable opportunity to participate in community service, learn about public interest and administrative law, and develop skills such as compassionate client interviewing and effective communication with government agencies.
Summary: Through the Public Benefits Advocacy Project (PBAP), student volunteers help Washtenaw County community members apply for and maintain public benefits including food assistance, cash assistance, emergency relief, and Medicaid through the MDHHS website.

Name: Public Health Association
Description: We are a student organization that aims to provide opportunities allowing for the education and discussion of public health while building a strong community of students that support one another in their exploration of and contribution to the field of public health. To achieve this, we host educational speakers such as current UM School of Public Health faculty and leading professionals in the field, provide community service projects and fundraisers, offer admissions and professional development workshops and organize social events, all to raise awareness of and advocate for public health issues.
Summary: An organization for future leaders in the field of public health.

Name: Public Health Genetics Journal Club
Description: PHGJC is a student organization aimed at enriching knowledge and understanding of the current public health genetics landscape. The club meets monthly to discuss current, relevant, and compelling journal articles.
Summary: PHGJC is a student organization aimed at enriching knowledge and understanding of the current public health genetics landscape. The club meets monthly to discuss current, relevant, and compelling journal articles.

Name: Public Health Student Assembly
Description:
The Public Health Student Assembly (PHSA) is the University of Michigan School of Public Health (SPH) student government. Our primary goal is to foster relations between the various school departments, support SPH students, and assist student organizations in hosting school-wide events. PHSA is a liaison between the student body and the school's administration.

Specific responsibilities of PHSA include:

  • Develop and maintain a strong working relationship between the PHSA and the School of Public Health to increase coordination on student events and SPH's professional and emotional resources.
  • Increase PHSA's internal advocacy role at SPH by [1] actively seeking and gathering input from SPH students, [2] synthesizing and providing information to the appropriate administration or body, and [3] following up to ensure due processing and attention
  • Support SPH student organizations through funding, marketing, communication, and collaborations.
  • Ensure effective communication between graduate programs, undergraduate programs, research mentors, and professors in SPH to foster an inclusive and interconnected community, uplifting the great work of each and gaining insights from one another.
  • Foster connections between SPH and other U-M programs to promote interdisciplinary events, learning, and collaboration between programs with similar interests and objectives.
  • Enhance and maintain sustainable partnerships between PHSA and the greater Ann Arbor
    community through equitable engagement, communication, and volunteer/service practices.
Summary: The Public Health Student Assembly (PHSA) is the student government for the University of Michigan School of Public Health.

Name: Public Health Students of African Descent
Description: PHSAD strives to create an atmosphere wherein academic and professional excellence can coincide with the interests of populations of African descent. We strive to disseminate and exchange information and concerns of marginalized groups in the field of Public Health and to serve as a network and support system for educational and professional purposes. In addition, we aim to disseminate knowledge to the southeast Michigan community and support the community through philanthropic endeavors and service.
Summary: PHSAD is a student organization centered around support, advocacy, and service that is committed to creating and fostering a sense of community amongst populations of African descent within and outside of the School of Public Health.

Name: Public Service Internship Program
Description: The University Career Center's Public Service Intern Program (PSIP) prepares undergraduate students to obtain summer internships in Washington DC, educates them to build career development skills, connects them with alumni mentors, informs them about career options through speakers panels & employer visits in DC, and supports participants while living in our nation's capitol. The University Career Center is proud to offer PSIP, the oldest and largest summer intern program in the country!
Summary: The University Career Center's Public Service Intern Program (PSIP) prepares undergraduate students to obtain summer internships in Washington DC.

Name: Puentes
Description: The mission of Puentes is to create an equitable space that centers the intersectional identities of incoming and current Latinx graduate students across schools, departments, and disciplines at U-M. We strive to foster a space of community, healing, and empowerment, where students feel supported and equipped to advocate for their needs and the needs of their community during and beyond their academic tenure at U-M.
Summary: Latinx Graduate Student Organization

Name: PULSE
Description:
PULSE is a student-run organization that aims to explore and promote the intersection between wellbeing and identity across the campus community through peer interactions and strategic programming. PULSE uses a holistic model of wellbeing in our conversations in order to generate a more complete picture of what wellness could look like and determine how our unique identities can affect those various aspects of wellness. As a PULSE member, students will have the opportunity to attend trainings and forums that facilitate conversations about wellness & identity-focused topics so that members can better equip themselves to handle the relevant and prominent trends across campus. Our goal is to empower members through conversations and community building in order to produce effective cross-campus programming and high-impact projects that address those prominent wellness & identity trends and provide solutions for the overall community, while fostering personal growth and creating a community for our members. 

To find out more about the mission of PULSE and how to become a member, please email askpulse@umich.edu for more information or visit our website!
Summary: PULSE is a student-run organization focused on the intersection of wellness and identity. We emphasize student-based change both inwardly within ourselves as members and outwardly by promoting health and holistic wellbeing throughout the campus community

Name: Pulse Magazine
Description: Pulse Magazine blends fashion, art, and culture into a unique space for fresh perspectives and trends. We strive to create a community where creatives on campus can come together and thrive. Our mission is to explore the intersections of style, art, and culture, offering a vibrant platform for emerging and established voices alike. Join us to explore the latest in style and creativity. We've got our finger on the pulse.
Summary: Pulse Magazine blends fashion, art, and culture into a unique space for fresh perspectives and trends. We strive to create a community where creatives on campus can come together and thrive. Join us to explore the latest in style and creativity.

Name: Punjabi Muslim Association
Description: The Punjabi Muslim Association (PMA) is a student organization at the University of Michigan dedicated to fostering community, unity, and spiritual growth among Punjabi Muslim students. Its mission is to create a culturally inclusive space.
Summary: The Punjabi Muslim Association (PMA) is a student organization at the University of Michigan dedicated to fostering community, unity, and spiritual growth among Punjabi Muslim students. Its mission is to create a culturally inclusive space.

Name: Punjabi Student Union
Description:
The Punjabi Student Union is an organization that aims to bring together students of Punjabi descent and those interested in Punjabi culture and heritage. The PSU works to create a supportive community on campus and to promote cultural awareness and understanding.

The Punjabi Student Union holds regular cultural events and activities that showcase the rich history and traditions of Punjabi culture. They also organize community service events to give back to the local community and raise awareness about important social issues. Whether it's through religious, social, or educational events, the Punjabi Student Union is dedicated to promoting a positive and inclusive environment for all members.
Summary: The Punjabi Student Union is a student-run organization dedicated to promoting Punjabi culture and heritage at the University of Michigan.

Name: Pure Dance
Description:
Pure is a microcosm of the Michigan experience: we provide dancers with the opportunity to work with others who have unique training backgrounds and strengths. Creating and maintaining an open and inclusive environment is extremely important to us. There are no financial barriers to joining Pure (we don’t charge dues), and we welcome ALL students. We recognize that the world of dance is often extremely demanding, both mentally and physically, and we strive to provide a safe environment where our members can express themselves without the pressure of conforming to the “ideal dancer” archetype. Fostering closeness in our community is a large part of this commitment - we make a strong effort to organize social events so that our dancers have the opportunity to build long-lasting friendships.

Pure Dance meets twice a week at the Intramural Sports Building to rehearse our student-choreographed pieces in anticipation of our annual showcase, which occurs at the beginning of the winter semester. We choreograph two to three large-group pieces and give our members the opportunity to choreograph small-group pieces each year. We perform these pieces at events around campus as well as at our annual showcase. Please reach out if you are interested in auditioning! watch us!
Summary: Pure Dance is a tight knit, student led group of passionate dancers from a variety of disciplines and backgrounds. Pure provides its members with opportunities to perform, choreograph, hold leadership positions, and participate in social events!

Name: Qingyun Chinese Music Ensemble at U of M
Description: Qingyun is established for the purpose of providing opportunities for performance experience and allowing students with previous experience in Chinese traditional instrument to continue their passion. We are determined to bring Chinese traditional music to the University of Michigan and promote cultural and musical diversity on campus.
Summary: Qingyun is established for the purpose of providing opportunities for performance experience and allowing students with previous experience in Chinese traditional instrument to continue their passion.

Name: Quantitative & Computational Finance Group
Description: Quantitative & Computational Finance Group is an organization that leverages computer science in order to create algorithms and code to solve business problems. We will create code in the context of consulting, finance (accounting, algorithmic trading, investment banking, etc), and marketing with the ambition of coming to data-driven solutions and advice.
Summary: Quantitative & Computational Finance Group is an organization that leverages computer science in order to create algorithms in the context of quantitative finance.

Name: Quantitative Investment Society
Description:
QIS is for students interested in applying quantitative models and algorithmic thinking to financial markets. Our members are comfortable with university level math and one or more programming languages. Our goal is to provide members the resources to develop trading strategies and a space to exchange ideas about financial markets.

To learn more, visit www.qisumich.com
Summary: The Quantitative Investment Society (QIS) provides University of Michigan students a collaborative environment to learn about quantitative finance, financial markets, and risk management through the creation and management of a student-managed fund.

Name: Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences
Description: The Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences (QMSS) program seeks to unite Michigan’s excellence in social science with the current revolution in the data science. The minor in Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences will train the next generation of social scientists in the methods needed to harness all types of quantitative data in order to generate new insights and solutions to the problems of today and tomorrow.
Summary: The Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences (QMSS) program seeks to unite Michigan’s excellence in social science with the current revolution in the data science.

Name: QuantUM
Description: QuantUM is the University of Michigan's student-led quantum club, sponsored by the department of Electrical and Computer Engineering. Hosting free events for people of all backgrounds, QuantUM is a place for students to share experiences centered around a common interest in quantum information science, engineering, and technology. Our mission is to introduce students to quantum science resources, research, events, and media, and to make quantum science accessible to all, eliminating all barriers to entry into the quantum realm.
Summary: QuantUM is a way for students to share experiences based on a shared interest in quantum information science, engineering, and technology, by introducing students to quantum science resources, research, events, and media.

Name: Queer Advocacy Coalition
Description: Through community engagement, programming and partnership with other LGBTQIA+ organizations on campus and within the community, our mission is to engage in advocacy work and educational opportunities and a sense of community and visibility for University of Michigan graduate and professional-level social work students.
Summary: QAC is established for the expressed purpose of holding space for graduate and professional-level LGBTQIA+ community members within the School of Social Work and beyond, and serving QAC’s higher mission.

Name: Queer ScientisTs
Description: A queer network based in the natural and health sciences. We hold social events, create resources, and look for new ways of increasing community and inclusion in STEM. Everyone is welcome at our events. Find more info on our linktree.
Summary: A network of queer researchers in the natural and health sciences.

Name: Rackham Student Government
Description:
The Rackham Student Government (RSG) is the student government that represents the thousands of graduate students in the Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies. RSG consists of 30 representatives who come from a variety of disciplines across campus as well as three executive officers. In addition to the elected members of the RSG Board, any graduate student may be a member of RSG's committees and/or serve as an associate representative on the Board. For more information, please visit http://rsg.umich.edu

 

Programs

See our website: http://rsg.umich.edu RSG Elections are held each November and March. Graduate students DO NOT need to run for office to be a part of RSG. While voting members of the RSG Board (our legislature) must be elected by the student body, affiliate representatives, committee members, and event volunteers DO NOT need to run for office. For more information about these activities, please email rsg-exec@umich.edu
Summary: Rackham Student Government is the student government that represents the 9,000+ graduate students on campus. Please visit our website, rsg.umich.edu for more information on our advocacy activities, funding, and events or follow us on social media.

Name: Radical Planning Initiative
Description:
This speaker series is part of an effort spearheaded by students to change the status quo of existing planning practices and challenge how conventional planning processes have enforced the material construction of inequities in the built environment. This speaker series will invite practitioners and community organizers to share lessons and tactics from their work. As activists working in real communities, they will inspire students, faculty, and staff with their visions and provide practical advice for on-the-ground change making.

Special attention will be paid to addressing lasting disparities and spatial inequalities that remain in part due to past planning actions. Students in the URP 611 section will explore these topics through attendance of mandatory Monday guest speaker sessions and discussion-based assignments. The course will empower students to collectively reimagine and implement new strategies in the future to address pressing urban issues and bridge the gap between reformist planning theory and practice to spur greater equity in the built environment.

Topics covered include: Indigenous land rights, racial and spatial justice, insurgency planning, collaborative planning, community engagement, urban informality, global planning approaches, community organizing, environmental justice, etc.
Summary: A student-led speaker series where planning practitioners and activists share their strategies, approaches, tools, and tips to understand how fight endemic racism, oppression, and injustice in the communities in which they live and work.

Name: RallyCap Sports
Description: We are the University of Michigan chapter of RallyCap Sports and we believe people with special needs deserve the chance to play sports! We provide year-round, recreational sports for children and young adults with special needs in the Ann Arbor community. Our volunteers are made up of University of Michigan students, who match-up one-on-one with local participants with special needs for each sporting activity. Our activities take place on the University of Michigan campus and surrounding area. About RallyCap
Summary: We are the UM chapter of RallyCap Sports and we believe people with special needs deserve the chance to play sports! We provide year-round, recreational sports for children and young adults with special needs in the Ann Arbor community.

Name: Rank MI Vote at the University of Michigan
Description: Whether you're seeking greater representation in elections, hoping to move beyond the two-party system, or wanting to hold politicians more accountable within a party you already support, Ranked Choice Voting (RCV) could be worth exploring. Instead of selecting just one candidate, RCV allows voters to rank candidates in order of preference. This means your vote can still count even if your top choice doesn't win, reducing the risk of 'wasting' your vote. If you're interested in joining a non-partisan student organization that educates people about Ranked Choice Voting, this one could be it! Our primary focus is education and sharing information, but we also have optional events and meetings throughout the year.
Summary: Ranked Choice Voting lets voters rank candidates by preference, ensuring their vote counts even if their top choice doesn't win. Join Rank MI Vote at UMICH, a non-partisan group dedicated to promoting and educating others about this voting method.

Name: Ratio Christi
Description:
Many university students wrestle with burning questions about purpose, faith, and identity. Ratio Christi provides a safe place to ask questions about the Christian faith--and gives resources to answer them with confidence.

We unite faith and reason to give students thoughtful reasons for following Jesus Christ. We seek to help Christians work through their doubts, and ultimately share Christ with their peers.

We are a Christian organization, but we welcome people of all views. We hope to be challenged by others and to share our beliefs with those who disagree.

Core Values:
Evangelism. We are evangelistic at heart. Our goal is to share the good news of Jesus on the college campus.

Training. We equip Christian students to answer the objections to faith that they hear.

Debate. If needed, we will directly fight against the ideas and worldviews that seek to pull people away from Christianity.

Fellowship. We’re just as quick to give a hug as we are to give an argument.
Summary: Ratio Christi (Latin for ‘The Reason of Christ’) is a global movement of university students and faculty seeking to unite faith and reason and present historical, philosophical, and scientific reasons for following Jesus Christ.

Name: RC Players
Description: The RC Players is a student-run theater group based in the Residential College. But fret not, you don't have to be a member of the RC to participate; anyone can join! Our performances are held in East Quad's Keene Theater. Each semester, the RC Players put on a variety of shows--ranging from sketch comedy (Evening of Scenes) to 24-hour theater (Red Eye), to full-length productions. So whatever your interest is, we've got a place for you to pursue it.
Summary: The RC Players is a student-run theater group housed in East Quad, courtesy of the Residential College at The University of Michigan. The group presents several productions each semester ranging from short sketch shows to full-length productions. Join!

Name: Reach Consulting Group
Description:
Reach Consulting Group (Reach) is a student-run, non-profit consulting organization that thrives on providing advisory services in technology, strategy, finance and management consulting. Our mission is to equip our members with real-world consulting experience, honing their skills in data analysis, problem-solving and effective communication. Through pro-bono engagements with both local and national clients, we strive to make a positive impact in the business community while staying at the forefront of technological advancements. Join Reach to be part of a collaborative and growth-focused community, where you can make meaningful connections with industry professionals and develop expertise applicable to careers in the consulting, finance and technology sectors.

For updated recruitment information and more about Reach Consulting Group, visit our website: https://www.michiganrcg.com.
Summary: Reach is a student-led technology consulting organization equipping members with real-world experiences. We make a positive impact with pro-bono projects and foster growth in a collaborative community. Join us at https://www.michiganrcg.com.

Name: Reaching out for betterment
Description: ROB serves as a platform for students to engage in healthcare-related projects, educational workshops, community outreach, and networking opportunities. By connecting students with professionals in the medical field, ROB aims to enhance members' understanding of healthcare challenges and innovations, ultimately preparing them for future careers in medicine.
Summary: Reaching out for betterment is a student-led medical club dedicated to fostering a community of aspiring healthcare professionals who are passionate about making a positive impact on society.

Name: Recreational Pickleball Club at the University of Michigan
Description: As Pickleball continues to gain popularity, there is a significant interest in fostering a community of enthusiastic players while addressing the financial barriers that some students may face. Through this organization, we aim to implement an affordable membership fee to enable students to engage regularly with their peers and cultivate enduring friendships rooted in a mutual passion for the sport. Our mission is to enhance accessibility to Pickleball by providing transportation to facilities for members in need and to promote an inclusive environment characterized by competitive play, friendly matches, and social events.
Summary: Our goals are to foster community, overcome financial barriers, and enable regular student engagement by enhancing accessibility and promoting an inclusive environment of competition, fun, and social events centered around the sport of pickleball.

Name: Recreational Sports
Description: Whether your goal is fitness, exercise, strength training, well-being, competition, adventure, friendship, or fun we've got you covered. Learn more by visiting our website.
Summary: Learn about how you can "Move Your Way to Well-Being with Rec Sports!

Name: Red Tree
Description: Red Tree is a Christian organization that believes that a person has a relationship with God through the person and work of Jesus Christ. We believe the Scriptures of the Old and New Testaments to be the Word of God and source to direct us how we may glorify and enjoy God. People who hold to other belief systems are always welcome to be involved with us and to worship and serve with us.
Summary: Red Tree meets students in this unique stage of life by exploring how the Bible impacts every area of life. We strive to be a place where students can ask hard questions of the Bible and grow in faith.

Name: Redeemed Christian Fellowship
Description: We welcome you to come and learn with fellow student believers about your true identity in Jesus Christ.  Our bible studies are centered around the Gospel of the Lord Jesus Christ. We believe students have such an immense opportunity to become well-rounded and excellent individuals right from college!
Summary: We preach the Gospel of the Lord Jesus Christ, teach the word of God from the Bible and care for people. Bible study holds every Friday from 6-8PM in 3901 BBB (Bob & Betty Beyster building on North campus.

Name: Redeemer Ann Arbor Student Group
Description: R A2 is a group of students connected to Redeemer Ann Arbor Church who gather for Bible study, community, and encouragment.
Summary: The purpose of Redeemer A2 Student Group is to provide spiritual encouragement and information to U of M students about Redeemer Ann Arbor.  Redeemer Ann Arbor is a church plant located close to the campus of U of M (www.RedeemerA2.org).

Name: Redefined
Description:
Redefined is a Christ-centered service organization made up of people who love each other and want to live out God-given mission to serve our communities.

 

We believe that service is one of the greatest acts of love and, as Christians, that it is part of our call to serve not as a ‘one time thing’, but as a lifestyle. Through partnerships created with local organizations in the greater Ann Arbor, Ypsilanti, and Detroit area, we will form specialized teams with individuals dedicated to service. We will also spend time in fellowship to grow closer with one another.
Summary: Redefined is a Christ-centered service organization made up of people who love each other and want to live out God-given mission to serve our communities.

Name: Reformed University Fellowship
Description: RUF is a Christian ministry for the glory of God and the good of UM. We are learning how to love God, love ourselves, love other people and love the University of Michigan. Learn more here!
Summary: RUF is a community of students at UM who are learning how to experience, embody, and extend the love of Jesus in the world.

Name: Refugee and Immigrant Success Establishment
Description: RISE aims to aid immigrants in establishing themselves in the United States by providing resources such as job searching, mentorship programs, and tutoring.
Summary: RISE aims to aid immigrants in establishing themselves in the United States by providing resources such as job searching, mentorship programs, and tutoring.

Name: Relevé Dance Company
Description: Relevé Dance Company is a jazz, lyrical, and contemporary student-run organization at The University of Michigan. Relevé aims to provide a place for those with a passion of dance to come together to dance, to choreograph, and to learn. Through dance, Relevé hopes to create a space where members can bond with one another, while expanding their experience as dancers and choreographers.
Summary: Relevé Dance Company is a jazz, lyrical, and contemporary student-run organization at The University of Michigan. Relevé aims to provide a place for those with a passion of dance to come together to grow as dancers and choreographers.

Name: Rem & Company
Description:
Rem and Company is a social impact initiative that offers pro-bono consulting services to minority, POC, and woman-owned small businesses impacted by COVID-19. There are tons of small businesses in Ann Arbor and the greater Detroit area that are struggling to navigate the post-pandemic world.

 

When helping small businesses, we want to place an emphasis on working with minority and female owned businesses, as well as non-profits. Rem on Campus is a great way to get hands-on consulting experience and work alongside professionals at top companies.

 

We are looking to work with driven and creative students who have a passion for making meaningful change. You will be joining a community of students from all different majors, backgrounds, and class years.
Summary: Rem and Company is a social impact initiative that offers pro-bono consulting services to small businesses impacted by COVID-19. Our primary business focuses include strategy, marketing, social media, UX, and financial management.

Name: Remission Detroit at the University of Michigan
Description: Cancer treatment is costly, and not all insurances are made equal. This means that many cancer patients cannot afford their treatment, and are left with an uphill, financial battle. According to a Survivor Views survey from ACS CAN, 61% of cancer patients and survivors found it difficult to afford their care. Affordability is a real issue for many cancer patients in Metro Detroit, where roughly 30% of people live in poverty, as reported by the University of Michigan. We are committed to advocating for greater accessibility to treatment, ensuring that every patient in Michigan receives the care they deserve.
Summary: We fight to advance cancer research and expand access to treatment, ensuring that every patient in Michigan receives the care they deserve.

Name: Res Gestae
Description: The Res Gestae, a newspaper published by an independent and self-perpetuating organization of law students, was established to give expression to the interests and opinions of students of the University of Michigan Law School, and to publish news and material of particular interest to the Law School community and alumni.
Summary: The Res Gestae is the student run newspaper of Michigan Law School.

Name: Res Sista Loquitur: Women of Color Coalition
Description: Res Sista Loquitur: Women of Color Coalition is dedicated to creating a supportive community for women of color at the law school through social activities and mentorship. We also seek to prepare our fellow women of color to navigate the legal profession through panel discussions and professional development events. Although Res Sista is a space created for women of color, we welcome and encourage membership of all people who are interested in learning more about the challenges women of color face within the law school, the legal profession, and society at large.
Summary: Res Sista Loquitur provides a supportive space for women of color at the law school to further their personal and professional development.

Name: Residence Halls Association
Description: Student Government in the Residence Halls at the University of Michigan.
Summary: Student Government in the Residence Halls

Name: Residential College Forums
Description: Residential College (RC) Forums provide a medium through which students can establish and strengthen relationships with other students and RC Faculty/Staff while engaging in the various social communities that surround them. Through the creative expression of ideas (in the form of any number of creatively themed projects) RC students will be able to share experiences that can have a positive impact upon the RC Community, the University of Michigan, and the city of Ann Arbor. Each individual forum is based on a specific interest and through will be able to attract students with similar interests and creative an environment in which students can find a space to discuss issues, interact socially, or work towards a goal they have regarding an interest they have. Beyond intra-forum affairs, the RC Forums also strive to pose profound and real "inter-forum" connections through events and discussions. Forums afford students the opportunity to actively engage in their education by encouraging them to take an innovative approach to problem solving and by preparing them for effective and responsible engagement in the real world.
Summary: The RC Forums are several student-led groups based on special interests. These include Letters Forum, Sex Forum, Health and Wellness Forum, Creative Writing Forum, Film Forum, Food Forum, RC Review, and Diversity & Politics!

Name: Resource Association of Premedical Students
Description: The Resource Association of Premedical Students is a premedical club that aims to provide academic resources, guidance, and professional development skills to its members. We are an inclusive organization whose mission is to ease the intimidation of being an undergraduate premedical student at U of M.
Summary: This club aims to provide resources for premedical undergraduate students in the form of regular meetings, guest speakers, club events, and exclusive classroom necessities.

Name: Retail and Luxury Goods Club
Description: RLG's mission is to establish the Ross School of Business as a core school with retail and luxury companies looking to recruit the unique and quality talent that only Ross can provide. Our mission will be achieved by developing our members professionally and academically, and by creating a connection between what is learned in the classroom and current industry trends. In addition, we aim to expose students to the variety of roles and opportunities in the retail and luxury industry–along with its many intersections such as design, sustainability and supply chain operations–and help them achieve their professional goals.
Summary: RLG's mission is to establish the Ross School of Business as a core school with retail and luxury companies looking to recruit the unique and quality talent that only Ross can provide.

Name: Revolution
Description: Founded in the Winter of 2009, Revolution is the Chinese Yoyo team at the University of Michigan. Blending the traditional pastime of Chinese Yoyo with modern music, Revolution aims to promote Chinese Yoyo/diabolo as a performance art and bring awareness to Asian American culture. As one of the most unique performance teams at UofM, Revolution has performed at some of the biggest events both on campus and off campus.
Summary: To raise awareness of Chinese Yoyo/diabolo as a performance art form and to raise awareness of Asian  American culture through performances and workshops.

Name: Rho Epsilon Iota
Description: The purpose of Rho Epsilon Iota, the nation’s first professional real estate fraternity, is to uphold the ideals of honesty, equality, representation, knowledge, and professionalism across all areas of real estate. These values are brought to life through comprehensive programs that empower members and affiliates to engage in real estate acquisitions, professional appraisals, fund management, residential licensure, continuing education, community outreach, networking, commercial development, and architectural design and innovation.
Summary: Professional Real Estate Fraternity at the University of Michigan. Members work in all facets of real estate, obtaining their license and actively engaging in commercial, residential, industrial, land, and special-use programs.

Name: RhythM Tap/UAC
Description: Our mission is to promote tap dance as a form of young American culture on campus. We practice and perform at community events throughout the year. We strive for excellence on stage and build lasting friendships in the process.
Summary: We are a student-run, self-choreographed, advanced tap performance group.  Our efforts can be seen in several large performances such as Dance Mix, as well as in our own show, It's TAPpening.

Name: Riley's Way at the University of Michigan
Description:
Riley's Way Foundation is a national nonprofit organization that invests in and supports a youth-led kindness movement, providing young people with the programs, support, and inclusive community they need to thrive as change-makers. 

Forbes Article
Summary: The Riley’s Way U of M chapter is focused on bringing together campus change-makers and like-minded students through entrepreneurial consulting, creating opportunities to lead with empathy and kindness to make a difference on social impact issues.

Name: Risky Business
Description: Risky Business is the epitome of good times and good tunes. It all comes together for several epic shows each year when we serenade our classmates, faculty members, and the Ross and University of Michigan community with an eclectic mix of our favorite jams. If you like to perform in front of a fanatical cast of groupies (read: your fellow MBAs), then this is the group for you.
Summary: Risky Business is a musical group comprised of MBAs and MBA partners. The group plays multiple shows throughout the school year with songs that span multiple musical artists, genres, and decades.

Name: Robotics Graduate Student Council
Description:
The mission statement of the RGSC is to create an organized group of graduate students in the Robotics Program who are committed to promoting the growth of the Robotics Program at the University of Michigan and to supporting the social, academic, and professional development of these students.  As part of this mission, we strive to:

  1. Foster an environment in which all students have a voice in their education and community. Ensure that voice is heard by coordinating with the students, the College of Engineering and Robotics Program leadership so that the goals of all three parties can be attained.
  2. Create a community for all the graduate students in the Robotics Program by organizing events that promote social interaction and a feeling of comradery among the students.
  3. Support the professional and academic development of the students and alumni of the Robotics Program.
  4. Promote the growth of robotics and STEM fields as a whole through organizing and participating in community outreach and service.
Summary: RGSC is established for the expressed purpose of developing a community for graduate students in the Robotics Program at the University of Michigan.

Name: Robotics Undergraduate Student Council
Description: The Robotics Undergraduate Student Council (RUSC), comprised of declared undergraduate robotics students, aims to actively contribute to the Robotics department's mission through various initiatives. We hope to strengthen the connection between students by organizing engaging social events that unite members of our community. We also seek to facilitate communication with faculty by providing a platform for constructive feedback regarding the new undergraduate robotics program. Furthermore, we are committed to making a positive impact beyond our campus by creating outreach programs that extend our knowledge and expertise to serve the broader community. Above all, we are dedicated to fostering an inclusive and equitable environment, ensuring that all robotics undergraduates feel a sense of belonging within the robotics community.
Summary: RUSC is established for the purpose of cultivating an equitable and inclusive environment for the undergraduate Robotics students to ensure all voices are heard and valued within the robotics community.

Name: Romanian Student Association
Summary: The RSA celebrates Romanian culture, heritage, and values among students at the University of Michigan. It serves as a platform for fostering a sense of community, organizing cultural events, and providing support for Romanian students on campus.

Name: Roots & Wings
Description: Our mission is to create a family-like environment for students who lack a traditional support system at home. Whether they come from foster care, have been adopted, or experienced kinship care, we want to provide a place where they can thrive. This includes independent students and those with incarcerated parents. We’ll host events that foster connections and build lasting relationships. Through workshops, social gatherings, and shared experiences we will improve the lives of these students and their future.
Summary: Our goal is to create a family-like environment for students who lack a traditional support system at home. Whether they come from foster care, have been adopted, or experienced kinship care, we want to provide a place where they can thrive.

Name: Ross BBA Council
Description: We as the BBA Council will work to empower the student body to grow both socially and professionally; this will be done by creating events that promote participation and which will achieve maximum impact both in and out of Ross.  As a council we wish to establish further credibility with the all associated stakeholders through the creation and preservation of positive relationship that will allow for more successful advocacy for the students.
Summary: BBA Council is the student government for undergraduate students at the Ross School of Business.

Name: Ross Fellows Student Philanthropy Board
Description: The Ross Fellows Student Philanthropy Board aims to build a positive culture of philanthropy at Michigan Ross. Fellows act as ambassadors to their classmates, engaging and educating around topics of philanthropy at Ross and in the world. Sponsored by the Michigan Ross Office of Development and Alumni Relations we provide Fellows with the strategic tools to successfully fundraise; and the opportunity to actively shape the conversation of student philanthropy at Michigan Ross. In order to participate we ask that members: commit to serving for a minimum of one academic year and exhibit a strong interest in philanthropy and volunteerism.
Summary: The Ross Fellows Student Philanthropy Board aims to build a positive culture of philanthropy at Michigan Ross. Fellows act as ambassadors to their classmates, engaging and educating around topics of philanthropy at Ross and in the world.

Name: Ross MBA Council
Description: The purpose of this organization shall be to further the mission of the Stephen M. Ross School of Business by representing the needs and interests of all business school students, promoting comprehensive student involvement in the school’s decision making process, providing a liaison between the student body and the Ross administration, and driving positive change by learning and evolving to meet the needs of our core constituents.
Summary: The MBA Council exists as a bridge between Full-Time MBA students and the administration to ensure a great student experience.

Name: Ross Retail Club
Description:
The Ross Retail Club (RRC) was established in 2003 at the Ross School of Business. RRC welcomes BBAs and non-BBA students who are interested in learning about and building careers in the luxury goods and retail industries. RRC brings students, alumni, and companies together through alumni networking, guest speaker events, corporate presentations, and company on-site visits. We provide members with career resources to help them get started and succeed in various retail and luxury goods disciplines. 


Our primary focus is on CPG companies, apparel, mass merchandising, retail consulting, retail manufacturing, and luxury retailing. In addition, our club addresses a spectrum of business functions, including business operations, finance, general management, marketing, merchandising, strategy, sales and supply chain management.
Summary: The Ross Retail Club (RRC), established in 2003 at the Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, is dedicated to cultivating a community of BBA and non-BBA students passionate about pursuing careers in the luxury goods and retail industries.

Name: Rotaract Club
Description:
Michigan Rotaract Club organizes a variety of projects and activities, depending primarily on the interests of our club members. However, within the Rotaract program, the club undertakes five main categories of activities:

- Local Service
- International Service
- Professional Development
- Networking
- Leadership Skills

Rotaract Michigan provides opportunities to volunteer both locally and internationally. There are 2-4 local service events each month, as well as an international service trip over spring break each year. The Local Service Committee and International Committee allow students to get more involved and even take part in planning these events. The club also has a new Environmental Committee to work on fulfilling the newest Rotary pillar centered on environmental action. Rotaract works closely with the Ann Arbor Rotary Club, and every week they open the doors to their meetings for our members to join and meet some of the Rotarians.

Rotaract is a great club to meet new friends, network, develop professional skills, and serve communities both locally and internationally. Any student is welcome to join us at our meetings- we would love to have you! Check our instagram page for more information.
Summary: Rotaract Club is an organization of young adults that provides opportunities for individuals to serve the local and international communities, along with opportunities for professional development, leadership development, and fellowship.

Name: Roundtable
Description:
Roundtable is a nonpartisan political student org that helps students develop their political views through research, reflection, and discussion. 

Each month, we focus on a new topic (i.e. affirmative action, policing) and engage with diverse arguments and evidence. The last meeting of every month is typically a special topic or special activity meeting. 

We occasionally host events to support viewpoint diversity and critical thinking at the University of Michigan at large.
Summary: Roundtable is a nonpartisan political student org that helps students develop their political views through research, reflection, and discussion. We actively support viewpoint diversity and respectful disagreement. All are welcome!

Name: Rude Mechanicals/UAC
Description:
Rude Mechanicals is the only student-run theatre organization on the University of Michigan Campus that offers students of all majors an opportunity to work on a full-scale production.  Founded in 1996 by two engineers, Michael Newberry and Christopher Ritchie, Rude Mechanicals has been producing a staged theatre production each semester.

We want our audience members to see something unique when they walk into a theatre, to be taken to another world. 

Rude Mechanicals offers you a chance to explore all aspects of theatre: acting, designing, lighting, costuming, scenic construction, marketing, run crew, and many more wonderful opportunities. Rudes strives to be an artistic outlet for everyone – regardless of your theatre experience.
Summary: Rude Mechanicals is a student-run theatre organization that offers students of all majors an opportunity to work on a full-scale production in any capacity: acting, directing, designing, and more. Rudes strives to be an artistic outlet for everyone.

Name: Runway of Dreams at the University of Michigan
Description: The Runway of Dreams Foundation is a nonprofit that works toward a future of inclusion, acceptance and opportunity in the fashion industry for people with disabilities. Founded on the basis that clothing is a basic human need, the Runway of Dreams Foundation develops, delivers and supports charitable initiatives to broaden the reach of adaptive clothing and promote the differently-abled community in the fashion industry. Through adaptive clothing donations, employment opportunity initiatives, adaptive design workshops, awareness building campaigns and scholarships programs, the Runway of Dreams Foundation is empowering people with disabilities with opportunity, confidence, independence and style.
