Runway of Dreams at the University of Michigan will work on supporting the three main branches of the Runway of Dreams nonprofit- inclusion, empowerment and opportunity. The organization will create fundraising platforms that will culminate in an annual RODF Fashion Show.
Summary: Runway of Dreams is a nonprofit that works toward a future of inclusion, acceptance and opportunity in the fashion industry for people with disabilities.

Name: Runway Rumble
Description: The student organization portion of Runway Rumble. Runway Rumble is a drag event series that features underutilized queer spaces in Ann Arbor. The series will be a guide to new people to the Ann Arbor area. Filmed and produced by UMich students. This will be a way for film students interested in show production and creation to get hands-on experience with the organization and production of this series.
Summary: The student organization portion of Runway Rumble. Runway Rumble is a drag event series that features underutilized queer spaces in Ann Arbor. The series will be a guide to new people to the Ann Arbor area. Filmed and produced by UMich students.

Name: Ruth Jackson Orthopaedic Society Chapter
Description: Ruth Jackson Orthopaedic Society (RJOS) is a national organization that supports women in orthopaedics throughout all stages of their careers. Through mentorship, educational initiatives, research opportunities, and advocacy programs, RJOS strives to bring gender diversity and equality to the field of orthopedics. Our chapter at the University of Michigan Medical School serves as a supportive network to break barriers and inspire the next generation of women in orthopedic surgery.
Summary: The RJOS Women in Orthopaedics Chapter at the University of Michigan Medical School aims to expose female medical students to the field of orthopedics and provide opportunities for mentorship and networking with orthopedic surgeons.

Name: SAE Michigan Baja Racing
Description:
The Michigan Baja Race team is an entirely student-run competition team housed within the College of Engineering. Every year we design and manufacture an entirely new custom off road race vehicle from the ground up. This effort takes a variety of skilled and ambitious team members. Students design all system components in CAD and integrate them together, working towards the common goal of building the fastest car on the track. These systems includes the frame, drivetrain and transmission, steering, suspension, brakes, and panels. Student team members are responsible for raising in-kind and monetary sponsorships and working with material and manufacturing sponsors in the area. Additionally, student team members manufacture the majority of the parts on the car, working in the Wilson Student Project Center to machine parts, fabricate molds and assemble the new car. After the car is assembled and unveiled, full testing of every component on the car at our on-campus test track ensures success at our three competitions around the U.S.

 

No experience necessary to join for new team members!
Summary: The Michigan Baja Race team is an entirely student-run competition team housed within the College of Engineering. Every year we design and manufacture an entirely new off-road race vehicle from the ground up and race it at three competitions nationally.

Name: SafeMD
Description: SafeMD is established to promote an environment in which sexual assault is illuminated, understood, not tolerated and actively combated; in which survivors of sexual assault have access to and are aware of supportive resources; and in which future medical professionals become proficient at handling patients involved in sexual assault with nuance, skill, and care. This environment will be actively fostered by students, faculty, and administration.
Summary: SafeMD aims to create a safe, open, empathetic community aware of and actively working to prevent sexual assault. Our reach extends both to our immediate peer community and to our future patients and communities.

Name: SAKAYUME_Underground Idol group
Summary: Underground Idol Group Student Organization in University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. You can immerse yourself in the magic of Underground Idols during our performance. Sing, dance, and take polaroid photos. We will release 1-2 songs every two months

Name: Salaam MENA Center Student Union
Description: The Salaam MENA Center Student Union is a student-led organization dedicated to uniting individuals and groups passionate about the cultures, histories, and people of the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. By organizing events, cultural exchanges, and educational activities, the Union fosters intercultural understanding and promotes the rich diversity of MENA communities. One of its key goals is to advocate for the creation of a permanent Salaam MENA Cultural Center at the University of Michigan, providing a space for learning, dialogue, and community engagement for all.
Summary: The Salaam MENA Center Student Union unites students and organizations to celebrate and promote Middle Eastern and North African cultures through events and activities. Its goal is to advocate for a permanent MENA cultural center at the University of Mic

Name: Salto Dance Company
Description: Salto is a student-run cultural organization that brings the art of contemporary ballet and pointe to the University community. Salto aims to express themselves creatively and inspire other people to appreciate these dance forms. The group was formed to provide an outlet for contemporary dancers on campus, and to give them an opportunity to develop as choreographers, dancers, and creative thinkers.
Summary: Salto Dance Company is a student-run contemporary ballet and pointe group. Salto hosts performances in both the fall and winter semesters, and can be seen performing throughout the University and Ann Arbor communities at various arts and charity events.

Name: SAPAC Peer Led Support Group
Description:
The Peer-Led Support Group (PLSG) is a weekly, drop-in, confidential group for survivors to address concerns and find support in a safe and comfortable space. The PLSG is open to University of Michigan students who have experienced sexual assault, intimate partner violence, sexual harassment, and stalking. Survivors of all genders and identities are welcome!

In Winter 2025, we will be meeting in-person every Sunday from 3:30-5:00 pm. Our final group date will be on April 20, 2025.
Summary: The PLSG is a weekly, drop-in, confidential support group for survivors to address concerns and find support in a safe and comfortable space.

Name: Sapphic Reads
Description: We are book club dedicated to reading Sapphic creative works and fostering a diverse Sapphic community! We read books, poems, zines, and more featuring Sapphic-identifying people.
Summary: We are a book club dedicated to reading Sapphic creative works and fostering a diverse Sapphic community! We read books, poems, zines, and more featuring Sapphic-identifying people.

Name: Saudi Students Association
Description: Our mission is to provide opportunities for the Saudi community to interact and establish a growing relationship among each other, assist new Saudi students to adapt living in Ann Arbor, and to promote Saudi culture on campus.
Summary: To provide opportunities for the Saudi community to interact, and establish a growing relationship among each other. To assist new Saudi students to adapt living in Ann Arbor. To promote Saudi culture on campus.

Name: Scandinavian Club
Description: This club will serve as a meeting place for anyone who is interested in any of the Scandinavian countries. There will be additional resources for Swedish language students learning the language in class at the University. All of our events are held in English and you do not need to speak a Scandinavian language to be involved! We will host movie nights, guest speakers, fikas (coffee chats), and other events throughout the year. This club is for anyone interested in Nordic culture and all are welcome.
Summary: Open to anyone interested in Scandinavia and Nordic culture, but will have a focus on Sweden and the Swedish language. Organized fika and fun activities within the community! Everyone is welcome!

Name: Scholars of Finance
Description: With chapters in 60+ universities across the nation, Scholars of Finance is a rapidly growing organization on a mission to inspire character and integrity in the finance leaders of tomorrow. Members develop their leadership skills and core values from a 7-week Leadership Development Program, a broad mentorship network, case studies, speaker events with leaders in the financial industry, and more.
Summary: Scholars of Finance is an organization that develops the next generation of highly capable financial executives, who will act and lead from a strong grounding in principles and ethics.

Name: School for Environment and Sustainability Student Government
Description: This organization exists to support the students of the School for Environment and Sustainability with their social, academic, professional, and community needs.
Summary: This organization exists to support the students of the School for Environment and Sustainability with their social, academic, professional, and community needs.

Name: School of Information Bachelor's Association
Description:
The purpose and aim of this organization shall be:

  • To provide official representation and a method of communication for the School of Information Bachelor’s students within the university.
  • To ensure effective communication among School of Information Bachelor’s students, and between the student body and the Administration.
  • To further build skills and relationships within the cohort of the Bachelor’s of Science in Information (BSI) student body by offering programming to:
    • Develop professional skills to effectively prepare for future careers in information
    • Connect and network socially to build relationships among the BSI student body
    • Work with other student organizations and university events to provide more professional and academic experiences and opportunities for BSI students
    • Communicate consistently with the Administration, faculty, staff, and graduate students of the School of Information of The University of Michigan to better acquaint and integrate the BSI students with the rest of the School of Information community.
Summary: SIBA's purpose is to build skills and relationships within the cohort of the Bachelor's of Science in Information student body by offering professional development opportunities and strengthening our relationship with the UMSI community.

Name: School of Information Doctoral Student Organization
Description: DSO serves all doctoral students in the School of Information. The group provides emotional and academic support for PhD students as they progress through the program.
Summary: DSO serves all doctoral students in the School of Information. The group provides emotional and academic support for PhD students as they progress through the program.

Name: School of Information Masters Association
Description: SIMA is the official University of Michigan School of Information student association for MSI masters students. It is composed of eight elected officers from the student body: a president, vice president, treasurer, information manager, diversity coordinator, social coordinator, alumni relations officer, and MHI representatives. The objective of SIMA is to represent the student body of the School of Information, as a vehicle for communication between students and the administration.
Summary: SIMA is the official University of Michigan School of Information Masters Association, composed of eight elected officers from the student body.

Name: School of Music, Theatre & Dance University Productions
Description: University Productions produces ten fully-staged productions and two studio shows every year for the School of Music, Theatre & Dance, while also managing Hill Auditorium, Mendelssohn Theatre, Arthur Miller Theatre, Power Center for the Performing Arts, and Rackham Auditorium.
Summary: University Productions produces fully-staged productions and shows for the School of Music, Theatre & Dance, while also managing Hill Auditorium, Mendelssohn Theatre, Arthur Miller Theatre, Power Center for the Performing Arts, and Rackham Auditorium.

Name: School of Nursing
Description: Thinking of a career as a nurse? Apply to the University of Michigan School of Nursing! Students are allowed to transfer up to 40 credit hours, primarily consisting of required prerequisite courses. This program will take three years to complete in a full time, lockstep format. To learn more about the program, our requirements and curriculum, please visit our Bachelor of Science in Nursing page or register for an Information Session with the School of Nursing. Admission for transfer students is for summer term only. Transfer students complete three full years in the program to earn a Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN).
Summary: At the University of Michigan School of Nursing, we dare every day, using our knowledge, skills, innovation and compassion to advance the public good and prepare the next generation of nurses to change the world. Join our school, and earn your BSN here!

Name: School of Public Health
Description:
The University of Michigan School of Public Health offers five graduate degrees across eight areas of study—including residential and online master's degree options—as well as several dual degree programs and two undergraduate degree options.

 

For more information on graduate level programs, please see our Programs & Degrees webpage. 

 

For undergraduate students, the School of Public Health (SPH) is an upper-level academic unit, meaning that students apply to the school during their sophomore year and, if admitted, spend their junior and senior years in SPH.

 

The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Community and Global Public Health and the Bachelor of Science (BS) in Public Health Sciences each provide an interdisciplinary undergraduate liberal education through the lens of public health. You can read more about our bachelor's degree programs, requirements, and application details on our website. 

 

Cross-campus transfer applicants and external transfer applicants are welcome to apply to our undergraduate program. The application for the Fall of 2022 opens on October 1st, 2021 and the deadline to apply is February 1st, 2022. Cross-campus transfer applicants are encouraged to apply by January 15th, the priority deadline, in order to ensure an admission decision by early March (before pre-registration backpacking for fall term). 

 

If you'd like to stay in the loop about upcoming SPH events such as information sessions, student fairs, and more, check out our Events Calendar for opportunities to engage with us this fall (and beyond)!
Summary: The School of Public Health offers two upper-level undergraduate degree programs that students can learn about by visiting our website or reading below for a more detailed description of our school's offerings and ways that you can stay informed.

Name: School of Social Work Student Government
Description: The mission of the School of Social Work Student Government is to support and encourage coordination and integration of the efforts of students and faculty to achieve greater academic excellence, student success, social justice, equity, and inclusion. View our website for more information.
Summary: The School of Social Work Student Government consists of elected SSW master's students. Our primary mission is to ensure students' needs are addressed, such as acting as facilitators and intermediaries between students, staff/faculty, and admin.

Name: Schriftlich: Michigan Journal of German Studies
Description:
The aim of this club is to provide a platform through which students interested in German Studies can publish their work in a semi-professional manner. This club will also make efforts to highlight the interdisciplinary aspects of German using its platform. Thematically, we plan to accept content from a wide variety of genres, including literature, poetry, translated excerpts, theory papers, history, etc., in order to capture the diverse course offerings of the department. We will publish this journal once per semester. 

Please look at our website for our most recent publication!
Summary: The aim of this club is to provide a platform through which students interested in German Studies can publish their work in a semi-professional manner.

Name: Science Engagement, Communication, and Outreach for Numerous Disciplines
Description: SECOND is a group of grad students, researchers, and staff that run a yearly science communication program in partnership with the Museum of Natural History. This program trains students to effectively communicate science to different audiences and culminates in video final projects that are shared on the museum's website.
Summary: Connecting STEM undergrads with science communication training and opportunities.

Name: Science For The People
Description:
Science for the People arose in 1969 out of the anti-war movement and lasted until 1989. With a Marxist analysis and non-hierarchical governing structure, Science for the People tackled the militarization of scientific research, the corporate control of research agendas, the political implications of sociobiology and other scientific theories, the environmental consequences of energy policy, inequalities in health care, and many other issues.

Its members opposed racism, sexism, and classism in science and above all sought to mobilize people working in scientific fields to become active in agitating for science, technology, and medicine that would serve social needs rather than military and corporate interests. They organized in universities and communities, published a magazine offering sharp political analysis, and sought meaningful scientific exchange internationally in Vietnam, China, Cuba, Nicaragua, and other countries.

Some of the issues we face today have changed in important ways, but fundamental questions of power, ideology, and democracy in science remain. The time is ripe to gather SftP veterans with other scientists, activists, students, and scholars in an exploration of what the history of SftP can teach us… and where we go from here.

To get involved, send an email to sciforthepeople@umich.edu.
Summary: We are a student organization dedicated to mobilizing people working in scientific fields to become active in agitating for science, technology, and medicine that would serve social needs rather than military and corporate interests.

Name: Scientific Computing Student Club
Description:
Mailing List
To join our mailing list, please fill out this form: Form
 
Event Calendar
Keep track of our events here: Calendar
 
Slack
Once you join the club or our mailing list, you can join our Slack Channel.  It may take a week or so for you to be able to join the slack after joining since it is a manual process. Email sc2-officers@umich.edu if it has been over a week and you cannot join the slack channel.
 
General Meetings
We hold general meetings once a month. At each general meeting, we have scientific computing trivia, a workshop or presentation, project proposals, and announcements. During the fall and winter semesters, we often provide free dinners. Look for our events for times and locations.
 
Focus Areas
This club provides a community for those interested in computer simulations, high-performance computing, or other software related to science. We are mainly focused on four areas: projects, workshops and presentations, events, and community.
 
Projects
For club projects, any member can submit a scientific computing project of interest to them or upload a personal project you want to share with the club. Then, the person who uploaded it manages the project and can engage others in contributing to the project or learning more about the subject material. By submitting/uploading a project, you have the opportunity to build teamworking skills and share your coding skills with the club. If you want to start a project, email a one page proposal to sc2-officers@umich.edu.
 
Project Proposal Template
 
Workshops and Presentations
The workshops and presentations focus of our club also encourages contribution from the club body. Any member can submit a workshop or presentation, and then, they can teach the club a new skill using a workshop or introduce new ideas through a presentation. This aspect of our club can be used by our members to improve their presentation skills, increase their knowledge of a particular subject, or practice a presentation for an important event. Additionally, we invite professors and other experts in scientific computing to present their research, allowing our members to connect to the larger scientific computing community.
 
Sumbit a workshop
 
Events
We host various internal events as a club, such as social and outreach events, but we are also interested in participating in many external events, such as hackathons and data challenges. Participating in these events individually can be challenging since they can demand hours or days of your time or even require registration fees. We provide the resources to make this process easier. We set up a system allowing you to create competition teams open to the club and request funding for registration fees, making it easier to participate in these events and gain the credentials associated with them.
 
Community
Besides the activities we list above, we also want to provide a space for those interested in scientific computing to meet one another, share experiences, and possibly collaborate.
 
Leadership Structure
Finally, This club has a robust leadership structure that allows many members to participate in leading the club to the degree that is suitable to them. The leadership is organized into six committees: an Executive Committee and five task-based committees. The Executive Committee can have at least 9 positions, and the task-based committees are composed of four members. Graduate student members may be elected to positions on the Executive Committee, and any club member may be nominated to a position on the task-based committees by the respective committee chair.
Summary: This club provides a community for those interested in computer simulations, high-performance computing, or other software related to science. We engage in club programming projects, host workshops and presentations, compete in hackathons, and more!

Name: Scrubs Addressing the Firearm Epidemic (SAFE) at the University of Michigan
Description:
SAFE is a nationwide organization of doctors, medical students, and healthcare providers dedicated to eliminating the United States firearm epidemic through research, policy reform, and education.

SAFE is established for the purpose of raising awareness of the firearm epidemic in the United States, advancing research on the epidemic, working towards policy reform, and integrating firearm awareness into the curriculum.

SAFE’s mission is to create a community of doctors, nurses, medical students, and healthcare providers dedicated to addressing the firearm epidemic in the United States.
Summary: SAFE is a nationwide organization of doctors, medical students, and healthcare providers dedicated to eliminating the United States firearm epidemic through research, policy reform, and education.

Name: Sentence Commutation Project
Description: The Sentence Commutation Project (SCP) at the University of Michigan Law School seeks to provide incarcerated individuals with high-quality advocacy via preparation for sentence commutation hearings and assistance with written commutation applications. SCP also advocates for policies designed to decarcerate Michigan, works to expand awareness of clemency within the Michigan Law community, and partners with other clemency advocates throughout Michigan. The Sentence Commutation Project aims to empower incarcerated individuals while engaging students with pro bono work in the criminal legal system.
Summary: The Sentence Commutation Project (SCP) at the University of Michigan Law School seeks to provide incarcerated individuals with high-quality advocacy via preparation for sentence commutation hearings and assistance with written commutation applications.

Name: Serbian Student Association
Description:
The Serbian Student Association’s purpose is to foster a tight-knit community of U of M students united in their interest of celebrating and sharing Serbian culture on campus and beyond. Our focus is to bring together Serbian students and their friends through a variety of regularly-held social and cultural events with a focus on enriching the cultural awareness of our members as well as creating fun and memorable experiences. 

 

We invite interested students of any background to join us at our events and dive headfirst into the rich tapestry that is Serbian culture. Dobrodošli!
Summary: The Serbian Student Association’s purpose is to foster a tight-knit community of U of M students united in their interest of celebrating and sharing Serbian culture on campus and beyond.

Name: Service with a Name
ShortName: Chapter of SWAN at the University of Michigan
Description:
As a 501(c)3 nonprofit, Service with a Name (SWAN) is an organization that was created by the Harvard College student body in the Spring of 2022. The goal of this organization is to increase inclusivity and the presence of public service on college campuses, along with inspiring youth to pursue careers in the field of public service. Its first chapter is at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor, founded in the Spring of 2025.

SWAN is an organization for undergraduate students interested in pursuing opportunities in public service. We stress the importance of community by holding SWAN social events to create a supportive and tight-knit community of public service-minded individuals.

The mission of SWAN is dedicated to catalyzing involvement, careers, and therefore lives, in public service for not only the Michigan student body but also for youth around the country, through mentorship, social engagement, and dynamic, outgoing community building. 

To promote involvement in public service beyond our on-campus community, SWAN partners with local organizations on semester-long service projects to help grow their initiatives and holds an annual public service conference for high schoolers. We believe it is of the utmost importance to provide youth with the resources to begin their journeys in service as early as possible. In doing so, we strive to encourage young people to become the change makers of tomorrow.
Summary: SWAN is dedicated to catalyzing involvement, careers, and therefore lives, in public service for not only the Michigan student body but also for youth around the country, through mentorship, social engagement, and dynamic, outgoing community building.

Name: Seven Mile
Description:
Seven Mile currently travels 3 days a week to community centers in Detroit to provide free music, arts, and coding lessons to the community. The public funding for such opportunities in Detroit has dropped considerably over the last several years, and many of these children have no other opportunities to learn and experience music, art, or coding. 

Check out our website for more information: sevenmileum.org
Summary: Seven Mile is a student-driven initiative to bring music, arts, and coding education to Detroit public schools. As a group of student volunteer teachers, we drive to Detroit weekly to engage with various local communities.

Name: Sexual and Gender Diversity in Public Health
Description:
Sexual and Gender Diversity in Public Health (SGDPH) aims

  • to promote the voices of LGBTQ+ students within dialogues at the University of Michigan, with a focus in the School of Public Health; to promote an inclusive and intersectional LGBTQ+ community among the School of Public Health students, faculty, and staff;
  • to create a safe space for conversation and individuality among LGBTQ+ students;
  • to create a collaborative effort with other values based student organizations at the School of Public Health and Rackham Graduate School;
  • to educate and inform the community about current topics and issues focused on LGBTQ+ rights, culture, or health;
  • and to make a welcoming environment for all School of Public Health students, faculty and staff, with a focus on LGBTQ+ persons.
Summary: Established in Fall 2018, SGDPH continues to be an advocate for increasing the visibility and support of sexual and gender minority students, faculty, and staff within the School of Public Health and across the greater Ann Arbor campus.

Name: Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center
Description: The Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center offers prevention education for students, confidential support for survivors (students, faculty, and staff), and collaborates with other offices to offer trainings, programs, and innovative community engagement strategies to collectively create a campus free from violence.
Summary: SAPAC offers prevention education for students, confidential support for survivors (students, faculty, and staff), and collaborates with other offices to offer trainings, programs, and innovative community engagement strategies.

Name: Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center Bystander Intervention and Community Engagement
Description: The Bystander Intervention & Community Engagement (BICE) program focuses on educating communities not typically involved in conversations surrounding sexual and intimate partner violence. By reaching out to student communities such as Transform, Out in STEM, South Asian Awareness Network, Students Allied for Freedom and Equality, athletics, fraternities, Co-ops, ROTC, and many more, SAPAC BICE aims to approach conversations about sexual misconduct in an intersectional manner.
Summary: Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center Bystander Intervention and Community Engagement works to involve and advocate for those often left out of the mainstream movement to end sexual violence by creating transformative community models.

Name: Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center: Consent, Outreach, and Relationship Education (CORE)
Description: Consent, Outreach, and Relationship Education (CORE) is a volunteer program within SAPAC which focuses on the primary prevention of sexual misconduct through interactive workshops, tabling, speaker events, and dialogues surrounding healthy relationships and consent.
Summary: Consent, Outreach, and Relationship Education (CORE) is a volunteer program that focuses on the primary prevention of sexual misconduct through interactive workshops, tabling, speaker events, and dialogues surrounding healthy relationships and consent.

Name: Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center: Survivor Empowerment and Ally Support
Description: SEAS  volunteers focus on tertiary prevention of sexual misconduct and violence through interactive workshops, tabling and events on self-care and wellbeing. SEAS serves to promote awareness, empathy, and understanding for the survivor experience, voice, and common reactions, as well as how to be supportive of survivors of sexual violence.
Summary: The Survivor Empowerment and Ally Support program is responsible for organizing and publicizing some of SAPAC’s biggest events. Undergrad and grad students network with student orgs, table at various events, and work tirelessly to further SAPAC's causes.

Name: SGI Buddhist Club
Description: The fundamental purpose of SGI Buddhist club is the pursuit of truth as well as development of scholarship, to enable all people to cultivate their characters and enjoy fulfilling and happy lives. SGI Buddhist club seeks to contribute to peace, culture and education based on the philosophy and ideals of the Buddhism of Nichiren Daishonin as shared by the Soka Gakkai International. We seek to establish life long friendships between students that begin within the University of Michigan and extends outward into the community at large.
Summary: SGI Buddhist club seeks to contribute to peace, culture and education based on the philosophy and ideals of the Buddhism of Nichiren Daishonin as shared by the Soka Gakkai International.

Name: Sharing Smiles
Description: Sharing Smiles is a student-led organization for pre-dentals or any students interested in healthcare. This organization focuses on providing and advocating for oral healthcare in underserved communities in Michigan. Our goal is to address these health disparities while hosting events to fundraise and volunteer in these communities. This organization plans to work with many other oral healthcare programs to advocate and provide for these health disparities present in surrounding communities.
Summary: Sharing Smiles is a student organization for pre-dentals and students interested in healthcare to volunteer and fundraise in underserved communities in Michigan in need of oral healthcare. Our goal is to address and advocate for these health disparities.

Name: SHEI Magazine
Description:
Since its 1999 debut as an Asian interest magazine, SHEI has transformed into the University of Michigan’s premier fashion, arts, and culture student publication. With readership ranging from college students to esteemed alumni across the nation, we reach a wide demographic through our online, print, and social media platforms. SHEI releases two print magazine issues per year; our fall issue is released mid-December and our spring issue, mid-April. With our recently redesigned website, SHEI’s reach is even greater, with content that includes, but is not limited to, fashion, arts, and culture. From coverage of New York Fashion Week to tips on revamping an old nightstand, SHEI has it covered. 

Along with editorial, we also have business teams featuring finance, HR, PR, Marketing, and Events. These teams work on real projects to bring SHEI to life. If you are interested in pre-professional experience, we highly recommend you joining a business team!
Summary: SHEI, an entirely student-run fashion and culture publication, is accessible on both print and digital platforms. We aim to provide students with fashion and media related opportunities to equip them with practical experience for their future careers.

Name: She’s the First at the University of Michigan
Description:
She's the First (STF) is a national nonprofit organization that fights gender inequality through education: we team up with grassroots organizations to make sure girls everywhere are educated, respected, and heard. A girl’s ability to decide her own future path often rests on her access to quality education, which is why STF proudly partners with many community-based organizations in 11 countries to ensure girls can attend school and after-school programming. According to UNICEF and the World Bank, 129 million girls are currently not in school and "are denied an education, told who and when to marry, and blocked from leadership. Educated and respected girls are the exception, not the norm."

Here at the University of Michigan, our main goal is to educate and raise money for girls who do not have access to education. We host fundraisers, informative meetings to educate club members as part of the Global Awareness Project, and social events for members to bond. UM-STF strives to be a safe space on campus where members can work collaboratively toward the improvement of the global education system.

Check out our linked social media sites or contact us using the contact information listed below for more information!
Summary: She's the First (STF) at the University of Michigan is a branch of a national nonprofit organization that fights gender inequality through education.

Name: Shiawassee Scholars at the University of Michigan
Description:
If you came from Shiawassee County and the surrounding areas and want to connect with individuals from the same area that are also here at UM or support the mission to see all students into secondary education, then this is the organization for you!
Our goal is to create an environment fostering new communities, outreach, and giving back to the community from which we came. Through events and participation in outreach, we aim to foster new communities here on campus. Through outreach and giving back, we can further support the Shiawassee Scholars and Cook Family’s mission of seeing students from Shiawassee County succeed in secondary education.
Summary: If you came from Shiawassee County and the surrounding areas and want to connect with individuals from the same area that are also here at UM or support the mission to see all students into secondary education, then this is the organization for you!

Name: Shift Creator Space
Description:
Shift is a creator space for students at the University of Michigan who want to chase their passions outside of the classroom. We’re a tight-knit community of artists, designers, developers, and makers that share the unparalleled drive to bring our ideas to life.

We’re a playground for experiential learning, constructive collaboration, and genuine relationships to flourish. We believe firmly in putting our creators first and prioritizing their personal growth, because we know that’s how the best ideas are born and the greatest projects are created.
Summary: Shift is a creator space for students at the University of Michigan who want to chase their passions outside of the classroom. We’re a tight-knit community of designers, hackers, and makers with the unparalleled drive to bring our ideas to life.

Name: Shipman Society
Description: The purpose of the Shipman Society is to enrich the collegiate experience of recipients of the Sidney J. and Irene Shipman Scholarship.  This enrichment is achieved through an emphasis on interdisciplinary education and discussion, as well as a commitment to social involvement both among society members and with the University of Michigan at large.  Through education, volunteerism, and social outlets, the Shipman Society seeks to inspire its members to reach their fullest potential as both leaders and individuals.
Summary: The Shipman Society is a community for recipients of the Sidney J. and Irene Shipman Scholarship. The Society emphasizes interdisciplinary academic discussion, volunteerism, social activities, and intramural sports.

Name: Shotokan Karate at University of Michigan
Description:
"True karate is this: that in daily life one's mind and body be trained and developed in a spirit of humility, and that in critical times, one be devoted utterly to the cause of justice."
--Gichin Funakoshi- Founder of Shotokan Karate

 

 

 

Fall 2024 Practice Hours and Locations

 

Wednesday 6:30pm - 8:15pm  @  Gretchen's House, 1580 Dhu Varren Rd (you can take the city bus route 22 to get there)

 

Sunday 2:30pm - 4:30pm  @  Intramural Sports Building, Medium Multi-purpose Room B （please complete this liability waiver before your first practice in IMSB)

New members are always welcome. No previous experience is necessary. Just come to any practice. You may watch a practice or actually participate when you come. If you want to participate, wear loose fitting clothes and no jewelry.
Summary: Traditional karate practice: many kihon (basics), kata (prearranged forms), and kumite (sparring). SKA affiliate.

Name: Sierra Club at the University of Michigan
Description: The Sierra Club is one of the most impactful grassroots environmental organizations in the United States. Nationwide, 3.8 million members and supporters are working together to enforce an influential environmental movement. The Sierra Club at the University of Michigan allows U-M students to become involved with this national organization by engaging them with its current sustainability initiatives and environmental political engagement actions, both locally and nationally. In addition to these involvements, the club maintains a welcoming community through a variety of outdoor activities, social events, and bi-weekly meetings. Meetings mostly consist of discussions on climate, sustainability, environmental politics, and activism, though may feature activities like screen printing, potting, or more!
Summary: This organization connects students to local and national Sierra Club chapters, therefore implementing sustainability initiatives and environmental political engagement actions both on campus and in the greater Ann Arbor community.

Name: Sigma Alpha Epsilon
Description: The Michigan Iota-Beta chapter of Sigma Alpha Epsilon promotes high standards of Friendship, Scholarship, Leadership, and Service – specifically enunciated in our creed, “The True Gentleman.” We strive to foster a brotherhood where a boy is transformed into a True Gentleman, making the world a better place one day at a time. At Michigan Iota-Beta we pride ourselves on our commitment to build off the legacy of those who came before us and carry the torch that will light our house for eternity. We place our brothers and the values of this brotherhood before our own needs. We respect the ideals that this bond of brothers was built on, and we strive for greatness in all that we do. We do this for the past and future generations of our great brotherhood. We do this for Michigan Iota-Beta of Sigma Alpha Epsilon. Phi Alpha, Phi Alpha, rah rah Phi Alpha.
Summary: The Michigan Iota-Beta Chapter of Sigma Alpha Epsilon is a social fraternity where Brothers are transformed into True Gentleman through philanthropic events such as our legacy Mudbowl, brotherhood events, and leadership opportunities.

Name: Sigma Alpha Mu (ΣAM)
Description: Sigma Alpha Mu is a fraternity at the University of Michigan. Sigma Alpha Mu is known for their brotherhood, philanthropic work and events throughout the campus.
Summary: Sigma Alpha Mu is a fraternity at the University of Michigan. Sigma Alpha Mu is known for their brotherhood, philanthropic work, and events throughout the campus.

Name: Sigma Alpha Nu
Description: We are the Beta Chapter of Sigma Alpha Nu at the University of Michigan, the Alpha chapter having been established at the University of California, Berkeley in 2005. We are establishing this new fraternity at the University of Michigan to open the door to more students that have a passion for law or working in the legal field. Our mission is to give students the tools to determine their direction and career paths within law by bringing in a variety of speakers to talk about their work. We also aim to help students apply to law school and legal jobs through resumé help, LSAT test prep guidance, and essay writing collaboration. The final goal for our fraternity is to bring a social element to our members and bring people together through their passion for law and create friendship and brotherhood among UM students.
Summary: A Co-ed pre-professional law fraternity at the University of Michigan looking to help students find their legal career paths and inspiration through professional development, speaker events, and brotherhood.

Name: Sigma Chi Fraternity
Description: The Theta Theta chapter of Sigma Chi at the University of Michigan was originally founded on November 20th, 1877 with our most recent rechartering occuring in November of 2009.  We are located at 548 S. State St in Ann Arbor in a house that was originally built for the chapter in 1912.  Sigma Chi is well known on campus for our academic performance, philanthropic enternrpises, and our social standing among the Greek and University communities.  Our most notable philanthropic event is our annual Derby Days celebration which raises money for Sigma Chi's national philanthropy, the Huntsman Cancer Foundation.  The chapter has members involved in all aspects life at Michigan and together are an active and driven brotherhood.  We are a diverse group of young men with different temperments, talents, and convictions, bound together by our devotion to the core principles for which Sigma Chi stands, Friendship, Justice, and Learning.  In Hoc Signo Vinces
Summary: Theta Theta Chapter of the Sigma Chi Fraternity at the University of Michigan. Founded in 1855 on the principles of Friendship, Justice, and Learning, the Sigma Chi fraternity strives to be the preeminent collegiate leadership development organization

Name: Sigma Delta Tau Sorority
Description: Our purpose is to form a close social and fraternal union of those of similar ideals and to foster, maintain and instill such ideals in the hearts of its members as will result in actions worthy of the highest precepts of true womanhood, democracy and humanity.
Summary: As an organization of over 200 members, we are dedicated to forming sisterhood bonds that last long beyond graduation, having fun, improving the University of Michigan community, and performing philanthropy.

Name: Sigma Eta Pi
Description:
Who We Are

Sigma Eta Pi is an entrepreneurship fraternity. We are a diverse brotherhood all united by a singular passion for entrepreneurship and creating innovative solutions. We provide both professional development through workshops, speakers, and startup treks to nearby cities, all focusing on providing you with the tools necessary to work for the next big startup or to create it. In addition, we are an extremely tight-knit group and hold many social events such as parties, retreats, and game nights.

Our Pillars:
 
Start-up Experience
In addition to supporting the entrepreneurs within our fraternity, we provide exposure to successful startups through speakers and treks. This year, we will be going on a trek to Chicago to meet with companies that have raised over $500m collectively. 
 
Innovative Mindset
We focus on constantly finding the most innovative solutions possible to solve pressing problems globally. Through events such as ideation sessions, we ensure that all of our members are always focused on improving the world around them through entrepreneurship. 
 
Lifelong Friendships
We work hard and we play hard. We set deadlines and adhere to them. If and when we attain our goals, we celebrate our accomplishments as one companionship. We build strong working business relationships off of the platform of friendship.
Summary: SEPi is a professional entrepreneurship fraternity! We're a diverse brotherhood all united by a singular passion for entrepreneurship and creating innovative solutions.

Name: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc.
Description:
Foundation

 

Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. was organized on November 12, 1922 in Indianapolis, Indiana by seven young educators: Mary Lou Allison Little, Dorothy Hanley Whiteside, Vivian White Marbury, Nannie Mae Gahn Johnson, Hattie Mae Dulin Redford, Bessie M. Downey Martin and Cubena McClure. The group became an incorporated national collegiate sorority on December 30, 1929, when a charter was granted to Alpha chapter at Butler University.


Soaring To Greater Heights Of Attainment Around The World, Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc., as a leading national service organization, has met the challenges of the day and continues to grow through Sisterhood, Scholarship and Service.

 

Sisterhood

From seven young educators, Sigma Gamma Rho has become an international service organization comprised of women from every profession. Sigma Gamma Rho offers its members opportunities to develop their unique talents through leadership training and involvement in sorority activities. Sorority activities provide an atmosphere where friendships and professional contacts are developed which often lead to bonds that last a lifetime.

Sigma women are dedicated to helping each other and their personal success is recognized in The AURORA and through various awards.

 

Service

Sigma Gamma Rho's commitment to service is expressed in its slogan, "Greater Service, Greater Progress." The sorority has a proud history of offering service wherever chapters exist, including OPERATION BigBookBag, a program designed to address the needs, challenges and issues that face school-aged children who are educationally at-risk in local homeless shelters and extended care hospitals. The objective is for chapters to provide their local homeless shelters and children hospitals with educational materials, equipment and supplies. Other national projects include Wee Savers, Project Reassurance and Habitat for Humanity,Sigma Gamma Rho built seven homes across the United States in Florida, District of Columbia, Wisconsin, California, and Texas.

The service of Sigma Gamma Rho from a global perspective includes Project Africa and Project Mwanamugimu. Through active participation in programs and through networking with other organizations such as the National Council of Negro Women, Urban League and the NAACP, Sigma's legacy of service to improve the quality of life for all mankind continues.
Summary: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority's aim is to enhance the quality of life within the community. Public service, leadership development and education of youth are the hallmark of the organization's programs and activities.

Name: Sigma Gamma Tau
Description: The Sigma Gamma Tau Society is established to recognize and honor those individuals in the field of aeronautics and astronautics who have through scholarship, integrity, and outstanding achievement been a credit to their profession. The Society seeks to foster a high standard of ethics and professional practices and to create a spirit of loyalty and fellowship, particularly among students of Aerospace Engineering.
Summary: Sigma Gamma Tau is the honor society for Aerospace Engineering. It seeks to identify and recognize achievement and excellence in the Aerospace field. SGT's collegiate chapters elect semiannually to grant membership to students, alumni, and professionals.

Name: Sigma Iota Rho Honor Society for International Studies
Description: Sigma Iota Rho (SIR) is a national honor society for those with an interest in International and Global Studies. We highly encourage declared International Studies majors and minors to apply.
Summary: Sigma Iota Rho aims to promote and reward scholarship, service, and integrity among international studies students in their conduct of world affairs.

Name: Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity, Inc.
Description: Our fraternity works to promote a multicultural and inclusive brotherhood that lives by the principles of brotherhood, scholarship, community service, and cultural awareness.
Summary: The mission of Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity, Inc. is to nurture and further a dynamic, value-based environment which utilizes our historically Latino-based fraternity as a catalyst to better serve the needs and wants of all people.

Name: Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority, Inc.
Description:
Sigma Lambda Gamma strives to be the premier organization committed to providing a mechanism of empowerment to all people.

We are committed to building a multicultural community. Recognizing our responsibility to promote the positive progression of our global community, we stress the importance of morals, ethics, and education in our daily lives so that we can serve the needs of our neighbors through mutual respect and understanding of our varying identities.
Summary: Through our network of more than 3,000 multicultural siblings across the U.S., we promote academic excellence in higher education through our 5 principles: Academics, Community Service, Cultural Awareness, Morals & Ethics, and Social Interaction.

Name: Sigma Nu
Description: Sigma Nu is a social fraternity at the University of Michigan that was founded nationally in 1869 at Virginia Military Institute in Lexington, Virginia. Sigma Nu currently has 166 active chapters and colonies on college campuses throughout the United States. Here at Michigan, Sigma Nu resides at 700 Oxford, a historic home built in 1910, and was originally a tenant in the house beginning in 1919. Sigma Nu is looking for potential brothers who are willing to excel at all of aspects of a fraternity as this chapter offers a social, as well as a professional experience.
Summary: Sigma Nu is a social fraternity at the University of Michigan that was founded nationally in 1869 at Virginia Military Institute in Lexington. Sigma Nu currently has 166 active chapters and colonies on college campuses throughout the United States.

Name: Sigma Phi Epsilon Fraternity
Description:
Sigma Phi Epsilon (SigEp) was founded on November 1, 1901 at Richmond College, now the University of Richmond, in Richmond, Va.  Since then, SigEp has grown to become one of the largest fraternities in the country.

Around 15,000 SigEp undergraduates are on 240 college campuses each year.  They are among the more than 300,000 lifetime brothers who have joined since 1901.

SigEp was founded with the cardinal principles of Virtue, Diligence and Brotherly Love.  Our mission is “Building Balanced Men,” which is achieved through a commitment to Sound Mind and Sound Body.

Sigma Phi Epsilon Fraternity is an equal opportunity/affirmative action fraternity, complies with all applicable federal and state laws regarding nondiscrimination and affirmative action. Sigma Phi Epsilon is committed to a policy of equal opportunity for all persons and does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, age, marital status, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, disability, religion, height, weight, or veteran status in employment, educational programs and activities, and admissions.
Summary: Sigma Phi Epsilon (SigEp) was founded on November 1, 1901 at Richmond College, now the University of Richmond, in Richmond, Va.  Since then, SigEp has grown to become one of the largest fraternities in the country. SigEp at UofM was founded in 1912.

Name: Sikh Students Association
Description:
The Sikh Students Association is an organization based on Sikh values that works to create a community amongst the Sikh students on campus, to educate both Sikhs and non-Sikhs about the Sikh religion, to promote dialogue about significant interfaith and youth issues, and to create a community and fellowship for students of the Sikh faith and those interested in Sikh values.

The Sikh Student Association has regular religious and social events. We also sponsor community service events in the Detroit and Ann Arbor area.
Summary: The Sikh Students Association is a religious organization seeking to promote unity among the Sikh and non-Sikh students on campus, raise awareness of the Sikh religion, and educate everyone, including its members, about the Sikh religion.

Name: Sinaboro
Description:
Sinaboro is a Korean Drumming Group based at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. Established in 1998, we specializes in playing four traditional Korean percussive instruments - the kkwaenggwari, jing, janggu, and buk.

Our group is a platform where Korean culture is celebrated and prospered through music, particularly through the unique sounds and rhythms of our four primary instruments. These instruments bring the traditional rhythms of Korea to life, presenting a captivating musical landscape.

Firstly, we strive to educate our diverse members on the intricacies of Korean drumming. In doing so, we cultivate an appreciation for Korean culture and music. Secondly, our aim is to inspire our audience through performance. By performing at various stages across the University's campus, we hope to share the vibrancy of Korean music and culture with a larger audience, thus fostering greater cultural understanding and exchange.
Summary: Sinaboro is a Traditional Korean Drumming Group at U of M. Sinaboro, founded in 1998, strives to educate members and our audience on Korean music and culture. By performing on various stages across the University, we hope to share the vibrancy of Korea.

Name: Singapore Students Association
Description: The Singapore Students Association (SSA) at the University of Michigan (UM) is an organization that represents Singaporeans at this institution. Our goal is to foster close ties among Singaporeans in the UM community. We act as a liaison between Singaporean students at UM, the Singapore Embassy, and all other official Singaporean organizations across the United States. We also work closely with the UM alumni in Singapore.
Summary: Our primary goal is to provide opportunities for the Singaporean community to interact such that it fosters cohesion and closer relationships within the Singaporean community.

Name: Sister 2 Sister
Description: Years ago, a group of African American women decided to come together and establish a student organization that would function as a safe haven for them to discuss issues pertinent to their lives as Black women on campus. In addition to forums, the women decided to give back to their community by participating with various volunteer sites and hosting social events to bring the entire African American community together. Thus, in 1997 Sister 2 Sister was born and ever since then, the women of Sister 2 Sister have strived to cultivate a positive college environment and experience for Black women on campus!
Summary: To provide service to the community through service activities, staple events, and fundraising. We also work towards creating a domain where women can influence and make a positive impact on their community and each other.

Name: Sisters In Scripture
Description: Our mission is to create a community where we uplift one another through prayer, encouragement, and the sharing of wisdom, built on the foundation of the Word of God. We strive to ensure that every meeting is where members can see God’s guidance, celebrate God’s goodness, and support one another in our faith journey.
Summary: Sisters in Scripture is an organization created to be a safe, empowering, and supportive space for women on campus to fellowship, deepen their faith, and build strong God-centered relationships.

Name: Ski & Snowboard Club at Ross School of Business
Description: The Ski & Snowboard Club at Ross organizes events for skiers and snowboarders of all abilities at the Ross School of Business. Club events generally consist of social activities in Ann Arbor and multiple destination trips throughout the winter. All MBA students, as well as their partners, are encouraged to join the club; our events and trips will be interesting to beginners and experts alike.
Summary: The Ski & Snowboard Club at Ross organizes events for skiers and snowboarders of all abilities at the Ross School of Business, with multiple destination trips during the year.

Name: Sling Health - Ann Arbor
Description:
Sling Health is a student-run group that facilitates bio-engineering design and entrepreneurship on campus. This incubator brings together student teams from various backgrounds to address medical issues and improve healthcare. Teams are made up of health focused students, such as medical, engineering, law, and business students, to bring their expertise to the problems facing healthcare today. Our four objectives for what students will attain as a part of Sling Health at UM are as follows.

1. To learn about medical entrepreneurship in a multidisciplinary context, with engineering, medical business, and legal perspectives, while gaining team leadership and technical experience.

2. To join a fast-growing national network that has produced many prototypes, patents, and startups.

3. To work with other bright students and faculty on a problem of interest with the supporting resources. 

4. Develop novel devices and software applications targeting unmet clinical needs.

Our 2024-25 season will kickoff with the Sling Health Problem Day on September 24th from 6-8 PM at the Danto Auditorium at the Frankel Cardiovascular Center. Dinner will be provided!

Please RSVP here for the event: https://forms.gle/X3GrBJAC9rdHcbyp7

We are also looking for students to serve as team leaders this year where you will pitch a healthcare problem that you are looking to solve at the Problem Day event. There is no entrepeneurship experience required to serve as a team leader and we can help you find potential healthcare problems to tackle if you do not have an idea in mind. This is a great opportunity to get involved in entrepeneurship in a low stakes environment with $1,000 of gauranteed funding for all teams!

Team Leader Application (due Sept 15): https://forms.gle/u7H1iswTsJ9kvbxY8
Summary: Sling Health is a student-run bioengineering design and entrepreneurship incubator that helps facilitate student teams address medical issues to improve healthcare. It brings together engineering, medical, law and business students.

Name: slts test org
Summary: slts test org for testing mouse

Name: Smart Cities Club
Description:
The Smart Cities Club at the University of Michigan was launched in 2015 to provide students across all disciplines and backgrounds with an outlet to learn about the intersection of business, government, policy, technology and impact. The club provides students with opportunities to pursue a civic mindset regardless of specific career paths or concentrations and build community with like-minded students and professionals. 

Student Opportunities

  • Increase opportunities for civic-minded interdisciplinary learning 
  • Engage local like-minded stakeholders (other groups at UofM, local Ann Arbor organizations, etc) to build community
  • Prepare members to advance the intersection of government, technology, and business, no matter what career or sector they pursue
Summary: The Smart Cities Club facilitates multidisciplinary learning, introduces career opportunities, and builds connections across the business, government/policy, technology, and impact fields of interest at the University of Michigan.

Name: Smile 4 Kids
Description:
Through community outreach programs, mentorship, education, and volunteering, members of Smile 4 Kids will have the opportunity to enrich the lives of children in the Ann Arbor area by providing hope, happiness, and positivity. Students will incorporate their passion for helping to make a positive impact in other children's lives.

Join Our Email List!
Summary: ​Through community outreach programs, mentorship, education, and volunteering, members of Smile 4 Kids will have the opportunity to enrich the lives of children in the Ann Arbor area by providing hope, happiness, and positivity.

Name: Sobriety Club of Michigan
Description: The Sobriety Club of Michigan is a student-led organization dedicated to providing a supportive, alcohol-free environment for students who want to socialize without the pressure to drink. We offer a variety of sober social events, activities, and gatherings that allow members to build meaningful connections, have fun, and create lasting friendships. Whether you’re simply choosing not to drink or looking for an inclusive community that embraces sobriety, the club is here to provide opportunities for students to connect and thrive in a social setting that prioritizes health and well-being.
Summary: The Sobriety Club of Michigan offers a social space for students who choose not to drink, providing fun, alcohol-free events and a supportive community. It’s all about connecting and having a good time without the pressure of drinking.

Name: Soccer Club at Ross
Description:
The Soccer Club at the Ross School of Business is resolved to enhance and enrich the experiences of students at the University of Michigan who are interested in the sport of soccer. The club we establish shall be governed as stipulated in our constitution.

The club will promote student interaction within the University of Michigan community both internally and externally of the Ross community. The interactions will revolve around soccer related activities that include weekly scrimmages, intramural competitions, national inter-business school tournaments, attendance at UM Soccer games, and other social events that involve watching soccer while bringing together students who share a passion for the sport.
Summary: The Soccer Club at the Ross School of Business is resolved to enhance and enrich the experiences of students at the University of Michigan who are interested in the sport of soccer.

Name: Social Tennis Club
Description:
**Events have begun - join today by submitting this form or by emailing us at stc.officers@umich.edu!**

 

The Social Tennis Club is a gathering point for tennis enthusiasts of all types and skill levels. Whether you like to play competitively or just for fun, or if you're a veteran or a complete beginner, or if you like watching tennis more than playing it - we would love to see you at the STC.

 

At the University of Michigan, we are the only tennis club that is beginner-friendly, and the only tennis club that is entirely free to join. Here are some things you can do at the STC:

 

 -Meet and hang out with other tennis players and fans

 -Find new hitting partners

 -Participate in casual hitting sessions as well as organized tournament play

 -Go to watch parties for professional tennis matches

 

All STC events and meetings are completely optional! This is a zero-commitment club - you can come to as many or as few meetings and events as you'd like. Join today by filling out this form or by sending us an email at stc.officers@umich.edu!

 

Note: we may charge a participation fee for some organized events in order to cover expenses such as court time, balls, etc.
Summary: The Social Tennis Club is a gathering point for tennis enthusiasts of all types and skill levels. This is a casual, zero-commitment club - come hang out, meet new hitting partners, and participate in organized events!

Name: Social Work Doctoral Student Organization
Description:
Mission:

The DSO advocates for Joint Doctoral Program in Social Work and Social Science students' interest and plans doctoral student /faculty events.

Programs:

Academic conferences, social events, student/faculty potluck, social work brownbag lecture series.
Summary: DSO is a student group for Joint Doctoral Program in Social Work and Social Science students. It acts as a liaison between doctoral students and the several supervising committees within the school of social work.

Name: Society for Conservation Biology
Description: The Society for Conservation Biology (SCB), University of Michigan Chapter strives to 1) promote and develop skills needed by professionals for effective participation in the field of conservation biology; 2) encourage an interdisciplinary approach; 3) promote a forum for involvement in local and global conservation issues. We are open to anyone in the UM Community who has an interest in biodiversity conservation. To hear about upcoming events, join our mailing list by emailing michigan.scb@gmail.com.
Summary: The Society for Conservation Biology UM Chapter strives to develop interdisciplinary knowledge, skills, and community for students pursuing professional careers in the field of biodiversity conservation.

Name: Society for Human Resource Management at the University of Michigan
Description: SHRM-UM is currently the only undergraduate Human Resources student organization at the University of Michigan campus. We strive to expand the network of students interested in Human Resources at U of M while connecting students in SHRM with notable alumni and other distinguished human resource professionals. Additionally, we plan various events, workshops, and company visits associated with Human Resources throughout the academic year.
Summary: We are committed to providing University of Michigan students with the opportunity to gain knowledge and insight into the effective management of human capital in the field of Human Resource Management.

Name: Society for Music Research at the University of Michigan
Description: This organization exists to represent the graduate students in music research (that is, Historical Musicology, Ethnomusicology, and Music Theory) in the School of Music, Theatre & Dance (hereafter SMTD) at the University of Michigan (hereafter U-M); to provide a central forum where SMR membership may meet to discuss issues pertaining to graduate students in music research at SMTD; to organize events and symposia that foster the sharing of knowledge in the research of music at U-M; to organize social events for SMR membership; and to support any other organizations whose goals relate to those of SMR.
Summary: This organization exists to represent the graduate students in music research (that is, Historical Musicology, Ethnomusicology, and Music Theory) in the School of Music, Theatre & Dance at the University of Michigan.

Name: Society for Space Law and the Law of the Sea
Description:
SSLLS focuses on exploring professional opportunities for those who hold career interests in space law or law of the sea, as well as bringing speakers to campus who can discuss various aspects of both areas of law.

Additionally, SSLLS seeks to foster community among students interested in these areas of law.  To this end, SSLLS regularly hosts social activities such as trips to the local planetarium.
Summary: SSLLS focuses on exploring professional opportunities for those who hold career interests in space law or law of the sea, as well as bringing speakers to campus who can discuss various aspects of both areas of law.

Name: Society of Arab American Engineers
Description: The Society of Arab American Engineers (SAAE) aims to empower Middle Eastern and North African (MENA) and non-MENA engineering students and form a tight-knit community through a variety of personal and professional development opportunities. We foster a safe environment for students, faculty, and staff to inspire and uplift one another through engineering pursuits. SAAE supports its members through mentorship, professional development, and social bonding opportunities. These experiences include but are not limited to networking events, interview and resume workshops, professional mixers, panels from MENA engineers, and more. SAAE welcomes members of all disciplines, ages, and stages of their engineering journey.
Summary: The Society of Arab American Engineers (SAAE) is part of the Arab Student Association umbrella. We engage with students, faculty, and staff who are passionate about advancing Middle Eastern and North African community members in the field of engineering.

Name: Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers
Description:
About

The Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) represents those of Asian heritage in the scientific and engineering communities. Our goal is to give the members the resources they need to succeed in their academic and career endeavors as well as being able to network with other fellow scientists and engineers.

Mission

The nationwide mission of SASE is to prepare Asian scientists and engineers for success in their careers and the global business world. As well as creating diversity on campus and in the workplace and providing opportunities for members to give back to their communities.

In addition to the national mission, the SASE-UM chapter has a mission to establish an active presence of Asians in engineering and science on campus and engage in the community by emphasizing each individual's technical skills. Furthermore, we hope to strengthen the leadership and communication skills of our members to better prepare them in the business world and their careers.

Founding

The University of Michigan chapter of SASE was founded in October 2010, and has since gained support from various departments in the university. Before a SASE chapter was started at the University of Michigan, there were many other ethnic scientific and engineering societies, but none that that truly represented those of Asian heritage. It was on this basis that the University of Michigan chapter of SASE was founded as well as the entire nationwide SASE community. The national SASE community was founded in 2007 by 10 Proctor and Gamble interns. Today, the SASE community spans across many colleges nationwide.

 

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/sase.umich

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/sase.michigan/

Slack: um-student-sase.slack.com

Website: http://www.umich.edu/~sase/
Summary: The Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) represents those of Asian heritage in the scientific and engineering communities. Our goal is to give the members the resources they need to succeed socially, academically, and professionally.

Name: Society of Asian Studies Students
Description: SASS is an established Sponsored Student Organization (SSO) aiming to create a community for Asian Languages and Cultures (ALC) students at the University of Michigan. SASS’s mission is to engage ALC students with meaningful interactions that will further their understanding and appreciation of Asian Studies, while providing them more access to learning opportunities in relevant fields.
Summary: SASS is a student organization dedicated to creating a community for fellow Asian Studies and Asian Languages and Cultures students. Our mission is to engage ALC students with meaningful academic interactions.

Name: Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
Description: Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology is committed to: 1) Expanding member’s knowledge on biological chemistry and molecular biology research topics; 2) Offering members opportunities to present their research abstract at annual conferences; 3) Interact with the community by holding social events concerning biological chemistry fields; 4) Holding academic events between campuses, allowing members to explore diverse research topics and share knowledge; 5) Organize social events to build a sense of community within the chapter.
Summary: The Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology at UofM focuses on expanding members' knowledge, providing opportunities for research presentation, fostering community interaction through social events, and promoting academic collaboration.

Name: Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers
Description:
Chapter Goals

    • To achieve a sense of community among Hispanic engineering and applied sciences students at the University of Michigan and other SHPE student chapters.
    • To unite and organize Hispanic/Latinx Engineering students based on their various needs.
    • To improve the academic success of Hispanic/Latinx students in STEM majors to increase opportunities during undergraduate years and for post graduation success.
    • To promote professional as well as well as cultural awareness by means of social and intellectual interaction.
    • To seek out and recruit potential Hispanic/Latinx engineering and applied sciences students.
    • To improve the retention of Hispanic/Latinx engineering and applied sciences students at the University of Michigan.

    • To assist University faculty and staff to learn about and appreciate Hispanic/Latinx American culture.
    • To connect our values of diversity, equity, and inclusion with the University of Michigan and other campus organizations.
Summary: SHPE changes lives by empowering the Hispanic community to realize their fullest potential and impacts the world through STEM awareness, access, support and development.

Name: Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers - Graduate Committee
Description:
The Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers - Graduate Committee (SHPE-Grad) is a student-led organization whose primary goal is to provide a professional and social network for Hispanic/Latinx engineering and applied sciences graduate students at the University of Michigan. We invite you to participate in any of the activities sponsored by this student-led organization:

  • Networking opportunities with Michigan alumni, current faculty and industry professionals in your research area.
  • Mentorship opportunities to support undergraduates who are interested in graduate school.
  • Sponsorship to attend SHPE national and regional conferences.
  • Academic/Professional development workshops to help you succeed in engineering classes, research, presentation skills, networking skills and much more.
  • Outreach opportunities like teaching engineering courses/workshops to minority high school students. 
  • Social activities: soccer tournaments, movie nights, bowling, BBQ’s, tailgates, parties, etc.
  • Social networking with other students in various departments, collaborations with other student organizations such as Grad SWE, GSBSE and more. 

 

OUR WEBSITE: https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/shpeg/home
Summary: We provide Latinx graduate students in engineering and applied sciences with opportunities for professional networking, academic support, and social events. We also support and motivate undergraduates to increase the number of Latinxs in graduate school.

Name: Society of Les Voyageurs
Description:
As the oldest continually active student group on the University of Michigan campus (founded in 1907), the Society of Les Voyageurs upholds a long-standing tradition of convening over the love for nature and the out of doors.  The Society owns a cabin on the Huron River just north of downtown called Habe Mills Pine Lodge that was built in 1927 to house the Society, its activities, as well as those members who choose to live there.  The group also hosts potluck dinners every Sunday at 6pm, followed by a program from a professor or a community member pertaining to learning more about the out of doors.  The group is known to embark occasionally on casual outings such as hiking, backpacking, rock climbing, caving, cross-country skiing, etc.

Please note that the primary use of this site is informational only. Membership is NOT managed through Maize Pages. If you are interested in being added to our guest email list, please write to lv-guests-requests@umich.edu.
Summary: Founded in 1907 at the University of Michigan, the Society of Les Voyageurs is a group of students dedicated to intellectual discourse and the enjoyment of the wonder and mystery of the out of doors.

Name: Society of Physics Students
Description:
University of Michigan's SPS is deelpy involved in the community, by volunteering at educational events, offering tutoring and GRE preparation to students in the area, and hosting biweekly lectures. SPS also hosts a variety of social events.

The SPS has seven unique roles within the physics community:

  1. Encouraging undergraduate research experience as a teaching tool.
  2. Promoting science literacy and appreciation through physics outreach programs to grades K-12 and the general public.
  3. Through SPS alumni and the members of Sigma Pi Sigma, the Society maintains the only institutionalized structure the physics community has for communicating with the "friends of physics" that exist throughout all walks of life in society.
  4. The SPS provides an effective signpost for educating the student on the many career options, in addition to traditional physics, that come with a degree in physics.
  5. The active SPS chapter is an especially effective student recruitment and retention tool for the physics department.
  6. The SPS is a gateway society to the other professional societies in physics.
  7. The SPS provides training for leadership. Through SPS activities, students' professional development, communication skills, leadership qualities, and professional networking is enhanced in ways that cannot be realized in course work alone.
