Summary: We are the largest student organization within the physics department and welcome anyone with an interest in physics. We offer tutoring, host social events, do public outreach, and serve as the social hub within the department.

Name: Society of Undergraduate Math Students
Description: The Society of Undergraduate Math Students, colloquially known as SUMS, is an organization whose goal is to facilitate friendships and community amongst mathematics concentrators and those interested in mathematics.
Summary: SUMS attempts to facilitate friendships and community amongst mathematics concentrators and those interested in mathematics

Name: Society of Wetland Scientists (North Central Chapter) Student Chapter at the University of Michigan
Description: We are a student group dedicated to promoting stewardship and understanding of crucial wetland ecosystems through hands-on experience and meaningful connections with experts and fellow students.
Summary: Student group dedicated to education, conservation, and appreciation of wetland ecosystems.

Name: Society of Women Engineers
Description:
Our Mission: 

To encourage women to excel as engineers and leaders, and to promote an inclusive community within the College and the profession that fosters universal success in engineering, independent of gender.

 

The Society of Women Engineers (SWE) is an international, non-profit educational service organization dedicated to supporting women in engineering careers or studies as well as encouraging young women to consider engineering as a career path. Since it was founded in 1950, SWE has given female engineers a platform and voice within the greater engineering industry and community. 

 

The Society of Women Engineers at University of Michigan is one of the largest student organizations on campus. We have a leadership core of 50 student leaders, and over 300 general members. Our members are actively involved in our many technical, professional, social, and service events both on and off campus. Every year, we send a delegation to the national and local conferences to connect with the larger SWE organization. We also work closely with SWE chapters in India and Liberia including a yearly visit to each location.

 

We run a wide variety of events every semester. We engage hundreds of K-12 students, parents, and teachers across the globe in engineering outreach activities. We also host several charity events including a 5K Fun Run and the Engineering Games competition. In the fall, we host the biggest career fair on campus and invite over 300 companies to host corporate information sessions (that are open to the entire student body).

 

Through all our events, we strive to achieve the following five values:

Integrity:  We aspire to the highest level of ethical behavior as evidenced by honesty and dignity in our personal and professional relationships and responsibilities.

Inclusive Environment:  We embrace diversity in its broadest interpretation and commit to creating an inclusive environment for all our members and stakeholders. We value the contributions of a diverse membership, which enables SWE to achieve its full potential.

Mutual Support:  We provide an organization that fosters mentoring, and the development of professional and personal networks.

Professional Excellence:  We conduct our activities in a professional manner, demonstrating and demanding the highest standards of business practices.

Trust:  We share a common definition of success with open, transparent access to common information, building mutual respect and confidence in the competence of those with whom we lead, serve and partner with.

 
If you are interested in joining our organization, we ask that you join the national SWE organization (scholarships available - contact SWE.Eboard@umich.edu). Information on how to join can be found at https://www.sweumich.org/become-a-member-or-renew-membership. For more general information, check out our website at https://www.sweumich.org/
Summary: The Society of Women Engineers at the University of Michigan encourages women to excel as engineers and leaders and promotes an inclusive community within the College and the profession that fosters universal success in engineering.

Name: Society of Women in Economics
Description: SWIE strives to foster an empowering environment for women in UofM within the challenging and often male-dominated undergraduate economics program. The Society has a focus on career development programming while also creating a community through the mentorship program and social events to allow members to form relationships with other women in their economics classes.
Summary: Society of Women in Economics (SWIE) strives to foster an empowering environment for women in UofM within this challenging and often male-dominated undergraduate program.

Name: Society of Women in Finance
Description: The Society of Women in Finance is dedicated to providing valuable experience, professional development, and community by bringing together women and gender variant students through their interests in finance.
Summary: The Society of Women in Finance is dedicated to providing valuable experience, professional development, and community by bringing together women and gender variant students through their interests in finance.

Name: Sociology Graduate Students Organization
Description: All current Sociology graduate students and dual Sociology students with Women's Studies, Social Work and Public Policy are automatically members of the organization. Co-chairs are elected yearly for this organization. The goal of SGS is to foster collegiality and support among the graduate student population as well as between faculty and graduate students in order to support research, healthy living, and successful completion of the PhD in Sociology and dual Sociology programs here at Michigan.
Summary: Sociology Graduate Students is an intentional community made up of current graduate students of the Department of Sociology at the University of Michigan. Our goal is to promote collegiality and support among the students and faculty of the department.

Name: Solidaridad Organizada para la Liberación
Description: Solidaridad Organizada para la Liberación (SOL) is a radical organization rooted in the African, Native, and Indigenous traditions of resistance and liberation. Through abolitionist, anti-capitalist, and anti-imperialist praxis, we aim to build a transformative space for the Latine community and diaspora to organize, educate, and fight for collective liberation. By centering those most impacted by systemic violence, we strive to dismantle white supremacy and eurocentrism while fostering global solidarity and cultivating new systems of accountability, care, and justice.
Summary: SOL is a Latine-based organization open to all members of the community and rooted in abolitionist, anti-imperialist, anti-capitalist, and anit-racist thinking. We are a community organized towards the liberation of all, in and outside of Latin America.

Name: Somali Student Association
Description: The Somali Student Association (SSA) at the University of Michigan is a cultural and community-driven organization dedicated to celebrating Somali heritage, fostering unity, and empowering students through mentorship, networking, and cultural events. Our mission is to create a welcoming space for Somali students and allies, promote academic and professional growth, and strengthen connections within the broader Somali diaspora.
Summary: The Somali Student Association (SSA) at the University of Michigan is a cultural and community-driven organization dedicated to celebrating Somali heritage, fostering unity, and empowering students through mentorship, networking, and cultural events.

Name: South Asian Awareness Network
Description: SAAN serves to engage and educate ourselves and the greater community to promote South Asian social justice with a focus on uplifting marginalized groups. Our programming aims to explore the intersectionality of identity through creative expression and community engagement. We are committed to raising social awareness, pursuing tangible change, and striving toward collective liberation with a diverse and inclusive South Asian lens.
Summary: The South Asian Awareness Network is dedicated to increasing knowledge of and promoting innovative solutions to issues relevant to South Asian and other communities all around the world.

Name: South Asian Law Students Association
Description: SALSA hopes to raise awareness of South Asian legal, political, and social issues. We also hope to provide our members with a space where issues relating to South Asian identity can be explored. We hope to create a community where members can turn for both academic assistance throughout their time as students as well as a social atmosphere where members can come to relieve stress and have fun.
Summary: SALSA seeks to create a social, inclusive community and provide academic assistance to students. We sponsor South-Asian speakers, hold social and cultural events, and provide a forum for learning about issues that affect South Asian communities.

Name: South Asian Medical Student Association
Description: We strive to provide support and guidance to medical students of South Asian descent as they enter the University of Michigan Medical School. SAMoSA has established relationships with UMHS physicians of similar descent so that students can gain valuable mentorship throughout their time here. We also strive to collaborate with the other student groups in UMMS to hold various community-building events including health fairs, health education, and volunteer opportunities. Finally, we organize various social events throughout the academic year so that a tight-knit community can be developed within all students interested in South-Asian health concerns. All students who are interested in learning about South Asian culture through a medical lens are welcome to join.
Summary: The South Asian Medical Student Association is a medical student organization designed to focus on the needs of the South Asian community both here in Michigan and globally.

Name: South Quad Hall Council
Description:
The South Quadrangle Hall Council recognizes that each student’s experience at the University of Michigan is shaped both within and outside of his/her academic life and that their residence hall life can be an important part of that experience. Therefore, the purpose of the Council is to develop a meaningful and enriching South Quad community for its residents.

The purpose of South Quad Hall Council shall be to:

  1. Plan, promote, and coordinate participation in residence hall functions.
  2. Encourage interaction between and within the houses.
  3. Improve the quality of residence hall life
  4. Serve as the official representative of South Quad residents expressing the opinion and interest in appropriate faculty, administrative, and student agencies.
  5. Be the central governing agency of South Quad.
  6. To appropriate dues, money, and all other sources of income.
Summary: The South Quad Hall Council recognizes that each student’s residence hall life can be an important part of their experience. Therefore, the purpose of the Council is to develop a meaningful and enriching South Quad community for its residents.

Name: Southeast Asia Business Association
Description:
The Southeast Asia Business Association (hereafter, “SABA”) at the University of Michigan - Stephen M. Ross School of Business has a fourfold mission. 

Firstly, SABA seeks to promote a deeper understanding of Southeast Asia (hereafter, “ASEAN”) business culture and practices within the Ross Business School (hereafter, “Ross”) community with the ultimate goal of assisting in the creation of a more diverse and culturally aware student body.

Secondly, SABA will serve as a social and networking support group for ASEAN students at Ross.

Thirdly, SABA will serve as Ross’ window to prominent Southeast Asian alumni for mentoring, job and internship opportunities and connecting alumni to the current ASEAN student body. 

Finally, SABA will serve as a channel of communication for prospective ASEAN students and admitted ASEAN students by providing orientation and guidance counseling to facilitate the transition into the Ross community.
Summary: The SABA serves as a venue for prospective students, current students, and alumni from Ross School of Business to connect with Southeast Asian business and culture, and to network with other students who share a common interest in the region.

Name: Southwest Asia and North Africa Social Work Association
Description: SWANA is established for the purpose of creating a safe environment for Southwest Asian and North African identifying social work students and professionals to discuss interests, plans, culture, advocacy, and reclaiming of our identities.
Summary: SWANA  is established for the purpose of creating a safe environment for Southwest Asian and North African identifying social work students and professionals to discuss interests, plans, culture, advocacy, and reclaiming of our identities.

Name: Spanish Club at the University of Michigan
Description:
The Spanish Club is a student-run organization that focuses on the Spanish language and Hispanic/Latinx culture, organizing a variety of activities and resources. We hold conversation hours during the academic year to practice speaking Spanish as well as free, walk-in peer tutoring. We also sponsor fun-filled culture-based and recreational events like Yost Skate Night, Latin Movie Night, and the Cultural Clubs' World Cup Soccer Tournament, as well as coordinating local community service.

Join our GroupMe! https://groupme.com/join_group/102709466/ggbs0MxJ

Email spanishclubeboard@umich.edu if you have questions or would like to be added to the Listserv where we will send out info about our events as well as the Zoom links (Make sure to include your expected graduation year in the email so we can add you to the correct list). 

 

Conversation Hours: Winter 2025: Mondays and Wednesdays from 6-7pm in the basement of the Michigan League Snacks at least once a wee! Location subject to change - please join our GroupMe / follow our Instagram @spanishclubuofm for updates

Tutoring Hours:

Tutoring hours take place every day in the Michigan League and/or on zoom. Check the GroupMe for daily updates.

Monday 5-6pm

Tuesday 5:30-6:30pm

Wednesday 5-6 PM

Thursday 5-6 PM

Friday 1-2 PM

Please join our GroupMe for announcements regarding tutoring hours and location!
Summary: Spanish Club is a casual organization that celebrates the Spanish language and Spanish and Hispanic culture through lively conversation hours, regular club meetings, tutoring, and fun social events.

Name: SPARK Electric Racing
Description: SPARK Electric Racing is a student team dedicated to the development of young and driven professionals in the designing, building and racing of an innovative electric racing motorcycle. Join us in our mission to creating the most powerful electric motorcycle in the world!
Summary: SPARK Electric Racing is as student team that designs, builds and races all electric racing motorcycles.

Name: Special Olympics College at the University of Michigan
Description:
"Spread the Word to End the Word"

 

Special Olympics College at the University of Michigan is an organization that advocates for people with cognitive and physical disabilities in the greater Ann Arbor area. Our mission is to provide a fun and inclusive environment for our athletes through our many sport activities and events. We offer our athletes the opportunity to play flag football, dance, soccer, and basketball.

 

SO College's student volunteers organize practices for athletes of all ages and abilities in each sport. SO College play UNIFIED. This means that both our athletes and volunteers are able to compete in our practices and events against other universities in our organized regional, state, and national tournaments.

 

SO College at UofM partners with Special Olympics Michigan to proudly participate in an annual flag football game against Michigan State University, along with many other tournaments (for each of our sports) with universities in the Midwest region including Adrian College, Eastern Michigan, Western Michigan, Notre Dame, and more!

 

We welcome everyone to join our mission at SO College at UofM!

Please contact us using our social media and email below if you are interested in joining or becoming a student volunteer!
Summary: SO College at the University of Michigan advocates for people with cognitive and physical disabilities in the Ann Arbor area. Our mission is to provide a fun and inclusive environment for our athletes through our many sports activities and events!

Name: Spectrum Center
Description:
Spectrum Center Mission

With sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression as our framework, the Spectrum Center is committed to enriching the campus experience and developing students as individuals and as members of communities. Our work is accomplished through a student-centered, intersectional lens.
Summary: The Spectrum Center at University of Michigan is a collaborative space in which all members of the university and local community are welcome. We work oi enhance the campus climate and support LGBTQ+ students, staff, and faculty at UM.

Name: Spectrum Center Programming Board
Description:
The Spectrum Center Programming Board is a volunteer leadership opportunity, with graduate and undergraduate students selected through application and interview. The Programming Board plans their own events and support for Spectrum Center signature events and theme weeks such as LGBT History Month, Trans Awareness Week, and Lavender Graduation. We need students who care about equity, social change, and skill-buildng to push our organization forward and hold events that uplift our community.

Any University of Michigan student can apply, no matter your year or discipline! We would especially love to see graduate, nontraditional, and first-generation students apply to increase the visibility and representation of your scholarly communities through your thoughts and participation.
Summary: The Spectrum Center Programming Board is a volunteer leadership opportunity and student organization run through the Spectrum Center, supporting major Spectrum events and hosting our own unique programming.

Name: SPhD
Description: SPhD seeks to support all UM SPH doctoral students in growing intellectually and professionally by enhancing communication between students, faculty, and administration and leveraging opportunities to enhance the student experience.
Summary: SPhD seeks to support all UM SPH doctoral students in growing intellectually and professionally by enhancing communication between students, faculty, and administration and leveraging opportunities to enhance the student experience.

Name: Sport Business Association
Description:
The Sport Business Association (SBA) is the largest sport business club on campus, with over 250 members, from freshmen to seniors. Our student membership touches 6 different schools at UM and because of this, SBA seeks to expose our members to multiple sectors of the sport industry including journalism, real-estate, finance, graphic design, etc.

Formed in August 2003 by Sport Management students, the purpose of SBA is to turn students who are interested in the business of sport into polished professionals who are ready to meaningfully contribute to the sport industry upon graduation. We do this by holding speaker events on campus, facilitating professional development workshops, and visiting leading companies domestically and internationally.
Summary: The purpose of this organization is to educate, connect, and inspire the future generation of sport business professionals.

Name: Sports Medicine Club
Description: The Sports Medicine group was founded in order to further educate students through lectures and first-hand experiences with qualified professionals in the field of sports medicine.  The club strives to create strong relationships with clinics and hospitals in the city of Ann Arbor, while promoting both community service and volunteering. Through guest speakers, shadowing experiences, and philanthropy and volunteer opportunities, the Sports Medicine Club aims to expand the education of pre-health/pre-medical students interested in a field related to sports medicine.
Summary: The Sports Medicine Club offers guest speakers, shadowing opportunities, and philanthropy involvement for all University of Michigan students focusing on pre-health/pre-medical concentrations related to sports medicine.

Name: Stamps in Color
Description: We are a community of creatives dedicated to enhancing creative, social, and professional opportunities for all members, with a particular focus on supporting the unique experiences and contributions of peers, faculty, and staff from underrepresented backgrounds. Our mission is to foster an inclusive environment that celebrates diverse perspectives and talents, empowering everyone to thrive in a creative and collaborative space through the facilitation of events, lectures, dialogue sessions, and exhibits that speak to the experiences of its members. Stamps in Color offers multiple engagement opportunities, including: Stamps in Color Welcome & Mentorship Program and the Stamps in Color Annual Professional Development Trip.
Summary: Stamps in Color is a student-facilitated group of artists/designers who aim to promote the creative, social, and professional opportunities for the minority communities of Stamps through various endeavors that stimulate creative and personal growth.

Name: Stamps Student Government
Description: Stamps Student Government is an organization at Stamps School of Art & Design working to build community and support student initiatives. SSG is a collective of active Stamps students seeking the best art & design educational experience in the world and working cooperatively with the student body, administration, faculty, and staff to achieve this experience.
Summary: Stamps Student Government is a representative student organization at Stamps School of Art & Design working to build community and support student initiatives. For more info on getting involved, email SSGExecBoard@umich.edu.

Name: Star Wars Fan Club
Description: We talk about Star Wars, watch videos about lore and theories, but the most fun thing we do is fight with lightsabers (we have a lot extras, so you don't need your own!). We will be holding watch parties as new content releases on Disney+ (account not required), and other events include game days where we play Star Wars related board games and video games, and other smaller projects. We also hope to attempt to build our own lightsabers and maybe even a droid one day. If you are interested, send an email or join our Discord or check out our Event Calendar! All of our links can be found on our LinkTree!
Summary: We talk about Star Wars, play Star Wars video/board games, watch clone wars episodes and fight with lightsabers (you don't need to have your own!) We also watch all the new shows as they come out (you don't need to have Disney+)

Name: Statistics in the Community
Description:
Introduction

STATCOM (Statistics in the Community) at the University of Michigan is a community outreach program provided by graduate students at the University of Michigan. The program offers the expertise of statistics graduate students, free of charge, to non-profit governmental and community organizations in the areas of data organization, analysis, and interpretation. 

Services Provided by STATCOM 

 Advice and assistance are offered on a wide variety of statistical issues including: 

  • Use of data to improve decision making processes
  • Survey/sample design and analysis
  • Design and analysis of studies and experiments
  • Graphical methods of summarizing and gaining meaning from data
  • Use of data to detect trends and make predictions and projections.

STATCOM is able to assist with study design, data analysis, and the interpretation of results, but does not have the resources to collect or enter data.

About our Volunteers

Our volunteers are students who are interested in serving the community through statistical consulting projects. Our volunteers are mainly comprised of graduate students in the Department of Biostatistics (M.S. and Ph.D.). Students in other departments (e.g., Statistics, Survey Methodology) are also members of STATCOM. Faculty members serve an advisory role in STATCOM, providing leadership, assistance with client meetings, and statistical consulting advice as needed, especially in initial consultations. However, projects are conducted and led by our student volunteers.

Contacting STATCOM

Department of Biostatistics
School of Public Health
University of Michigan
1415 Washington Heights
Ann Arbor, MI 48109
Email: statcom-um@umich.edu
Summary: STATCOM (Statistics in the Community) offers the expertise of statistics graduate students, free of charge, to non-profit governmental and community organizations in the areas of data organization, analysis, and interpretation.

Name: Stockwell Hall Council
Description:
• Cultivation of greater awareness of personal beliefs and values.
  • Exploration of academic and career goals.
  • Enhancement of intercultural knowledge and competence.
  • Development of a deeper understanding of personal and civic responsibility and connection with others in the residential, campus and local communities.
Summary: Stockwell Hall Council (SWHC), a community focused on the unique needs and interests of second year students living in residence at Stockwell Hall.

Name: Stop the Bleed Chapter at the University of Michigan
Description: STB at UofM is is established for the purpose of spreading proper bleeding control techniques to the public, in light of the occurrence of mass casualty events and deaths from bleeding. Check out upcoming Stop the Bleed courses at https://cms.bleedingcontrol.org/class/search to get trained.
Summary: STB at UofM is established for the purpose of spreading proper bleeding control techniques to the public, in light of the occurrence of mass casualty events and deaths from bleeding.

Name: Student 2 Student
Description: Student 2 Student is an extension of the Help Iraq branch that advocates and aims to provide Humanitarian Aid & Advocacy for college students who are displaced due to religious persecution.
Summary: Student 2 Student is an extension of the Help Iraq branch that advocates and aims to provide Humanitarian Aid & Advocacy for college students who are displaced due to religious persecution.

Name: Student Actuaries at Michigan
Description: Student Actuaries at Michigan is an organization for undergraduates and graduates interested in actuarial science and related fields. The club's main focus is to leverage its resources to support the actuarial career and the professional development of its members through recruiting, networking, exam support, mentorship, and other services.
Summary: Student Actuaries at Michigan is an organization for students interested in actuarial science and related fields. The club's main focus is to leverage its resources to support the actuarial career and the professional development of its members.

Name: Student American Dental Hygienist Association
Description: To provide a supportive environment for dental hygiene students to expand their professional development and promotion of oral health for the public through community service, leadership, education, and advocacy
Summary: To provide a supportive environment for dental hygiene students to expand their professional development and promotion of oral health for the public through community service, leadership, education, and advocacy.

Name: Student Association for Psychedelic Studies
Description: Our objective is to create a space to discuss the growing body of research on therapeutic uses of psychedelics and related political, ethical, and PODS (privilege, oppression, diversity, and social justice) issues. We hope to expand objective awareness and promote fair and responsible access to alternative treatments.
Summary: A space to learn about and discuss the therapeutic use of psychedelics and connect with others. --> PLEASE EMAIL US TO JOIN <--

Name: Student Astronomical Society
Description:
SAS educates the public and student body about astronomy, connecting students of all majors with the community through bi-weekly meetings and exciting outreach opportunities. Bi-weekly observing nights in Angel Hall are held in collaboration with the Astronomy Department and provide a great opportunity for members to take on leadership and interact with the community. SAS welcomes individuals from all majors and backgrounds, and the only requirement for membership is an interest in astronomy. We additionally provide academic and professional opportunities for astronomy undergraduates through workshops, research presentations, and community building. There are no formal requirements for becoming a member, just show up to one of your meetings or events!

Visit us at umichsas.com!
Summary: SAS educates the public and student body about astronomy, connecting students of all majors with the community through bi-weekly meetings, outreach opportunities, and trips. We additionally support astronomy students both academically and professionally.

Name: Student Chapter of American Society of Landscape Architects
Description:
The purpose of the Student Chapter American Society of Landscape Architects is the advancement of education and skill in the art of landscape architecture and the promotion of the profession as an instrument of service in the public welfare.

The Student Chapter provides networking opportunities for members by facilitating contact with professionals. The chapter also facilitates student input regarding academic programs in landscape architecture at the School for Environment and Sustainability (SEAS). The chapter seeks to increase the visibility of the practice of landscape architecture across campus and promote interdepartmental cooperation.
Summary: The purpose of the Student Chapter of American Society of Landscape Architects is the advancement of education and skill in the art of Landscape Architecture and the promotion of the profession as an instrument of service in the public welfare.

Name: Student Chapter of the Academy of LDS Dentists at University of Michigan School of Dentistry
ShortName: LDS Dental Student Chapter at U of M
Description:
This Student Chapter of the Academy of LDS Dentists is an organization of dental students who are dedicated to serving mankind.  Our mission is to:

- Promote dental education among fellow professionals and the general public;

- Facilitate dental service by its members, providing manpower and expertise in dental care as far as our training allows;

- Help procure and distribute dental disease prevention educational materials to underserved populations;

- Assist its members learn techniques for facilitating patient treatment to underserved demographics; and

- Introduce its members to Continuing Education Modalities (including study clubs, mentors, attending C.E. courses, and seeking learning through other medias like DVDs, MP4s, Webinars, etc.). 

The purposes of this Student Chapter shall be:

1.      To help its members learn the social, moral, and ethical obligations of the profession of dentistry and the provision of oral healthcare to all people as they are pursuing careers in dentistry.

2.    To introduce, promote, and encourage student participation in organized dentistry, humanitarian services and to position the Student Chapter membership as the beginning of a lifelong involvement with organized dentistry.  

3.    To create and disseminate information important to LDS students pursuing careers in dentistry. 

4.     To represent the needs, interests, and welfare of the Student Chapter’s members to legislative bodies and other organizations that have influence on these concerns and the profession of dentistry.

5.  To be helpful, if invited, to assist school administrators in evaluating dental education and policies affecting dental students.

6.    To foster the attainment of each member’s full potential by promoting, encouraging, and providing opportunities for participation in leadership development, community service, dental research, and other experiences for personal improvement and advancement of the profession.
Summary: This Student Chapter of the Academy of LDS Dentists is an organization of dental students who are dedicated to service, promoting dental education, preventative dental care, and optimal oral health.

Name: Student Community of Progressive Empowerment
Description: The purpose of SCOPE is to support and empower undocumented students and the larger immigrant community. To create a safe space that protects students who are undocumented or of DACAmented (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) status. To advocate for prospective and current students such that an education is accessible to all. To work together to create a community that will guide and empower members through a successful college experience while providing them with the necessary life skills to prepare them for a post college transition. In addition, SCOPE serves as a forum for undocumented/DACAmented students, students from mixed-status families, and allies to work in conjunction to advocate for the rights of immigrants by educating and mobilizing the campus community and the general public around immigration related issues.
Summary: The purpose of SCOPE is to support and empower undocumented students and advocate for the immigrant community.

Name: Student Diversity Council
Description:
The Student Diversity Council (SDC) is one of the two governing councils of the University of Michigan Medical School (UMMS). Through education, outreach, and activism, the SDC addresses issues involving Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, Accessibility, and Justice (DEIAJ) at UMMS and Michigan Medicine. The SDC is committed to: 

  • Supporting the cultivation of a safe and inclusive culture and environment for all students, especially those who identify as a member of a historically marginalized group—including Black, Indigenous and People of Color (BIPOC), Latinx, Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI), persons with disabilities, and lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, asexual, pansexual/polyamorous (LGBTQIAP+) communities. 
  • Responding swiftly and competently to acts of bias, prejudice, discrimination, racism or other threats that may target the aforementioned communities.
  • Ensuring accountability for the continued progress of DEIAJ initiatives at UMMS.
  • Fostering an environment of inclusion, collaboration, and the sharing of best practices, resources, and knowledge to work effectively towards these goals.

These values anchor the council’s mission and purpose. With a unified voice, the SDC will advocate for organizations and student initiatives related to DEIAJ within UMMS and issues related to health disparities in healthcare and health education in collaboration with other student organizations, faculty, and administration.
Summary: The Student Diversity Council (SDC) is one of the two governing councils of the University of Michigan Medical School (UMMS) and addresses issues involving diversity, equity, inclusion, accessibility, and justice (DEIAJ).

Name: Student Film Festival Project
Description:
Our club hosts a short film festival for the students at Michigan. The final festival operates through teams of contestants who enter. At the start of the timeline for creating films, the students will be given random rules that they must follow for their film, outlining a necessary character, genre, role, line, and prop that they must incorporate into their film. The groups will then have a short period to develop a short film based off of these prompts that they get. During this time they must write a script, find locations to shoot, record, edit, and submit their entry. The films are going to be played in a booked auditorium on the festival date. At the end of the showing, the audience will be have ranked choice voting to determine the prize winning teams. 

       The goal of this event is to showcase Michigan student’s creativity and ability to work under time pressure with preset rules that they must follow. We want to showcase the work of the student body and reward those who go above and beyond. This will be a good opportunity for some students to begin to develop and have work that they have done outside of a class and gives experience in working both in high pressure situations and as a team. Of course, we also want to emphasize that the event will be fun for all - those who are creating the actual short films and those who choose to go and support their friends or see the work that their peers have worked hard on creating.
Summary: Our club hosts a short film festival that is run by students for students. Using randomized prompts and a short deadline, we aim to inspire creative and fun short films, resulting in a final festival in which winners are chosen and rewards are given.

Name: Student Funded Fellowships
Description: SFF raises money to fund first year law students doing unpaid public interest work in their first summer of law school. All funding decisions are made through a competitive grant process. SFF grants enable 1L students committed to pursuing careers in public interest to take the jobs that they are passionate about without having to accrue more debt.
Summary: SFF raises money to fund first year law students doing unpaid public interest work in their first summer of law school. All funding decisions are made through a competitive grant process.

Name: Student Leadership Board in IOE
Description: The SLB exists to support and encourage the academic, social, and professional pursuits of students in Industrial and Operations Engineering (IOE). This is done in several ways: 1) facilitating communication between IOE student organizations; 2) providing resources for students and organizations; and 3) acting as a liaison between the general student body of IOE and the department administration. Each IOE student organization is represented on the officer board, and every IOE student is welcome to be an active member.
Summary: The SLB exists to support and encourage the academic, social, and professional pursuits of students in Industrial and Operations Engineering.

Name: Student Life Sustainability
Description: Student Life Sustainability seeks to connect students with opportunities to practice sustainable leadership, partner with staff to amplify a culture of sustainability on campus, and reduce the carbon footprint of the division’s buildings and operations. Student Life Sustainability offers a range of co-curricular programs, academic partnerships and internships - including the UM Sustainable Food Program, Planet Blue Student Leaders, the Student Sustainability Coalition, and Excellence in Sustainability Graduation Cords.
Summary: Student Life Sustainability seeks to connect students with opportunities to practice sustainable leadership, partner with staff to amplify a culture of sustainability on campus, and reduce the carbon footprint of the division’s buildings and operations.

Name: Student Life: Dean of Students - Expect Respect
Description: Expect Respect is not a student organization, but a program of the Dean of Students Office. Expect Respect is a messaging campaign, a unique partnership among students, faculty and staff with intentional collaboration and campus unity around our values. Expect Respect upholds diversity, equity, and inclusion and honors all voices. It is an educational initiative aimed at supporting a campus climate in which all persons are treated with civility and respect while being their authentic selves. How students experience their campus environment influences learning and growth. Having a positive campus climate can shape our institution into a community with a sense of belonging and a sense of home. A healthy campus climate is safe and inclusive, and offers everyone a chance to succeed. By working to create an environment that values and celebrates our diverse community and fosters respect for every individual, you can help ensure that all persons can perform up to their full potential. Acts of intolerance hurt both the person they are directed at and on the University community as a whole. Being aware and sensitive to campus climate concerns is essential to creating and sustaining the best possible environment for learning, scholarship, creative activity, and working together. Together, we can create and maintain a respectful and inclusive environment that provides the support and opportunity necessary for each member of our community to prosper and achieve. Contact Us Email us at expectrespect@umich.edu
Summary: Expect Respect upholds diversity, equity, and inclusion and honors all voices. It is an educational initiative aimed at supporting a campus climate in which all persons are treated with civility and respect while being their authentic selves.

Name: Student Members of the American Chemical Society
Description: ACS at the University of Michigan is devoted to fostering interest in chemistry throughout campus and the community, facilitating networking between students and faculty, establishing opportunities for students, and sharing the excitement of chemistry with one another.
Summary:
Community: Foster relationships between chemistry students, professors, & faculty through social and career-focused events
Volunteer: Spread our excitement about science to members of the community
Connect: Speak with local and national ACS Chapters

Name: Student Michigan Pharmacists Association
Description:
The Student Michigan Pharmacists Association (SMPA) is an affiliated chapter of the Michigan Pharmacists Association (MPA) that promotes engagement in and activism for the profession. MPA’s vision is for its members to be an influential force in developing health policy and optimizing patient health, safety, and medication management. University of Michigan members of the SMPA represent the will of the students to the MPA through the Student Pharmacist Executive Council.

The University of Michigan chapter of SMPA offers networking and mentorship opportunities with leaders in pharmacy and provides a platform for involvement in legislative affairs at the state and national level. At U-M, SMPA holds financial, ethics, legislative, and community service events.
Summary: The Student Michigan Pharmacists Association (SMPA) is an affiliated chapter of the Michigan Pharmacists Association (MPA) that promotes engagement in and activism for the profession.

Name: Student National Pharmaceutical Association
Description: SNPhA is an educational service association of pharmacy students who are concerned about pharmacy and healthcare-related issues and the poor minority representation in pharmacy and other health-related professions. Our mission is to improve healthcare outcomes, help provide care to underserved communities, and address healthcare disparities
Summary: Educational service association of pharmacy students who are concerned about pharmacy and healthcare related issues, and is dedicated to serving underserved communities.

Name: Student Nurses' Association
Description: The Student Nurses’ Association at the University of Michigan is a student organization of the School of Nursing, and a constituent of Michigan Student Nurses’ Association (MSNA). SNA is a student-driven organization that focuses on fostering an individual’s professional development and a sense of responsibility for their future career. We also coordinate volunteer and fundraising opportunities in the greater Ann Arbor community, create opportunity for networking between nursing students and with professionals in the nursing field, and strive to optimize nursing students' exposure to the various opportunities available for health care providers.
Summary: Nursing students coming together to grow in professional development, promote networking, and serve the community.

Name: Student Organization Accounts Services
Description:
Office Hours:

Monday-Friday 9 am-5 pm

Find us on the 3rd floor of the Michigan Union!
Summary:
Student Organization Accounts Service (SOAS) provides financial services to student organizations and acts as the liaison on behalf of student organizations with campus partners.

 Our office hours are Monday-Friday 9:00 am - 5:00 pm.

Name: Student Organization for Computer-Human Interaction
Description:
SOCHI Consulting Group (Student Organization for Computer-Human Interaction) is all about exploring the overlap between design, tech, and how people interact with the tools around them. Our goal is to create a space where people can learn by doing. That means hands-on workshops and real-world projects to put on your resume. Whether you’re just getting into design or already have experience, we make sure there’s something valuable for everyone. 

At the end of the day, SOCHI is about building community and growing together. If you're interested in creating better experiences for people—through apps, websites, or even just ideas—we'd love to have you be part of it.

Stay up to date through our newsletter: https://forms.gle/tVuZU6LuLYjoC4eh7
Summary: SOCHI in UX

Name: Student Panel
Description: The Student Panel is a student-led organization that manages and trains teams of dedicated student leaders within each of their represented courses to gather and present class feedback to professors and share the meeting summary with current students. The goal of the Student Panel is to help facilitate better communication between students and professors and create a more positive learning environment in large STEM classes.
Summary: The Student Panel is a student-led organization that manages and trains teams of dedicated student leaders to gather and present class feedback to professors and share the meeting summary with current students.

Name: Student Rights Project
Description:
Please note: Membership in this organization is open to graduate students in the fields of law, social work, education, and public policy only.


The Student Rights Project (SRP) is an interdisciplinary project of law, social work, education, and public policy graduate students from the University of Michigan. SRP was founded in 2013 in response to the tremendous need for free, high-quality representation and support for students facing suspension and expulsion hearings in southeast Michigan. In all of our activities, SRP seeks to keep students in school, learning, and out of the criminal justice system. Members of our organization become talented interviewers and oral advocates. They also develop zeal and cultural humility.

In addition to advocating for students in disciplinary hearings, SRP advocates also:

  • support community outreach and youth development work;
  • lobby for youth­-centered and restorative school discipline policies and laws;
  • provide targeted special education support for students facing disciplinary exclusion due to disability ­related behaviors;
  • engage in non-­hearing advocacy in disciplinary matters;
  • host and attend events designed to educate the university and larger community about the school­-to-­prison pipeline in Michigan and best practices to oppose it; and
  • challenge institutional threats to educational opportunities for children.

A centerpiece of SRP is its interdisciplinary advocacy, combining the strengths of education, social work, public policy, and law in order to promote positive outcomes for Michigan’s youth. Our advocates are valued for their contributions to student advocacy, whether that be training in client interviewing, statutory research, or helping families access community resources. For this reason, each hearing advocacy is comprised of students from each discipline, insofar as possible.

Since our founding, SRP has partnered with the Student Advocacy Center of Michigan (SAC) in the shared drive to end the school­-to­-prison pipeline in the state. SAC is a non­profit educational advocacy organization headquartered in Ypsilanti, Michigan. SRP receives its referrals through SAC’s intake process, and our case advocacy is supervised by an SAC attorney. Each organization supports the other in their collective youth justice efforts.
Summary: SRP is a pro bono project comprised of graduate students in the U-M schools of Law, Social Work, Education, and Public Policy. In partnership with the Student Advocacy Center (SAC), we advocate for K-12 students facing suspension or expulsion.

Name: Student Sustainability Coalition
Description: The Student Sustainability Coalition is a group of university-employed students dedicated to building a sustainable campus culture at the University of Michigan. Our mission is to unite students, student organizations, and administration to advance shared goals of sustainability and environmental justice that benefit all members of the U-M community. Whether it’s building connections, fostering new partnerships, or amplifying initiatives already underway, SSC exists to serve as a resource for all.
Summary: The Student Sustainability Coalition (SSC) promotes a sustainable campus culture at the University of Michigan by bringing people together to achieve social and environmental change.

Name: Student Theatre Arts Complex
Description: The Student Theatre Arts Complex (STAC) is a preproduction facility located in south campus in the south end of the Plant Operations building across from Crisler Arena 1201 Kipke Drive. It was developed for student performance organizations to use to build sets, rehearse shows/dances, and to make costumes for their productions. There are three rehearsal rooms with a piano and wall of mirrors in each room. A full scene shop with heavy power tools, hand tool room and rigging hardware. Platforms and scenic flats are provided, as well.
Summary: The Student Theatre Arts Complex, or STAC, is a facility dedicated to the support of co-curricular student theatrical and performance organizations. It consists of a scenery shop and costume shop, as well as three rehearsal spaces with a piano in each.

Name: Student Travel Group at the University of Michigan
Description: Student Travel Group is Michigan's first travel focused organization that works directly with leading travel brands to send students on sponsored vacations. Our mission is to increase awareness and engagement in the travel & tourism industry.
Summary: Student Travel Group is Michigan's first travel focused organization that works directly with leading travel brands to send students on sponsored vacations. Our mission is to increase awareness and engagement in the travel & tourism industry.

Name: Student Veterans of America at the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Description:
Student Veterans of America® (SVA) elevates the academic, professional, and personal development of veterans in higher education through chapter programs and services, outcomes and impacts research, and advocacy at every level. With a mission focused on empowering student veterans, SVA is committed to providing an educational experience that goes beyond the classroom.

Through a dedicated network of more than 1,500 on-campus chapters in all 50 states and three countries overseas representing more than 750,000 student veterans, SVA inspires yesterday’s warriors by connecting student veterans with a community of dedicated chapter leaders. Every day these passionate leaders work to provide the necessary resources, network support, and advocacy to ensure student veterans can effectively connect, expand their skills, and ultimately achieve their greatest potential.

SVA’s National Headquarters oversees the provision of programs and services that empower student veterans to succeed to, through, and beyond higher education by focusing on the chapter-centric life cycle of student veterans. In order to lower technical barriers to success, SVA’s team of legislative and policy experts oversees advocacy efforts including preserving the integrity and evolution of the GI Bill. As a data-driven organization, SVA’s research arm collects, analyzes, and interprets data from national partners as well as institutions and chapters, and then tells the story of our nation’s most talented group of college students.
Summary: SVAUM is an organization that helps student veterans transition into student life, make meaningful connections, and develop professionally to ensure their success following graduation. We invite all veterans and students who support veterans to join!

Name: Students 4 Decareration
Description:
Students 4 Decarceration is a student organization seeking to end inequities within the criminal legal system through our 4 pillars: Advocacy, Education, Community Investment, and Restorative Justice. We aim to assist returning citizens as they re-enter society through a host of workshops and programs. We believe in the power of people and that students have the power to enact change in the criminal legal realm.

Please fill out this form to receive communications.
Summary: Students 4 Decarceration seeks to end inequities within the criminal legal system.

Name: Students Against Domestic Abuse
Description: Our student organization is committed to preventing domestic violence and supporting survivors. Through our media campaigns, speaker series, and workshops, we aim to raise awareness about the issue and educate students on warning signs, healthy relationships, and resources available for survivors. We also partner with local organizations to host events that benefit survivors, such as supporting events at shelters and clothing drives. Our advocacy efforts focus on promoting policy changes that support survivors, while our awareness events promote a culture of respect and nonviolence. We offer a safe and supportive community for survivors and allies to connect and heal, and encourage volunteering opportunities at local domestic violence organizations or shelters. Join us in our mission to end domestic violence and create a safer, more equitable community for all.
Summary: Our student organization is committed to preventing domestic violence and supporting survivors through our media campaigns, speaker series, and workshops.

Name: Students Allied for Healthcare Accessibility
Description:
Students Allied for Healthcare Accessibility (SAHA) is a student-led initiative that seeks to improve access to healthcare in the local community. SAHA is a group of passionate students who are committed to making a positive impact in their community through healthcare advocacy and outreach.

The main goal of SAHA is to provide resources and education to underserved communities to help them gain access to healthcare services. The organization works closely with local healthcare providers, community organizations, and government agencies to identify the healthcare needs of the community and to develop effective strategies to meet those needs.
Summary: SAHA is a student-led initiative that seeks to improve access to healthcare in the local community. SAHA is a group of passionate students who are committed to making a positive impact in their community through healthcare advocacy and outreach.

Name: Students as Living Testimonies
Description: We're a group of students looking to go deeper in our spiritual lives through knowing the Bible, practicing God's word in our lives, and fostering a community based in love. We have weekly meetings where we sing in worship and study the Bible together, and we also welcome each other into our homes, lives, and church life. We're part of Church in Ann Arbor; please visit www.annarbor.church for more information.
Summary: We are a group of Christians associated with the Church in Ann Arbor. Our aim is to build community, show love to people around us, and seek to grow in faith. We have weekly meetings where we sing in worship and study the Bible together.

Name: Students Engaged in Global Health
Description: Students Engaged in Global Health connects students at the School of Public Health with valuable experiences and knowledge in global public health by facilitating engagement in global internships and discussions with experts in the field. SEGH's mission is to promote the idea that public health is global health, to significantly enhance the presence of global health at the SPH, and to encourage student interest in working in diverse locations around the world.
Summary: Students Engaged in Global Health connects students at the School of Public Health with valuable experiences and knowledge in global public health by facilitating engagement in global internships and discussions with experts in the field.

Name: Students for a National Health Program at the University of Michigan
Description: SNaHP is the student arm of Physicians for a National Health Program (PNHP). Both organizations are committed to to fighting for single payer healthcare in the United States through educating the next generation of providers and advocating for policy change.
Summary: SNaHP is the student arm of Physicians for a National Health Program (PNHP). Both organizations are committed to to fighting for single payer healthcare in the United States.

Name: Students for Biden at the University of Michigan
Description:
Students for Biden at the University of Michigan is working to re-elect President Joe Biden! 

Our focuses for the election season are registering students to vote, volunteering with the Biden campaign and that of other Democrats running for office, and amplifying student turnout on election day.
Summary: Students for Biden at the University of Michigan is working to re-elect President Joe Biden and advance his agenda. We work around the clock to register students to vote and provide opportunities to get involved with the campaign.

Name: Students for Clean Energy
Description:
Please join our 2024-25 group chat to receive general club announcements and communications: https://groupme.com/join_group/102579907/LxpwbJEa.  
 
Students for Clean Energy (SfCE) promotes awareness and implementation of renewable energy at the University of Michigan while providing educational and professional development opportunities for its members. We fulfill this mission with our three teams: Engagement, Policy, and Research & Development. SfCE challenges the status quo of burning emissions-producing fuels at U-M and works to promote a just transition towards clean energy.
 
We believe that:
 
- All people have the right to clean, safe, affordable, and reliable energy. 
- The environment has the right to be sustained and healthy.
- The University of Michigan, as a well-endowed, innovative, leading institution, has an obligation to be a pioneer in a just transition to carbon neutrality.
 
Weekly meetings for the 2024-25 school year will take place on Wednesdays from 7:00 - 8:00 pm ET in Mason Hall (see GroupMe for room numbers). These meetings have dedicated time for team bonding, guest speakers, educational activities, and inter-team collaboration. Each team also holds weekly meetings to work on their specific projects - feel free to move around teams and work on different projects throughout the year.
 
There is no application to join our club; all are welcome!
Summary: Students for Clean Energy (SfCE) is dedicated to increasing awareness, knowledge, and usage of renewable energy at U-M. We fulfill our mission through advocacy, campus projects, outreach, and professional development.

Name: Students for Democracy
Description:
Students for Democracy is established with the purpose of providing its members with the tools necessary to actively participate in the democratic processes through researching issues, educating the public, and advocating for change.

Through research, education, and advocacy, the mission of Students for Democracy is to promote active participation in America’s democratic processes and to enact sustainable changes to American policies in order to make this country a better place for all individuals who reside here.
Summary: Students for Democracy is established with the purpose of providing its members with the tools necessary to actively participate in the democratic processes through researching issues, educating the public, and advocating for change.

Name: Students for Disability Rights Inclusivity Visibility and Equity (DRIVE)
Description: Disability Rights Inclusivity Visibility and Equity (DRIVE) exists to be a source of community for Disabled students and a space for students to engage with topics of Disability Justice. Our goal is to facilitate collective student led accessibility and advocacy, and to build community with similarly aligned partners. We hope that through this work we can minimize access barriers, strengthen peer based support, and work towards improving representation of disability, across the ability spectrum. DRIVE is a voluntary student organization, based in the School of Public Health, and is open to all U of M students of any ability status.
Summary: Disability Rights Inclusivity Visibility and Equity (DRIVE) is a voluntary student organization that exists to be a source of community for Disabled students and a space for allies to engage with the Disability community.

Name: Students for Health Equity and Advocacy
Description: Students for Health Equity and Advocacy (SHEA) is a student run organization that strives to foster health equity by empowering underserved and underprivileged communities. Through advocacy, education, and direct service, we strive to address health disparities and promote access to quality care for all. We will focus on community work within Washtenaw County with the help of other partners and collaborators in the area.We are committed to making a lasting impact in the communities we serve.
Summary: Students for Health Equity and Advocacy (SHEA) is a student run organization that strives to foster health equity by empowering underserved and underprivileged communities. Through advocacy, education, and direct service, we strive to address health disp

Name: Students for Reproductive Rights and Justice
Description:
If you would like us to add you to our email list, please send a request to srrjeboard@umich.edu.

Students for Reproductive Rights and Justice, or SRRJ, advocates for reproductive rights and justice, sexual health, and feminism through tabling, larger events, and making our voices known to state and national legislators. We distribute thousands of condoms a year and educate hundreds of people through events that promote the de-stigmatization of abortion and provide a platform for people to creatively express their experiences of womanhood and bodily autonomy. We work within an intersectional framework that recognizes how identities like race, socioeconomic status, sexual orientation, and gender identity interact and impact a person's control over their reproductive and sexual health.
Summary: Students for Reproductive Rights and Justice is a pro-choice organization focused on advocacy and activism that works closely with Planned Parenthood to host a variety of events promoting reproductive justice and sexual health on campus and nationally.

Name: Students for Sunrise
Description:
Students for Sunrise is a group dedicated to donating money to the Sunrise Association and raising awareness of pediatric cancer.

Often isolated from the normal activities of childhood, children with cancer rarely have a chance to see beyond the closed worlds of home, hospital and doctors’ offices. The Sunrise Association changes that by opening the door to a new world, making it possible for children  to enjoy a summer filled with exciting daily activities, enduring friendships and laughter, while paying careful attention to their special medical and emotional needs.Sunrise on Wheels is an innovative program that provides a day filled with Sunrise fun to children awaiting treatment in pediatric oncology units of participating hospitals. Volunteers wheel a rainbow trunk bursting with toys, games and activities right into many of our affiliated hospitals and change what could have been a bleak and depressing day into a day of camp fun!

All Sunrise programs are free of charge, which is why donations are so important. Students for Sunrise at U-M hosts fundraising events where all proceeds are donated to the Sunrise Association, allowing children with cancer and their siblings to have the best summers of their lives.
Summary: Students for Sunrise is an organization dedicated to raising funds and awareness for the Sunrise Association, which provides in-hospital programs and summer-long day camps across the world for children with cancer and their siblings.

Name: Students for Sustainable Artificial Intelligence Development
Description:
Did you know behind every AI response is a sprawling network of data infrastructure that requires large amount of water and energy to be sustained? Did you know AI has potential to help craft innovate solutions to global climate issues? If you have ever wondered about how we might reconcile the growing use of artificial intelligence with its expanding environmental footprint then Students for Sustainable Artificial Intelligence Development (SSAID) is the place for you! 

 

As an organization we are interested in exploring the environmental ethics of AI development, its potential uses in addressing climate challenges, and how large institutions can lead the way in development transparent and clean AI infrastructures. 

 

SSAID is open to all members of the community with an interest in the environment, data and AI, and energy systems! Members can contribute to a lively and timely conversation on AI usage with students and faculty across the university through attending panel discussions, workshops, and more!
Summary: Students advocating for greater transparency and sustainability in AI development.

Name: Students for the Exploration and Development of Space: Chapter @ University of Michigan
Description:
Calling all space enthusiasts!

 

Students for the Exploration and Development of Space is a worldwide student-run organization whose mission is to enable progress in space exploration and development through student empowerment.

 

We host a variety of professional, outreach, and social events throughout the year to increase awareness and participation in space related issues and advancements. We also sponsor a group of students to attend the annual SEDS SpaceVision Conference.

 

All majors and backgrounds are welcome.

SIGN UP FOR OUR EMAIL LIST: https://forms.gle/bkJDkRYKwS3bDaqKA
Summary: Students for the Exploration and Development of Space is a worldwide student-run organization whose mission is to enable progress in space exploration and development through technical projects, outreach events and guest speakers.

Name: Students of Color in Public Policy
Description:
The main goals of SCPP include:

* Providing a venue for students of color to share ideas and work on issues that most directly affect communities of color

* Serving as a voice for students of color in the Ford School and within the community

* Actively participating in dialgoue with faculty from diverse backgrounds

* Giving back to the community

* Organizing events that promote greater cultural understanding and interaction
Summary: SCPP (Students of Color in Public Policy) advocates for positive change for BIPOC communities both in and out of Ford through special events, networking, and outreach.

Name: Students of Color in Public Policy - Undergraduate Chapter
Description: Students of Color in Public Policy- Undergraduate Chapter strives to create a tight-knit community for undergraduate students of color and allies in the Ford School. We work to connect students of color through events that promote networking and community building; provide a brave and inclusive space for students of color to collaborate and share ideas and experiences to increase conversations around policy issues that impact communities of color domestically and internationally; facilitate meaningful dialogue with professionals from diverse backgrounds.
Summary: Students of Color in Public Policy - Undergraduate Chapter (SCPP - Pronounced “Skip”) strives to create a tight-knit community for undergraduate students of color and allies in the Ford School.

Name: Students of Color Interested in Law, Government, Policy, and Social Justice
Description: SOCiiL is a space for students of color interested in public service careers to connect with one another, learn about paths they can go into, have discussions about the intersection of their identities within the public sector, and educate students.Through campus involvement, our mission is to educate, support, connect, and provide resources to help students of color thrive in public service related careers and aspirations.
Summary: SOCiiL is a space for students of color interested in public service careers to connect with one another, learn about paths they can go into, have discussions about the intersection of their identities within the public sector, and educate students.

Name: Students of Color of Rackham
Description:
The SCOR Graduate Organization is a dynamic network for Rackham graduate and professional students at the University of Michigan. Committed to fostering the social, cultural, and academic well-being of students from diverse cultural, ethnic, and international backgrounds.

We advocate for initiatives that enhance the academic, professional, and social experiences of our members while respecting cultural differences, disabilities, gender identities, and sexual orientations. To support graduate students of color, SCOR organizes a variety of social, political, and community service events throughout the academic year. Our mission is to cultivate a strong, supportive community that empowers students throughout their journey at U-M.
Summary: SCOR (Students of Color Rackham) is a network for Rackham graduate and professional students at the University of Michigan. SCOR is dedicated to the social, cultural, and academic well-being of graduate students of color.

Name: Students Organize for Syria
Description:
Students Organize for Syria (SOS) is the only movement for Syrian people in the United States that is entirely governed by students. As an individual chapter, we are responsible for ensuring SOS’s existence as a national and unified movement through our collaboration with chapters at other universities. Together, with the leaders of each chapter, we are the student voice for Syria, committed to standing with the Syrian people in their aspirations for freedom and liberty. Our three pillars are Education/Awareness, Advocacy/Solidarity, and Fundraising. Our chapter is dedicated towards fulfilling these three pillars, fundraising for orphans and refugees that have been affected by the Syrian Civil War, and raising awareness of the crisis that currently exists in Syria. We do this with the hope of making a positive national AND international impact, racing towards a better future for the victims of the war. 

We are currently accepting new members, and if you're passionate about spending a portion of your youth making a difference in the lives of the vulnerable and needy, please email us! Our email is sos.eboard@umich.edu
Summary: SOS is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit, student led organization. Our mission is to stand in solidarity with the Syrian people in their struggle for human rights, and to raise awareness of and help alleviate the humanitarian crisis currently taking place in Syria.

Name: Students Providing Aid at UMich
Description: SPAid@UMich is a student-driven organization committed to improving global health by constructing and distributing kid-friendly first aid kits to underserved areas worldwide. Through collaborative efforts, we foster partnerships, engage in educational outreach, and promote health awareness. Our mission is to address the critical lack of healthcare access in third-world countries and make a tangible impact on global health. Join us as we work together to empower communities and create a healthier, more compassionate world.
Summary: SPAid@UMich is dedicated to improving global health by providing kid-friendly first aid kits to underserved communities. We focus on educational outreach and fundraising initiatives to empower students and address critical healthcare needs.

Name: Students Taking Action for Racial Solidarity
Description: STARS is a law school student organization, thought of and advanced by the Michigan Journal of Race & Law (MJRL), dedicated to race relations within the law school (in class and outside of class). The idea for this student organization was created after members of the Race and Curriculum Committee of MJRL recognized that they'd like to do more advocacy within the law school but are restricted due to the limited number of Committee members (4). STARS is aware that many affinity groups address racial problems on campus through advocacy and events, but think it would be advantageous to form a student organization that is not an affinity group dedicated to this topic. This group would appreciate and welcome intersectionality and diverse viewpoints, as other identities that we hold impact racial issues at the law school.
Summary: STARS is a law school student organization, thought of and advanced by the Michigan Journal of Race & Law (MJRL), dedicated to race relations within the law school (both inside and outside of the classroom).

Name: STUDIO 605
Description: STUDIO605 is a student-run organization at the University of Michigan focused on unifying, elevating, and expanding the creative spaces on campus. We see ourselves as a creative culture studio with a mission to activate the community through centering Black and Brown students in creative and hype culture, particularly in modes such as fashion, photography, and art. Our mission is to create formal platforms where creative talent is showcased and celebrated. Through collaboration with diverse organizations, we aim to curate and support events and projects that build a network within and beyond campus to reflect the dynamic nature of our community at Michigan.
Summary: STUDIO605 is a student-run organization at the University of Michigan focused on unifying, elevating, and expanding the creative spaces on campus.

Name: Sudanese Student Association
Summary: SUSA is an organization that provides students of Sudanese ethnic descent with a space to connect with fellow Sudanese students and express their culture freely, as well as a space for non-Sudanese students to learn about Sudanese culture.

Name: Sunny
Description: Sunny enriches the lives of foster children by providing a wide variety of experiences that result in unique and unforgettable memories. Outside of coordinating activities and programming for the foster youth, our organization raises societal awareness about the unmet needs of foster children and inspires individuals to increase their attentiveness to children who are often overlooked. Sunny members also engage in tutoring and penpal programs to build relationships and help the youth develop skills.
Summary: Sunny enriches the lives of foster children in Metro Detroit by providing engaging activities and enriching mentorship programs.

Name: Sunrise Ann Arbor
Description: Sunrise Ann Arbor is a local chapter of the Sunrise Movement which is building an army of young people to stop climate change and create millions of good jobs in the process. We organize locally and in congruence with the national Sunrise Movement for climate justice. This means we do both local and community activities around climate issues but we are also involved in electoral politics at all levels of government.
Summary: Sunrise Ann Arbor is a local chapter of the Sunrise Movement which is building an army of young people to stop climate change and create millions of good jobs in the process. We organize locally and in congruence with Sunrise Movement for climate action.

Name: Supplies For Scholars
Description: By partnering with local schools, we identify and fulfill the needs for essential school supplies among students from low-income families. Our mission is to promote educational equity, ensuring no student falls behind due to a lack of resources.
Summary: By donating backpacks filled with the essential school supplies, we aim to alleviate financial burden on low-income families, empower students, promote educational equity in the Ann Arbor community.

Name: Support for Incoming Black Students
Description:
The mission of SIBS is to increase the retention and success of black students by providing mentorship and unique opportunities for learning and engagement within the broader University of Michigan community; this shall include personal, academic, and professional development opportunities that create a fulfilling first- year experience.

SIBS is a widely respected year-long student run program that sustainably engages Black first year students. We work to provide a successful social and academic experience through mentorship and programming. This is accomplished by:

o Providing year-round recognition for big/little SIBS

o Providing valuable leadership training and professional development opportunities

o Planning well organized and impactful events

o Building relationships through year round connections between big/little SIBS

o Creating opportunities for students to advance into leadership positions

o Maintaining SIBS alumni involvement, engagement, and investment in SIBS

o Assessing the effectiveness and impact of the SIBS programs
Summary:
The SIBS program strives to increase the retention and success of black students by providing 
mentorship and unique opportunities for learning and engagement within the broader University of Michigan community.

Name: Supporting Hands Closet at the University of Michigan
Description: Supporting Hands Closet is an organization of students at the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor that supports the philanthropic objective of donating necessities (i.e. clothes, school supplies, financial donations) for adolescents and young adults in the community. Our purpose is to initiate volunteering opportunities at off-campus non-profit organizations who need our help and donations. For this matter, we will be working closely with a non-profit organization(s) off -campus that supports our cause. We also intend to hold drives, fundraisers, social events, and collaborations with other student organizations throughout the campus to promote and bring awareness to adolescents and young adults within the community that are in need of our help.
Summary: Supporting Hands Closet is an organization of students at the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor that supports the philanthropic objective of donating necessities (i.e. clothes, school supplies, donations) for adolescents and young adults in the community.

Name: SURJ UMich
Description: SURJ UMich works to motivate and make known transformative education opportunities that sharpen the analysis, organizing skills and leadership of white anti-racist organizers and the broader University of Michigan community.
