Summary: SURJ UMich (Showing Up for Racial Justice at the University of Michigan) builds and deepens accountable ally relationships in order to achieve victories for racial justice and contribute to local movement-building efforts.

Name: Sweetland Center for Writing
Description: The Sweetland Center for Writing is a comprehensive writing center that supports student writers at all levels, and in all forms and modes. Sweetland oversees the First-year and Upper-Level Writing Requirements for the College of LSA, Offers one-to-one tutoring for undergraduate and graduate students in our faculty-led Writing Workshop and undergraduate Peer Writing Center, and teaches writing courses from the 100 to the graduate level. Sweetland also provides support for multilingual and international students offering a range of courses for these students. Finally, Sweetland offers the Minor in Writing and supports new media and multimodal forms of writing.
Summary: The Sweetland Center for Writing is a comprehensive writing center that supports student writers at all levels, and in all forms and modes.

Name: Swing Ann Arbor
Description:
What is Swing Ann Arbor?
Swing Ann Arbor (SAA) provides opportunities for the University and greater community to learn swing dancing, which developed alongside Jazz music in Harlem. Our focus on dancing is both for social and performance purposes! Note: We do not permit aerials in our scene.

What we offer:
- FREE beginner drop-in classes
- Weekly social dances
- Progressive classes on 6- and 8-count Lindy Hop, Charleston, Balboa, and Shag.
- Special events featuring live music, guest instructors, and weekend-long workshops.

Beginner lessons and all dances are open to everyone regardless of experience or affiliation. You do not need to a student to dance with us!


No partner needed!

Drop-in lessons are every Wednesday from 6:30-7:30pm, social dances every Wednesday from 7:30-9:30pm, and progressive lessons are usually held on Tuesday evenings. Check out our website for more information on when and where you can find us!
Summary: Swing Ann Arbor teaches 6-and 8-count Lindy Hop, Charleston, Balboa, and more under the swing dance umbrella! Come learn these jazzy, early 20th century dances with us and make new friendships that will last a lifetime! No experience or partner needed!

Name: Synapse National
Description:
Synapse National is an organization dedicated to building social support networks for
individuals with brain injury, who often face social isolation and mental health challenges. This is accomplished by a network of undergraduate students working with faculty and rehabilitation centers to provide peer support groups, educational events, and buddy programs. We are also committed to educating and inspiring the next generation of leaders in the field of Brain Injury. By engaging directly with individuals with brain injury and reflecting on their perspectives and needs, students can learn about the issues these individuals face.
Summary: Synapse National is dedicated to providing support to individuals living with a brain injury. This includes organizing educational events, leading support groups, and offering a one-on-one volunteer program connecting undergraduates with TBI individuals.

Name: Synchronized Skating
Description: The University of Michigan Synchronized Skating Team consists of collegiate and open collegiate level teams. We are an entirely student run club sport at U of M. The Collegiate team has finished on the national podium for the last 13 consecutive years. They have won the US Synchronized Skating Championships 4 times in the team’s history, most recently in 2020. In 2017, UMSST expanded its program to include an Open Collegiate team. The Open Collegiate team has finished on the Midwestern-Pacific Sectional Synchronized Skating Championships podium nearly every year since its creation, most recently earning the pewter medal in 2024. Looking forward to the upcoming season, we hope to continue our success and love of the sport while proudly representing the University of Michigan. Go Blue!
Summary: The University of Michigan Synchronized Skating Team is a collegiate and open collegiate team, which is entirely student run. The team has medalled at the National Championships the last 13 years. The team is the 2017, 2018, and 2020 national champions

Name: Syrian Students Association
Description: The Syrian Student Association aims to unite and serve the Syrian community on campus by providing a space for all Syrian students to express themselves culturally through cultural events and educating the general campus about Syrian culture and society. The association is committed to promoting Syrian culture and heritage in order to increase the diversity of campus as well as promote the narrative of Syrian people. The Syrian Student Association represents all Syrian students on campus regardless of ethnicity or religion. The Syrian Student Association is an apolitical organization.
Summary: The Syrian Student Association aims to unite and serve the Syrian community on campus by providing a space for all Syrian students to express themselves culturally through cultural events and educating the general campus about Syrian culture and society.

Name: Tabletop Gaming Club
Description:
The Tabletop Gaming Club is designed to provide a network for people who are interested in TTRPGs. We are open to players of all experience levels and strive to create a welcoming environment in which everyone can play games, learn new systems, meet friends - and most importantly, have fun!

Our biweekly meetings are held during Fall and Winter semesters on Tuesdays at 7:00PM in the Duderstadt Center Design Lab 1, and on Fridays at 6:40PM in Mason Hall (rooms vary, and will be announced weekly in the club Discord server). No membership fees are needed to come to these meetings. Anyone can show up at any point during the semester! Come as often as you like. 

Feel free to join our Discord server to connect with other members! Our Discord is our main platform for club announcements and communications. You can also join our MCommunity email list here to receive the club's weekly newsletter.
Summary: The Tabletop Gaming Club is designed to provide a network for people of all experience levels that are interested in tabletop roleplaying games, such as D&D, Pathfinder, and so on and so forth.

Name: Taiwan Business Association
Description: TBA is a cultural and career-oriented organization, focusing on education, career development, and networking with Taiwanese corporations. The purpose of the organization is to increase the awareness of Taiwanese culture and business development.
Summary: TBA is a cultural and career-oriented organization, focusing on education, career development, and networking with Taiwanese alumni. The purpose of the organization is to increase the awareness of Taiwanese culture and business development.

Name: Taiwan Student Association
Description: The mission of Taiwan Student Association (TWSA) is to provide service for over 500 students and professionals from Taiwan in the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor. The group has traditionally provided a well-served communication channel among the students. The mission of our association is to share Taiwanese culture with all University members, to promote cross-student organization relationships, to assist Taiwanese international students to adapt to living in Ann Arbor, and to establish a friendly and neutral environment for members to share experiences with each other. We mainly sponsor and hold events that promote the exchange of Taiwanese and American culture. Some events include, Moon Festival Celebration, Taste of Taiwan, Celebrasia, Lunar New Year Celebration, Annual Ski trip, Karaoke Competition and much more!
Summary: The purpose of our organization is to share Taiwanese culture with all University members, to promote cross-student organization relationships, and to assist Taiwanese international students to adapt to living in Ann Arbor.

Name: Taiwanese American Student Association
Description: Our vision is to increase awareness of and appreciation for Taiwanese American culture and experiences through modes of food, music, history, current events, and much more. We strive to build community from ground-up individual connections within TASA, the larger APIA community, and the even greater University of Michigan campus community.
Summary: Taiwanese American Student Association at the University of Michigan exists to preserve and promote the understanding of Taiwanese culture for Taiwanese American students and the greater University of Michigan campus community.

Name: TAMID Group
Description: TAMID is a student organization at Michigan Ross dedicated to providing members an all-encompassing business experience through strategy consulting for high-tech Israeli startup companies and actively managing a $25,000 equity portfolio. Our Fund allows our members the opportunity to take what they learn in the classroom and apply it to real-world business valuation, analysis, and active portfolio management. Our Consulting gives our members the opportunity to solve business problems for international venture-backed startup companies in industries such as mobility, cybersecurity, agricultural technology, healthcare, and fintech. Lastly, we strive to foster an environment for our members to learn, grow, and develop, while empowering a tight-knit community on campus. TAMID has no political or religious affiliations.
Summary: The TAMID Group was founded at the University of Michigan and has since expanded to over 50 chapters worldwide. TAMID manages a $25,000 student-led equity portfolio and consults for high-tech, venture-backed Israeli start-ups.

Name: Tamil Student Association at the University of Michigan
Description:
The Tamil Student Association at the University of Michigan is dedicated to celebrating and sharing the rich heritage of Tamil arts, food, and culture with the university community. Our mission is to create a vibrant space for students to connect with Tamil traditions and build a strong, supportive community. We aim to foster appreciation for Tamil language, arts, and history while providing a platform for students of Tamil origin or those with an interest in Tamil culture to engage and grow.

We proudly organize cultural events and activities that bring the Tamil community together, including the celebration of major festivals like Pongal and Tamil New Year. These events showcase traditional Tamil music, dance, food, and rituals, offering an authentic experience of Tamil culture. In addition, we host movie screenings, performances, and culinary gatherings to celebrate the artistry and cuisine unique to Tamil Nadu.

Our club is committed to enriching the cultural diversity of the University of Michigan by collaborating with other student organizations and participating in university-wide events. Led by a passionate team of volunteers, we work to ensure that our activities not only strengthen the Tamil community but also invite the broader student body to experience the beauty of Tamil arts and traditions.
Summary: The Tamil Student Association at U-M celebrates Tamil arts, food, and culture. We host events like Pongal and Tamil New Year, along with movie screenings, performances, and food fests. Join us in sharing and preserving Tamil traditions on campus!

Name: Tau Beta Pi - Michigan Gamma Chapter
Description:
Tau Beta Pi (TBP) is the only engineering honor society representing the entire engineering profession. It is the nation's second-oldest honor society, founded at Lehigh University in 1885. There are now collegiate chapters at 242 US colleges and universities, 39 active alumnus chapters in 16 districts across the country, and more than 554,000 total members.

Tau Beta Pi was founded in 1885 to mark in a fitting manner those who have conferred honor upon their alma mater by distinguished scholarship and exemplary character as undergraduates in the field of engineering, or by their attainments as alumni in the field of engineering, and to foster a spirit of liberal culture in the engineering colleges. 

The Michigan Gamma Chapter of TBP is committed to providing service to the college and the community and to help members develop both personally and professionally. Membership in Tau Beta Pi is by invitation only, based on high scholastic achievement and exemplary character.
Summary: Tau Beta Pi (TBP) is the national engineering honor society for all majors. The Michigan Gamma chapter of TBP is committed to integrity and excellence in engineering, serving the community, and promoting a spirit of liberal culture within the CoE.

Name: Tau Epsilon Kappa
Description: Tau Epsilon Kappa is a co-ed professional technical fraternity committed to professional technical development as well as the advancement of social and academic excellence among the fraternity brothers. We strive to provide opportunities for our members to explore their technical interests and further their relationships in both a social and professional environment. Tau Epsilon Kappa fosters members who are passionate to cultivate their skills to help better the community, as well as encourage a diverse, inclusive, and equal community.
Summary: Professional Co-Ed Technology Fraternity, founded at the University of Michigan in 2022.

Name: Tauber Institute Student Advisory Board
Description: The Student Advisory Board is a liaison between the Tauber Institute for Global Operations' students, co-directors, alumni, and industry partners. SAB brings Tauber student concerns to light and works with the Co-Directors for solutions and improvement.
Summary: The Student Advisory Board is a liaison between the Tauber Institute for Global Operations' students, co-directors, alumni, and industry partners. SAB brings Tauber student concerns to light and works with the Co-Directors for solutions and improvement.

Name: Taubman Architecture Ball
Description: The purpose of this organization is to organize, in full, the annual Taubman Architecture Ball (TAB). This organization is responsible for picking a theme for TAB, planning of events leading up to the ball, marketing, and all other logistics required for the success of the event. This largely involves supporting students in creating artworks and installations, with the intent of bringing together the Taubman College community and inspiring creative work outside of the studio.
Summary: The purpose of this organization is to organize, in full, the annual Taubman Architecture Ball (TAB)

Name: Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning
Description: Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning offers 11 degree programs and certificates along with a minor in Real Estate Development. Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning at the University of Michigan aims to create a more beautiful, inclusive and better environment for generations to come. Through interdisciplinary education and research, we prepare graduates for positions of responsibility within a wide spectrum of professions, organizations, and institutions that shape the built environment at scales ranging from local to global.
Summary: Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning at the University of Michigan aims to create a more beautiful, inclusive and better environment for generations to come.

Name: Team Aquador
Description:
Team Aquador brings together University of Michigan students to create sustainable, responsible, and empowering water accessibility solutions for Ecuadorian communities. In Ecuador, many communities, depend on bottled or corporate-controlled water for drinking and household use; those who cannot afford bottled water typically drink unfiltered, often polluted, water. This lack of access to clean water leads to the spread of disease and perpetuates economic disadvantages.

Team Aquador traveled to Ecuador for two weeks in the summer of 2018 and three weeks in 2019 to conduct needs assessments and strengthen relationships with our partner communities: the village of Olmedo and Nido de Vida of La Bolivarense. Our community partners experience limited access to clean water and storage, especially during the dry season. We have been working with both communities to improve in-home water access and water storage infrastructure. Our projects use recycled, discarded, and regionally accessible materials. We aim to create water infrastructure that is effective, sustainable, and environmentally responsible. The team is currently working to design gray water recycling systems and water pumps that community members in La Bolivarense and Olmedo can build and maintain themselves. Through consistent communication and annual trips to visit these partners, we will continue to work with these communities to alleviate some of the resource inequality that rural Ecuadorian communities face by providing sustainable and responsible solutions.
Summary: Team Aquador is focused on designing, building, and implementing sustainable water systems in rural Ecuador, in cooperation with our partner communities near Loja and Los Bancos.

Name: Team Awareness Combatting Overdose at the University of Michigan
Description: TACO Inc. is a peer-to-peer, national 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization dedicated to combating accidental drug overdoses among young adults through non-judgemental, data-backed education and subsidized harm reduction materials such as fentanyl test strips and nasal Naloxone. We are recruiting individuals who want to use their skills to save countless lives and make universities around the nation a safer place.
Summary: We help combat accidental overdose deaths among students through data-backed education & accessible harm-reduction supplies. We are neither pro nor anti-drug use. We would host fundraisers and stands to hand 100% subsidized fentanyl test strips / Narcan.

Name: Tech 4 Social Good
Description:
Founded in 2020, Tech 4 Social Good (T4SG) creates cross-campus dialogues to explore the social/cultural/political dimensions of digital technologies and the culture of contemporary technological institutions. We work with social-good oriented student orgs and non-profits on technical projects and contribute to equity, and advocate for curricula that help every student learn and define their own career path in tech.

Our work is expanding and currently entails the following three areas: 

  1. creating dialogues (via panels, workshops, etc) inside and outside of the classroom around the social/cultural/political dimensions of digital technologies and current technologist communities 
  2. pushing for curricular change in (1) engineering departments to make sure technical students understand the social context in which they are building their technology in, as well as being aware of how their own background and social identities result in unintentional negligence and potential harm; (2) non-engineering departments to make sure students are familiar with the ways technology impacts them and basic understanding of how they might use it for their own pursuits .
  3. working on technical projects that contribute to equity. This includes collaborations with social good oriented student orgs and non-profits, as well as student-led projects in different areas.

Join us to define T4SG from your own perspective!
Summary: Tech 4 Social Good is a community of students from all disciplines building technology for impact and situating STEM fields in socio-cultural contexts. We do this through events, project teams, workshops, career development, and more!

Name: Tech Club at the Ross School of Business
Description: The Tech Club is focused on supporting students interested in the technology industry. Our goal is to build a diverse community of Rossers interested in the tech industry and help community members identify and recruit for appealing roles across the industry. We hold regular trainings to support members in recruiting for internships/jobs at tech companies. We also hold company information sessions, coffee chats, and industry panels to provide information to members. The Tech Club helps members connect with each other through social events. Our largest event is the annual Tech Week, which includes alumni panels, mock interviews, coffee chats, and a keynote speaker.
Summary: The Technology Club at Ross is a career oriented student organization focused on education, career development, and networking in Technology and related fields.

Name: Tech Plus
Description: The Tech Plus Club at the Ross School of Business is dedicated to bridging the gap between business acumen and technological expertise. Open to students of all majors, our mission is to empower students with the essential skills, comprehensive knowledge, and robust network needed to thrive in tech-driven business environments. We are committed to fostering a culture of innovation, collaboration, and continuous learning. Through a variety of educational programs, industry partnerships, and peer support initiatives, we aim to develop future leaders who are well-equipped to drive technological advancements and business innovations. Our focus on inclusivity and diversity ensures that every member has the opportunity to grow, succeed, and make a meaningful impact in the dynamic intersection of business and technology. Join us to be part of a community that is shaping the future of business and technology.
Summary: We are the Tech Plus Club @ Ross, our mission is to empower students with the skills, knowledge, and network to excel in tech-driven business. We focus on innovation, collaboration and continuous learning to grow, learn, and lead in tech and business.

Name: TEDxUofM
Description:
TEDxUofM is a university-wide initiative to galvanize the community for an event like no other; filled with inspiration, discovery, and excitement. Borrowing the template from the world-renowned TED conference, TEDxUofM aims to bring a TED-like experience to the University of Michigan.  The vision is to showcase the most fascinating thinkers and doers, the “leaders and best” in Michigan terms, for a stimulating day of presentations, discussions, entertainment, and art.  The annual conference brings together great minds, brilliant talent, and innovative thinkers who are eager to inform the universe about their passions and dreams for the future. The ideas and stories radiating from the TEDxUofM stage are meant to generate an energy in the audience watching, transforming their perception of the world and provoking them to act upon their own ideas as well as collaborate with those around them.

 

To find out more, visit our website, tedxuofm.com. To join our club, shoot us an email at team@tedxuofm.com and we'll tell you everything you need to know.
Summary: TEDxUofM aims to galvanize the University of Michigan community by bringing together passionate individuals across all disciplines who believe in TED's motto of "Ideas Change Everything."

Name: Tell Your Story
Description: Tell Your Story is an organization dedicated to improving the literacy of refugee youth within the Ann Arbor community. Through our tailored educational program, we strive to connect students on campus with the resources to empower refugee youth with the language skills necessary for academic success. Our commitment extends beyond literacy, fostering confidence, cultural understanding, and a sense of belonging among refugee youth on our campus.
Summary: Tell Your Story empowers refugee youth in Ann Arbor through tailored literacy programs. We connect students with resources to build language skills, confidence, cultural understanding, and a sense of belonging for academic success.

Name: Tennis Club at Ross
Description:
Mission Statement: The Tennis Club at Ross aims to foster a vibrant community of tennis enthusiasts within the University of Michigan's Ross School of Business. Our mission is to provide a welcoming, inclusive environment where students of all skill levels can improve their tennis skills, engage in healthy competition, and form lasting friendships. Through organizing regular practice sessions, instructional clinics, and competitive tournaments, we seek to promote physical wellness, teamwork, and leadership skills among our members.

Objectives:

To offer regular tennis playing opportunities for Ross students, fostering a community around a shared love for the game.
To organize instructional clinics and workshops for skill development at all levels, from beginner to advanced players.
To facilitate inter-university tennis tournaments and friendly matches, promoting a spirit of healthy competition and sportsmanship.
To support the physical and mental well-being of our members through regular exercise and social interaction.
Membership: Open to all students of the Ross School of Business, regardless of their tennis skill level. Membership aims to be diverse and inclusive, reflecting the broad spectrum of the Ross community.

Activities:

Weekly practice sessions organized at local tennis courts, suitable for various skill levels.
Monthly skill development clinics led by experienced coaches.
Semesterly tournaments and friendly matches with other university clubs or within club members to foster a competitive spirit.
Social events to enhance community bonding and networking among members.
Summary: The Tennis Club at Ross aims to foster a vibrant community of tennis enthusiasts within the University of Michigan's Ross School of Business

Name: Test Org One
Summary: This is a test org.

Name: Test Org Three
Summary: This is a test org.

Name: Test Org Two
Summary: This is a test org.

Name: Thai Student Association
Description:
The Thai Student Association (TSA) at the University of Michigan (UM) is one of the oldest student organizations founded by Thai students in the United States. Established for over fifty years, TSA is a Thai student-based organization which includes Thai and non-Thai members who are interested in Thailand and its culture, politics, people, and other aspects. We have around 100 members including undergraduate and graduate students, visiting scholars and research fellows, building a very diverse group. Other than our various activities at the University of Michigan that have been the social involvement hosted by TSA at UM, our main event of “Thai Night” has been a focal attraction with a joint effort between Thai students at the University of Michigan and Eastern Michigan University (EMU) for many years. We also receive overwhelming support from the Thai community in Michigan, the Michigan Student Assembly, and other local organizations. In the past, our Thai cultural performances and exhibitions have been highly recognized in the community over the years.

In addition, TSA has been working closely with the Center for Southeast Asian Studies and the University of Michigan, along with the Tourism Authority of Thailand to enhance the understanding of Thai and Southeast Asian cultures among the community. We also work in collaboration with other student groups such as Vietnamese, Singaporean, and Indonesian student associations to promote our culture.
Summary: Thai Student Association is an organization that brings together students from Thailand, Thai-U.S. and anyone interested in the Thai Culture. Our goals are to promote a unified community of Thais and share our culture with the UM and Ann Arbor community.

Name: The Accounting Club
Description:
https://www.michiganaccountingclub.com/

Our Mission

Promoting the study and practice of accounting and finance; providing opportunities for self-development, service, and association among members and practicing professionals, and encouraging a sense of ethical, social, and public responsibility.

Our Purpose

  • Encourage students to choose a career within the field of accounting.
  • Stimulate interest and encourage scholarship of students presently in the accounting curriculum.
  • Strengthen the ties between executives in business and students preparing to enter business.
  • Provide students with the opportunity to participate in organizing, planning, directing, and controlling an organization dedicated to the promotion and advancement of the art and science of accounting.
  • Encourage interaction among these college students, faculty and business executives through corporate presentations, educational workshops, and other unique opportunities. The professional and social environments offered to the members of this organization are opportune times for students to learn more about the different fields of business and create various networking connections that will aid in their future success.

Visit our website to become a member!
Summary: Established to aid in the professional development of college students actively interested in accounting, corporate finance and other related fields.

Name: The American Cancer Society on Campus
Description:
The American Cancer Society on Campus focuses on creating engaging events with communities across campus to build awareness and raise money for research and programs for those impacted by cancer. Each participant fundraises throughout the year, and the money in turn goes to support the activities of the American Cancer Society, including patient support, raising awareness, educating, and of course, cancer research. Events have included concerts, fundraisers with Ann Arbor restaurants, partnerships with other student organizations, pre-med health and speaker panels, pickleball, and an incoming 5k. We hope you'll join us in supporting those in need.

Celebrate, Remember, Fight Back, and Go Blue!
Summary: The American Cancer Society on Campus is a student-run organization that fundraises through the year for research, patient support, advocacy, and education on cancer. We work to support families locally and nationally in their fight and honor those lost.

Name: The American Conservation Coalition at UMich
Description: The American Conservation Coalition (ACC) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization dedicated to mobilizing young people around environmental action through common-sense, market-based, and limited-government ideals. As a branch of the American Conservation Coalition, ACC at UMich engages the student body in climate advocacy with events such as outdoor activities, hands-on environmental service projects, impactful education activities, and more! ACC at UMich hosts 2-3 of these events each month, and they are open to any faculty, staff or student!
Summary: As a branch of the American Conservation Coalition(ACC), ACC at UMich engages the student body in climate advocacy with events such as outdoor activities, hands-on environmental service projects, impactful education activities, and more!

Name: The American Constitution Society at the University of Michigan
Description:
The American Constitution Society (ACS) is a national organization that shapes debate on important legal and constitutional issues through development and promotion of high-impact ideas to opinion leaders and the media; by building networks of lawyers, law students, judges and policymakers dedicated to those ideas; and by countering the activist conservative legal movement that has sought to erode our enduring constitutional values.

The American Constitution Society at the University of Michigan seeks to influence debate on the law by advancing a progressive interpretation of the Constitution through forums, speakers and debate. By reintroducing the values of compassion, justice and respect for human dignity into the debate about the role of law in the America, the ACS hopes to build a stronger and more decent national community and bring the United States closer to its founding principles.

At the American Constitution Society at the University of Michigan, we organize discussions featuring prominent legal experts and professionals. We also host special events ranging from our Supreme Court Roundup to our periodic small-group Professor Lunches. We are one of the nation's most active ACS chapters. Our chapter was awarded the ACS National Chapter of the Year Award in 2009, 2020, and 2024. We were awarded the National Chapter of the Week in 2015, 2016, and 2024. Our Chapter was also awarded the "Programming Award" in 2014, 2017, 2022, 2023, and 2024.
Summary: This is the American Constitution Society at the University of Michigan. ACS is a national network of progressive constitutional scholars and attorneys.

Name: The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention at the University of Michigan
Description: Our chapter of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention is part of a national organization of community and campus chapters across the country, created to prevent suicide and provide hope for those affected by suicide. Our campus chapter will serve University of Michigan students by advocating for their mental health, raising and allocating funds towards mental health resources and suicide prevention tools, collaborating with other University of Michigan organizations to improve existing opportunities and host events to educate students about suicide prevention and mental health, and organizing our annual Out of the Darkness walks.
Summary: A student group affiliated and sponsored by the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention to continue suicide prevention, education, and advocacy work on UM's campus, and to continue organizing Out of the Darkness walks.

Name: The Amity Project
Description: The Amity Project at the University of Michigan supports low-income communities locally and globally by organizing volunteers, sharing resources, and launching initiatives that provide education, healthcare, and financial aid.
Summary: We aim to improve lives by supporting low-income communities in Michigan through volunteering, resources, and fundraising. Our mission is to unite people and create lasting change, locally and globally.

Name: THE ANN ARBOR TENANTS UNION
Description:
The Ann Arbor Tenants Union (AATU) is a tenant organization founded in 1968. In 2004, the AATU ceased operations due to a lack of funding, however the organization was restarted in August of 2023. The original iteration of the AATU advocated for tenants' rights, provided a tenant counseling hotline, and directed actions to support legislation favorable to tenants at the city and state levels.

 

The AATU was originally formed to lead a citywide rent strike starting in 1968. At the time, about 90% of rental units in Ann Arbor were not up to code. Similar to today, the quality of rental housing was low and the prices high. The rent strike, which lasted two years, involved tenants paying their rent into an offshore escrow account rather than to the landlord. Landlords would receive their rent from the account if they either brought the rental unit up to code or agreed to collective bargaining with the tenants union. Collective bargaining in this context would entail a negotiation between the landlord and a Tenants Union representative over the provisions in the leasing contracts for all tenants renting from that particular landlord. This differs from the normal process of the landlord negotiating individually with each tenant. The strategy was successful in some instances, but many landlords ultimately did not agree to collective bargaining. Nonetheless, the AATU was able to significantly improve the quality of rental units in Ann Arbor and challenge the power of landlords both at rental complexes and in the city and state government.
Summary: We are a group of tenants in Ann Arbor interested in fighting for stable, just, and affordable housing for students and townies alike. We believe organizing

Name: The Art of Science
Description: The Art of Science was established to improve scientific understanding through the use of visual and physical models. We are a casual group of students who enjoy art and science, united through a joint appreciation for scientific study as a field that involves visual and observable information; we are hoping to make it more relatable and accessible in formal education and business by moving the emphasis from rote memorization to broader understanding through artistic application. If you enjoy animation, model art, posters, digital art, and also like science a little bit, we'd love to have you on our team! We are also looking for people who like making videos and content creation, and like to teach others. Ideal for majors from the sciences and engineering to art, business, and education.
Summary: We aim to make science more relatable and accessible in formal education and business by moving the emphasis from rote memorization to broader understanding through artistic application.

Name: The Auscultations
Description:
Focused H&P
Name: The Auscultations

HPI: a ragtag group of med students with histories of past singing experiences ranging from "not" to "a lot," presenting today with chief complaint of wanting to rock out. Symptoms began in 2005 when UMMS was noted to be A Cappella-deficient. The group went into remission in 2007, but returned in 2009. From 2020-21, the group members found themselves occasionally hearing voices and singing to themselves alone in their bedrooms. A brisk resuscitation began in fall of 2021 although the group made an even stronger comeback in 2022.

Physical Exam:
General: appropriately fun-loving attitude with elevated energy level
CV: upbeat rate and rhythm
Lung: clear harmonies bilaterally

Assessment:
Ready to knock your socks off.

Plan:
1. Visit our Facebook page at http://tinyurl.com/umms-auscultations-fb

2. Sit back and enjoy.
Summary: The Auscultations is a co-ed a cappella group made up of University of Michigan Medical School students.  Students have tons of fun performing a cappella music for a variety of audiences, including patients at the hospital.

Name: The Bright Future Project
Description: Many pediatric patients who are frequently hospitalized often struggle to keep up with their education due to long periods of time spent in the hospital, treatment side effects, etc. To help relieve the financial burden of these hospital stays and treatments, this project performs fundraising events throughout the school year to obtain educational supplies and toys for the kids at Mott's Children's Hospital. We perform small table fundraising events all the way to hosting big events, such as concerts.
Summary: This project helps relieve the financial burden of extended hospital stays and treatments by performing fundraising events throughout the school year to obtain educational supplies and toys for the kids at Mott's Children's Hospital.

Name: The Classical Guitar Society at the University of Michigan
Description: The Classical Guitar Society at the University of Michigan is a group that aims to provide its members opportunities to meet, learn from, and collaborate with other classical and fingerstyle guitarists in a fun, low-stakes setting.
Summary: The Classical Guitar Society at the University of Michigan is a group that aims to provide its members opportunities to meet, learn from, and collaborate with other classical and fingerstyle guitarists in a fun, low-stakes setting.

Name: The Compulsive Lyres
Description:
The Compulsive Lyres is a tight-knit group of upbeat students dedicated to performing and arranging A Cappella music from a variety of different genres. The Lyres host a concert each semester, perform at both on-campus and off-campus gigs, and attend a retreat every semester which never fails to bring us closer as a group. The Lyres are comprised of charismatic, motivated, sarcastic, creative, devoted individuals who take pride in the music that we create and the family that we have become. Make sure to check out our recent EP and newest single on Spotify or Apple Music, and to follow us on Instagram @thecompulsivelyres for more information! Please enjoy this video of the Lyres' performance at the 2023 ICCA Great Lakes Quarterfinals:

https://youtu.be/imu_hczM-X4
Summary: The Lyres are an a cappella group that performs and arranges songs from a variety of genres- everything from Miley Cyrus to Stevie Wonder! We perform at a variety of gigs, host a concert each semester, and are best known for winning ICCA in 2002.

Name: The Creator Society
Description:
The Michigan Creator Society is a dynamic community of self-starters, entrepreneurs, and visionaries.

Through weekly outings like nature walks, fireside chats, hikes, and campus strolls, we go beyond traditional networking events. We are a close-knit family of creators who thrive on learning through hands-on experiences.

Join us to inspire, fuel motivation, and spark discovery within a supportive and authentic community. We welcome those who are boldly pursuing their dreams—everyone who identifies as a creator is invited.
Summary: The Creator Society at Michigan is a place to connect with self-starters, entrepreneurs, and visionaries who are boldly pursuing their dreams—everyone who identifies as a creator is invited.

Name: The Dance Student Assembly
Description:
MISSION STATEMENT

The Dance Student Assembly (DSA) is committed to a nourishing and supportive learning environment by representing undergraduate and graduate students' learning interests, concerns, and issues relating to policies in the Department of Dance. DSA comprises one volunteer representative from each of the undergraduate and graduate classes, in addition to the President and Vice President. Members report to and collaborate with the Chair of the Department on a regular basis allowing for DSA to act as both a formal and informal liaison between students and the faculty. Moreover, DSA organizes student activities, keeps them informed of events occurring in the Department, provides an open forum for students to voice their opinions and always strives to collaborate with other Departments in the School of Music, Theatre & Dance. DSA strongly encourages active participation in Department activities led by students, faculty and guests.
Summary: The Dance Student Assembly is the official student government of the Dance Department at the University of Michigan.

Name: The Detroit Partnership
Description: The DP exists in order to facilitate service-learning opportunities for volunteers in the city of Detroit. This organization is an initiative to involve a diverse student population in service, and to create sustainable partnerships between students and community groups. The DP is a resource available to the University of Michigan and greater community for active service-learning opportunities. In addition to weekly programs, the organization also holds two large events. In the fall, The Detroit Partnership partners with community members to bring a large food and clothing drive titled One-Stop Shop to the citizens of Brightmoor and surrounding areas. Also, every March or April the group routinely brings 300+ volunteers to sites across Detroit for a one-day service-learning event known as DP Day.
Summary: The Detroit Partnership seeks to connect the students at the University of Michigan with Detroit-based community partners by facilitating service-learning opportunities and on-campus events.

Name: The Diabetes Link at UofM
Description:
We are the University of Michigan chapter of The Diabetes Link. The group is made up of both diabetics and non-diabetics with the primary goals of raising awareness and money, and educating the greater University of Michigan campus about type 1 diabetes!

We hold multiple events throughout the year to raise awareness about diabetes, in addition to raising funds to donate to organizations that help the lives of those affected by Type 1. In addition, DLM holds events during Diabetes Awareness Month in November to help educate the University of Michigan community. DLM also holds smaller events throughout the year to spread advocacy about diabetes on campus and provide support for students living with Type 1.

For more information about The Diabetes Link, click here.

Interested in joining DLM? Follow us on social media to find out about our next upcoming meeting, or email us at umich.sda@gmail.com
Summary: The Diabetes Link at UofM is the University of Michigan chapter of The Diabetes Link. Our focus on campus is to spread awareness, educate, and raise money to cure type 1 diabetes.

Name: The DR's Laboratory
Description: The DR’s Laboratory is a student organization at The University of Michigan that builds equity in the arts by giving underrepresented students and alumni mentorship and opportunities to develop community programs and artistic projects rooted in Black liberation. We advance Black liberation research to divest from prejudices within performance, discover new solutions to exploitation in entertainment, and develop new forms in film and fine arts.
Summary: The DR's Laboratory is a process-production company finding new territory for Black artists in film and fine arts through research and storytelling.

Name: The Fermentation Club at The University of Michigan
Description: Beyond the kitchen, fermentation is deeply connected to history, tradition, and community building. Our goal is to foster a welcoming environment where students can connect over their shared curiosity, exchange cultures and ideas, and appreciate the intersections of food science, health, and environmental sustainability within our club.
Summary: Whether you are an experienced fermenter or a complete beginner, our club offers a space to learn, experiment, and build friendships through the magic of fermentation.

Name: The Friars
Description: An a cappella subset of the University of Michigan Men's Glee Club (UMMGC), consisting of 10 members. The Friars travel with UMMGC on tours and other club functions.
Summary: 10 men, 4 voice parts, and plenty of awful dance moves. The Friars have been 'entertaining' audiences for over 50 years, and are proud members of the University of Michigan Men's Glee Club.

Name: The Gathering at FBCA2
Description:
The Gathering is a weekly event for college and university students at all levels: undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate. (“Significant others” who are not students are also most welcome!) We often have a meal together, sometimes home-cooked. We share what’s going on in our lives, then have discussion on a relevant topic. The conversations are great, and the friendships we form are significant and mutually supportive. Sometimes, we just party!


The Gathering is sponsored by, and hosted at, First Baptist Church of Ann Arbor (not a Southern Baptist church, but a progressive American Baptist one); but participants are of all faiths, or of undefined faith, or of no faith. Our goal is to think honestly and openly together about important issues and concerns, and to be good friends to each other.


We meet on Wednesday evenings from 5:30 till 7:00 (but we are open to changing the times according to when most students can meet). Arriving late or leaving early is fine. Such is student life!

Last year our discussion theme was "Getting Through the Tough Stuff" where we talked about topics such as Boundaries, Self Care, Anxiety, Self Esteem, Grief and Death, New Beginnings, and Tough Relationships.
Summary: The Gathering is a weekly event for college students to share a meal and awesome conversation about relevant topics together!

Name: The Gentlemen
Description: The goal of The G-Men (Gentlemen for long) is to perform a cappella music while having a good time. We perform all types of music and are open to any sort of music opportunities, including recording albums, competing on the national stage, and touring the county. We rehearse 3 times a week and regularly hold concerts and gig around the community. Every spring break, we embark on a weeklong tour and we occasionally travel for gigs. More information about our group and the audition process can be found at our website, thegmen.org. We welcome all singers regardless of previous music experience!
Summary: The G-Men (or Gentlemen for long) is the premier all-male a cappella group at Michigan. The group strives to create unique music while having a good time. In recent years, The G-Men have toured the country, performed in the community, and placed in ICCA.

Name: The Ginsberg Center for Community Service Learning
Description: Through service, community partnerships and social justice education, the Ginsberg Center enriches student learning, advances community priorities and inspires a lifelong commitment to citizenship. The Ginsberg Center offers a range of programs and works with students and faculty to strengthen community service learning across the University of Michigan.
Summary: The Ginsberg Center’s mission is to engage students, faculty and community members in learning together through community service and civic engagement in a diverse, democratic society.

Name: The Gourmet Club
Description: The purpose of the Gourmet Club is to unite Ross's foodies of all levels and provide a fun community to converse and form friendships over food. We are also a place where students of diverse backgrounds can learn to cook intricate meals from student-led cooking demos. Our events focus on bringing together smaller groups of people to learn about each other in intimate settings at restaurants, cafes, farms, and dinner parties from Ann Arbor to Detroit. Most importantly, we are a club where if you have any passion for how the power of food can connect us all, the Gourmet Club is the place to be.
Summary: The purpose of the Gourmet Club is to unite Ross's foodies of all levels and provide a fun community to converse and form friendships over food.

Name: The Halimah Project UofM
Description: The Halimah Project pairs Muslim students from the University of Michigan with refugee mentees, fostering meaningful relationships through weekly meetings. These interactions not only offer academic and emotional support to the children but also help them build self-confidence and learn valuable life skills. Our mission is to provide support, guidance, and a sense of community to refugee children as they navigate their new lives and identities as Muslims in America.
Summary: The Halimah Project pairs Muslim students from the University of Michigan with refugee mentees, fostering meaningful relationships through weekly meetings.

Name: The Harmonettes
Description: Founded in 1979, the Harmonettes have been contributing to the ever-growing University of Michigan A Cappella community with their unique sound and signature blend. As the first A Cappella group on campus consisting of women and non-conforming individuals, these passionate musicians pride themselves on their inclusivity, tight-knit friendships, and innovative music. The Harmonettes, compassionately known as the Harmas, strive to create a community of laughter, support, and collaboration. Outside of rehearsals in the Bell Tower, they can be found studying late at the Union, learning music at retreats every semester, immersing themselves in numerous campus activities, and bonding over their love for Skylar Astin.
Summary: all-treble a cappella group

Name: The Impro-Fessionals
Description: We're the Impro-fessionals, the most unhinged improv comedy performance group on campus. We perform FREE monthly improvised shows open to the whole student body. Open auditions are held at the beginning of each semester. Check out our Instagram for more updates!
Summary: A short-form improvisational comedy group.

Name: The Intermezzo Fund
Description:
The Intermezzo Fund works year round to award microgrants to high school musicians in Southeast Michigan who identify with marginalized communities, in order to offset "invisible" costs of pursuing music. 

Operations include facilitating two grant cycles per year, working under a biannual benefit concert schedule, and forming and maintaining relationships to donors and community organizations.
Summary: The Intermezzo Fund is an arts equity student organization that works to empower young musicians within marginalized communities to pursue their artistic passions without the fear of financial burden.

Name: The Lookout Project
Description:
The Lookout Project aims to equip college students to reduce overdose death in their community through advocating for criminal justice reform and providing education and life saving overdose prevention supplies to the Washtenaw community. 

TLP envisions a future in which community members are equipped to respond to an overdose and individuals exiting incarceration are no more likely to die of overdose death than the general population.

Members of The Lookout Project vow to fight the opioid epidemic by increasing access to community overdose prevention information, distributing our free Opioid Overdose Response Kits, and working with local organizations to educate the U-M campus and community at large about how to inspire rehabilitation instead of criminalization.

Join TLP to to fight the opioid crisis, end the stigma surrounding substance use disorders, and save lives!
Summary: The Lookout Project aims to equip college students to reduce overdose death in their community through advocating for criminal justice reform and providing education and life saving overdose prevention supplies to the Washtenaw community.

Name: The Michigan Animation Club
Description:
The Michigan Animation Club (MAC) is dedicated to creating and appreciating animation. Our mission is to provide a safe and fun environment for students across all disciplines and experience levels to: access animation learning resources and information about the industry, explore both individual and collaborative projects, and watch/discuss animation with people who share their love for it. MAC also hosts speaker events with animation professionals, and other events like field trips and collaborations with other orgs! MAC events are dedicated to supporting the animation community at the University of Michigan and/or encouraging members to have fun and build connections.

 

We meet in-person on Fridays, 6-8PM in Design Lab 1 (Room 1321) of the Duderstadt Center on North Campus. If remote, our meetings take place same day and time on our Discord server. Optional animation screenings follow until 9PM!

 

We do not have club dues or an application. To receive meeting info, club + animation announcements, opps, and resources, join our email list here (click "Join Group") and our Discord (we recommend joining both). Also, please connect with us on Instagram ! For any questions or concerns, please contact the current standing President at the email below!
Summary: The Michigan Animation Club is dedicated to creating and appreciating animation. We invite students from any year, department, or experience levels to join, the only specification being a passion to learn and create.

Name: The Michigan Archive
Description:
At the Archive, we want to provide a chance for non-history majors and history majors alike to write about, read about, and generally enjoy history and its documentation. This magazine is a chance to engage in historical writing, journalism, and all other artistic endeavors under the sun.

The Archive is open to all interested participants, no history background necessary.
Summary: The Archive serves to produce a student-written, edited, and designed magazine containing historical articles, essays, and art created by members and guest writers/artists.

Name: The Michigan Blacksmithing Club
Description: The Michigan Blacksmithing Club teaches members blacksmithing basics with various projects and also collaborates to design and forge a blade to showcase in the TMS Bladesmithing Competition. This event is designed to promote engagement within the field of materials science and provide students with opportunities for industry jobs and advanced research. Members play a part in fabricating the blade using traditional and modern bladesmithing methods, and perform material analysis using tools in the MSE Van Vlack Laboratory. In the off-season, members work on refining their own smithing skills to create blades for club use. No prior experience is necessary as members are all taught safety guidelines and basic hand forging skills at the beginning of each year. We encourage both engineering and non-engineering members to join and take a swing at some hot steel!
Summary: The Michigan Blacksmithing Club teaches members blacksmithing basics with various projects and also collaborates to design and forge a blade to showcase in the TMS Bladesmithing Competition.

Name: The Michigan Gayly: LGBTQ+ Issues
Description: The Michigan Gayly: LGBTQ+ Issues is a monthly periodical consisting of articles focused on LGBTQ+ issues here on campus and in the world at large. We want to elevate the voices of queer people in general with a focus on those who are most marginalized-- queer people of color, queer people of faith, trans and nonbinary folks, etc. We hope to create an outlet of self-expression for Michigan students of all backgrounds within the LGBTQ+ community, while also spreading awareness of LGBTQ+ issues to queer and straight readers alike.
Summary: The Michigan Gayly: LGBTQ+ Issues is a monthly periodical consisting of articles focused on LGBTQ+ issues here on campus and in the world at large.

Name: The Michigan Institute for Progressive Policy
Description: We are a student-run organization that seeks to research, write, and advocate for progressive policies. Regardless of your major or year, we would love to have you in our organization. We do not have dues or an application.
Summary: The purpose of MIPP is to bring student-initiated progressive public policy ideas into the public discourse and build skills and networks to make us more effective change agents of society upon leaving the university.

Name: The Michigan Law Review
Description: The Michigan Law Review (MLR) is a student-run legal journal that publishes articles, student-written notes, book reviews, and online essays.
Summary: The Michigan Law Review (MLR) is a student-run legal journal that publishes articles, student-written notes, book reviews, and online essays.

Name: The Michigan Quadball Team
Description:
We play Quadball, a full contact and all genders inclusive sport, using the rules provided by United States Quadball (USQ) against teams at other universities. Quadball is a fast paced, high intensity sport with a unique style of gameplay akin to a combination of basketball/rugby/dodgeball (for videos of gameplay check out our YouTube channel!). In the fall, we have practices throughout the week and attend around 4 tournaments at other universities over various weekends. In the winter, we have workout groups, a practice on the weekends, and usually attend 2-3 tournaments.

We are a social club as well and host regular game/movie nights, parties, and other team hangouts. If you want to be part of the MQ community but are not interested in athletics, we happily welcome anyone onto our Support Staff! Support Staff members are an invaluable part of our team who support us logistically at tournaments in addition to being social members of MQ. 

If you have any questions or are interested in joining the team, please reach out to us at michiganquidditch@gmail.com!
Summary: The Michigan Quadball Team (MQ) is an official member of United States Quadball. We play Quadball, a sport adapted from the sport Quidditch from the Harry Potter universe.

Name: The Microbiology Club at the University of Michigan
Description: Our organization strives to introduce students to different topics within microbiology and explore the many opportunities within the field. We strive to promote science outreach to the community, by organizing field trips to different universities and grade schools to spread the passion for science and biology.
Summary: Our organization strives to introduce students to the different topics within microbiology as well as explore different careers and opportunities within the field.

Name: The Muslim Coalition
Description: The Muslim Coalition is a union of 35+ Muslim-adjacent religious, professional, and cultural student organizations at the University of Michigan. It aims to serve U-M's diverse Muslim student body and represent Muslim interests to the greater campus community in a pluralistic fashion. The Muslim Coalition has a Council, with delegates from the Muslim-adjacent student organizations at U-M and provides them with a forum to foster efficient communication, discussion, and collaboration. Furthermore, as the student-arm of the Islamophobia Working Group (IWG), The Coalition facilitates and supports Muslim-relevant projects that aim to address matters affecting all Muslim students on campus, such as access to prayer spaces, halal food, availability of bidets, surveying, and Ramadan programming. With these goals, the Coalition seeks to embrace U-M's diverse Muslim student community and enrich the Michigan experience.
Summary: The Muslim Coalition is a union of Muslim-affiliated student organizations at the University of Michigan. It aims to serve U-M's diverse Muslim student body and represent Muslim interests to the greater campus community.

Name: The National Society of Black Women in Medicine
Description: The National Society of Black Women in Medicine aims to increase the retention of underrepresented minority women pursuing careers in all pre-professional healthcare pathways.
Summary: The National Society of Black Women in Medicine aims to increase the retention of underrepresented minority women pursuing careers in all pre-professional healthcare pathways.

Name: The Neuroscience Student Association
Description:
The mission of this organization is to benefit students with an interest in neuroscience in their current roles as undergraduate students and in their future professions in a wide variety of fields by providing networking opportunities, seminars, and exposure to the depth of neuroscience.

We believe that neuroscience is fascinating, and that the field as a whole contains a wide array of opportunities that serve to reach advancements in applied science and health. Many students enter the University of Michigan with a limited understanding of available careers, and we hope to broaden their horizons by exposing them to medicine, public health, research, and engineering. Neuroscience is, at its very core, an interdisciplinary subject. It requires a relatively deep understanding of biology, chemistry, physics, and psychology. Beyond that, when it is crossed with computer programming, electrical engineering, biomedical engineering, or animal studies, it gains an even broader scope of possibilities. We hope to expose students to the many facets of this broad, advancing field.

If you are interested in joining the mailing list so that you can stay up-to-date with events, please email Caroline (cgebczak@umich.edu) or Tanay (tanbhan@umich.edu).
Summary: An association of students interested in applications of the advancing field of neuroscience.

Name: The Office of Student Conflict Resolution
Description: The Office of Student Conflict Resolution promotes a safe and scholarly community in which students navigate conflict in a peaceful, socially just, and self-reflexive manner. OSCR offers a spectrum of conflict resolution pathways that are educationally focused, student-driven, community owned, and restorative in nature, which are adaptable to meet the needs of individuals experiencing conflict.
Summary: The Office of Student Conflict Resolution promotes a safe and scholarly community in which students navigate conflict in a peaceful, socially just, and self-reflexive manner.

Name: The Pakistani Student Association
Description:
The Pakistani Student Association (PSA) is a student-run organization at the University of Michigan – Ann Arbor that works to create a home away from home for Pakistani students in Ann Arbor, and helps promote Pakistani culture within the Michigan community.

Keeping its vision in mind, PSA holds numerous events throughout the academic year. Some of our staple events are cricket watch parties, Piston's game nights, mentorship/study tables, and our capstone cultural event, Michigan Mehndi. PSA also plays a role in the Center for South Asian Studies' Pakistan Conference, where guest speakers with expertise on Pakistani society, politics, and political economy from leading research universities around the country are invited to present and engage in discussion on the pertinent issues facing Pakistan today.

We encourage all those interested in learning about Pakistan, participating in a cultural event, or settling in and getting comfortable on campus to become a member of our community. We are sure you will enjoy our company. Go Blue and Pakistan Zindabad!
Summary: The Pakistani Student Association (PSA) is a student-run organization at the University of Michigan – Ann Arbor that works to promote Pakistani culture within the university community.

Name: The Pearl Project
Description: The Pearl Project’s mission is to support and empower young mothers in financially unstable circumstances by working closely with community leader, Ms. Pearl. Ms. Pearl provides low-cost childcare services and emotional support to mothers in her area, which allows them to continue their education and support their families. To that end, The Pearl Project supports the Roseland Community “Good News” Daycare, in the South Side of Chicago with fundraising events and volunteering at the daycare on an alternative school break. Additionally, The Pearl Project works to provide education on what it truly means to volunteer and give back to a community outside of your own through service efforts throughout Southeast Michigan and Chicago.
Summary: The Pearl Project is dedicated to supporting Ms. Pearl and the Roseland "Good News" Daycare on the South Side of Chicago. Members will volunteer at the daycare on an alternative school break as well as throughout Washtenaw County.

Name: The PhD Forum at the Stephen M. Ross School of Business
Description: The Forum is a student group whose primary purpose is addressing the needs of the Ross Ph.D. student body. From social events to resources essential for a successful doctoral candidate in business, the Forum will provide supplemental services to ensure the success of doctoral students during their academic careers at Ross.
Summary: The PhD Forum is an elected group of currently enrolled Ph.D. students at the Ross School of Business, University of Michigan.

Name: The Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Organization at the University of Michigan
Description: The Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Organization at the University of Michigan is a group of law students who compete in the yearly Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court competition. As competitors, the team members research public international law legal problems, draft briefs, and participate in oral arguments. Tryouts are held annually.
Summary: The Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Organization at the University of Michigan is a group of law students who compete in the yearly Jessup Moot Court competition where team members research, draft briefs, and participate in oral arguments.

Name: The Pickleball Club at Ross
Description: The Pickleball Club at Ross creates opportunities for Ross MBA students to play pickleball and connect through open play, tournaments, workshops, and social events.
Summary: The Pickleball Club at Ross creates opportunities for Ross MBA students to play pickleball and connect through open play, tournaments, workshops, and social events.

Name: The Prison Creative Arts Project
Description:
• We place human connection at the center of our process.
  • We join with community partners in the movement toward social justice through the arts.
  • We facilitate art workshops, a literary review, a podcast, and one of the world's largest art show of incarcerated people's art.
  • We welcome all people who wish to join PCAP’s work into our community at the University of Michigan.
  • We recognize the power of diversity and of intersection between different parts of society to create learning opportunities.
  • We celebrate artists, writers, and performers at all skill levels and provide support for artistic growth.

Please email mierm@umich.edu to find your fit and help us in our mission for social change within our justice system!
Summary: The Prison Creative Arts Project brings those impacted by the justice system and the University of Michigan Community into artistic collaboration for mutual learning and growth.

Name: The Program on Intergroup Relations
Description: The Program on Intergroup Relations (IGR) is a social justice education program. We offer courses as well as co-curricular programming that blends theory and experiential learning to facilitate students' learning about social group identity, social inequality, and intergroup relations. The program prepares students to live and work in a diverse world and educates them in making choices that advance equity, justice, and peace. IGR is a partnership between Student Life and the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts.
Summary: The Program on Intergroup Relations (IGR) is a social justice education program. IGR blends theory and experiential learning to facilitate students' learning about social group identity, social inequality, and intergroup relations.

Name: The Quarterdeck Society
Description: The Quarterdeck Society is a student organization dedicated to serving the students of the Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering department. Quarterdeck provides to its members the ability to advance themselves professionally, gain a better awareness of our industry, and build a valuable network consisting of fellow students as well as industry professionals.  All of this is accomplished through corporate presentations, industry related field trips, attendance to the Great Lakes/Great Rivers SNAME section meetings and the SNAME Annual Meeting, volunteer opportunities, mentorship  and social events. Both undergraduate and graduate students welcomed!
Summary: The Quarterdeck Society aims to give its members a variety of opportunities ranging from professional development and networking opportunities to social events and mentorship in the Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering community.

Name: The Quito Project
Description:
The Quito Project is a multidisciplinary organization with students and faculty from schools across the University of Michigan including: Social Work, Nursing, Education, Business, Literature Sciences & Arts, Engineering, etc. As of 2023, TQP is in its nineteenth year of operation. Since its formation in 2004, TQP has evolved to support projects in the realm of public health, social work, and education for 8,000 community members of San Martin, San Blas, and Pifo in Quito, Ecuador.

The Quito Project’s mission is to collaborate with local partners in developing evidence-based solutions that support and build capacity in the health, educational, and social sectors.

 

TQP Model:  In partnership with the Universidad de San Francisco in Quito, students from the University of Michigan partner with education students in Ecuador to hold a summer camp for underprivileged children each summer. The curriculum is student-developed with support from mentor faculty members and emphasizes the strengthening students' understanding of public health and core academic subjects in reading, writing, mathematics and the sciences while encouraging creative expression and exploration, elevating the importance of academic performance, and boosting in-class self-confidence.  Each year approximately 60 students aged 5-12 years old attend the camp. 

We provide our students with engaging educational activities, two meals at the summer camp, school supplies, and hygienic supplies which is entirely free of charge and organized by undergraduate students from the University of Michigan and La Universidad San Francisco de Quito. 

 

Membership: The Quito Project members are recruited and managed by the TQP executive board and our faculty advisor. Every fall, TQP recruits UM undergraduate students through campus events, direct marketing, and social media campaigns. Prospective tutors for our program must complete an application and an interview conducted in both English and Spanish before being selected to participate in our summer travel program. However, traditional membership for on-campus activities throughout the school year is open to all and does not have an application nor interview.
Summary: The Quito Project is a multidisciplinary organization working to advance education alongside low-resource communities in Ecuador, organized by the collaborative efforts of students from the University of Michigan and La Universidad San Francisco de Quito

Name: The RC Review
Description:
The RC Review is the annually published literary magazine of the Residential College, a subdivision of UM's College of Literature, Science, and the Arts. Each year, we publish student poetry, prose, photography, art, and any other creative work that can fit flat on a page (or be uploaded on our website). We always welcome new staff members to take part in the process of reviewing submissions, assembling the magazine, advertising, fundraising, and other literary hijinks.

Find us at thercreview.com or @thercreview on Instagram.

To join our email list for meeting times and events, click HERE!
Summary: The annual literary magazine of the Residential College, publishing student poetry, prose, photography, art, and any other creative work that can fit flat on a page.

Name: The Red Glasses Movement at the University of Michigan
Description: Just as Audrey’s story has inspired us, we wish to inspire the world to live boldly, love big, and pass it on. The Red Glasses Movement Student Chapter will further this mission by helping bridge the gap between individuals with disabilities and people without disabilities, to allow ALL to feel included and loved. This chapter aims to not only help educate the community about down syndrome and other types of disabilities but also to create impactful events to encourage the bridging of this gap. Through fundraising and volunteering, The Red Glasses Movement Student Chapter will work closely with organizations that support individuals with down syndrome and other disabilities in order to bridge this gap by living boldly, loving big and passing it on.
Summary: The goal of The Red Glasses Movement chapter at the University of Michigan is to the bridge the gap between between individuals with and without disabilities to allow ALL to feel included and loved through fundraising and volunteering.

Name: The Rho Chi Society Alpha Chapter
Description:
The Society's vision is to achieve universal recognition of its members as lifelong intellectual leaders in pharmacy. As a community of scholars, the Society will instill the desire to pursue intellectual excellence and critical inquiry to advance the profession.

The Mission of the Society is to encourage and recognize excellence in intellectual achievement and foster fellowship among its members. Further, the Society encourages high standards of conduct and character and advocates critical inquiry in all aspects of pharmacy.
Summary: To advance practice and pharmaceutical sciences through the encouragement and recognition of sound scholarship

Name: The Serotonin Society
Description: The Serotonin Society aims to create a supportive community for pre-health students by promoting mental wellness and self-care practices. We believe that maintaining good mental health is essential for academic success and professional growth. Through a variety of activities, such as workshops, discussions, and social events, we strive to raise awareness about mental health issues and combat the stigma associated with seeking help. Our ultimate goal is to empower pre-health students to prioritize their mental health and build resilience for the challenges ahead.
Summary: The Serotonin Society is established for students with pre-health concentrations who value mental and physical health and wellness, as well as pre-health students looking to connect with their peers outside of an academic setting.

Name: The Sirens A Cappella
Description: The Sirens are a treble cappella group at the University of Michigan dedicated to their legacy of musical excellence, female empowerment, and creative expression. Formed in 2011, the Sirens are committed to fostering an inclusive environment for all members, exploring and challenging their vocal abilities, and supporting each other as the Leaders and Best!
Summary: The Sirens is an all-female a cappella group, dedicated to musical excellence, maintaining democracy, and building friendships. Through our performances, values, and community, we create a positive, fun, unique, and artistic presence on campus.

Name: The Smile Bringer Singers
Description:
The group was started by alumnus Sasha Altschuler in 2010. Since its creation, the group has grown to become well-known not only in the University of Michigan community, but in the Ann Arbor and surrounding area as well. 

We are a group of upbeat University of Michigan students dedicated to making a positive difference in our community! We perform at Nursing Homes, Assisted Living Facilities, a girls group home, as well as at different events on campus. And we are always looking for new places to attend.

We sing energetic songs- both old and new- such as "Build Me Up Buttercup," "Shake It Off," and "Footloose," making each one special and made just for you!

The Smile Bringer Singers is a unique, innovative group of students with compassion, talent, and committment to spreading happiness through harmonies!
Summary: The Smile Bringer Singers is a group designed to bring happiness and inspiration to our surrounding areas. We mix our passions for performing and community service to create a positive, fun, and loving organization.

Name: The Society of American Archivists Student Chapter at the University of Michigan
Description: The Society of American Archivists Student Chapter at the University of Michigan is an organization for students interested in archives, records management, and the preservation of information at the School of Information. It exists to promote the work of its members through its website and conferences, to create connections with future colleagues through social events, to expose students to new trends in practice through guest lectures, and to give them the opportunity to use their skill to improve the community through service projects. Please note that the organizational roster is not kept up to date on Maize Pages.
Summary: The chapter of the Society of American Archivists for students at the University of Michigan School of Information. We organize Q&A sessions with archives professionals, presentations, workshops, service projects, tours, and social gatherings.

Name: The Sopranos
Description: The Sopranos​ are a fun-loving, tight-knit treble a cappella group at the University of Michigan united by a commitment to musical excellence and creating long-lasting friendships. Their members come from all over campus, but are united by their deep love for music. Founded in 2001, this hard-working family of passionate musicians records their own music and aims to positively impact the world of collegiate a cappella.
