Summary: The Sopranos are a treble a cappella group dedicated to musical excellence and forging lasting friendships. Throughout the year, the Sops put on concerts, perform at various gigs throughout the year, compete in the ICCA, and record their own music!

Name: The Squirrel Club
Description: The Squirrel Club is an organization of students, alumni, and members of the community that come together every Sunday during the fall and winter semesters to feed squirrels. Anyone is welcome to come to a meeting regardless of whether they are signed up for the club or not. Proceeds from t-shirt sales go to purchasing peanuts that are passed out at meetings (mainly to be fed to the squirrels). The technique that has been perfected is demonstrated and taught at meetings for those who are new, and results in an enjoyable outdoor experience that is unique to the University of Michigan.
Summary: The Squirrel Club is a fun and easy student organization that meets approximately every Sunday during the school year to feed squirrels in the Diag and around campus. Anyone and everyone is welcome to join!

Name: The Stampede
Description: The Stampede aims to foster community among the Stamps student body while providing real-world experience in exhibiting art. Our organization will orchestrate, curate, and exhibit shows that welcome all students across the University of Michigan campus with the goal of facilitating connections so that students can come together, with art as the common ground. These shows will take place in both informal off-campus independent/guerilla art shows, along with shows in more formal exhibitions connected with university spaces. We plan to cultivate a platform where students can display their work that may not connect in a traditional Stamps classroom setting, and develop skills with students of similar interests.
Summary: The Stampede aims to foster community among the Stamps student body while providing real-world experience in exhibiting art. Our organization will orchestrate, curate, and exhibit shows that welcome all students across the University of Michigan campus.

Name: The Student Giving Council
Description:
1. The SGC seeks to educate the student body on the value of philanthropy at the University of Michigan, show the impact that philanthropic giving has on all students at the university, and fundraise for meaningful and impactful causes on campus. The SGC ensures that the student perspective on giving and philanthropy is well represented and heard by the university. The council empowers members to grow as leaders on campus and gain valuable skills related to fundraising, event planning, marketing, and more.
  2. With the support of the University Student Philanthropy Team (SP), the objective of the SGC is to build a culture of philanthropy at the University of Michigan, to encourage lifelong engagement with the university, and to inspire a commitment to financially supporting the mission of the institution that starts on campus and lasts long beyond graduation.
  3. The SGC defines philanthropy at U-M as the giving of money, time, expertise, and resources to better the university community.
Summary: The Student Giving Council (SGC) empowers students to be more actively engaged in philanthropy at the University of Michigan by giving them a seat at the table within the annual giving department. By creating a culture of giving on campus, the SGC hopes

Name: The SunBundle
Description: Our mission is to empower athletics and foster wellness education within underserved communities. The SunBundle is a care-package-based program that donates shoes, clothing, hygiene products, and educational resources to underserved areas to promote health and wellness. We collect athletic clothing and sneaker donations from schools, running stores, and individuals to engage the community for our initiative. Our initiative engages the community by holding care-package-building events and organizing trips to collaborate with underserved youth. We want to cultivate an environment of people who want to make a difference, and transform the way that health&wellness are viewed around the world!
Summary: A non-profit organization dedicated to helping individuals jumpstart their wellness journeys.

Name: The Taylor Swift Club at the University of Michigan
Description: The Taylor Swift Club at the University of Michigan is a casual club that hosts open social gatherings such as album listening parties, movie nights, and many more activities to foster an inclusive environment perfect for finding new friends or enjoying the company of other fans of the pop star. We have occasional quick mass meetings designed for brief overviews of club plans and e-board activities. This club is low-commitment, simply here to create a welcoming and safe atmosphere with the common denominator of Taylor Swift!
Summary: The Taylor Swift Club at the University of Michigan (TSC) strives to create an inclusive and light-hearted atmosphere where fans of Taylor Swift can come together to enjoy her music, engage in club-sponsored social events, and make new friends.

Name: The Ukrainian Club at UM
Description: The Ukrainian Club at UM is an organization that represents students of Ukrainian background at the University of Michigan and provides a forum for voicing their mutual concerns and interests. This organization will promote and propagate Ukrainian and Ukrainian-American studies by bringing awareness of major historical events,  promote and propagate Ukrainian and Ukrainian-American culture and heritage, and promote the Ukrainian language. Most importantly, this organization aims to provide a method for social interaction among Ukrainian-Americans and non-Ukrainians, who are interested in Ukrainian culture.
Summary: This organization represent students of Ukrainian background at the University of Michigan and provides a forum for voicing their mutual concerns and interests.

Name: The Undergraduate Journal of Public Health
Description:
The Undergraduate Journal of Public Health is established with the purpose of increasing awareness of local, national, and international public health related issues within the the University of Michigan campus and the greater Ann Arbor community.

We aim to to create a platform for students to voice their opinions and engage with peers on a variety of public health issues and topics. This will be accomplished through the release of an annual printed journal as well as rolling blog articles.
Summary: Our mission is to provide a platform for undergraduate students at UMich and other universities to publish articles on public health topics such as healthcare access, health disparities, social justice, and epidemiology.

Name: The University of Michigan College of Engineering Honor Council
Description:
Please check out our main website here: https://www.honorcouncil.engin.umich.edu/

The Engineering Honor Council is a distinguished student-led organization serving the College of Engineering for over a century. Our mandate is to ensure the administration of the Honor Code is conducted fairly and impartially. We are responsible for investigating reported violations, educating students and faculty about the Honor Code, and ensuring that all parties involved in the process are treated with the utmost respect and fairness. To achieve this, we recruit investigators and faculty representatives from various departments within the college, to ensure that each case is examined from a comprehensive and holistic perspective. We are committed to maintaining the highest standards of integrity and accountability within the College of Engineering.

If you would like to apply to our organization, we are actively recruiting engineering first and second-year undergrad and Ph.D. students year-round: https://www.honorcouncil.engin.umich.edu/apply
Summary:
Founded in 1904 by Michigan undergraduates, we aim to uphold the Engineering Honor Code, promote student integrity, and work with students and faculty to reduce academic violations on campus.

https://www.honorcouncil.engin.umich.edu/

Name: The University of Michigan Czech Student Association
Description:
The University of Michigan Czech Student Association is a student-run organization that focuses on building a stronger Czech community among the student body. This club will provide a space for students of Czech heritage, as well as students interested in the Czech to learn more about Czech culture through cultural events, as well as a long-term oral history project highlighting the Czech and Czech American community. 

If you are interested in joining or learning more about the University of Michigan Czech Student Association, please email us at timcheek@umich.edu! We would love to meet you! To reiterate, we are active as of the 2024-25 academic year.
Summary: The University of Michigan Czech Student Association is a student-run organization that focuses on building a stronger Czech community among the student body.

Name: The University of Michigan Fencing Club
Description:
The University of Michigan Fencing Club is a competitive training environment for experienced fencers and newcomers alike. We offer an inclusive atmosphere that encourages fencers to improve to the best of their abilities while developing supportive relationships with their teammates. 

To join our practices, you will need the Participation Agreement filled out and approved. The agreement is under the Forms section. Practices are Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Friday at the Sports Coliseum 7pm-9pm.
Summary: The University of Michigan Fencing Club provides opportunities for both experienced fencers and newcomers to train and compete at the collegiate level. We are open to all students, staff, and faculty at the University of Michigan.

Name: The University of Michigan Polish Student Association
Description:
The University of Michigan Polish Student Association is a student run organization with the purpose of spreading Polish culture on campus and to the surrounding areas of Ann Arbor. We bring together Polish students, citizens and their friends by organizing a wide variety of social and cultural events throughout the year, including several mixers and bonfires, which allow for our members and friends to interact. Students experience Polish culture by participating in the special events we hold such as Andrejki (St. Andrews Day) and Pisanki (Easter Egg Decorating). They are also more than welcome to come cook Polish favorites, Pierogi and Golapki, at any one of our cooking events during the year.

Aside from all the events hosted by the organization, we work closely with our friends from the Polish American Congress and the Political Cultural Fund in assisting them with the preparation of the Annual Ann Arbor Polish Film festival. We have strong ties with the Copernicus Program in Polish Studies and the Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures and help them accommodate visitors invited from Poland and neighboring Slavic countries. 

We plan on hosting many more events this year and welcome everyone to come join us at any one of them to socialize and learn about our culture.
Summary: The University of Michigan Polish Student Association is a student run organization with the purpose of spreading Polish culture on campus and to the surrounding areas of Ann Arbor.

Name: The Urban Planning Student Association
Description: UPSA explores, promotes, and supports academic understanding, professional development, and the overall advancement of the field of Urban and Regional Planning.  To uphold these objectives, UPSA provides a forum for intellectual and social interaction among students of Urban Planning, promotes fellowship between Urban Planning students and the faculty/staff within the Department of Urban and Regional Planning, acts as the official spokesperson for the Masters students within the Department, and promotes interest in and understanding of the Urban Planning profession.
Summary: To explore, promote and support academic understanding, professional development, and the overall advancement of the field of Urban & Regional Planning.

Name: The Urban Wordsmith Society
Description: It is our mission and obligation to promote and foster artistic freedom and philanthropic ideas in minority communities and urban environments that promote unity, writing, and creative expression. Collectively, we will constitute a voice for people coming from marginalized communities that will strive to familiarize others with the struggles of underrepresented Americans. Our fundamental purpose will follow an original 4-block commandment represented by the acronym MAAP (Minority based, Activism, Art, & Philanthropy). This constitutes our goal to strive to respectfully represent minorities through activism, art, and philanthropy. MAAP is a guide for U.W.S. and will play a key role in our fundamental decision-making as an organization. At U.W.S. we will provide a safe and familiar environment for all P.O.C, where each member can hone their skills and participate in movements or shows meant to give back to our communities through entertainment and any aid we find ourselves capable of.
Summary: The Urban Wordsmith Society is an organization designed to foster artistic expression in minority communities through conversations, literature, and creative auditory expression. All voices are welcome and anyone is welcome to come share and listen.

Name: The Wesley Foundation at the University of Michgan
Description:
The Wesley Foundation at the University of Michigan --- a campus ministry related to the United Methodist church --- provides a place of community and faith in the midst of college life. Through Bible studies for grads and undergrads, social activities, service projects, movies, Holy Communion, programs, and speakers, we grow together and give the academic life a sense of balance and perspective. We laugh a lot and we care about each other - God is always with us.

We strive to be a pluralistic community - academically, theologically, and by age and interest. We are also a community of persons committed to caring, sharing, serving, learning, and growing with each other regardless of ethnic origin, gender, sexual orientation, marital or economic status, handicapping condition, or other human differences. Our common bond is God's love shown through Jesus Christ. Our emphases include concern for the social implications of the gospel in the world and personal growth as Christians.
Summary: The Wesley Foundation at the University of Michigan is a campus ministry related to the United Methodist Church providing a place of community and faith in the midst of college life.

Name: The Women's Network at Michigan
Description:
The Women's Network (TWN) is the largest collegiate women's networking organization in the United States. Our mission is to connect collegiate and recently graduated women and non-binary people to each other and to industry leaders, while celebrating ambition. We host a variety of experiential events and programs - both at a chapter and national level - such as speaker panels, networking events, and professional development workshops.

TWN has a presence on over 120 college campuses in the United States and Canada, and, at present, over 50,000 members in our community.

TWN is a great way to form authentic connections, develop leadership skills, gain insight into different careers, and meet other ambitious women on your campus and across the world. (Encourage your friends to join TWN by sending them our membership form: bit.ly/jointwn!). Open to all years and majors, non-competitive and free to join.

Nationals Webpage: https://www.thewomens.network/

Join the network:  bit.ly/jointwn

Chapter Instagram page: https://www.instagram.com/thewomensnetwork_michigan
Summary: The largest women-led collegiate networking org. in North America! We have chapters at 120+ universities in the US, Canada, and Ireland dedicated to uplifting women across disciplines, celebrating ambition, and connecting women with resources to succeed.

Name: The Youth Movement Against Alzheimer's
Description: YMAA is a non-profit student organization aimed at promoting the understanding of Alzheimer’s among the youth by providing opportunities to help those affected by this disease through research, advocacy, and volunteerism. Our vision is to create a culture where our youth embrace aging and help alleviate the impact of Alzheimer’s Disease.
Summary: YMAA is a non-profit student organization aimed at promoting the understanding of Alzheimer’s among the youth by providing opportunities to help those affected by this disease through research, advocacy, and volunteerism.

Name: Theta Alpha Psi
Description: Theta Alpha Psi’s leadership and members are committed to our values of activism, education, friendship, and community within our fraternity operations, initiatives, and interactions. Through academic, professional, and personal education Theta Alpha Psi will focus on three clusters of Business, Technology, and Environment regarding social and environmental sustainability to inform students passionate about these sectors. Theta Alpha Psi is committed to diversity, equity, inclusion, and justice within our recruitment, education, partnerships, and fundraising.
Summary: Theta Alpha Psi is a professional co-ed sustainability fraternity with the purpose to connect students passionate about environmental and social sustainability topics and educate undergraduates with accurate and inclusive sustainable-action knowledge.

Name: Theta Capital
Description:
Founded in 2019, Theta Capital is a highly selective public markets investing and trading organization at the University of Michigan Stephen M. Ross School of Business. Theta Capital is built upon active traders and investors. It is the place to be for those with a deep passion for the stock market.

Theta Capital models itself after an investment fund, allowing new analysts to learn from experienced traders. Analysts are immersed in a collaborative environment, helping them become more acclimated to financial markets. Daily market discussion and debate are core to our strategy. We cultivate an environment where ideas and theses can be shared and refined. We give analysts a very unique perspective on the stock market. Useful real-life investing & trading skills are built here.

Theta capital is unique in that we focus on a mix of long/short equity, bonds, and derivatives. We provide an experience similar to what it is like working at an investment fund.

There are also resources provided for members to go directly into buy-side investment positions out of undergrad.
Summary: Theta Capital is a University of Michigan investment research club centered around finding winning investments/trades and active stock market discussion.

Name: Theta Tau Professional Engineering Fraternity
Description:
Theta Tau is a brotherhood of engineers dedicated to bolstering our professional and social lives through professional development workshops such as resume builders and "career fair tips" presentations, many philanthropic opportunities with local charities such as Food Gatherers or DAPCEP, and social events that include a weekend retreat, semi-formal dinner, and a multitude of fun activities with our brothers.

 

Interested in rushing? Please don't join our maize pages roster - instead follow our Instagram account @thetatau_umich for rush information, hope to see you soon :)
Summary: Theta Tau is a co-ed professional engineering fraternity that combines the best aspects of social life and professionalism to create a close knit brotherhood.

Name: Thrift and Gift
Description: "Thrift and Gift" is a club dedicated to collecting and redistributing gently used clothing to support individuals in need within our community. Our club organizes donation drives with local brands, Greek life, and the broader campus community, gathering clothing contributions that are then stored, sorted, and transported to our pop-up "store." At these events, members help style outfits and set up racks of clothing for individuals from local shelters, orphanages, foster homes, and social work organizations to "shop" free of charge. With promotional efforts on social media and designated donation bins around campus, we encourage everyone to get involved and make a difference.
Summary: Thrift and Gift collects gently used clothing from brands, Greek life, and campus, redistributing items to those in need through local organizations. One event per year where members help style outfits for attendees to shop for free

Name: Timber Strong Design Build
Description: Participates in an ASCE competition where students design and build a two-story timber structure. Students use Revitt to model the structure and fabricate construction plans. At competition, the structure is constructed and tested
Summary: Participates in an ASCE competition where students design and build a two-story timber structure. Students use Revitt to model the structure and fabricate construction plans. At competition, the structure is constructed and tested

Name: TJ Hooper & the Learned Hands
Description: TJ Hooper & the Learned Hands is a musical ensemble made up of law school students. The group's mission is to provide entertainment to the law school student body and musical opportunities for its members through performances at school events. The group has traditionally been a rock/pop ensemble that performs cover versions of popular songs at school events such as the Halloween Party and Law Prom.
Summary: TJ Hooper & the Learned Hands is a musical ensemble of law school students. The group's mission is to provide entertainment to the law school student body and musical opportunities for its members through performances at school events.

Name: TOM Club at the University of Michigan
Description: TOM -- Tikkun Olam Makers is a global movement of communities to create and disseminate affordable solutions to unmet challenges of people with disabilities and the elderly. TOM:Club at the University of Michigan takes a "university approach" to this movement, where students at the University of Michigan will be paired with a "need-knower," or an individual who lives with a physical disability, and will be tasked with creating a solution to address this need-knower's unmet challenge during a 2-3 day make-a-thon held on campus. While many of the products that students will be creating will be engineering-based, TOM:UM encourages and even seeks out other students who are not engineers (artists, physical therapists, etc.) to be members of the teams that create solutions for these individuals. With the new challenges faced due to COVID-19, TOM will be hosting both in-person and virtual events including hosting speakers and working and design challenges to address problems for those in need. Learn more: https://vimeo.com/430001604
Summary: TOM (Tikkun Olam Makers) is a student-led chapter of an organization dedicated to creating and distributing extremely affordable open-source solutions to challenges that impact people living with disabilities, veterans, the elderly, and more.

Name: TOMS at the University of Michigan Campus Club
Description: Join us to promote the 'One For One' model in giving both shoes and sight to people in need all across the world.  We hold large events, including Style Your Sole, One Day Without Shoes, etc.  Additionally we choose our own community service spots to ensure people are passionate about they volunteering they do.
Summary: We work to promote the One For One model by hosting events about the importance of shoes and giving and participate in community service.  We work closely with TOMS in helping bring shoes to those who do not have any.

Name: Touch of Blue: New American Vocal Ensemble
Description:
Touch of Blue (formerly known as BlueNote Vocal Ensemble) is comprised of musicians who have a strong desire to improve their overall musicianship through jazz and improvisational study and learn through peer-to-peer mentorship. As an extracurricular group, the ensemble will meet approximately 1-2 times a week with more rehearsal time pending on an upcoming performance. 
 
The group will work towards one main performance at the end of each semester, and will make guest appearances on other departmental concerts as well as participate in outreach events scattered throughout the year. 
 
Touch of Blue's mission is to inspire diverse audiences through the exploration and presentation of jazz-centric American vocal music, with a commitment to uplifting and celebrating this music through both improvisatory and more conventional performance modes.
Summary: Our mission is to inspire diverse audiences through the exploration and presentation of jazz-centric American vocal music, with a commitment to uplifting and celebrating this music through both improvisatory and more conventional performance modes.

Name: Traders at Michigan
Description:
Quantitative Finance is a very mysterious field. We seek to educate students at UMich so that they're informed and prepared enough to enter industry! We're excited to hone the future of software engineering, trading, and research in the quant world! We're sponsored by quant finance leaders in Citadel + Citadel Securities, Jane Street, Susquehanna International Group, DRW, Optiver, Five Rings, IMC Trading, DE Shaw, Old Mission Capital, Two Sigma, Chicago Trading Company, Hudson River Trading, Hap Capital, and Flow Traders!

Our organization is primarily focused on education, making sure that everyone is academically prepared to their fullest extent, while also ensuring that everyone is knowledgeable about all the different tricks to land interviews and bypass the difficulties in entering the industry.

We also hosted UMich's first ever trading competition, the UMich Quant Convention, last semester. We had $1000 in prizes, 100 participants from over 15 different schools, and 9 sponsors (all those mentioned earlier as well as Susquehanna International Group and Optiver)!

There are several misconceptions surrounding quantitative finance and we seek to nullify them: many people think you have to be a genius or that you have to work 70 hour weeks in this industry, however this couldn't be further from the truth! Really, the people who thrive the most in industry are normal smart folks who understand and are able to apply fundamental concepts excellently! Also, quantitative finance is very similar to tech in the regard that it is not a job that is meant to stress you out or have you overworked - many find that the industry is much more relaxed and collaborative than it gives off!

Through a rigorous and thorough education department, an extensive focus on networking with peers within and out of the club, recruiters, and companies, and a strong sense of community, we seek to enable everyone at UMich to enter the world of quantitative finance.

A few of our offerings are as follows:

- Hundreds of interview preparation materials

- Pdfs of several industry "must-reads"

- Multiple social events each month to tighten bonds and a sense of community within the club

- Strategic partnerships with similar clubs and in industry leaders

- Opportunities to expand your network to interns and full-timers at the best companies in industry (as well as recruiters)

Even if you don't know if "quant" is right for you, we encourage you to ask yourself:

- Do I like solving challenging problems in creative ways?

- Am I very analytical?

- Do I like strategic games like poker and chess?

If the answer to any of these is yes, we encourage you to apply to Traders at Michigan because you may be destined for this field and you just don't know it yet!
Summary: Quantitative Finance (Trading and Research) is a very mysterious field. We seek to educate students at UMich so that they're informed and prepared enough to enter industry! We host the UMich College Poker Tournament and UMich Trading Competition!

Name: Transfer Support Society
Description: TSS is a club for transfer students at the University of Michigan looking for resources to improve their experience socially and academically. Our club focuses on mental health and building a tight-knit community through activities, study sessions, etc.
Summary: TSS is a club for transfer students at the University of Michigan looking for resources to improve their experience socially and academically. Our club focuses on mental health and building a tight-knit community through activities, study sessions, etc.

Name: Trash Club
Description: School for Environment & Sustainability circular economy and degrowth club.
Summary: School for Environment & Sustainability circular economy and degrowth club.

Name: Treasuring Christ Collegiate Ministry at the University of Michigan
Description: TCCM’s purpose is to mobilize students to seek the good of the campus and live on mission through tangibly serving the needs of others, building a passion for God’s Word, cultivating community, fostering a desire for evangelism and discipleship, training for Christian leadership, equipping students to understand the implication of faith for their work, and connecting students to the local church.
Summary: TCCM is a student organization that seeks to multiply disciples of Jesus Christ who will delight in, declare, and display the Gospel in all of life and for the good of the University of Michigan.

Name: Trial Advocacy Society
Description: The Trial Advocacy Society (TAS) is an organization that encourages Michigan Law students to learn trial advocacy skills and equip them to pursue careers as trial lawyers. TAS offers law students opportunities to meet practicing trial attorneys, attend speaker events focused on trial theory and evidence, and participate in student-taught workshops on trial skills. To give students an opportunity to use their skills in practice, TAS coordinates tryouts, practices, and travel logistics for the Michigan Law School Mock Trial Team -- a select group of students who compete against other law school mock trial teams at regional and national tournaments. By providing opportunities to learn, practice, and compete, TAS aims to help law students gain the skills and knowledge necessary to be effective trial-level litigators.
Summary: The Trial Advocacy Society (TAS) is an organization focused on encouraging law students to learn trial advocacy skills through training workshops, speaker events, and mock trial competitions.

Name: Triangle Fraternity Michigan Chapter
Description:
At first glance, Triangle seems like a student organization that wanted to be in the Greek system but did not want Greek letters. However Triangle, in every sense, breaks the mold of what a fraternity is and ought to be. The original founders chose to not have Greek letters because they did not want an organization that loosely focused on one thing. Rather, this fraternity was established as a means to create a close-knit community of like-minded men that focused their efforts on several core aspects of life and strived to achieve the perfect balance between work, play, and service to the community.

So what is Triangle Fraternity? At the University of Michigan, Triangle is a community of various students studying technical programs, such as engineering, biology, neuroscience, and architecture, centered around its chapter home and its core values. The members strive for the balanced lifestyle and forge lifelong friendships along the way. At the national level, Triangle Fraternity is an organization that seeks to develop men as leaders and create a widespread network of individuals dedicated to personal growth, brotherhood, and their professional interests.

Each member joins Triangle for a different reason, but every member is able to find an atmosphere which fosters friendship and academic, social, and professional growth.
Summary: A social fraternity that recruits men studying engineering, the sciences, or architecture.

Name: Trotter Multicultural Center
Description:
Hours of Operation

Monday - Friday: 8:00am to 12:00am
Saturday and Sunday: 10:00am to 12:00am
Summary: The Trotter Multicultural Center offers facilities and programs to provide a supportive environment in which all students can learn, strive, and grow at the University of Michigan.

Name: Turkey Treaty
Description: The Turkey Treaty is dedicated to fostering awareness, understanding, and coexistence between the campus community and our resident turkey population. Our mission is to educate students, faculty, and staff on why turkeys are present on campus, their ecological role, and best practices for peaceful interaction with them. Through outreach, workshops, and informational campaigns, we aim to cultivate a respectful and informed campus environment where both humans and turkeys can thrive.
Summary: Turkey Treaty aims to spread awareness on turkey safety with regards to students on the University of Michigan Campus.

Name: Turkic Student Association
Description: The Turkic Student Association aims to foster unity among students from Turkic countries at the University of Michigan. The organization is dedicated to promoting the rich cultures, languages, and traditions of Turkic nations, creating a space where students can connect and celebrate their shared heritage. Through events such as culture nights, celebrations, and discussions about the history and diversity of Turkic countries, the association strives to build a vibrant and supportive community on campus. By encouraging collaboration and engagement, it serves as a bridge between students and their cultural roots while fostering mutual understanding among the broader university community.
Summary: The Turkic Student Association aims to foster unity among students from Turkic countries at the University of Michigan. It focuses on promoting the rich cultures, languages, and traditions of Turkic nations through events, discussions, and activities.

Name: Turkish Student Association at the University of Michigan
Description: The Turkish Student Association (TSA) is a social, cultural, non-political, and non-religious organization dedicated to fostering unity within the Turkish community and celebrating Turkish culture on campus. The association welcomes and engages participants from all backgrounds who are interested in Turkish culture. TSA's mission extends beyond social and cultural activities; it also acts as a resource for prospective and current students, providing valuable insights into life at the University of Michigan and the Ann Arbor area. Throughout the semester, TSA organizes a wide array of events and gatherings that aim to strengthen connections within the broader Turkish community and to share the vibrant culture of Turkey with the wider campus community.
Summary: TSA aims to promote Turkish culture on campus by organizing various events and meetings. We also provide information to prospective and current students about the life in Ann Arbor. We are open to everyone who wants to celebrate the Turkish culture.

Name: Turn Up Turnout
Description: Turn Up Turnout (TUT) is an organization dedicated to increasing youth voter turnout in the United States, especially in midterm elections. Our efforts include voter registration, education, and turnout mobilization. Join us if you are passionate about promoting voting among your peers.
Summary: Turn Up Turnout (TUT) is an organization dedicated to increasing youth voter turnout in the United States, especially in midterm elections. TUT initiated the Big Ten Voting Challenge.

Name: Turning Point USA at University of Michigan Ann Arbor
Description:
Educate || Empower || Organize

Turning Point USA, a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, educates students about the importance of free markets, limited government, and personal liberty through non-partisan debate, dialogue, and discussion.
Summary:
Educate || Empower || Organize

Turning Point USA, a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization, educates students about the importance of free markets, limited government, and personal liberty through non-partisan debate, dialogue, and discussion.

Name: Tutors for Refugee Education Equality
Description:
Tutors for Refugee Education Equality (TREE) is an organization founded and based in Ann Arbor, Michigan at the University of Michigan. Our members are undergraduate and graduate volunteer tutors at the University of Michigan. We provide free personalized tutoring (virtual) to refugee children/children of refugees of all ages. We are in connection with several refugee assisting organizations across Michigan that pass along our info to anyone who may need it. 

 

The tutors in TREE are all volunteers. This is a great opportunity to receive consistent volunteer hours! We hold the requirement that all volunteers meet with their assigned student once a week for at least an hour. Training and guiding educational materials will be provided for reference. Sorting out the time, duration, and other logistical information is left to the tutor to arrange with the student in a way that works with both of their schedules. 

 

This is a great opportunity for those looking for teaching experience, volunteer hours, and a way to make a positive impact in the world around. If you would like to join, please email treeexecutive@umich.edu.
Summary: Tutors for Refugee Education Equality (TREE) is an organization founded and based in Ann Arbor, Michigan at the University of Michigan. We provide free personalized tutoring to refugee children/children of refugees aged kindergarten to 12th grade.

Name: Tzu Ching
Description: Tzu Ching, or Tzu Chi Collegiate Association [TCCA] at UM, is a student-led and run student organization that focuses on empowering our world through community action and reflection. TCCA has its core focuses on international relief, medicine, education and culture.  We promote environmental protection and conservation to fundraising for natural disasters. TCCA works to improve the campus through efforts related with Tzu Chi, an international relief non-profit organization.
Summary: Tzu Ching, or Tzu Chi Collegiate Association at UM, is a student-led and run student organization that focuses on empowering our world through community action and reflection.

Name: U-M Transit Services
Description: Join the Team that MAKES BLUE GO!! U-M Transit has a staff of over 100 student and non-student bus drivers that help provide the daily bus service on our Ann Arbor campuses. U-M Transit is a friendly, fun, and supportive place to work. The work is rewarding, the flexibility is ideal, and the opportunities to earn your CDL and gain valuable work experience can help you make the most of your time here! Most importantly, we know school is your priority and we're ready to work with your busy schedule! Safety is our first priority, and it starts with training! All of our training is conducted one-on-one. You'll work with our experienced and dedicated student training staff to: *Get your Commercial Driver's License. *Learn how to safely and comfortably operate our buses. *Learn how to confidently and reliably drive our routes. We'll pay you to train and cover your testing fees. It's a challenging program, but we'll work with you every step of the way! Trainees earn $16/hr and move to $18/hr after completing training Applicants must be current U-M students with at least 3 semesters remaining. Apply Now: https://ltp.umich.edu/campus-transit/transit-careers/
Summary: Join the Team that MAKES BLUE GO!! U-M Transit has a staff of over 100 student and non-student bus drivers that help provide the daily bus service on our Ann Arbor campuses.

Name: Ulman Foundation Cancer to 5K
Description: Cancer to 5K is a national program created by The Ulman Foundation that provides cancer survivors with a 12-week training program to run or walk a goal 5K race. During this program, student volunteers meet with survivors twice a week to train together. The focus of the program is connecting cancer survivors and helping them regain strength and trust in their bodies after cancer.
Summary: Cancer to 5K is a training program for cancer survivors to run or walk a goal 5K race. Student volunteers meet with survivors twice a week to train together, helping survivors regain strength and trust in their bodies after cancer.

Name: UM-SJTU Joint Institute Alumni Association
Description: Under the strategic partnership between the University of Michigan and Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU), the UM-SJTU Joint Institute (JI, https://umji.sjtu.edu.cn) was founded to cultivate a new generation of leaders who are able to corporate and innovate in a global context. The collaboration between the two universities started with engineering majors in 2006 and has now expanded to business, science, etc. Every year more than 150 SJTU students come to UM through the dual degree (2+2), GDP (3+2), or joint graduate (4+1) programs. As the official student organization recognized by both universities, UM-SJTU Joint Institute Alumni Association (JIA) is completely run by graduated and current SJTU students and is aimed at serving the SJTU students and alumni at UM. We work with both universities as well as industry partners to provide professional development resources, culture immersion programs, and networking opportunities. We help the students and alumni be involved and successful at UM. In addition, JIA also serves as a community builder by connecting cross-culture and cross-industry talents together. We work closely with the alumni association from both universities. President and advisors of JIA also serve on the board of directors of the SJTU Alumni Association in Greater Michigan (SJTUAAMI).
Summary: The UM-SJTU Joint Institute Alumni Association aims to create a vibrant social network for students, scholars, and alumni who have participated in the partnership programs between Shanghai Jiao Tong University and the University of Michigan.

Name: UM::Autonomy
Description:
Interested in joining the team for 2024-2025? Fill out our interest form for information about our mass meeting and to sign up for coffee chats (free coffee!) with team officers: https://forms.gle/MMrAUHdfYhWRmkTL7

We are an engineering team that designs, fabricates, and programs a robotic surface vessel that can navigate obstacles and perform tasks on the open water all on its own with no human interaction. Working year-round, the team competes internationally against other autonomous boats every March in RoboNation's RoboBoat Competition in Sarasota, Florida. Last season, we took home 6th out of 28 teams, and won two awards - but this year, we're chasing the top. 

 

Our team is multidisciplinary, and has no barrier to entry - we encourage students from all different schools and colleges within the university with only a persistent curiosity and good spirits required. The goal of the team is to create a functional, efficient vessel while seeking out opportunities for learning and growth every step of the way. Bringing up questions and proposing adjustments are encouraged, as they help make a more cohesive team and a better overall product.

 

The team is split up into five main subteams: Mechanical, Electrical, AI, Advanced Capabilities, and Business.

 

The mechanical team designs and fabricates a new boat for competition each year, employing naval architecture and marine engineering principles to create resilient, waterproof hulls that can cut smoothly through the water, and a deck and superstructure that can support and protect the electronics housed within the boat. In addition, they provide support for mounting sensors onboard and help facilitate the boat's testing in the water in the Marine Hydrodynamics Laboratory. Students majoring in ME, NAME, ISME, RE, and many others can find their interests here!

 

Our electrical team is responsible for all electronics onboard - they ensure that the boat has a reliable, safe electrical system capable of supporting the immense amount of software running on deck, which is crucial to our overall performance. Every year, they build a full computer capable of supporting our AI team's work, designing printed circuit boards (PCBs), and protecting everything in secure housing. Students majoring in Computer and Electrical Engineering, as well as those interested in integrated systems in general, are encouraged to join!

 

The AI team develops all of the boat's software, and consists of the bulk of our team - without them, our boat would simply be a sitting duck. Their team consists of multiple parts - Computer Vision, Task Planning, and Navigation/Controls. All of these make up a software pipeline that work in tandem to perceive tasks and obstacles, plan paths around or toward them, and navigate the boat according to that path. Computer Science and Robotics Engineering students, as well as anyone interested in programming, is encouraged to join!

 

The Advanced Capabilities team is an interdisciplinary unit that works closely with other subteams to develop task-specific hardware and software that can vary wildly with the changes in competition challenges every year. Members work on specific mechanisms, and are responsible for everything from CAD, electronics, and embedded software, while ensuring integration with other subteams. 

 

Lastly, the Business team is what holds our team together - not only do they coordinate the finances and budget for the team, working to secure private sponsorships and manage funding, but they also market the team to the rest of the university and the world. Through outreach events, interaction with other teams and even some of our competition, to managing our technical documentation and presentation material for both our judges and the sponsors we work with, they ensure a unified brand and a team that can continue to reach new heights. While STEM students are highly encouraged, the business team also offers endless opportunities for those from any other discipline - everything from art, to writing, to business, to management is crucial to our team's success. 

 

Our team welcomes all, and encourages opportunities to learn, grow, and build the most important ship of all - friendship! If you have an interest in helping create an unmanned vessel, come join the team!

 

More information can be found at www.umautonomy.com

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZxFV9WLaQ88
Summary: UM::Autonomy is an award-winning autonomous boat team where students work together to create an autonomous surface vessel capable of navigating obstacles and performing tasks using AI for the RoboBoat Competition. Join us and learn more at umautonomy.com

Name: UMHealthResearch.org - Michigan Institute for Clinical & Health Research
Description: The Michigan Institute for Clinical and Health Research (MICHR) at the University of Michigan, developed an online platform (UMHealthResearch.org), that connects the community to research studies taking place at the University. The goal is to spread awareness about health research, and allow participants to search for studies of interest. Most studies will compensate participants for their time.
Summary: The Michigan Institute for Clinical and Health Research (MICHR) at the University of Michigan, developed an online platform (UMHealthResearch.org), that connects the community to research studies taking place at the University.

Name: Uncover
Description: Uncover provides a platform for A/PIA individuals to tell their own story. Our mission is to promote connection and understanding while challenging stereotypes associated with the A/PIA identity by showcasing the diverse narratives in our community.
Summary: Uncover provides a platform for A/PIA individuals to tell their own story. Our mission is to promote connection and understanding while challenging stereotypes associated with the A/PIA identity by showcasing the diverse narratives in our community.

Name: Undergraduate American Medical Women's Association
Description: American Medical Women’s Association undergraduate branch at the University of Michigan unites students to work to create a diverse community dedicated to women in medicine, through education, leadership, and advocacy.
Summary: American Medical Women’s Association undergraduate branch at the University of Michigan unites students to work to create a diverse community dedicated to women in medicine, through education, leadership, and advocacy.

Name: Undergraduate Consulting at Ross
Description: Undergraduate Consulting at Ross (UCAR) serves to create a community of driven undergraduates through their common interest in consulting as a career path. Through workshops, keynote presentations, and hands-on learning UCAR prepares its members for the consulting recruiting cycle and allows individuals to practice fundamental skills in a safe environment.
Summary: The mission of Undergraduate Consulting at Ross is to create a community of future business leaders interested in pursuing consulting as a career path and to provide undergraduates with the tools necessary to succeed.

Name: Undergraduate Entertainment & Media Club
Description: The Undergraduate Entertainment & Media Club is a student-run organization for University of Michigan students from all majors actively pursuing careers in the Entertainment industry. EMC aims to support undergraduate students with an interest in the Entertainment industry (film & television, media, sports, music, and gaming) through professional development and community building.
Summary: Undergraduate student organization for students interested in careers in the entertainment industry. All majors welcomed!

Name: Undergraduate Hall of Phi Delta Phi at the University of Michigan
Description:
The Undergraduate Hall of Phi Delta Phi at the University of Michigan, known colloquially as PDP, was established in 2019 as a premier pre-professional legal honor society and co-educational fraternity to promote advancing the highest intellectual, professional, and ethical standards within the University community. With an equitable emphasis on brotherhood, professional development, philanthropy, and service, the around 60 brothers of Phi Delta Phi find success in the fields of law, government, consulting, finance, business, and more.

 

Phi Delta Phi was established in 1869 at the University of Michigan Law School to promote a higher standard of professional ethics and is among the oldest and most prestigious legal organizations in the United States. It is uniquely positioned in the U.S. history of the bench, bar, and law schools. With over 200,000 lifetime members, Phi Delta Phi’s reputation as an organization devoted to legal excellence has spread worldwide, with many successful chapters in North America, Central America, and Europe.

 

Direct questions about Phi Delta Phi to Vice President of Recruitment Shane Baum at smbaum@umich.edu.
Summary: Phi Delta Phi Michigan Hall was established in 2019 as a premier pre-professional legal honor society and co-educational fraternity to promote advancing the highest intellectual, professional, and ethical standards within the University community.

Name: Undergraduate Political Science Association
Description: UPSA hosts events and workshops designed to facilitate a better understanding of politics and political issues on campus. We also host many events that allow students to get to know our amazing Political Science faculty in a smaller, more intimate setting. We additionally host guest speakers, trivia nights, watch parties, and many more fun events!
Summary: The Undergraduate Political Science (UPSA) is a non-partisan organization established to create a community for Political Science undergraduates at UM and aims to serve as a liaison between students and the Political Science faculty and department.

Name: Undergraduate Psychology Society
Description:
The Undergraduate Psychology Society (UPS) is a student-run organization that aims to provide support for undergraduates majoring in psychology, as well as other students interested in the field. This support shall include academic and networking related events designed to help further our members’ goals. Although UPS is primarily an academic organization, we also plan community service and social events, in order to stress the need for a well rounded college experience and to facilitate high quality connections with fellow psych concentrators, graduate students and faculty. Ultimately, UPS aspires to act as an arena for discussion and a valuable resource for its members. We also serve to ensure that the voices and opinions of psychology concentrators are heard by the department.

Link to the website: https://umichups1.wixsite.com/undergraduate-psycho
Summary: The Undergraduate Psychology Society (UPS) provides support for undergraduates studying psychology. We plan events that function to help students to learn about opportunities and develop interests in psychology.

Name: Undergraduate Student National Dental Association Chapter at the University of Michigan
Description: The USNDA aids in the advancement and retention of minority students within the field of dentistry by connecting like-minded undergraduate students in achieving their goals of becoming a dentist. USNDA provides opportunities to serve the community with various volunteering events, facilitates mentorship between members of the Student National Dental Association (SNDA) here at the University of Michigan and provides opportunities to connect and shadow dentists. Members also get to connect with speakers with relevant social, service, professional, and educational information about the field of dentistry.
Summary: The USNDA is the undergraduate chapter for the National Dental Association (NDA) and we uphold NDA's values by aiding in the advancement and retention of minority students within the field of dentistry.

Name: Underrepresented Biomedical Engineers
Description: Our goal is to provide a community space for students interested in biomedical engineering, medical research and the biotech industry that offers support, resources, and space to learn, connect, and grow.
Summary: Our goal is to provide a community space for students interested in the biomedical engineering field.

Name: UNICEF at the University of Michigan
Description:
The United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) works in 190 countries and territories to save children's lives, defend their rights, and help them fulfill their potential from early childhood through adolescence. The UNICEF Campus Initiative at the University of Michigan plays a powerful role in this mission. As one of more than 600 active Campus Initiative Clubs around the country, members of the UNICEF chapter at the University of Michigan strive to educate, advocate and fundraise on behalf of UNICEF to reach zero preventable deaths. 

Interested in joining? Fill out this interest form to stay updated.
Summary: The United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) works in 190 countries and territories to save children's lives, to defend their rights, and to help them fulfill their potential from early childhood through adolescence.

Name: United 2 Heal
Description:
United 2 Heal (U2H) is an undergraduate-run nonprofit humanitarian organization at the University of Michigan that helps eliminate global health disparities by collecting, sorting, and shipping surplus medical supplies to countries in need.

 

Every Saturday morning, we provide rides to World Medical Relief in Southfield, where we assist in sorting and packing donated medical supplies to be sent off to communities around the world lacking access to adequate healthcare. Our volunteers are also involved in Project My Heart Your Heart, a clinical research project to safely sort, refurbish, and sterilize used, donated pacemakers for reuse by those in need abroad ━ we directly assist in this project by cleaning, interrogating, and de-leading thousands of pacemakers. 

 

Our club also aims to foster connections among its members beyond just volunteering activities. We hold weekly member meetings, some of which are focused on professional development, including workshops and presentations geared toward pre-health students. We also host regular member socials, ranging from cider mill trips to movie nights to group study sessions! 

 

For more information and to see more of our club, check out our Instagram (@u2h.umich) or our website u2h.org!

 

If you're interested in joining us, get on our email list by filling out the form at the bottom of our website :)
Summary: United 2 Heal (U2H) is an undergraduate-run nonprofit humanitarian organization at the University of Michigan that helps eliminate global health disparities by collecting, sorting, and shipping surplus medical supplies to countries in need.

Name: United Asian American Medical Student Association
Description: We are the United Asian American Medical Student Association (UAAMSA) at the University of Michigan Medical School, a chapter of the Asian Pacific American Medical Student Association (APAMSA). Our organization was established to support the health care and community needs of patients, students, and medical professionals in the greater southeast Michigan area. Not only are we committed to improving health care services and education, but also to building connections and bringing our community closer together.  Past events have included attending the National APAMSA Conferences, organizing mentorship dinners with faculty members, hosting physician panels, and running annual health fairs for the benefit of those in our community.
Summary: A chapter of APAMSA dedicated to supporting the health care and community needs of patients, students, and medical professionals by improving healthcare services and education, building connections, and bringing the AAPI community together.

Name: United Asian American Organizations
Description: The United Asian American Organizations was established in 1988 to work in unity with the Asian American community on campus. We are a coalition group representing various Asian American organizations on campus. Our aim is to serve as the liaison and collaboration agent for diverse Asian American organizations at UM, promote awareness of Asian American issues, serve as a political voice for Asian American organizations on campus, and develop relationships with other POC groups on campus and Asian American organizations outside of UM.
Summary: The United Asian American Organizations serves as a unified voice for Asian American communities at UM, connecting and supporting more than 25 member organizations and legacy programs through community organizing and collaborative programming.

Name: United Students Against Sweatshops at the University of Michigan
Description: United Students Against Sweatshops advocates for the rights of workers worldwide, especially those in the garment industry and especially those that sew apparel for universities. USAS is a national student organization that has existed for decades and has made significant positive impacts on global garment supply chains through our university activism. U of M has a $174 million contract with Nike for our university apparel, and USAS aims to keep the University and Nike accountable to our Code of Conduct ensuring the rights of these workers to collective bargaining, fair wages, and safe working conditions are respected. USAS is also involved in the broader movement to advocate for ethics in textile & garment supply chains.
Summary: USAS at U-M is a student group dedicated to fighting for university and corporate accountability regarding international supply chain ethics, particularly within the University of Michigan's sphere of influence.

Name: Universities Allied for Essential Medicines
Description:
https://www.uaem.org/mvv

Our vision is a world where universities play a key role in promoting access to life-saving medicines and technologies for all, regardless of income. We encourage students to become leaders, advocators, and passionate supporters to create a better world!
Summary: Our vision is a world where universities play a key role in promoting access to life-saving medicines and technologies for all, regardless of income. We encourage students to become leaders, advocators, and passionate supporters to create a better world!

Name: Universities Allied for Essential Medicines - University of Michigan Law
Description:
Our Mission is simple but powerful: we work to promote access to medicines and medical innovations, change norms and practices in academic patenting and licensing, and empower students to advocate for a biomedical R&D system that works for everyone. Guided by principles of non-partisanship, democracy, transparency, solidarity and respect, we are a non-profit organization driven by the passion and commitment of our members.

As students from all over the world, we stand united in our belief that access to medicines is a basic human right. Universities have a social contract with society, and as educational and research institutions, they have a responsibility to promote and manage the deployment of innovations for the public benefit. With the intellectual sophistication, rigor and integrity of our members, we will fight for increased innovation and access to medicines and health-related technologies for all.
Summary: UAEM works to promote access to medicines and medical innovations, change norms and practices in academic patenting and licensing, and empower students to advocate for a biomedical R&D system that works for everyone.

Name: University Activities Center
Description: To provide the campus community with a wide array of cultural, social, educational, and artistic programming while creating opportunities for the development of students through a full range of experiential learning.
Summary: UAC is composed of eighteen student committees whose common goal is to provide the very best in entertainment and extra-curricular enrichment at the University of Michigan.

Name: University Blood Initiative at The University of Michigan
Description:
Our chapter of the University Blood Initiative at the University of Michigan is part of a larger grassroots organization dedicated to combating local blood shortages in the Ann Arbor area. Our mission to support local blood centers through empowering, motivating, and educating blood donors both on campus and in our community. We are different from other blood drive orientated organizations in that we collect donations that stay local. All blood donations that go through us help serve the local community. Giving blood is one of the easiest ways to save lives, through local donations, we can make a big impact on Michigan. 

Our core values center around education, leadership, community, and a passion for our cause. We want to advocate for increased blood donation in our campus community so that we can establish a strong foundation of united blood donors in the next generation. We organize and sponsor blood drives in the Ann Arbor and Metro Detroit area, connect with other organizations in Michigan to educate youth, and are constantly growing in the ways in which we support blood donation.
Summary: Our chapter of the University Blood Initiative at the University of Michigan is part of a larger grassroots organization dedicated to combating local blood shortages in the Ann Arbor and Metro-Detroit area.

Name: University Career Center
Description:
The Career Center is a diverse, professionally trained career development team employing a student-centered, multicultural, educational approach to meet your career needs.

Mission Statement

The Career Center is committed to preparing University of Michigan students and alumni/ae to be active, life-long learners in developing and implementing their career decisions. Guided by theory and reflective practice, The Career Center facilitates clients' overall development and provides resources to help them explore and pursue their career and educational goals in a complex, diverse and interconnected world. The Career Center forges appropriate partnerships with the University community, as well as employers and educational institutions, to support our clients. In these ways, The Career Center fosters meaningful links between education and fulfilling lives.

Principles of Service

Our expectation: To assist you in achieving your goals
Students are at the center of our work, and our goal is to intentionally enhance your educational experience. We hope to exceed your expectations through friendly service from knowledgeable staff.

Our approach: Educational, respectful, flexible, and creative
The Career Center has high office standards and draws on our staff's strengths and expertise to deliver comprehensive, innovative services. We employ a team-oriented approach within an environment that both challenges and supports you and our staff.

Our impact: Helping you contribute to a multicultural society
Through our services, The Career Center strives to create experiences that foster reflection on actions and beliefs. Through these experiences we hope to contribute to your learning and enrich the contribution you make to a multicultural society. We challenge ourselves, as well, to cultivate an open and accepting learning environment.

Our practice: Intentional continuous improvement
Using a theoretical orientation, national benchmarking and input from you, we actively engage in continuous improvement of our services and resources.
Summary: Internship, career and graduate school coaching, connections and resources brought to you by The Career Center at the University of Michigan

Name: University Christian Outreach
Description:
UCO is a community of disciples on mission. Our goal is to lead university students into a personal, mature relationship with Jesus Christ and prepare them for a life of radical discipleship. We long to see God's kingdom be established in the hallways, classrooms, houses and dorms on campus. 

We meet weekly for prayer meetings and bible studies, form men's and women's groups, hold retreats and organize social activities (sometimes crazy ones).
Summary: Founded in 1965, UCO is an ecumenical Christian group enriching our faith as students.

Name: University Lutheran Chapel Student Group
Description: University Lutheran Chapel is an LCMS Lutheran Church located in downtown Ann Arbor. We also have the Common Cup Coffeehouse in the basement! We meet for weekly All Student Gathering on Wednesday evenings to study the Bible and share a free meal, and we also host other social events throughout the school year!
Summary: An official group for students who attend (and who want to attend) University Lutheran Chapel on Washtenaw Ave.

Name: University Musical Society Student Committee
Description:
Gain experience in arts administration, grassroots marketing, and event production.

The University Musical Society Student Committee (UMSSC) is a U-M student organization that connects students across campus to the arts and provides professional development opportunities for its members.

Committee members host events, attend performances together, reach out to students across the university, meet professionals in the performing arts field, and have the opportunity to earn free tickets to UMS events. All U-M students are invited to join!
Summary: The University Musical Society Student Committee (UMSSC) is a U-M student organization that connects students across campus to the arts and provides professional development opportunities for its members.

Name: University of Michigan 3D Printing Club
Description: The University of Michigan 3D Printing Club organizes projects, competitions, and collaborative learning workshops to ultimately enhance knowledge and increase interest in the field of additive manufacturing. A new project is introduced every semester of the school year. All majors are welcome - 3D printing is applicable to all majors.
Summary: The University of Michigan 3D Printing Club strives to bring together 3D printing enthusiasts across campus to advance the science and art of additive manufacturing and providing learning materials to interested groups.

Name: University of Michigan Active Citizens - Alternative Spring Break
Description: Michigan Active Citizens (MAC) is a student organization at the University of Michigan committed to sending students on service-learning based spring break trips since 1990. We accomplish this through established community partnerships with 25 sites, thorough education and training for all site leaders and participants, and thoughtful campus engagement. It is important to us that participants of MAC Alternative Spring Breaks have a holistic understanding of social justice, their selected site topic, and the intersectionality associated with all of our site topics. Our goal is to cultivate a community on the University of Michigan campus of Active Citizens who take part in positive social change for their lives during spring break, their college careers, and their lives after college.
Summary: Alternative Spring Break is a program that encourages learning through community service in communities across America.

Name: University of Michigan Anthropology Club
Description: The goal of our club is to encourage student engagement with all four sub-fields of Anthropology. We aim to provide a unique and laid back experience for aspiring anthropologists, including anthropology and evolutionary anthropology majors, as well as non-majors who are simply curious to learn more about the field. We host academic events including discussions with graduate students and research talks. We also host social events such as game nights and movie screenings.
Summary:
University of Michigan Anthropology Club
Group for all students interested in the different facets of anthropological study.

Name: University of Michigan Archaeology Club
Description:
The continuum of human culture and history by preservation, interpretation, and learning through archaeology. The University of Michigan Archaeology Club is aimed towards professional and community development in the field of archaeology. Offering workshops (e.g. bioarchaeology, archaeobotany, ceramics, funding, etc), experimental archaeology (e.g. making ceramics, flint knapping, wind tunneling, etc), lectures or seminars, training and experience opportunities (e.g. field school, volunteering, research, internships, etc). 

 

Both a social science and a humanities, we question and then work to understand. Transcending stratigraphic divide to represent the human past. The theoretical to the topical, searching for the unexcavated, or better yet, the unanswered. Evolving social and environmental adaptations, analysis of complex transitions and organizations in ancient societies, to emerging sedentism and agriculture, together we can conceptualize the past to better the present and our future.
Summary: The University of Michigan Archaeology Club provides a continuum of human knowledge by means of preservation, learning, and interpretation. We offer both professional and community engagement through hands-on learning and research opportunities.

Name: University of Michigan Asylum Collaborative
Description:
The Asylum Collaborative (UMAC) was conceptualized in 2012 and founded in 2013 by student members of the University of Michigan Medical School chapter of Physicians for Human Rights. In partnership with the University of Michigan Law School, Physicians for Human Rights and community organizations such as Freedom House, this student-led initiative empowers medical professionals and students to advocate for victims and survivors of human rights violations and serve as a voice for those who have limited access to such resources. Our focus is to facilitate inter-professional collaboration between pro bono legal and medical providers to conduct forensic evaluations and medical affidavits for asylum, human trafficking, and other cases that have experienced human rights abuses. We also seek to educate providers and medical students to recognize and advocate for victims of torture and abuse in clinical practice. Our goal is to establish and work with a consortium of providers in the Midwest to provide forensic medical evaluations to support legal cases. Working closely with the national organizing Physicians for Human Rights (PHR), the University of Michigan Law School, and Freedom House Detroit, members invest in projects that challenge the boundaries of the physician’s role and act to protect human rights both in the United States and abroad.  

 

Evaluation requests should be submitted via email to UMACevaluations@med.umich.edu.

For general inquiries, please email umasylumcollaborative@med.umich.edu
Summary: The Asylum Collaborative mobilizes health professionals to advocate for victims and survivors of human rights violations. UMAC members conduct forensic medical evaluations to support legal cases for asylum and human trafficking.

Name: University of Michigan Bodybuilding Club
Description: Michigan Bodybuilding Club aims to educate and inspire members to achieve their physical fitness goals and maximize hypertrophy. We will present and debate the current scientific literature surrounding resistance training and exercise programming.
Summary: Michigan Bodybuilding Club aims to educate and inspire members to achieve their physical fitness goals and maximize hypertrophy. We will present and debate the current scientific literature surrounding resistance training and exercise programming.

Name: University of Michigan Central Student Government
Description: The Central Student Government (CSG) is the primary and central student government of the University of Michigan, representing students from all university schools and colleges. CSG is the primary funding source for UM registered student organizations through the Student Organization Funding Committee and Wolverine Consulting Group.  CSG also oversees the AirBus program, a non-profit transportation service for UM students from UM campus to the Detroit Metro airport, during the university breaks.
Summary: The Central Student Government (CSG) is the primary and central student government of the Univeristy of Michigan, representing students from all university schools and colleges. CSG is the primary funding source for U-M registered student organizations.

Name: University of Michigan Cheer Team
Description: Athletics
Summary: Athletics

Name: University of Michigan Chem-E-Car
Description: The ChemE Car team is responsible for designing, testing and building a shoe-box sized car that starts, runs, and stops solely on chemical reactions. Competitions sponsored by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE) establish a pre-determined distance that our car is required to travel for each race. Our organization prides itself on bringing together students of different disciplines, levels of expertise and backgrounds in order to not only advance our car, but also offer an opportunity to connect and learn from each other.
Summary: The University of Michigan Chem-E-Car provides student engineers with hands-on experience on a multi-disciplinary student project team. We design, build, test, and compete with shoe-box-sized cars powered by chemical reactions.

Name: University of Michigan Club Gymnastics
Description: Club gym is a student run, co-ed athletic club. We aim to make gymnastics accessible for all students, regardless of background, experience, or financial barriers. Our club is no cut- anyone can join! Our practices are on campus year-round, serving as the perfect break and athletic outlet from the stress of the school year. We compete for the University of Michigan at NAIGC events around the nation, and work together to keep doing the sport that we love!
Summary: We practice and compete for the love of sport. Our team strives to create a sense of unity and give all individuals the chance to continue or begin participating in gymnastics, creating an uplifting and supportive community outside of the classroom.

Name: University of Michigan Club Triathlon Team
Description: M-Tri's mission is to promote a healthy lifestyle focused on fitness through the emerging sport of triathlon. We have over 70 active members that attend practices, competitions, socials, and fundraising events throughout the year. Attendance at every practice and race is not mandatory. We are sponsored by Zoot Sports, Blanks Sports Nutrition, and Rudy Project North America. Learn more about our club in the following video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D6ABI0jPfMc
Summary: The U-M Club Triathlon Team is a student-run organization focused on promoting the multi-sport lifestyle at the collegiate level.  As a member of the Mideast Collegiate Triathlon Conference, the club works to develop a strong community of triathletes.

Name: University Of Michigan Dentistry Student Council
Description:
The purpose of the student council includes:

1. To provide for the student body an effective means of communication with the administration and faculty in order that the student body can express opinions or ideas related to their dental education or any other professional matter.

2. To poll the student body regarding their opinions or concerns in order that The Council accurately and appropriately represents the student body.

3. To innovatively conceive, plan and execute projects and events for the good of the student body, The School of Dentistry, the dental profession, and the community.

4. Organize and facilitate appropriate student recruitment in organizations, events, and functions, as well as host events for the student body such as Student Organizations Fair.

5. Facilitate interprofessional collaboration with other professional students, while providing events that expose undergraduate students to the field of dentistry.
Summary: Dental student council is a student run organization formed to represent the students of the University of Michigan Dental School in matters including but not limited to policy formation, curriculum design and student welfare.

Name: University of Michigan Detroit Center
Description: The University of Michigan Detroit Center is a meeting and events facility in Midtown Detroit. The goal of the Detroit Center is to facilitate engagement between the U-M community and the city of Detroit. The space is available for University units and student organizations to host events in the city and to spark dialogue between city and the University.
Summary: The University of Michigan Detroit Center is a meeting and events facility in Midtown Detroit. The goal of the Detroit Center is to facilitate engagement between the U-M community and the city of Detroit.

Name: University of Michigan Electric Boat
Description: University of Michigan Electric Boat designs, builds, and races an electric boat to compete in multiple events. Past events include the Promoting Electronic Propulsion competition (PEP) hosted by the American Society of Naval Engineers and the Lake of the Ozarks (LOTO) Shootout in Missouri. Our team offers students the unique opportunity to work on a full-scale boat project. Some challenges we face include designing and fabricating a hull and propeller for efficiency and high-speed performance, building an electrical system for high peak power output, integrating controls and software to our mechanical and powertrain sub-projects, and final testing of our vessel before competition.
Summary: University of Michigan Electric Boat designs, builds, and races an electric boat to compete in multiple events.

Name: University of Michigan Esports
Description:
