University of Michigan Esports (Michigan Esports) is a Sponsored Student Organization that falls under the Recreational Sports Department. We currently have 9 sponsored titles: CS2, Dota 2, League of Legends, Overwatch, Rainbow 6, Rocket League, Starcraft II, Super Smash Ultimate, and Valorant. All titles have a varsity team that competes in the highest level collegiate tournaments and most have junior varsity variants that also compete in various collegiate tournaments. Want to compete with us? Reach out to us via email to learn how you can get sponsored to compete under Michigan Esports!

Michigan Esports is the largest gaming community on campus! With our Discord having over 3,500 members and sponsoring over 100 competitors, we are growing esports at Michigan every semester!

Competition isn't our only focus! With such a large community, we host many casual and planned events, such as LAN parties, in-house tournaments, watch parties, sponsored events with giveaways, and much more. To stay up to date with all the latest Michigan Esports news and events, join us on discord by clicking the link below, or follow us on social media!

  • Discord: https://discord.gg/michigan-esports-96777971330748416

 

Competitive gaming can often lead to a toxic environment. Here at Michigan Esports, we are dedicated to creating a safe and inclusive space for all members of our community. All competitive team members are required to attend a workshop on creating a safe environment.


If you have any questions or concerns relating to diversity, equity, and inclusion, please contact the Head of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion via Discord or email.
Summary: We are the official University of Michigan Esports under Recreational Sports.

Name: University of Michigan Figure Skating Club
Description:
Visit our webpage for lots of additional information about our team! https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/umichskating/

(Prospective U-M skater? Check out the 'Prospective Skaters' page where you'll find a link to our interest form and an extensive list of FAQs just for you!)

 

〽️⛸️

 

The University of Michigan Figure Skating Club (UMFSC) is a university organization and U.S. Figure Skating (USFS) collegiate team that offers competitive and recreational opportunities for University of Michigan students.

 

During the school year, the UMFSC team competes at the three midwestern USFS intercollegiate competitions and (if we qualify) at the USFS National Intercollegiate Final as well. The intercollegiate competitions include competitive events in freestyle, solo dance, and 'team maneuvers'.

 

In addition, the UMFSC team hosts multiple showcases at our home rink throughout the year. These public performances are a great chance for skaters to perform for fun and show off their talents to family and friends.

 

UMFSC has three practice sessions per week at our campus rink, Yost Ice Arena. These sessions serve not only as a time to practice individual skills and programs but also as an opportunity for skaters to build team friendships.

 

We currently employ two skate coach professionals from the Ann Arbor Ice Cube as coaches for our team.

 

All UMFSC team members must be current, registered members of USFS in order to be eligible to compete. UMFSC does not provide USFS testing opportunities, but many skaters take advantage of the ice time, coaches, and testing sessions offered at nearby rinks, including the Ann Arbor Ice Cube.
Summary: The University of Michigan Figure Skating Club (UMFSC) is a university organization and U.S. Figure Skating (USFS) collegiate team that offers competitive and recreational opportunities for University of Michigan students.

Name: University of Michigan Gilbert and Sullivan Society
Description:
The University of Michigan Gilbert and Sullivan Society (UMGASS) is delighted to welcome members from the University and from the larger Ann Arbor area to join our cast or crew, or to serve in directorial or production staff positions. As the oldest student-run society dedicated to producing the works of William Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan in the country, UMGASS has presented various operettas from the Gilbert and Sullivan canon for decades.

 

We produce two shows per year: one in the fall semester and one in the winter semester. Both take place in the beautiful Lydia Mendelssohn theater, with full staging and orchestration. If you’re interested in joining us, stop by one of our mass meetings (held at the beginning of each semester), check out umgass.org, or reach out to us at umgassexec@umich.edu.
Summary: The University of Michigan Gilbert and Sullivan Society has been dedicated to performing the theatrical works of William S. Gilbert and Sir Arthur Sullivan for over 70 years.

Name: University of Michigan Hawaii Club
Description: As the University of Michigan Hawaii club, our goal is to promote exposure of the Hawaiian culture and lifestyle to the University of Michigan and Ann Arbor community. This would include social events throughout the year, the type of events that you would expect living in Hawaii. We also believe in the motto “Mālama the ‘Āina” which means to respect the land, therefore we also make efforts to engage in community service such as park /river clean-ups.
Summary: To promote exposure of the Hawaiian culture and lifestyle to the University of Michigan and Ann Arbor community.

Name: University of Michigan History Club
Description:
History Club is the departmental club of the History Department. We work with faculty to have regular discussions with them, in addition to fostering a strong partnership with the Clements library to hold related events. In addition to that we promote finding history outside the classroom through field trips and social events, as well as weekly meetings that cover interesting historical events. Through the History Club, we hope to foster a community of history lovers, both within and outside of the History Department! 

For the 2025 Winter semester, History Club typically meets from 6-7pm on Mondays, but please send an email to HistoryClubExec@umich.edu for more details and to be added to our email list as this may change from week to week. History Club is open to all university students and does not require any form of application.
Summary: The History Club is an inclusive club for any U of M students who have an interest in History. We host weekly meetings with historical interest, speaker talks with professors, trips to interesting sites, and other excellent events.

Name: University of Michigan Industrial Hygiene Student Association
Description:
UMIHSA is a student group for those interested in industrial hygiene and occupational safety.  We are a recognized local student section of the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) and collaborate closely with the Michigan Industrial Hygiene Society(MIHS), which is the local AIHA section. We are also recognized as a student chapter of Workplace Health Without Borders (WHWB) and as such focus on both global and domestic occupational health education.

Our members enjoy the many social events sponsored by UMIHSA as well as the opportunity to network with current industrial hygiene professionals.  In addition, we also provide philanthropic and professional development events to help our members become more well rounded and productive professionals. We work closely with our professors to ensure that our activities consistent with our departmental and program goals.
Summary: The University of Michigan Industrial Hygiene Student Association (UMIHSA) is a student group organization committed to promoting and improving the practice of industrial hygiene.

Name: University of Michigan Journal of Law Reform
Description:
The University of Michigan Journal of Law Reform is one of the country’s foremost academic journals dedicated to promoting legal reform. Across its four issues, annual symposia, and online publication, Caveat, the Journal identifies the critical problems facing domestic decision-makers and presents responsive solutions. In every medium, the Journal provides content that is timely, novel, and focused on reform.

The Journal is one of the oldest and most well respected law and policy publications in the nation. It publishes cutting-edge legal scholarship by both academics and legal practitioners. Established in 1968, the Journal finds its roots in a desire to propose constructive, well-reasoned reforms in all areas of the law.
Summary: Publishes legal academic articles on topics involving law reform.

Name: University of Michigan Library
Description: U-M Library Student Ambassadors are undergraduate students who work for the Library to do outreach to other students through programs and social media.
Summary: U-M Library Student Ambassadors are undergraduate students who work for the Library to do outreach to other students through programs and social media.

Name: University of Michigan Men's Club Soccer (UMMCS)
Description: The University of Michigan Men's Club Soccer team is a student run organization which provides competitive soccer without the time commitment of a varsity program. We strive to build a supportive environment built on family, excellence, and joy. UMMCS is perfect for those who would like to play competitively, yet still have enough time for studying and being social with your friends. We compete in the MASC Conference in NIRSA's Region 3, which spans the Midwest from Michigan to Iowa. Our regular season consists of 10 games within our division, which is made up of teams from Michigan including Michigan State, Western Michigan, and Grand Valley State.
Summary: The University of Michigan Men's Club Soccer team is a student run organization which provides competitive soccer without the time commitment of a varsity program.  We strive to build a supportive environment built on family, excellence, and joy.

Name: University of Michigan Men's Glee Club
Description:
Founded in 1859 on the principles of Tradition, Camaraderie, and Musical Excellence, The University of Michigan Men's Glee Club is one of the oldest collegiate choirs in the United States and the oldest continually-run student organization on the Michigan campus. The group is regarded as one of the world’s finest male choruses, and its members, undergraduate and graduate students chosen by audition at the beginning of both the Fall and Winter terms, represent a majority of the University's 19 schools and colleges. 

Club members serving on the Executive Board and as junior managers are responsible for overseeing all non-musical Club operations. The Glee Club’s musical repertoire ranges from Renaissance motets and opera choruses, to folksongs and spirituals, and, of course, to our signature Michigan songs. The Friars, a nine-member subset of the Glee Club, are in their 64th year and serve as an extension of Club as they maintain an ambitious performing schedule. Please visit our website to learn more about our annual tours, social activities, and everything else that has kept members returning to this organization for over 160 years. Don’t hesitate to reach out to ummgc.info@umich.edu with any further questions!
Summary: Founded in 1859, The University of Michigan Men's Glee Club is one of the oldest collegiate choirs in the nation. The club consists of male and non-binary individuals and its student leadership is responsible for all non-musical aspects of the club.

Name: University of Michigan Powerlifting
Description: Founded in 2021, our team aims to introduce students at the University of Michigan to the world of Powerlifting. We strive for an inclusive and supportive community that prioritizes strength and friendship.
Summary: Founded in 2021, our team aims to introduce students at the University of Michigan to the world of Powerlifting. We strive for an inclusive and supportive community that prioritizes strength and friendship.

Name: University of Michigan Pre-Student Osteopathic Medical Association
Description: UM Pre-SOMA is a club dedicated to pre-med students who are interested in pursuing osteopathic medicine.  The club provides members with volunteer and job shadowing opportunities and a chance to learn more about osteopathic medicine.
Summary: Pre-SOMA is a club dedicated to pre-med students who are interested in pursuing osteopathic medicine. The club provides members with volunteer and job shadowing opportunities with osteopathic physicians.

Name: University of Michigan Rhythm Games Club
Description:
We welcome rhythm game players of all kinds, games of including but not limited to:

maimai

SDVX

osu!

WACCA

Chunithm

 

Please email the Club President for Discord link!
Summary: UMRGC is a safe and chill place for rhythm game lovers from all walks of life! Join us on game nights (at an arcade or custom-made controllers) and meet more people!

Name: University of Michigan Rugby Football Club
Description:
The University of Michigan Rugby Football Club competes against other Big Ten teams in NCR Division 1, the top division of collegiate rugby in the United States. We provide players with a competitive environment aimed at on-field excellence while also offering a supportive, welcoming community for players to engage socially. Founded in 1959, we have an extensive network of thousands of alumni.

 

We play our primary 15s season in the fall and travel across the country to compete in 7s tournaments during the winter semester. Annually during spring break, we go on tour to another country to play local clubs and bond as a team. Players join the team with varied levels of experience and all athletes are welcome.

 

For more information, go to mrugby.com. Want to play? Email mensrugby@umich.edu.
Summary: UMRFC is Michigan's men's rugby team. We compete against other Big Ten teams at the D1A level. Prior rugby experience isn't required; all athletes are welcome.

Name: University of Michigan Sailing Team
Description:
OUR ORGANIZATION

The Michigan Sailing Team is a Club Sport at the University of Michigan. We are affiliated with the Midwest Collegiate Sailing Association (MCSA), a conference in the Intercollegiate Sailing Association (ICSA). Our sailors compete across the Midwest and on both coasts. We sail in both dinghy and keelboat events, and we compete in both co-ed and women's regattas. Our program has consistently qualified for a variety of national sailing events. 

 

TEAM MISSION

To provide opportunities and to represent the University of Michigan across a range of competitive sailing events.

 

TEAM INFO

The team practices at the Michigan Sailing Club on Baseline Lake. We start practicing the first week of school in the fall and as soon as the ice melts in the spring. Practices are held from 3:00 until dark Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday.
 
There are a few ways to join the team.
 
1.) Come to our weekly Monday Meetings (email sailing.exec@umich.edu for the location).
2.) Email sailing.exec@umich.edu or our Sailing Development Chair Grace Redner at gredner@umich.edu for information on Practice Times and Carpools
3.) Email our Communications Chair Ben Visco at benvisco@umich.edu.
 
 
The Michigan Sailing Team owns a fleet of 12 FJ's that are about two years old. FJ's and 420's are the standard boats for MCSA regattas. By joining the Michigan Sailing Team each member also becomes a member of the Michigan Sailing Club and gains access to its fleet of 14 JY-15's and 5 Lasers. We are always looking to improve our fleet and we do a large amount of fundraising every year to support our fleet replacement fund.
 
The team is run entirely by its elected executive board and general membership. If you have any questions or comments please contact the executive board or the listed contacts.
Summary: The University of Michigan Sailing Team is a competitive dinghy and keelboat team within the Midwest Collegiate Sailing Association (MCSA).

Name: University of Michigan Science Olympiad
Description:
Science Olympiad is a nationally recognized competition that involves teams of 15 students competing in 23 different events related to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Events range from Electric Vehicle, in which participants design, program, and build an electric locomotive device that has enough precision and speed to stop at a tiny dot several meters away in just 4 seconds, to Chemistry Lab, where participants complete an especially rigorous written test and physical lab based on two fields of chemistry. Science Olympiad events introduce students to new fields in science and technology, that they might not have otherwise found a passion in. Also, many events test concepts and ideas that would be found in college-level textbooks and classes. More details about Science Olympiad’s philosophy, events, and annual competitions can be found at soinc.org.

Members of the UM Science Olympiad chapter can get involved in our tournament by serving as event supervisors, Core members assisting the board with tournament logistics, or as volunteers on the day of the tournament.
Summary: Science Olympiad is a nationally recognized competition that involves teams of 15 students competing in 23 different events related to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. Our club organizes an invitational tournament held at UM.

Name: University of Michigan Society for Advancement of Hispanics/Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) Chapter
Description: The Society for Advancement of Hispanics/Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) at UMich Chapter is a student run organization that fosters the advancement of underrepresented students in the sciences. The purpose of this chapter is to bring scientists of all levels together and mentor one another. In addition, we will have the support from faculty that promote diversity in the sciences and aid those of underrepresented communities. SACNAS as a whole is a national organization with over 110 professional and student chapters working to increase diversity in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). All chapters meet annually at the SACNAS national conference in which students present their research and participate in leadership and professional development sessions. Involvement in SACNAS at Umich will provide members the opportunity to get involved in the community, network with other SACNAS members around the country, and increase diversity in STEM.
Summary: The purpose of SACNAS at UMich is to encourage and promote the advancement of minorities in the sciences at the University of Michigan and surrounding communities. This organization will allow a bridge between students of all levels and professors.

Name: University of Michigan Solar Car Team
Description:
The University of Michigan Solar Car Team is an entirely student-run organization that designs and builds solar electric vehicles. The team races both nationally and internationally. Since its establishment in 1989, the team has built 17 vehicles, won the American Solar Challenge nine times, placed in the top three in the World Solar Challenge seven times, and won one international competition. The team is recognized as the most successful team in North America, and one of the most successful teams in the world.

 

Our primary competition is the Bridgestone World Solar Challenge, a 5-day, 3,000 km endurance challenge across the Australian Outback, designed to push the limits of renewable energy technology, automotive engineering, and the race participants. Our car is designed by the full team during the school year; then a sub-team, called the Race Crew, builds the car over the summer, and takes the following Fall semester off to travel to Australia and race the car. 

 

Members of our team come from many different backgrounds, disciplines, and colleges from within the university, ranging from undergraduate to doctoral studies. Any and all majors welcome! 

 

The team consists of 4 major divisions: Engineering, Business, Operations, and Communications.

 

The Engineering Division is responsible for designing the most efficient solar vehicle in the world. They accomplish this by optimizing each and every system in the car, including the aerobody, array, battery, suspension, structures, and more. The Engineering Division also includes the Strategy and Software team, who are responsible for developing our models and simulations. This division is ideal for people interested in aerospace, electrical, mechanical, and materials engineering, as well as computer and data science, mathematics, and physics. 

 

The Business Division is responsible for fundraising, as well as the public image of the team. Accounts members work to develop and maintain sponsor relations with corporations around the world, large and small. This division is ideal for people interested in business development, finance, and sales.

 

The Operations Division manages supply chain logistics, manufacturing, procurement, and facilities organization for the team. Alongside the Business Division, Operations works to ensure the team has the materials and resources required to build a cutting-edge electric vehicle. Additionally, operations members handle shipping our car, equipment - notably including a 40ft container mobile workspace - and team to Australia. This division is ideal for people interested in industrial and operations engineering, manufacturing processes, supply chain management, transportation and shipping, and business administration. 

 

The Communications Division is responsible for promoting the team. Members produce media dedicated to generating interest in our team, solar racing, renewable energy technologies, and to build the “UM Solar Car” brand. This division is ideal for those interested in marketing, communications, creative writing, graphic design, and media production.

 

Check out our website for more info about our team, our project, and our history: umsolar.com

 

IMPORTANT WINTER 2024 RECRUITING INFORMATION:

Only our Business, Communications, Vehicle  Dynamics, Weather Strategy, and Mechanical Systems Divisions are open for recruiting at this time. Our application is due by Thursday 1/19 11:59pm. You can find the form to submit here.

Mass Meeting on North Campus 

  • Tuesday, January 16, 2024
  • 6:30 PM – 7:30 PM
  • DOW 1013 (map)

Join us to learn more about the different divisions and ask our members questions! Everyone has a place on our team, so whether you're interested in engineering, business, or communications, we hope to see you there!
Summary: The Solar Car Team is a student-run organization that designs, builds, and races solar vehicles. Our team includes business, operations, communications, and engineering divisions, with undergraduate and graduate students from across the University.

Name: University of Michigan Steel Bridge Team
Description: The University of Michigan Steel Bridge Team is a student project team comprised of undergraduate and graduate engineering students. Each year, the team designs, fabricates, and constructs a 1:10 scale bridge according to a set of rules from the American Institute of Steel Construction. The team then competes against other universities at a regional competition, and if the team performs well, they will qualify for the national competition.
Summary: Steel Bridge Team is made of undergraduate and graduate engineering students. Each year, the team designs and fabricates a 1:10 scale bridge based on a standard set of rules.  The team then competes by constructing and loading the bridge at competitions.

Name: University of Michigan Student-Run Free Clinic
Description: The Student-Run Free Clinic is a student organization dedicated to providing quality healthcare free of charge to uninsured adults, while creating opportunities for UM students and physicians to confront health disparities through direct action. At the UMSRFC, patients can receive basic primary and preventative care. Basic tests such as routine blood work or X-rays are also free of charge when the physician refers the patient for testing. The UMSRFC also creates a unique learning and mentorship environment in which clinical and preclinical medical students work together to care for patients, all under the guidance of a volunteer UM physician. The UMSRFC also provides valuable opportunities for inter-professional education, working closely with students from Pharmacy, Nursing, and Social Work.
Summary: We are medical students that run a clinic in Pinckney, MI every Wednesday and Saturday. We have dual responsibilities: to provide free medical care to uninsured adults by recruiting physician volunteers, and to clinically educate medical students.

Name: University of Michigan Supermileage Team
Description:
Supermileage is a student-led multidisciplinary project team creating high efficiency single occupant electric vehicles and internal combustion vehicles to compete in the annual Shell Eco-Marathon (SEM) Americas event. 

 

Established in 2010, Supermileage has raced vehicles at both the SEM and SAE Supermileage competitions. Currently, Supermileage races annually at the Shell Eco-Marathon. Historically, the competition has taken place in Indianapolis IN, Sonoma CA, Fontana CA, Houston TX, Detroit MI, and more. The competition has three energy categories (Battery Electric, Internal Combustion, Hydrogen Fuel Cell) and two body-style categories (Prototype, Urban Concept) providing 6 possible divisions to race in. Currently our team is preparing our internal combustion urban concept vehicle, Maple, for the 2025 Shell Eco Marathon.

 

In the past our vehicles have achieved 4,536.693 MPG. This year, Supermileage has ambitions to attain 10,000 MPGe for our prototype electric vehicle, and 700 MPG for our internal combustion vehicle. We can only achieve these lofty goals with your help!

 

Our team’s success relies on the diverse talents, perspectives, and backgrounds of our members. Some of our current members’ fields of study include Electrical Engineering, Computer Science, Computer Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Aerospace Engineering, Physics, Environmental Science, Business, Finance, Art & Design, and more. However, ALL MAJORS ARE WELCOME! 

 

Our team is broken up into 2 major divisions and an executive board.

 

THE ENGINEERING DIVISION is responsible for the design and manufacturing of our vehicles. We have 5 engineering sub-teams, namely Electrical Systems, Mechanical Systems, Aerodynamics, Internal Combustion, and Vehicle Integration, and all engineering is overseen by the chief engineer.

Electrical Systems has two primary focuses: power electronics for our electric drivetrain and vehicle telemetry for data collection and race strategy. The design and testing of the PCB’s which control an electric motor running our car is all done in house. Additionally, electrical systems develops vehicle telemetry software and hardware, tunes motor control algorithms, designs our electrical harnesses, simulates our vehicles, and more.

Mechanical Systems is responsible for chassis design and manufacturing, transmission, steering, brakes, suspension, and more. Members of the mechanical systems team use Computer Aided Design (CAD) and Finite Element Analysis (FEA) softwares to to model and simulate the entire vehicle prior to manufacturing. They also utilize the mill, lathe, CNC mill, CNC lathe, CNC router, and welder while manufacturing our vehicles.

Aerodynamics has two main responsibilities pertaining to the bodies of our vehicles. Iteratively modeling and simulating the body in NX CAD and Hyperworks Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) softwares. And manufacturing the body using carbon fiber layups.

Powertrain primarily focuses on the GY6 moped engine currently used in our ICE car, Maple. The team tunes the engine’s software by modifying the engine control unit (ECU) code. Additionally, they develop the transmission of our ICE vehicles, ensuring energy is transferred from the engine to the tires most efficiently.  This year, the team plans to optimize the engine’s performance using a dynamometer to create an optimal fuel efficiency map.

Vehicle Integration uses systems engineering principles to ensure that all aspects of the vehicle work together in unison. They develop tests designed to ensure that the vehicle is both structurally sound and safe for the driver while remaining optimally fuel efficient. Most importantly, they promote proper communication and collaboration between each sub-team.

 

THE BUSINESS DIVISION is responsible for all other aspects of the team. It is comprised of Public Relations, Sponsorship, Finance, and Internal Relations.

Public Relations is responsible for all external communication, marketing, and advertising of the team. They make social media posts, plan recruitment events, create a team newsletter, organize fundraising events, update the team website, and more.

Internal Affairs deal with inner-team logistics such as planning social events, running elections, welcoming new team members, reserving rooms, etc.

Finance focuses on managing the team’s budget, filing reimbursements, financial planning for large purchases and competition events, and forecasting financial needs for current and future projects.

Sponsorship maintains relationships with current sponsors, secures funding/services from old and new sponsors, develops a sponsorship packet and team resume book for company recruitment events, and more.

 

To learn more about The University of Michigan Supermileage team, please visit our website https://UMSM.engin.umich.edu/ . Go Blue!
Summary: Supermileage is a student-led multidisciplinary project team creating high efficiency single occupant electric vehicles and internal combustion vehicles to compete in the annual Shell Eco-Marathon Americas event.

Name: University of Michigan Sustainable Food Program
Description:
UMSFP fosters collaborative leadership that empowers students to create a more just and sustainable food system at the University of Michigan while becoming change agents for a resilient planet. To further this mission, UMSFP focuses effort on partnering with organizations and events that support the local food system, thereby: 

1) Developing responsible student leaders by facilitating education, professional development, and discussion on sustainable food systems.

2) Building community through collaborative programming and mutually beneficial partnerships.

3) Redistribute power between institutions and groups through the principles and practices of visionary organizing.
Summary: UMSFP fosters collaborative leadership that empowers students to create a more just and sustainable food system at the University of Michigan while becoming change agents for a resilient planet.

Name: University of Michigan Wolverine Battalion
Description:
The University of Michigan Army Reserve Officers’ Training Corp (ROTC)—known as the Wolverine Battalion—is an elective military program based on the Ann Arbor campus offered to undergraduate and graduate students. Our storied battalion traces its origin to 1917 and has since continued to provide a transformative opportunity for all of the leaders and best: we seek to cultivate personal mastery in physical fitness, critical thinking, and effective leadership in an environment that promotes camaraderie and scholarship.

Our mission is to prepare UMich students to become officers in the U.S. Army upon graduation. Any student, however, may enroll in the program and receive the same quality of training and professional development with no expectation to commission as an Army officer upon graduation.

There are also opportunities to earn 2, 3, and 4 year scholarships for those applicable.
Summary: We are the Army's Reserve Officer Training Program at the University of Michigan. Every year, our storied battalion, the Wolverine Battalion, commissions new officers into the U.S. Army.

Name: University of Michigan Women's Club Volleyball
Description: University of Michigan Women's Club Volleyball is a competitive organization that allows young women to continue their volleyball career at a high level and build a fun, close-knit community on campus while still having time to focus on academics. We have two teams that practice twice a week at Cliff Keen Arena and attend 4 tournaments per semester, with 22-26 members total. The season starts in September and ends in April at the NCVF National Collegiate Club Volleyball Championship.
Summary: University of Michigan Women's Club Volleyball is a competitive organization that allows young women to continue their volleyball career at a high level and build a fun, close-knit community on campus while still having time to focus on academics.

Name: University of Michigan Women's Glee Club
Description: The University of Michigan Women’s Glee Club is a vocal performance group for students at the University of Michigan. We represent the University through the medium of music and promote the arts on campus and beyond, all while building a close-knit community through the making of music. The Women's Glee Club welcomes singers who excel at singing in an SSAA choir, regardless of gender identity.
Summary: The University of Michigan Women's Glee Club is a choral ensemble of undergraduate and graduate students from diverse fields and backgrounds. As a club, WGC allows students to form a community that is bonded by a shared love of music.

Name: University of Michigan Women's Rugby Football Club
Description:
Our club aims to provide everyone a chance to learn the sport of rugby. We will provide all committed and hard-working teammates the opportunity to grow as rugby players, athletes and individuals. We are devoted to building a competitive team and program focused on athletics, teamwork, dedication and camaraderie. Joining UMWRFC requires no experience with the sport, just a love for competitive athletics and lasting friendships. Rugby is a game of strategy, grit, and teamwork. Rugby can be played by people of all body types and athletic abilities and it combines elements of many sports. The majority of our team consists of crossover athletes from other sports. Even if you’ve never heard of rugby before, we will teach you everything you need to know to play. If you are interested in playing rugby, please contact us any time at rugby.recruiting@umich.edu for more information!

 

UMWRFC is a Division I Collegiate Women's Rugby Club team. We belong to the Big Ten Universities Conference and play against other notable Big Ten Schools such as Michigan State, Ohio State, and Penn State. Women's Rugby is also designated as a Club Sport at the University of Michigan and has a strong tradition of athletic and academic excellence.
Summary: Michigan Women’s Rugby requires no experience with the sport, just a love for competitive athletics and lasting friendships. Rugby can be played by people of all body types and athletic abilities and combines elements of many sports.

Name: University of Michigan Young Science Innovators
Description: University of Michigan Young Science Innovators encourages socioeconomically disadvantaged students to enter the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering, Math, and Medicine (STEM^2) by running a free week-long summer science camp, planned and run entirely by undergraduate and graduate University of Michigan student volunteers.  The primary goals of U-MYScI are to (1) provide underprivileged students with an opportunity to explore the real-world links among science and engineering disciplines, (2) foster teamwork, enthusiasm, and career interests in science and engineering, and (3) use current bioinformatics , chemistry and educational research to develop mentoring, teaching, and learning methods that build student confidence in problem-solving.
Summary: UMYScI encourages socioeconomically disadvantaged students to enter the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering, Math, and Medicine by running a free week-long summer science camp, planned and run entirely by University of Michigan students.

Name: University Skate Collective
Description:
We live by our primary values of Inclusivity, Fun, and Safety, so we want to emphasize that we love beginners and ALL WHEELS ARE WELCOME!!! 

The purpose of the University Skateboard Collective is to highlight, expand, and unite the skateboard community (which includes longboards, penny boards, scooters, rollerskates/blades...). In addition, we want to cultivate a more skateboard-friendly environment on campus.

Our mission is to forge a safe and encouraging community with healthy and productive relationships and a shared love of these sports. Moreover, we hope to gain the support of the community by expressing the joy and importance of skateboard culture. We welcome all skill levels and love to help each other learn and improve, so come join us!

Members also receive a 10% discount on all items at Olympia Skate Shop!!

Join the community group-chat to stay up to date

And follow us on instagram: @Sk8_umich
Summary:
The University Skate Collective highlights, expands, and unites the wheeled-sports community, and seeks to legitimize these sports on campus

We live by our primary values of INCLUSIVITY, FUN, and SAFETY

EVERYONE is welcome and will be respected

Name: University Students Against Rape
Description: University Students Against Rape is the organizer for the University of Michigan Chapter of Take Back the Night, an international rally and march that is organized in local communities with the purpose of unifying all people in an awareness of violence and sexual assault.  We celebrate survivors, honor victims, and educate the community with the Take Back the Night rally and march as well as sexual assault prevention events and a survivor speak out, in which both survivors and supporters are welcome.
Summary: University Students Against Rape organizes the Michigan chapter of Take Back the Night, a rally and march that raises awareness against sexual assault and violence and celebrates survivors.

Name: Unplug UMich
Description: Unplug UMich is a student organization focused on helping individuals manage their screen time. We assist students with device restrictions, content blocking, and personalized strategies for healthier digital habits.
Summary: Unplug UMich is a student organization focused on helping individuals manage their screen time. We assist students with device restrictions, content blocking, and personalized strategies for healthier digital habits.

Name: Up Cancer at the University of Michigan
ShortName: Up Cancer at U of M
Description: Up Cancer at the University of Michigan is committed to educate, engage, & empower those touched by the burden of cancer. Our organization creates a community of patients and survivors and achieves our goals through health & fitness, legislative action though Team Up Cancer, and music & arts. Up Cancer at the University of Michigan is an organization made up of students dedicated to supporting patients and survivors of cancer. We are a chapter of the larger, parent organization, Up Cancer, which is located in Hartford, Connecticut.
Summary: Up Cancer at the University of Michigan is an organization dedicated to raising awareness for cancer research, promoting the health & wellness for cancer patients and survivors, as well as advocating for cancer legislation.

Name: UpRound Ventures
Description: UpRound's mission is to support and enhance the entrepreneurial ecosystem at Michigan and across the region. UpRound's primary activities are designed to source, accelerate, and write checks out our fund to startups that are founded by students. UpRound recruits and provides rich education to new members every semester, while providing a space for students passionate about entrepreneurship to bond, develop, and innovate. We  partner with Plug and Play, Detroit Venture Partners, Bessemer Venture Partners and others to create exclusive career pathways and opportunities for our analysts within the venture capital space. We host open events with prominent VC figures to provide learning opportunities for the Michigan community, and work with university partners to make strategic mentorship available to our analysts and the community at large. Our goal is to increase the prevalence of impactful innovation at Michigan while simultaneously increasing the potency and effectiveness of startups in our shared campus community.
Summary: UpRound sources, funds, and accelerates startups as the universities' first student led venture capital firm. We also work with partners and entrepreneurs to host pitch events, panels, and internal development events throughout the semester.

Name: URB Consulting
Description: The goal of URB Consulting is to consult for urban technology companies to help them in their various missions.
Summary: We are a multidisciplinary cohort of students who are passionate about rethinking the way we live. Our goal is to provide a professional community for students and offer creative solutions to companies in this specific niche.

Name: Urban Technology Student Organization
Description: UTSO strives to create an inclusive environment for Urban Technology (UT) students and others with similar interests to gather. Since UT is an emerging discipline, there is a lack of awareness about the field and its possibilities. Our organization hopes to foster a strong community by hosting social events, exploring our interests within the UT discipline, and enhancing in-class learning with technical training and real-world applications.
Summary: Our organization hopes to foster a strong community by hosting social events, exploring our interests within the Urban Technology discipline, and enhancing in-class learning with technical training and real-world applications.

Name: Urbanism at The University of Michigan
Description:
We are an organization for students interested in the development and management of cities and urban public policy. Our mission is to spread awareness of the virtues of urbanism from environmental, social, and cultural lenses. We strive to promote low-waste, accessible, collaborative societies that are based in smart, efficient policy. We value walkable communities, reliable public transportation, plentiful housing, dense development, environmentally-friendly infrastructure, and financially sustainable cities. We work with local and regional organizations to develop tangible solutions for contemporary urban issues. We hope that our work will improve the overall quality of life for the community’s inhabitants while also benefiting the global community by practicing sustainability.

.
Summary: We examine and discuss public policy in urban areas. Specific focus areas include public health, economic policy, infrastructure, and walkability. Levels of policy include federal, state, and municipal. Any policy related to urban vitality is relevant.

Name: US Coast Guard Auxiliary University Program at the University of Michigan
Description:
We are service-minded college students who volunteer in support of US Coast Guard missions, including search and rescue; environmental protection; boating safety, and more. Members receive training at no cost, can earn qualifications for their resume and personal development, and are eligible for Coast Guard internships. 

We are a public service organization, not an ROTC program -- there is no service commitment and no scholarships are offered.

Please see our Web site at: https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/coastguardauxiliary/
Summary: We are service-minded college students who volunteer in support of US Coast Guard missions, including search and rescue; environmental protection; boating safety, and more.

Name: Us Too @UMich
Description: Our mission is to give any students who are intimately acquainted with sexual assault/ violence/ harassment, domestic violence, or similar experience a safe and inclusive community to share their stories as well as make a difference for those who are currently going through similar situations. Us Too @UMich aims to create volunteer opportunities, raise awareness, money, and goods for domestic violence shelters in the Detroit area.
Summary: Us Too @UMich is an organization dedicated to providing aid for domestic violence shelters in the Detroit area.

Name: V.O.I.C.E.S. Baits Multicultural Council
Description: The Baits II V.O.I.C.E.S Multicultural Council works to enrich the lives of all Baits II residents by creating opportunities for positive community development; serving as a liaison to Dining, Facilitates, and the Residence Hall Association (RHA); fostering a safe and welcoming environment in recognition of our intersecting identities; and advocating on behalf of historically underrepresented communities at the University of Michigan. In short, we envision a community that is united in common cause and reflective of the change we wish to see in the world.
Summary: V.O.I.C.E.S Baits Multicultural Council serves as the Multicultural Council for the residents of Baits II.

Name: V1 Michigan
Description:
V1 Michigan is a place for driven students to do more than learn — here, they build. We start with crazy, ambitious ideas, from a startup fair designed to land students their dream job to a studio designed to create the next generation of products. But we don't stop there — our team helps bring each of these ideas into fruition. Each of us are driven individuals, but we are more motivated, creative, and innovative together than we could be alone. We all want to do great things — here at V1, we want to equip others with the tools, connections and experience they need to make it happen.

 

By joining V1 Michigan, you will have access to our very own V1 Cohort - build connections and solve problems creatively —  and Product Studio to not only build the next successful student startup, but to meet potential lifelong friends. Other than that, we host regular events like V1 Connect — networking, startup/venture opportunities, and more — and Michigan’s largest student-organized career fair: V1 Startup Fair. 

 

Subscribe to newsletter here: https://v1network.substack.com/
Summary: V1 is the community for ambitious student builders. We provide the most driven students with an extraordinary network, exclusive opportunities within startups, and mentorship to grow and achieve great things.

Name: VAW Global Health Alliances
Description: Volunteers Around the World (VAW) is a national organization that empowers members to collaborate with community partners to improve health outcomes both abroad and locally. In countries abroad, Interns work directly with doctors to help implement and run primary medical clinics in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), addressing critical healthcare needs. Locally, volunteers engage in fundraising and health promotion activities, working with organizations like CAN (Community Action Network) and Big Brothers Big Sisters to make a meaningful impact in Ypsilanti schools and communities. Our volunteers help do health education presentations and seminars all around the Ypsilanti area. This unique combination of global and local efforts equips members with valuable hands-on experience in healthcare and community service, fostering a deeper understanding of diverse health challenges and solutions.
Summary: Providing students the unique opportunity to gain valuable medical experience and volunteer in underprivileged communities.

Name: Vedanta Study Circle at University of Michigan
Description: VSC has been established for the purpose of promoting the study and practice of Vedanta philosophy as propounded by Sri Ramakrishna and Swami Vivekananda. It shall be a forum for the study and promotion of spiritual and practical wisdom as expounded in the ancient spiritual texts. It shall have an emphasis on practice of spiritual values in daily life. It shall be a non-sectarian and non-political organization with an all-inclusive approach. Volunteers of VSC shall strive towards social service with an attitude of Service to Humanity is Service to Divinity. All members of the university community are welcome to attend any event organized by the VSC.
Summary: Vedanta Study Circle at University of Michigan, Ann Arbor has been established as a registered student organization of University of Michigan for the study and practice of the Vedanta, an ancient philosophy with a universal message.

Name: VeryUs
Description: VeryUs is an all-female Asian-pop dance group at the University of Michigan. Our mission is to spread awareness of the underrepresented Asian cultures in the U-M dance community. We perform songs from across Asia including J-Pop, P-Pop, C-Pop, and more. Through choreographies created by Asian artists and our members, we showcase the beauty of pop/modern music and dance. Our performance uplifts and promotes unity between A/PIA groups in the U-M dance community.
Summary: VeryUs is an all-female Asian-pop dance group at the University of Michigan. Our mission is to spread awareness of the underrepresented Asian cultures in the U-M dance community.

Name: Vibrance Dance Company
Description: Modern, contemporary and jazz dance performance company for University of Michigan students. Vibrance group members choreograph their own pieces for stage performance. The company meets to rehearse the choreography and performs for organizations around campus as well as their own showcase at the end of the semester.
Summary: Vibrance is a student-run contemporary and jazz dance company at the University of Michigan. Each member has the opportunity to choreograph and perform unique styles of dance at our annual showcase in the spring.

Name: Victors FC
Description: The goal of this organization is to supply girls with a competitive soccer environment, but with a smaller time commitment than the standing club soccer program. This organization will compete in a league with other local college club teams in Michigan and would participate in all league events/games.
Summary: The goal of this organization is to supply girls with a competitive soccer environment, but with a smaller time commitment than the standing club soccer program.

Name: Victors Value Investments
Description:
Victors Value Investments (VVI) is Michigan's foremost value investing undergraduate club with over $15,000 in assets under management. We invest in a highly concentrated, long-only portfolio of US equities by practicing strict value investing philosophies.

 

Our mission is to bring an engaging investing experience to all members by promoting education, professional development, and industry exposure to students of all levels and backgrounds.

 

Our club runs an education program dedicated to building the foundation for value investing expertise. Topics range from the basics of value investing, financial accounting, valuation, financial modeling, technical analysis, and information sourcing.

 

Each semester, members will join a pitch team where they will identify, research, and pitch a stock to the rest of the club during a fund meeting on the Tozzi Trading Floor. We also have many different committees that members are encouraged to join that dive deeper into specific aspects of our club and its operations. On top of all of that, our club provides professional development resources, technical skill workshops, and mentorship from upperclassman members.

 

We pride ourselves in our tight-knit organization. We focus on fostering relationships and building a strong network within our team and the greater Michigan community.

 

For more information: https://www.umichvvi.com
Summary: Victors Value Investments (VVI) is a student-led organization with an emphasis on community that provides real-world investing experience by managing a portfolio using value investing philosophies and educating its members on financial topics

Name: Video Game Music Club
Description:
This is a student-run organization for anyone interested in video game music, whether you have an insatiable love for the genre or are completely new to it. No commitment required! You can just join our Discord and say hello!

We hold weekly meetings, with the time and day varying by semester based on member availability. At meetings, we discuss anything and everything related to the field of game audio. We also introduce members to composition and music production!

Anyone interested in performing video game music can join the band portion as well!

Fall 2024 Meeting Times:

General Meetings: TBD

Band Meetings: TBD

Announcements are made through our Discord Server which can be joined at the link below!

https://bit.ly/vgmclub
Summary:
This is a student-run organization for anyone interested in video game music, whether you have an insatiable love for the genre or are completely new to it. We've got a band too!

Join our Discord server to join the fun! https://bit.ly/vgmclub

Name: Vietnamese International Student Association
Description:
At VISA, we strive to foster a deep understanding of Vietnamese contemporary culture while providing a “home away from home” for all Vietnamese students. Our vision is to create a tight-knit and inclusive environment where members can find friendship, guidance, and a sense of belonging when studying abroad.

Our logo features the ‘chim lạc,’ or the mythical crane, a prominent symbol in ancient Vietnamese culture. The crane soars high through the boundless skies, symbolizing the ancient Vietnamese people’s resilience and ambitions. No matter where they are in the world, they remain anchored to their resilient roots, forever driven by their desires to conquer the skies.

From mouth-watering Hanoian cuisine to Saigon’s vibrant nightlife, we hope to bring authentic Vietnamese culture to the Michigan community. Stay tuned for our upcoming activities!
Summary: Vietnamese International Student Association is a cultural association that aims to foster bonds between Vietnamese international students. The association also aims to promote an authentic Vietnamese culture to students at the University of Michigan.

Name: Vietnamese Student Association
Description: Through numerous activities focusing on the celebration and exposure of Vietnamese culture, we hope to provide the necessary interaction between those of different backgrounds to build cross-cultural bridges and foster acceptance and awareness. As a dynamic and open organization, the Vietnamese Student Association prides itself on its diverse and unified membership and dedication to decreasing cultural tension on campus.
Summary: The Vietnamese Student Association is an organization dedicated to increasing cultural awareness and diversity on campus and in the community. We strive to create a supportive and cooperative environment for those of Vietnamese and non-Vietnamese descent

Name: VitalLink Health
Description: VitalLink Health is a nonprofit organization focused on bridging healthcare gaps for underserved populations. Through strategic partnerships, community education, and essential resource distribution, we work to empower communities with access to healthcare information and resources. Our initiatives range from creating health kits to hosting educational programs, all aimed at supporting marginalized groups and addressing health inequities in local and regional communities. VitalLink Health strives to make a measurable impact by ensuring that individuals, regardless of socioeconomic background, have the tools and knowledge needed for healthier lives.
Summary: VitalLink Health is dedicated to improving healthcare access and outcomes for underserved communities through educational outreach, resource distribution, and partnerships with local health organizations.

Name: VoiCSEs
Description:
We are a vibrant and inclusive CSE graduate student community. Through meaningful conversations, interactive activities, and workshops, we create welcoming environments where everyone feels comfortable, supported, and empowered to take charge of their own growth and learning in graduate school.

Our Mission: 

  1. Celebrate our Identities and Forge Connections: We are a vibrant and inclusive community that embraces diversity and celebrates individuality. We discover new perspectives together, engage in meaningful conversations, and build friendships.
  2. Foster Welcoming and Approachable Communities: Stepping into new social settings can be intimidating, but rest assured, we foster an environment that encourages conversations, ensuring that even those of us who are shy feel comfortable. We participate in ice-breakers, interactive activities, and workshops specifically designed to help us feel comfortable and confident in social situations.
  3. Advocate and Support one another: Our organization is rooted in the principles of support and safety. No matter what we're looking for - whether it's advice, guidance, or just someone to talk to -, we are here for one another. We advocate for ourselves, promoting and encouraging each other throughout our grad school journeys.
  4. Create Empowerment and Learning Opportunities: our organization places students at the forefront, empowering us to take charge of our own growth and learning. Together, we can organize or host any events that would enhance our graduate school experiences.
Summary: A vibrant and inclusive CSE graduate student community. Through conversations, interactive activities, and workshops, we create welcoming environments where everyone feels comfortable, supported, and empowered to take charge of their own growth.

Name: VOID Tech
Description:
VOID Tech gives members real-world software development experience through real-world projects. We bring together student developers, designers, and Product Managers to partner up in order to create beautiful, functional websites and applications.
We set up students for success by creating cross-functional teams that will allow them to explore their design, development, and management abilities while learning about the process of developing a functional application that solves a real-world problem. Students will have to undergo a development process that ranges from brainstorming, to development, then testing and finally, deployment. We also host multiple social and professional development events throughout the year that will allow you to make lifelong friends and connections!
This club is open to Computer Science, UX Design, Ross or any other student who has the skills and/or passion to learn how to develop an application.
To join our org, come to our events and apply here.
Summary: VOID Tech gives members real-world software development experience through real-world projects. We bring together student developers, designers, and Product Managers to partner up in order to create beautiful, functional websites and applications.

Name: Washtenaw Rock Stars
Description: The mission of Washtenaw Rock Stars is for students to gain an outlet to express themselves, join a supportive community, and discover the lifelong joy music can provide. We seek to provide free musical instruction focused on exposure, exploration, and sustained accessibility in order to eliminate financial barriers to music in Washtenaw County.
Summary: Washtenaw Rock Stars provides free musical instruction focused on exposure, exploration, and sustained accessibility in order to eliminate financial barriers to music in Washtenaw County.

Name: WCBN FM
Description:
Mission: WCBN's mission is to provide educational, adventurous and diverse Freeform radio to both the University of Michigan and the city of Ann Arbor, educating DJs and listeners on all kinds of music, campus athletics, and perspectives outside of the mainstream.

 

About: WCBN is the student run radio station at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. We broadcast at 200 watts to the University and its surrounding communities from the Basement of the Student Activities Building on campus. It is staffed by students and members of the Ann Arbor community who work together to ensure unique, quality programming that cannot be heard elsewhere in the city or the state. We've been around for over 50 years in one form or another, so our history is quite extensive.

 

Join: WCBN-FM is always looking for University of Michigan students to help out at the station. There are opportunities in all of our departments, including broadcasting, fundraising, layout and graphic design, and engineering. If you are interested in non-commercial, freeform radio and want to know more, send a message to training@wcbn.org or call 763-3535. Introductory training sessions are held year-round. If you would like to get involved off the air, email volunteer@wcbn.org.

WCBN Sports travels across the country providing live commentary for Michigan varsity athletic events including football, men’s and women’s basketball, hockey, baseball, softball, and much more. The sports department also hosts a talk show 4 days a week over the FM airwaves. Topics of discussion range from breaking down games to chopping up trades, and various debates. Please email ocrain@umich.edu and millerai@umich.edu if you are interested in joining the sports department.
Summary: WCBN is a broadcast station at 88.3 FM. The station also sponsors and organizes concerts, lectures and other events. Students can join the station as radio DJs on-air, help with events off-air, or join our sports broadcasting team.

Name: Weekend MBA Association
Description:
The Weekend MBA Association is dedicated to promoting the Weekend MBA experience at the Stephen M. Ross School of Business.The primary goals of the Association are:

  • To provide professional, academic, and social networking opportunities for Weekend MBA students.
  • To ensure continual Weekend MBA student representation and perspective in Business School affairs.
  • To contribute to the building of the larger Business School community by partnering with other programs and clubs within the school.

The Weekend MBA Association strives to fulfill these goals through events and activities planned to appeal to the unique perspective and situation of the Weekend MBA student. The Weekend MBA Association serves as an information source and support organization for each stage of involvement in the program: prospective students wishing to learn more about the program, new and current students navigating their way through opportunities and resources available in the Business School while facing work/school/life balance, and graduating students transitioning to the Alumni community.

Weekend MBA supported events include:

  • New Student Orientations
  • Prospective Student Weekend MBA Information Sessions
  • Academic Advocacy Programs
  • Weekend MBA Ambassador Program
  • Career Path and Career Change Panel Discussions
  • Annual Family Picnic
  • Semester Kick-off Gatherings
  • Graduation Celebrations
  • Social and Networking Events

Membership in the Weekend MBA is open to all registered Weekend MBA students. We welcome and encourage students to become involved in the Weekend MBA Association to maximize the potential of their experience here at Ross.
Summary: The Weekend MBA Association is dedicated to promoting the Weekend MBA experience at the Stephen M. Ross School of Business.

Name: Weinberg Institute for Cognitive Science
Description: Cognitive Science is an exciting, fast-growing, and revolutionary area of study which seeks to develop integrated explanations of mind, brain, and behavior. Drawing on concepts and methods from a range of related fields — including linguistics, psychology, philosophy, neuroscience, and computer science — Cognitive Science students acquire a truly interdisciplinary knowledge base and a multifaceted set of analytic skills. The Cognitive Science major is intended for students interested in a natural or social science degree in the behavioral and brain sciences with a combined focus and breadth not accommodated by a major within any single department.
Summary: Cognitive Science is an exciting, fast-growing, and revolutionary area of study which seeks to develop integrated explanations of mind, brain, and behavior.

Name: Wellness and Weight management club (W&W)
Description:
What We Do:

We host weekly/biweekly activities related to wellness and weight management for everyone to participate, including calories counting, food preparation, cooking demonstration, group grocery, gym workout, knowledge share, and fun networks like hangout or field trip.

We also offered peer-monitored weight management plan to clients, including the diet and exercise plan. There will be a "supervisor" to guide you to conduct your plan.

Join us as a Member:

We are a group of students (The board) majored in different field, interested in nutrition, exercise, lifestyle changes, fitness and well-being. We dream to help others to reach their fitness goal! Join us at Festifall, or email the president and vice presidents.

Join us as a Client:

Registered through the shared google document with your information, and you could enjoy peer-monitored weight management plan based on your goal, and the engagement in the weekly/biweekly activities.

Join us as yourself:

Definitely welcome! You can join our weekly/biweekly activites anytime without being a "member" or "client".

Disclaimer:

The members are not registered dietitian and the service is totally free, so we do not guarantee complete success of each wellness plan, and we are not allowed to give any diagnosis or intervention with pathological problems. What we can do is to help you reach the fitness goal, and remember knowledge empowerment is our primary goal!

Ethics:

We are firmly committed to fostering a weight-inclusive environment, free from bias and focused on the holistic well-being of every member. We respect any weight or fitness goals and are willing to help you reach your goal.
Summary:
Welcome to Wellness and Weight management club (W&W)! This is a student run organization open to the whole campus!
Our primary goal is to spread the knowledge of wellness and weight management from the view of nutrition and lifestyle habit.

Name: Wellness Investment Club
Description: Through a blend of education, collaboration, and strategic investment discussions, WIC aims to equip its members with the tools and knowledge necessary to navigate the complexities of the financial world while prioritizing their physical, mental, and emotional health. By offering a supportive environment where members can learn about various investment opportunities, risk management techniques, and wealth-building strategies, we strive to empower individuals to achieve their financial goals while maintaining a balanced and fulfilling lifestyle.
Summary: The Wellness Investment Club (WIC) is a community dedicated to fostering financial literacy and empowering its members to make informed decisions that promote both financial understanding and mental well-being.

Name: West Quad Hall Council
Description: The West Quad Hall Council is a student government organization run by residents of West Quad tasked with positively contributing to the experience of West Quad residents.
Summary: The West Quad Hall Council is a student government organization run by residents of West Quad tasked with positively contributing to the experience of West Quad residents.

Name: What the F/UAC
Description: What the F is an intersectional feminist organization on campus that engages in the fight towards equality in a multitude of ways. Each year, What the F publishes two print magazines that include a wide variety of writing styles, voices, and artistic expression. We also run a podcast and blog where writers and artists can react to more relevant issues at any time. In an effort to build community and activism on campus, we believe it is important to push past the boundaries of what it means to be a traditional publication. As an organization, we hold multiple events throughout the semester that promote discussion, evoke empowerment, and provide an alternative social setting for students. In our writing, our artistic expression, and our events, What the F is dedicated to a form of feminism that values intersectionality and inclusively. We recognize that individuals face oppression through multiple different facets of their identity, whether it be through gender, race, nationality, sexual identity, religion, ability, etc. We aim to support, to heal, and to express ourselves freely. Reach out to whatthefmagazine@gmail.com if you would like to get involved in our community!
Summary: What the F strives to educate the student population at the University of Michigan on topics related to feminism and identity, and to empower and participate in feminist action by publishing two magazines during the year and hosting many events.

Name: White Coats for Planetary Health
Description: White Coats for Planetary Health was founded by a group of University of Michigan medical students to increase awareness of and find solutions to the impacts of climate change on health, to address the impact that the US healthcare system has had on climate change and pollution, and to utilize the healthcare voice in advocacy for systemic change to address climate change and environmental injustice. We additionally seek to integrate climate change and sustainability into the education of our future healthcare professionals.
Summary: WCPH aims to increase awareness of and find solutions to the impacts of climate change on healthcare as well as to address the impact that the US healthcare system has had on climate change and pollution.

Name: Whitewater Kayaking Club
Description:
WWKC (the club formerly known as RSCK) was created to offer an inclusive, safe, non-competitive environment for students and community members passionate or curious about whitewater kayaking. We provide our members with the knowledge and tools necessary to safely enjoy the sport. Anyone is welcome, whatever your skill/experience level. Other water sport enthusiasts (canoe, SUP, etc.) are welcome to join too, but our instruction experience and gear are primarily focused on whitewater kayaking.

While whitewater kayaking is our primary focus, we also offer other nature-related activities (like camping road trips and kayak sledding) depending on member interest/availability and weather.

WWKC is a voluntary organization administered by the University of Michigan. Non-student members are welcome; however, the club must maintain at least 50% student membership to be a UM club sport. Because of university policy, we are not allowed to have non-student participants under the age of 18.

We are working to update our information on Maize Pages. Please disregard the Meeting information within the constitutions; we do not currently meet at NCRB pool. We will send out information on weekly kayaking sessions, weekend trips and winter pool sessions at the start of the next semester. We usually don't offer any sessions or trips during the summer, but if you're hoping to kayak and looking for a group to join, Michigan Adventure Paddlers is a great option (and we can also send you other resources if you'd like)

If you'd like to participate in club activities please join through Maize Pages and/or reach out to Jon (jdlowry@umich.edu) and Liem (liem@umich.edu). They're also happy to answer any questions if you're curious about the club or whitewater kayaking. You can also reach out to Avik (abmondal@umich.edu) and Christina (chendren@umich.edu), but they are very busy with pursuing PhDs.

The most up-to-date social media below that we still use is our Instagram page @wwkayakmichigan.

If you're passionate about kayaking and would be interested in helping the club (with instruction, student outreach, etc.), send us an email!
Summary: A group of students, alumni, and community members who enjoy kayaking and exploring nature together. Members of the club provide free instruction to those who want it. Our club gear is mostly for whitewater kayaking but all types of paddlers are welcome

Name: Whole Health at the University of Michigan
Description: Whole Health is an approach to healing used by the Ann Arbor VA hospital that emphasizes holistic methods that treat the body, mind and spirit. Using this framework, our goals are to educate the community about integrative medicine, implement holistic practices into students’ daily lives, fundraise and work with patients at the VA. Activities include various fundraising projects for Whole Health at the VA, movement classes with members and veterans and educational experiences about alternative forms of medicine.
Summary: Using a holistic health framework, the Whole Health Club works with both students and the VA hospital in Ann Arbor to utilize integrative medical practices. Activities include VA community service and interactive experiences using holistic healthcare.

Name: Whole Health Awareness and Community Knowledge Symposium
Description: Through our annual conference and other engagement activities throughout the year, our mission is to support students and affiliates of U-M with whole health and wellness support and educate the university community about whole health practices.
Summary: Through our annual conference and other engagement activities throughout the year, our mission is to support students and affiliates of U-M with whole health and wellness support and educate the university community about whole health practices.

Name: WOLV TV
Description:
WOLV TV is the University of Michigan’s completely student-run television station. We’re sponsored by the University of Michigan’s Department of Film, Television, and Media (FTVM), and we’re located in the North Quad Complex on Central Campus. Founded in 1994 by three students: Danny Schwab, Scott Doyne, and Jeff Holzhausen, WOLV TV has evolved from simply covering Michigan Ice Hockey games to producing ten different shows and even partnering with the Big Ten Network to live-broadcast a range of Michigan sports!

Where do our new members fit in? Everywhere! Each show successfully functions because of its crew. Crew members start at WOLV by being taught to operate a camera, run the TelePrompTer, mix the audio, run the switcher, edit highlights or packages, write scripts, conduct live interviews, or whatever job the show needs to run smoothly. We highly encourage new crew members to try many of these positions. Then, if a crew member decides to apply for a producer role and is selected, he or she will be responsible for passing on their knowledge to their new crew members.

If you're interested in finding out more information, check out our website http://wolvtv.org or email join.wolv@umich.edu.
Summary: Interested in hosting, directing, or producing your own television show? Check out WOLV TV, the University of Michigan’s student-run television station! There are opportunities to create original entertainment, news, and sports programming.

Name: WolverBot Kickers
Description: WolverBot Kickers is a student-run robotics group at University of Michigan aiming to develop humanoids for RoboCup competitions.
Summary: WolverBot Kickers is a student-run robotics group at University of Michigan aiming to develop humanoids for RoboCup competitions.

Name: Wolvereads
Description:
Wolvereads is a monthly undergraduate book club. We seek to inspire college students to read more in their free time as well as build a literature-loving community on campus. Those who read will be champions!

Meetings are in the evening on the last Wednesday of every month. Keep up with us on Instagram (@wolvereads_) and GroupMe (link in Instagram bio).

Our last meeting of the year will be a social event where we walk to the Literati bookstore! We will meet in the Diag on Wednesday, April 9th at 6pm.
Summary: Wolvereads is a monthly undergraduate book club dedicated to fostering openminded conversation and community. It meets monthly and its goal is to inspire college students to read more in their free time.

Name: WolverEcon Forum at The University of Michigan
Description:
WolverEcon Forum is a versatile and comprehensive economics club tailored to the interests of its members. Discussions cover a wide range of topics, from personal investment strategies and market current events to Michigan course recommendations.

-

WolverEcon Forum is a great place to get hands-on experience in a professional setting, hold a leadership position, and improve your network both within the University of Michigan and with industry professionals.

-

WolverEcon Forum is open to all students, regardless of major, and does not require a formal application. All students interested in economics, business, finance, or policy are encouraged to join by emailing manleycm@umich.edu.
Summary: Economics-focused organization providing opportunities for open discussion, professional development, and leadership.

Name: Wolverine Achievers in Volunteer Excellence
Description:
Wolverine Achievers in Volunteer Excellence (WAVE) is dedicated to organizing effective and meaningful community service events throughout the year.

Our mission is to unite U-M students in service, fostering leadership, compassion, and social responsibility. Through volunteering, through outreach, and through developing strong partnerships with local organizations, we hope to serve individuals and families in need while addressing key social issues.

WAVE provides students with hands-on experience that promotes teamwork, problem-solving, and leadership as well as having a beneficial effect. Empowering students to take action allows us to promote a culture of service and engagement that lasts beyond college and into a lifetime of activism.

From direct service and fundraising to awareness raising and community outreach, WAVE strives to make a lasting difference in Ann Arbor and the world.
Summary: Wolverine Achievers in Volunteer Excellence (WAVE) organizes impactful community service events year-round. Our mission is to unite U-M students in serving those in need, fostering leadership, and creating lasting change in our community through meaning.

Name: Wolverine Airmen Association
Description: The mission of the Wolverine Airmen Association (WAA) is to institute cadet advocates, ensure financial well-being, and promote successful programs to nurture and support developing leaders of character. By supporting these students, WAA shares a common mission with the Air Force Officer Education Program (AF-OEP): to develop leaders of character for tomorrow’s Air Force. WAA recognizes the financial, social, and extracurricular sacrifices made by students committed to the AF-OEP.
Summary:
The Wolverine Airmen Association recognizes the financial, social, and
extracurricular sacrifices made by students committed to the Air Force-Officer Education
Program. WAA’s mission is to fund programs to help students in these 3 areas.

Name: Wolverine Bhangra
Description: A collegiate, competitive bhangra team at the University of Michigan looking to bring the culture and performance of bhangra to the community
Summary: A collegiate, competitive bhangra team at the University of Michigan

Name: Wolverine Capital Investments
Description:
About WCI

Wolverine Capital Investments is an undergraduate investment organization formed in 2009 by four University of Michigan students interested in philanthropy and investing. Since then, WCI has grown into a club of 60+ active members managing a $20,000+ portfolio.

Education and Professional Development
