During weekly meetings, we discuss current events in the market and hear stock pitches from club members. We also host education sessions and professional development workshops to educate new analysts about accounting, finance, markets, and career readiness.  

Philanthropy

WCI is the sole philanthropic, non-profit undergraduate investment club at the Stephen M. Ross School of Business. Each semester, we donate a portion of our portfolio's proceeds and participate in charitable efforts to serve our community. Previous philanthropy events include making holiday cards for Navy SEALs, volunteer missions in Detroit, and funding micro-loans for small businesses in developing economies.

Recruitment

WCI conducts recruiting cycles in September and January of each academic year. We strongly recommend joining our interest list if you would like to be informed of recruitment timelines. WCI welcomes members from all majors and does not require prior investing experience.

To learn more, please visit us at www.wciumich.com.
Summary: Wolverine Capital Investments is a philanthropic undergraduate investing organization that seeks to educate members about finance through active portfolio management while also serving the Ann Arbor community. WCI is a 501(c)(4) nonprofit organization.

Name: Wolverine Esports & Gaming Association for Multiplayer Entertainment
Description: 1. This organization will focus on providing a space for Ross MBA students to network, learn, and engage in interactive and strategic games as well as publicize professional opportunities for those who hold career interests in the gaming industry.
Summary: WeGame strives to provide opportunities for personal and professional enrichment to its members and the Stephen M. Ross School of Business student body by deepening their understanding of gaming and the gaming industry.

Name: Wolverine F.C.
Description: Wolverine F.C. (formerly Futsal Club) offers the Michigan community competitive and recreational soccer/futsal.  Previously, there were several factors limiting Michigan students from pursuing these sports such as lack of fields, distance, weather, and unorganized pickup games. Together, we have resolved those issues by establishing an environment for friendly competition and exercise. We are open to anyone across campus who wants to engage in team building and make connections with fellow Wolverines. Our current activities include: pickup soccer, scrimmages, Sunday leagues, professional tournaments, social events, and more.
Summary: Wolverine F.C. is the place for futsal and soccer fanatics to bond over the beautiful game through year-round soccer. We offer indoor and outdoor soccer as well as futsal for those cold Michigan Winters.

Name: Wolverine for Israel
Description:
Wolverine for Israel is the pro-Israel community supporting Zionists (students, faculty, staff, etc.) at the University of Michigan. Through student-to-student dialogue, guest lectures, and public displays, we aim to educate, support, empower, and strengthen Zionists on campus.

 

** Zionism: the right for Jews to self determine, safely and securely, in their ancestral homeland. Zionism does not preclude the coexistence of others in the land.
Summary: Wolverine for Israel is the pro-Israel community at the University of Michigan.

Name: Wolverine Maritime Battalion
Description: The NROTC Program was established to develop midshipmen mentally, morally and physically and to imbue them with the highest ideals of duty, and loyalty, and with the core valus of honor, courage, and commitment in order to commission college graduates as naval officers who possess a basic progessional background, are motivated toward careers in the naval service, and have a potential for future development in mind and charater so as to assume the highest responsibilities of command, citizenship and governement.
Summary: The battalion prepares both University of Michigan and Eastern Michigan University students for service as officers in both the United States Navy and the United States Marine Corps

Name: Wolverine Offshore Wind
Description:
Wolverine Offshore Wind is a student-led organization that seeks to promote the development of and research into offshore wind energy technologies. Our work includes designing, building, and testing prototype model offshore wind turbines and turbine components, developing siting and financial plans for the implementation of offshore wind farms, and conducting other research focused on the development of offshore wind technologies. Throughout our work, we will conduct outreach in coastal and Great Lakes communities, and engage with members of the wind and offshore wind industries.


This year, we are focusing on the National Renewable Energy Laboratory’s (NREL’s) Collegiate Wind Competition, which challenges students to design an offshore wind farm, build and test a fixed-bottom offshore wind turbine prototype for that farm, and engage with communities to promote renewable energy.

 

For more information regarding the competition, please see the competition webpage here: 2025 Collegiate Wind Competition | HeroX

 

We seek students of all backgrounds to join us in our work, which represents an excellent opportunity to learn more about offshore wind or renewable energy more broadly while developing valuable industry and academic connections.
Summary: Wolverine Offshore Wind is a student-led organization that seeks to promote the development of and research into offshore wind technologies and promote awareness of renewable energy through community engagement.

Name: Wolverine Sports Analytics
Description:
A University of Michigan student-led club focused on sports analytics. While we are computer science, data science, and engineering nerds, we love sports and have a vision to utilize our skillset to analyze sports. Our club is open to any interested Michigan students.

Wolverine Sports Analytics
Summary: Wolverine Sports Analytics combines analytical analysis, statistical knowledge, algorithms, and sport acumen to devise the best strategies to play in different daily fantasy sports competitions.

Name: Wolverine Street Law
Description: Wolverine Street Law ("Street Law") allows students an opportunity to utilize their legal education by teaching community members about legal rights and remedies as they relate to a variety of subjects, particularly those whose access to legal advice and education is limited. Students work with adults and children at five different sites within Ann Arbor and the nearby community: Bryant Elementary School, Parnall Correctional Facility, the Washtenaw County Juvenile Detention Center, the Women’s Huron Valley Correctional Facility, and the Conviction Integrity Unit. Street Law provides training at the beginning of each semester.
Summary: Street Law is an umbrella group that currently serves four different sites within the Ann Arbor and nearby Michigan community.  The goal of Street Law and the common theme throughout these sites is to share our legal knowledge with the community.

Name: Wolverine Street Medicine
Description: Wolverine Street Medicine was founded in 2017 by medical students interested in the health disparities of those facing homelessness or housing instability. Our mission is to improve the health of the homeless community, to incorporate education about the care of and service to this population into the medical student curriculum, and to educate the members of the community about health issues related to homelessness.
Summary: Wolverine Street Medicine was founded by medical students committed to improving the health of members of the homeless community and improving medical student education around health issues faced by people who are homeless or housing-insecure.

Name: Wolverine Support Network
Description:
Wolverine Support Network (WSN) empowers University of Michigan students to create a safe community and support each other’s identity, mental well-being, and day-to-day lives through peer-facilitated support groups, mental health advocacy, and community events.

 

WEEKLY GROUPS

WSN facilitates peer-led support groups across campus for both undergraduate and graduate students that fit within students’ own availability. Upon signing up for a weekly group, students meet in a peer-led group once a week for ~1 hour. This space is intentionally designed to be comfortable and confidential. It is an honest outlet for students to support and engage with one another. To join a weekly group, visit umichwsn.org/join. 

 

DROP-IN GROUPS

WSN also hosts weekly drop-in groups both in person and virtually. Each of these groups are led by two peer facilitators, and there is no sign-up required. Follow our Instagram for updates on when drop in groups occur! @umichwsn

 

ORGANIZING TEAM

In addition to or as an alternative to joining a weekly group, students can also join our WSN Organizing Team: our committee-based program that works to create a culture of community care and mental well-being via unique projects, marketing & fundraising, and outreach to the greater U-M community. You can view committee offerings and apply at umichwsn.org/organizingteam.

 

COMMUNITY EVENTS

WSN offers a variety of community events! These are cost-free and open to all U-M students.
Summary: Wolverine Support Network (WSN) empowers University of Michigan students to create a safe community and support each other’s identity, mental well-being, and day-to-day lives through peer facilitated groups and community social events.

Name: Wolverine Tough
Description:
The mission of Wolverine Tough is to support the ChadTough Defeat DIPG Foundation’s efforts to fund research to cure the deadliest form of pediatric brain cancer (DIPG/DMG), including by raising awareness, volunteering, supporting impacted children and their families, and promoting fundraising.

We will honor the lives of the DIPG fighters and support the Foundation’s efforts to provide hope to current and future families facing this horrific disease:

  • Raise awareness through individual and group marketing efforts, including amplifying information shared by the Foundation and hosting campus events
  • Volunteer at local or virtual Foundation events and other third-party events that support the Foundation
  • Support impacted children and their families through letter writing, care packages, social media support and local hospital visits
  • Promote fundraising by amplifying Foundation and third-party fundraising events; this may also include club fundraisers on campus

 

The Foundation has strong ties to the University of Michigan, through its co-founders (the Carr family), student and alumni supporters, and ongoing research at the University. To learn more about the ChadTough Defeat DIPG Foundation, see https://chadtough.org/
Summary: The mission of Wolverine Tough is to support the ChadTough Defeat DIPG Foundation’s efforts to fund research to cure DIPG/DMG, including by raising awareness, volunteering, supporting impacted children and their families, and promoting fundraising.

Name: Wolverine Tutors
Description:
Wolverine Tutors provides university students an opportunity to tutor middle and high school students in whatever way is convenient for them, either online or in-person. They also have opportunities to participate in other community service projects throughout the year.

Wolverine Tutors is geared toward providing free online and in-person tutoring services to middle and high school students. We strive to motivate our students to succeed academically and relieve educational disparities through technology and personal mentoring.

 

Please visit our website for sign up links and more information. Signing up on Maize Pages does not automatically add you to our organization.
Summary: Wolverine Tutors utilizes technology and personal mentoring to provide academic support for students. Through in-person tutoring and our national nonprofit partner Learn To Be, we hope to support students in under-resourced communities.

Name: Wolverine Wellness
Description: Wolverine Wellness is a Public Health resource center within UHS that works to meet the diverse and changing needs of students, faculty, and staff through a holistic approach. Our team members are specialists in providing individual and group coaching, motivational interviewing, wellness courses, and tailored workshops on topics such as sexual health, sleep, stress and self-care, body image and mindful eating, and more. We also provide support services for students in recovery from alcohol or other drugs through our Collegiate Recovery Program (CRP) and lead campaigns such as “Stay In The Blue'' and “I Am A Wolverine And…” to promote an inclusive and safe campus culture. Visit our website and follow our Instagram to learn more about us!
Summary: Wolverine Wellness is a student-centered unit within University Health Service. We utilize a multi-dimensional model of well-being to provide wellness resources and services to students, faculty, and staff across the Ann Arbor campus.

Name: Wolverine Wine Club
Description: The Wolverine Wine Club is a non-profit organization devoted to promoting the many joys of wine.  Founded in 1999, the Wolverine Wine Club has established a diverse membership of MBA students at the University of Michigan. Spouses and significant others are welcome.  The Wolverine Wine Club's goal is to de-mystify wine through our educational and fun tasting events and to help students socialize/network assigned section and other segmented groups.
Summary: Wolverine Wine Club is a social club that organizes various wine tasting and education events throughout the year.

Name: Wolverines for Donation
Description: Wolverines for Donation, the undergraduate chapter of the Wolverines for Life organization, is dedicated to saving lives through donation by collaborating with other donation-based student organizations and empowering its members to make a difference throughout campus. The goal of WFDU is to increase participation in donor registries and blood drives, educate those on organ donation, give undergraduates an opportunity to participate in awareness events, and connect those affected by transplant. We also look to volunteer our time to enhance the lives of those affected by these issues. WFDU understands and is committed to fulfilling its responsibilities of abiding by the University of Michigan's policies and procedures.
Summary: WFD is established to advocate for organ, tissue, marrow, eye and blood donation and to raise awareness. We seek to restore lives by raising awareness and increasing participation on donor registries.

Name: Wolverines On Wheels
Description:
Have you ever wanted to get more involved with biking on campus, but felt overwhelmed on where to start? Or maybe you know your way around Ann Arbor on wheels, but need more resources to support your riding? Wherever you’re starting from and wherever you want to go, Wolverines on Wheels is here for you!

 

Wolverines on Wheels (WoW) is dedicated to building a safe, accessible, and sustainable bicycling community as a sponsored student organization at the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor. We aim to support and advocate for all members of the Ann Arbor bicycling community and ensure that students, faculty, and staff can benefit from and contribute to a bike-friendly campus.

 

WoW is open to all campus members and sponsored by the Center of Socially Engaged Design. Anyone can attend our group rides or visit our pop-ups! 

 

Members have the opportunity to plan rides, expand campus outreach, and ideate infrastructure improvement projects. Participating members have the opportunity to speak directly with community stakeholders to strengthen collaboration and university-run bike resources. 

 

Biweekly meetings occur Sundays from 5-6:30pm. Group rides and pop-up events are posted to our Instagram and Google Calendar. Simply join us for a meeting or event to join the club! Email us with additional questions or inquiries: wolverinesonwheels-admin@umich.edu
Summary: Student organization on the University of Michigan Ann Arbor campus dedicated to building a recreational cycling community that advocates for safe and accessible sustainable transportation.

Name: WolverineSoft
Description:
WolverineSoft is the premier community for game development at the University of Michigan. Our goal is to provide a friendly community for gamers and game developers and to ensure the success of U of M students in the video game industry.

 

All gamers and developers, no matter their experience level, are welcome to join the group. We are open to artists, musicians, programmers, designers, producers, writers, and anyone else who is interested in making or playing video games.

 

WolverineSoft holds both online and in-person meetings and game jams, and attendance is never required — come join us for whichever meetings and events that you'd like!

 

WolverineSoft also holds a semesterly MDP studio called WolverineSoft Studio. Join a large team of students to create innovative and polished game projects for your portfolio by the end of each semester. Check out and play previous game projects at the WolverineSoft Studio Itch.io or Steam pages.

 

Join our Discord server through this link (bit.ly/wsoft_server) to stay informed about upcoming events, meetings, and activities and hang out with our other members. Our announcements will also be sent to our email list and posted on Instagram, both of which you can join on our Linktree (linktr.ee/wolverinesoft).
Summary: Video Game Development at the University of Michigan! Design, program, draw, write, compose, and play video games. Work in teams, meet industry professionals, and release real products! All experience levels and time commitment levels are welcome!

Name: Women and Gender in Public Policy
Description:
Originally formed in 2002, Women and Gender in Public Policy (WGPP) is comprised of students affiliated with the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy.  WGPP engages the Ford School community in a dialogue about gender and related domestic and international public policies. WGPP promotes professional development activities by facilitating communication and networking among current students, Ford School Alumnae, faculty, and working professionals to form a lasting community of policy professionals.

 

 As an organization we seek to:

  • Raise awareness of and encourage thoughtful analyses and critiques of domestic and international policies specific to gender and sexuality issues
  • Present speakers, discussion panels and professional development activities
  • Promote the advancement of women and sexual minorities in leadership positions
  • Maintain a formal network with current students, Ford School Alumnae and other policymakers to form a lasting community of policy professionals
Summary: Women and Gender in Public Policy is a student organization at the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy that is committed to addressing gender issues in domestic and international policy contexts.

Name: Women and Gender Minorities in Chemistry
Description: WiC+ will focus on planning community building events, professional development workshops, outreach, and industry collaboration with the mission to boost the confidence of gender minorities in the field of chemistry.
Summary: We are dedicated to creating a supportive network of women and gender minorities to promote inclusivity and equity in chemistry. We hope to foster a community where all members will gain confidence and receive support during their graduate careers.

Name: Women and Gender Minorities in Mechanical Engineering
Description: WaGMiME is established for the express purpose of connecting women and gender minorities in mechanical engineering with professional opportunities and mentorship. It works to socially and professionally connect current students, staff, and faculty with the greater engineering community through networking with academic and industry professionals. Our mission is to provide the sense of community necessary for women and gender minorities to become leaders on campus and in their field; and improve retention rates of women and gender minorities in mechanical engineering.
Summary: WaGMiME aims to connect women and gender minorities in mechanical engineering with professional opportunities and mentorship.

Name: Women in Aeronautics and Astronautics
Description:
Women in Aeronautics and Astronautics is dedicated to fostering a sense of community among women and underrepresented groups in fields related to aviation and space, improving diversity within the College of Engineering, focused on Aerospace Engineering, and helping members to develop both personal and professional connections in the aerospace industry.

You should join WAA if you are interested in:

  • Meeting other young women and gender minorities at the University of Michigan interested in fields related to aerospace engineering
  • Encouraging students of all levels to consider aerospace careers
  • Being involved in 'mentorship families' with WAA members of all grade levels
  • Supporting diversity in the field of aerospace engineering even if you don't identify as a woman
  • Connecting with successful women in academia, research, and industry
  • Having fun and making new friends at our frequent social and professional events!
Summary: Women in Aeronautics and Astronautics is dedicated to fostering a sense of community among women and underrepresented groups in aerospace, improving diversity in Aerospace Engineering, and developing personal and professional connections amongst members

Name: Women in Aeronautics and Astronautics Rocketry Program
Description: The Women in Aeronautics and Astronautics Rocketry Program is dedicated to fostering a sense of community among women and other gender minorities in aviation and space. WAARP aids members in building technical skills through the creation of a rocket or other aerospace device.
Summary: TThe Women in Aeronautics and Astronautics Rocketry Program fosters community among women and gender minorities in aerospace. WAARP helps members develop technical skills by designing and building rockets or other aerospace devices.

Name: Women in Electrical and Computer Engineering
Description: WECE is a student-run organization whose purpose is to provide an inclusive space for gender minority students in the Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) fields at the University of Michigan to connect and collaborate. WECE is dedicated to assisting in the recruitment and retention of minorities in ECE industries and academia. WECE focuses on the development of individuals committed to innovation and excellence in electrical and electronics engineering fields. Although WECE is intended to support women and gender minority individuals, membership is open to UM students with an interest in the mission of WECE.
Summary: WECE is a student-run, identity-based organization whose purpose is to foster community among women and other gender minorities in the Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) fields at the University of Michigan.

Name: Women In Leadership
Description:
WiL serves as a creative connector for the Organizational Studies program by connecting all its students, regardless of gender, with resources to develop leadership skills and empower women to leverage their unique capabilities to make an impact. Through these connections, WiL seeks to create a stronger OS community, develop leadership skills in its members, and create an understanding of the challenges and experiences many women face in the workforce today to help students become more effective leaders.

WiL has no official membership process, rather, OS students can become a part of WiL by attending the events the organization hosts each month. These events consist of guest speakers and luncheons, leadership skill workshops, and community events to provide a social and academic setting for OS students to connect with each other and with other female professionals, learn from others' experiences, network, and discuss important issues surrounding women, the workforce, and leadership. Attendees of WiL's event will find the organization to be an educational and professional resource, facilitate meaningful discussions about women, the workforce, and leadership, and create a supportive community.
Summary: WiL serves as a creative connector for the Organizational Studies program by connecting all its students, regardless of gender, with resources to develop leadership skills and empower women to leverage their unique capabilities to make an impact.

Name: Women in Mathematics
Description: The Women in Mathematics Club seeks to provide academic, career, and social support for women and gender minorities studying or interested in mathematics, statistics, or data science. WIM provides opportunities to hear from women or gender minorities who use mathematics in their professional lives, meet other students with similar academic interests, and receive peer support for classes and career options. To achieve this, WIM holds a variety of academic, professional development, and social events every Fall/Winter semester.
Summary: The Women in Mathematics Club seeks to provide academic, career, and social support for women and gender minorities studying or interested in mathematics, statistics, or data science.

Name: WOMEN IN NUCLEAR STUDENT CHAPTER AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
Description: To support an environment within the University of Michigan Department of Nuclear Engineering and Radiological Sciences (NERS) in which women and men can succeed through professional development and outreach.
Summary: To support an environment within the University of Michigan Department of Nuclear Engineering and Radiological Sciences (NERS) in which women and men can succeed through professional development and outreach.

Name: Women In Real Estate
Description: At Women In Real Estate (WIRE), our vision is to build a community that offers educational programming, networking opportunities, and valuable career connections. By embracing the diverse perspectives and experiences of our members, we aspire to create an environment where passionate, intelligent, and empowered women in real estate can thrive. If you share our passion for empowering women in real estate, we invite you to join us! WIRE membership is open to current undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Michigan.
Summary: Women In Real Estate (WIRE) is committed to building a diverse network of people across the real estate industry who are interested in empowering and supporting women who want to translate their UM education into a meaningful career in real estate.

Name: Women in Science and Engineering Residence Program Peer Mentors
Description: The mission of the WISE RP Peer Mentors is to recruit, support, and retain a diverse population of students in the science, mathematics, engineering, and technology fields; to link students with resources and opportunities that will support their academic and personal pursuits; and to develop relationships among students with similar interests while building a community based on mutual respect and affirmation of diversity.
Summary: A community of students with academic and career interests in the sciences, technology, engineering, mathematics and health fields.

Name: Women Law Students Association
Description:
The Women Law Students Association envisions a Law School community in which every woman and non-binary person is an equal member of Michigan Law School academically and socially. Our organization advocates for students to meet and see positive non-binary and female role models in the legal profession on a daily basis, offering professional development and networking opportunities. Members of WLSA at Michigan Law School are prepared to assume any leadership role in society to further achieve their visions of success. Additionally, WLSA educates the law school community on legal issues facing women and non-binary people throughout society including sex discrimination, employment, health, education, violence, and access to resources. WLSA is open to all gender identities and is committed to creating a law school community centered on the pillars of Leadership, Mentorship, Community, and Equitability. 

 

The University of Michigan is committed to a policy of equal opportunity for all persons and does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, age, marital status, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, disability, religion, height, weight, or veteran status in employment, educational programs and activities, and admissions.
Summary: WLSA supports the academic and professional growth of women and non-binary people at Michigan Law School. WLSA is committed to creating a law school community centered on the pillars of Scholarship, Leadership, Mentorship, Community, and Equitability.

Name: Women of Color & The Academy
Description: WOCATA centers women, femmes, and non-binary scholars in bringing together education scholars and practitioners to examine issues related to race, research, and representation. Participants of this group work in various fields that intersect with education. Our work across these fields provides us varying insights into the representation and positioning of women of color within and outside of the university.
Summary: We center women, femmes, and non-binary scholars in bringing together education students, scholars, and practitioners to examine issues related to race, research, and representation.

Name: Women's Basketball Club at The University of Michigan
Summary: This organization is working towards becoming an official club team. We plan to participate in scrimmages with other colleges and play at the IM throughout the week. We proudly accept all skill levels and hope to grow the love for women's sports.

Name: Women's Club Lacrosse
Description: We are a talented and committed group of female student athletes who proudly represent the Michigan name on the lacrosse field. Winning WCLA National Championships in 2015 and 2018!
Summary: The Women's Club Lacrosse team is a competitive organization that allows Michigan students to compete at the national club level of lacrosse.

Name: Women's Club Soccer - UMWSC
Description: UMWSC is a student-run organization which provides competitive soccer for women who want to continue playing at the college level without the commitment of being a varsity athlete. The last 2 years, UMWSC has advanced to the national tournament in Round Rock, Texas, where we played UCLA, Vanderbilt and Texas this past season. UMWSC competes in the W-MASC Conference in NIRSA's Region 3 with other teams like Michigan State and Grand Valley. During the regional tournament, the team competes against other competitive schools such as University of Wisconsin and Ohio State.
Summary: UMWSC provides University of Michigan students the opportunity to play competitive soccer without the commitment of a Varsity program. Further, UMWSC seeks to cultivate a community on campus by allowing members to share their love of soccer.

Name: Women's Club Water Polo
Description:
The Women's Club Water Polo Team commits to ensuring all interested students an opportunity to be a part of a team, meet new friends, develop new skills, challenge one's self, have fun, and play competitive water polo. Our club is based on the support of our teammates and our love of the game.

Our season is in the winter semester, during which we compete in many tournaments in the Midwest. We attend two CWPA seeding tournaments, an MSU invite tournament, and other unranked tournaments throughout the season. Our season ends at the Big Ten Championship Tournament in late April or the National Championships in early May, if we take first place in the Big Ten. During both the 22-23 and 23-24 seasons, WCWP won the CPWA National Championships and will begin the 24-25 season ranked #1. 
 
During the fall semester, we practice twice a week to get in shape for our season. We also do a few fundraisers each semester because our team is mainly self-funded.
Summary: The Women's Club Water Polo Team commits to ensuring all interested students an opportunity to be a part of a team, meet new friends, develop new skills, challenge one's self, have fun, and play competitive water polo.

Name: Women's Ice Hockey
Description: To provide an opportunity for women at the University of Michigan to play intercollegiate ice hockey at a competitive level.
Summary: To provide an opportunity for women at the University of Michigan to play intercollegiate ice hockey at a competitive level.

Name: Women+ Excelling More in Math, Engineering, and the Sciences
Description:
F.E.M.M.E.S. is dedicated to closing gender and racial divides in computer science and science, technology, engineering, and math (CS/STEM) fields. Working specifically in diverse, underserved communities, F.E.M.M.E.S. creates collaborative teaching and learning environments to promote leadership development, technical skills and self-confidence of women* of all ages.

​

*We support inclusive definitions of “women,” and welcome all people who identify as women, including transgender and non-binary women.
Summary: FEMMES is a student-led organization which hosts educational outreach programs related to science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) for 4th-12th grade students from underserved areas.

Name: Women+ in Robotics and Engineering
Description: Women+ in Robotics and Engineering (WiRE+) is a group that seeks to connect graduate students at the University of Michigan who identify as women and are pursuing robotics and engineering. We focus on providing community, mentorship, and support to improve the retention and advancement of women in the field. Our organization also advocates for women to have greater access to opportunities and resources within robotics academia and industry.
Summary: Women+ in Robotics and Engineering (WiRE+) is a group that seeks to connect graduate students at the University of Michigan who identify as women and are pursuing robotics and engineering. We focus on providing community, mentorship, and support to impro

Name: Womxn in Health Leadership
Description: Womxn in Health Leadership (WiHL) is a student organization housed at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health. WiHL promotes the professional success of women and others in the workplace and is focused on educating groups.
Summary: Womxn in Health Leadership (WiHL) is a student organization housed at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health. WiHL promotes the professional success of women and others in the workplace and is focused on educating groups.

Name: WORTH
Description:
Through consciousness-raising and activism, WORTH's mission is for members to empower one another and confront prevalent issues in women’s health, subsequently enacting change at various levels. WORTH approaches these issues through smaller focus groups by partnering with organizations that cater to the needs of women’s health.

Website: https://worthatumich.wixsite.com/worth
Summary: WORTH is an organization for the discussion of women's health issues as they appear in our campus environment as well as worldwide. The organization approaches these issues through smaller focus groups striving to enact change locally and globally.

Name: Writer to Writer
Description: Writer to Writer aims to foster interdisciplinary creativity by showcasing the literary work of University of Michigan students in a variety of modes, mediums, and genres. We hope to create a space through which we can not only cultivate an appreciation for the minds behind the work, but also encourage collaboration and growth amongst our community of writers. By building a publication of strong, challenging, and engaging content, we seek to provoke readers and celebrate the power of creative expression.
Summary: A literary journal produced by University of Michigan Sweetland Minor in Writing students.

Name: Writer's Den
Description: Writer’s Den aims to provide a space for University of Michigan students of diverse backgrounds to explore creative writing and connect with the greater writing community, without a pressure to produce work. Meetings involve creative-writing related activities in a relaxed atmosphere, including poetry board games, prompt generation, chill writing sessions, and much more! Additionally, there are more formal creative writing events each month, such as guest speaker events, open mics, and workshops. Writer’s Den is open to everyone, whether you’re a seasoned writer or a person who’s never heard of creative writing.
Summary: Writer’s Den aims to provide a space for University of Michigan students of diverse backgrounds to explore creative writing and connect with the greater writing community.

Name: Writers' Community
Description: Writers' Community is a student-led creative writing group founded in 2008. We are a very laid-back group that aspires to provide constructive criticism and support as we all navigate the sometimes-treacherous terrain of characters, words, and plot twists. Creative writing of any kind is welcomed with open arms. Writing exercises, workshop sessions, prompts, and games are frequently featured, adding sparkle and pizzazz to our already scintillating meetings.
Summary: Writers' Community is a student-led creative writing group running since 2008. Each week, members are encouraged to bring their works to be presented to the group for reactions and critique. Writing exercises and prompts are also frequently featured.

Name: Xi Psi Phi
Description: The purpose of Xi Psi Phi is to foster a community where dental students are able to engage in camaraderie, scholarship, and hospitality. We hope to create an inclusive and enriching organization by providing educational resources to our members, engaging with our community through volunteer events, and creating mental health initiatives to assist all students.
Summary: The purpose of Xi Psi Phi is to foster a community where dental students can engage in camaraderie, scholarship, and hospitality.

Name: Xylem Literary Magazine
Description:
Xylem Literary Magazine provides the opportunity for undergraduates to publish their creative works in a professional literary publication organized and designed by UM students. Through this work, Xylem strives to spread awareness of UM students' creativity. 

All students are encouraged to submit art and writing for consideration. Beyond merely submitting work, there are numerous other ways to become involved in the creation of Xylem Literary Magazine including advertising, layout design, and submission selection.
Summary: Xylem Literary Magazine is an independent, student-run journal that annually publishes original undergraduate student writing and art, including poetry, fiction, creative nonfiction, artwork and photography.

Name: Yemeni Students' Association
Description: The purpose of the Yemeni Students’ Association is to serve and unite Yemeni students on campus. Our goals include building a Yemeni community that promotes a safe space for students of Yemeni descent, raising awareness regarding Yemeni culture, heritage, and contemporary issues that pertain to Yemen and the Yemeni diaspora, as well as connecting and cultivating relationships with students from various backgrounds. Additionally, YSA aims to connect with Yemeni students and other minorities in high schools around Michigan encouraging the pursuit of a higher education.
Summary: The Yemeni Students' Association promotes and motivates awareness of Yemeni existence and culture on campus.

Name: YENIKA Editorial
Description:
We are YENIKA Editorial. We are a student-run magazine who's pages tell stories of every individual through fashion, highlighting their future and beauty. With each issue, we curate a collection that transcends the ordinary, celebrating sophistication and individuality.

Within YENIKA Editorial, we redefine storytelling, emphasizing the richness of every human experience. Our commitment to diversity is a celebration, a nod to the elevated looks of every culture that grace our pages.

YENIKA Editorial isn't just a magazine; it's an exploration of concepts, a sanctuary for those who appreciate the art of storytelling in its most refined form; A world where the focus is not on struggles but on the future, where beauty is elevated, and each story is a celebration of the fire in every individual.
Summary: We are YENIKA Editorial. We are a student-run magazine who's pages tell stories of every individual through fashion, highlighting their future and beauty. With each issue, we curate a collection that transcends the ordinary, celebrating individuality.

Name: Yoga and Pilates Club
Description: A safe space for MBA students to prioritize wellness while bonding over an enjoyment for yoga, pilates and fitness through in-person and virtual classes from certified instructors.
Summary: A safe space for MBA students to prioritize wellness while bonding over an enjoyment for yoga, pilates and fitness through in-person and virtual classes from certified instructors.

Name: Yooper Club
Description:
We are a club designed to connect students from the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. We strive to help students feel more connected with their fellow Yoopers and get a chance to embrace some of the things we know and love from the U.P.

The Yooper Club is a club open to all who want to learn more about the Upper Peninsula, just make some new friends, or are passionate about embracing the outdoors!

Examples of events we may do include: pasty making, snowman competitions, ice skating, perogi making, and euchre.

In addition to events, we hope to serve as a connection point for students traveling over breaks to form carpools, making the trip home a little more accessible for more students. All of our events and carpool spreadsheets will be posted in our Groupme!
Summary: The Yooper Club is dedicated to helping those from the Upper Peninsula and other rural areas feel a sense of community and to help those interested learn about the U.P. as well. We host various events to embrace the things we know and love from the U.P.

Name: Young Americans for Freedom
Description:
Weekly meetings on Tuesdays at 6:30pm in the Parker Room of the Michigan Union. 
 
Follow us on social media to stay up to date:
  • X/Twitter: https://www.x.com/YAFUMich 
  • Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/yafumich/
  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/YAFUMich
 
Leadership:
  • Kyle Brown - Chairman
  • Brian Cao - Vice Chairman
  • Isaac Gardner - Treasurer
  • Ava Siegers - Secretary

 

Who We Are

Young Americans for Freedom at The University of Michigan is made up of passionate undergraduate and graduate students whose goal is to educate students about conservative values and the principles of limited government. Young Americans for Freedom is a project of Young America's Foundation, which is a national non-profit organization which was founded in 1960 to develop and promote conservative ideas among our nation's young people. While the YAF chapter at the University of Michigan was originally founded decades ago, the chapter was reorganized in 2015 after being dormant for several years. Since then, the chapter has hosted the likes of Steven Crowder, Ben Shapiro, Michael Knowles, and other speakers, in addition to weekly meetings, tabling, and social events. Our chapter also won YAF Chapter of the Year in 2019.

 

What We Do

Our chapter promotes conservative ideas on campus through weekly meetings, speaking events, tabling, and social events. 

Meetings

Our chapter meetings are held on Tuesdays at 7 p.m. in Room D of the Michigan League. We typically discuss current issues and important conservative ideas as a group. Board members often give presentations on specific topics of interest to spur a deeper dive into the issues. Members and non-members are free to join us at our meetings to discuss the issues and meet fellow conservatives.

Speakers

Our chapter promotes conservative ideas through speaking events each year. Our speaking events (typically one each semester) are designed to give U of M students the opportunity to hear from some of the most prominent and cutting edge conservative voices, as well as ask questions during the Q&A portion of the event. Our events are always free and usually live streamed on YAF's Youtube channel. 

Tabling

Our chapter promotes conservative ideas on campus by tabling in support of various topics several times each semester. We typically set up a table on the Diag or in Mason Hall to discuss conservative ideas with students. We also take part in YAF's 9/11 Never Forget Memorial each September, where we place 2,977 flags on the Diag to honor those who lost their lives on September 11th. 

Social Events 

Our chapter also hosts social events to have fun together as a chapter. We typically hang out several times each semester to play paintball, walk around the Arb, go ice skating at Yost, or enjoy a bonfire. 

 

Conferences

Members from our chapter typically attend several YAF conferences throughout the year. See yaf.org/events for more information

 

The Sharon Statement

In this time of moral and political crises, it is the responsibility of the youth of America to affirm certain eternal truths.

We, as young conservatives, believe:

That foremost among the transcendent values is the individual’s use of his God-given free will, whence derives his right to be free from the restrictions of arbitrary force;

That liberty is indivisible, and that political freedom cannot long exist without economic freedom;

That the purpose of government is to protect those freedoms through the preservation of internal order, the provision of national defense, and the administration of justice;

That when government ventures beyond these rightful functions, it accumulates power, which tends to diminish order and liberty;

That the Constitution of the United States is the best arrangement yet devised for empowering government to fulfill its proper role, while restraining it from the concentration and abuse of power;

That the genius of the Constitution—the division of powers—is summed up in the clause that reserves primacy to the several states, or to the people, in those spheres not specifically delegated to the Federal government;

That the market economy, allocating resources by the free play of supply and demand, is the single economic system compatible with the requirements of personal freedom and constitutional government, and that it is at the same time the most productive supplier of human needs;

That when government interferes with the work of the market economy, it tends to reduce the moral and physical strength of the nation; that when it takes from one man to bestow on another, it diminishes the incentive of the first, the integrity of the second, and the moral autonomy of both;

That we will be free only so long as the national sovereignty of the United States is secure; that history shows periods of freedom are rare, and can exist only when free citizens concertedly defend their rights against all enemies;

That the forces of international Communism are, at present, the greatest single threat to these liberties;

That the United States should stress victory over, rather than coexistence with, this menace; and

That American foreign policy must be judged by this criterion: does it serve the just interests of the United States.
Summary: YAF is a non-profit, non-partisan organization that brings students together to advocate for the ideas of limited government, individual freedom, free enterprise, and a strong national defense.

Name: Young Democratic Socialists of America at the University of Michigan
Description:
The Chapter’s mission is to educate and organize students and young people to play a principled role in the movement for social and economic justice that fall under any leftist tendency. Only through democratic control of our economy, or socialism, can liberation be achieved. We seek social change toward full democratic control of our society. Our vision of socialism is fundamentally feminist, anti-capitalist, anti-imperialist, anti-racist, and LGBTQ+ inclusive. We reject discrimination and inequality on the basis of age, ability, religious belief, or cultural background. We work towards bringing our goals to fruition through supporting organized labor, grassroots organizing, community engagement, and partnering with other like-minded student organizations in order to build a campus coalition dedicated to positive and substantive societal change.

 

Active membership shall be limited to persons officially connected with the University of Michigan as faculty, staff, or registered students. In addition, the following requirements are necessary to constitute active members: attend three events a semester and is a current dues-paying or dues-waived member of DSA
Summary: We are this university's DSA (Democratic Socialists of America) chapter. Our mission is to educate and organize students and young people in unique positions as students to play a principled role in the movement for social and economic justice.

Name: Yuru Band
Description:
YURU Band (formerly Ontaku!) is a musical club dedicated to connecting musicians and performers of all skill levels and backgrounds who share a passion for East Asian music and culture. We aim to create an inclusive, collaborative environment where individuals can express themselves musically, grow their skills, and celebrate a shared appreciation for diverse musical genres. We aim to develop engaging group performances across various styles, including J-Pop, J-Rock, K-Pop, and J-RnB. By incorporating classical instruments, modern rock setups, and vocal elements such as singing and rapping, we embrace the rich musical diversity of East Asian media while promoting cross-genre exploration and innovation.

 

During the semester, we participate in multiple concerts and gigs in collaboration with other organizations on campus or hold our own performances.
Summary: Yuru Band (formerly Ontaku) is a student-run music band that loves watching anime and playing music. Our ensemble performs Japanese and anime-related pieces at various events held on campus each semester. Musicians of all skill levels are welcome!

Name: Zeta Omega Eta
Description:
From Zeta Omega Eta's constitution: "Zeta Omega Eta is a non-traditional sorority devoted to diversity, inclusiveness, and the advancement of feminist ideals. Inherent in the goals of Zeta Omega Eta is a commitment to action and engagement on the campus, in the community, and in the world. Through their work in community service, their roles as leaders in campus organizations, and their pursuit of academic excellence, ZOEs seek to reclaim and redefine what it means to be a feminist and to be a sorority member.”

ZΩH aims to bring together feminists with a shared passion for equality, social justice, inclusiveness. We hope to provide an organization for feminists to call their home away from home while studying at Michigan. ZΩH's participate in typical bonding events such as adventuring to the cider mill in the fall, ice skating in the winter, and potlucks, while also aiming to be socially aware and involved on campus, always continuing the fight for equality.

ZΩH was founded at Trinity College in 2003 as the first feminist sorority in the United States.
Summary: Zeta Omega Eta is a non-traditional and intersectional sorority that aims to bring strong, passionate people together to redefine what it means to be a feminist and sorority member.

Name: Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc. Gamma Delta Chapter
Description:
Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc. fosters the ideals of service, charity, scholarship, civil and cultural endeavors, sisterhood, and Finer Womanhood. These ideals are reflected in the sorority's national programs for which its members and auxiliary groups provide voluntary service to staff, community outreach programs, fund scholarships, support organized charities, and promote legislation for social and civic change.

Founded on January 16, 1920 on the campus of Howard University, five women believed that sorority elitism and socializing should not overshadow the real mission for progressive organizations. These five Pearls dared to break the mold that was predicated for the role of black women during this time, envisioning a new organization established on the precepts of the aforementioned ideals.

“In the ideal collegiate situation, there is a Zeta in every girl regardless of race, creed or color, who has high standards and principals, a good scholarly average and an active interest in all things that she undertakes to accomplish,” a statement oft quoted by Founder Viola Tyler Goings and a testament to the passion that Zeta as well as its members hold to the upliftment, empowerment, and commitment to our community.
Summary: As one of nine historically Black fraternities and sororities, Zeta Phi Beta Sorority, Inc. is “a community conscious, action-oriented organization,” striving to uphold and exemplify the ideals of scholarship, service, sisterly love, and Finer Womanhood.

Name: Zeta Pi Professional Technology Fraternity
Description: Zeta Pi Professional Technology Fraternity, aims to support students who share a passion for technology academically, professionally, and socially. We host frequent events that help members prepare for their careers and network, as well as work on their skills in relation to various fields in technology. Zeta Pi also offers a mentorship program and has social events for members to connect and destress. You can find out more about us on our website, zetapi.tech!
Summary: Co-ed Professional Technology Fraternity established in 2023 at the University of Michigan.

Name: Zeta Tau Alpha
Description: A member in good standing of the Panhellenic Association, Zeta Tau Alpha is a recognized University student organization.  For more information on this sorority, contact the chapter president Kailey Koshorek.
Summary: A member in good standing of the Panhellenic Association, Zeta Tau Alpha is a recognized University student organization.  For more information on this sorority, contact the chapter president.

Name: Zouk Dance Club
Description:
Zouk Dance Club is a dance club intended for everyone interested in the Brazilian social partner dance called Zouk, body rolls, excessive hair whips, and access to a fun-loving local, national and international community. Zouk is mentally and physically fulfilling, and our community is a tight-knit and welcoming one.

Never tried Zouk before? Never danced before?  We’d love to teach you! We meet weekly for beginner classes & practicas, monthly for socials, and occasional workshops lead by internationally acclaimed Zouk instructors.  In addition to bringing Zouk to Ann Arbor, our members often attend zouk festivals and workshops in other cities such as Chicago, Washington, D.C., and Toronto, so dig up your passport and get ready to ZOUK IT OUT!!

 

Want inspiration? Here's a YouTube playlist of some of our favorite Zouk dance examples (the majority of these are improvised dances): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ITRCYkFMqfk&list=PL14pM3nI0KyYvEkSk0BCaAcCanrjjRbSp

 

Join us anytime! The majority of the people that join have never had any dance or movement experience before. No partner is required!

 

CONTACT US

Email: dancezouk@umich.edu

Facebook Page: zoukdanceclub

Instagram Page: zoukdanceclub

Our Facebook and Instagram will have our most up to date event information
Summary: A dance club intended for everyone interested in Brazilian Zouk dance, body rolls, and excessive hair whips. We meet weekly for beginner classes, socials, informal practicas and workshops lead by internationally acclaimed Zouk instructors.

Name: [RE]vive Refugee Education Initiative
Description: [RE]vive is a refugee education initiative, founded in 2017 at the University of Michigan. [RE]vive's mission is to bring educational and vocational resources to empower refugee students to apply to higher education opportunities, scholarships, and jobs.
Summary: [RE]vive is a refugee education initiative, founded in 2017 at the University of Michigan. [RE]vive's mission is to bring educational and vocational resources to empower refugee students to apply to higher education opportunities, scholarships, and jobs.
